HEADLINE: Budget Baloney

 BODY:
In 1981, a newly inaugurated President Reagan proudly announced plans to cut taxes, boost defense spending and balance the Federal budget within three years through "additional savings to be proposed" later. In fact, the Reagan team had been unable to agree on just what to cut, so that little line was an effort to finesse the problem.
"I buried it way down at the bottom of the white paper appendix table," recalled David Stockman, a young Midwestern Congressman whose devotion to slashing Federal spending had propelled him into the White House as President Reagan's budget director. "If you had a magnifying glass, you could read it." 
 It worked, at least politically. Taxes were cut and defense spending raised. But those "additional savings" never did get identified, for the same reason they were not cited at the beginning. There were no cuts that could be made without unacceptable political cost.
Since the Republicans took control of Congress in 1994, they have been reluctant to play similar games. Previous budget proposals by the House Budget Committee chairman, John Kasich of Ohio, openly targeted areas that he would like to cut, whatever the political risks. But this year he reverted to Stockman-like tactics.
Mr. Kasich himself favored an ambitious list of cuts -- eliminating the Energy and Commerce Departments, privatizing the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, wiping out the Legal Services Corporation, trimming Medicare and Medicaid, and abolishing a tax break for low-income couples without children. But his colleagues had no appetite for the combat these proposals would bring. The result is a budget that pretends savings have been found, though they have not been. On paper, that frees up money for a big tax cut that some Republicans think will be a great campaign issue, and leaves the actual cuts until later.
This page would oppose most of the cuts Mr. Kasich had in mind, but it would not question the honesty of the budget he was pushing. The budget approved by his committee and scheduled for a vote soon by the full House fails the basic integrity test, and the House should vote it down, demanding instead a budget that is real, not rigged.
In his memoirs, Mr. Stockman wrote that he knew huge deficits would be coming if spending was not slashed far beyond any proposals the Reagan Administration was willing to make. But he thought that fact "would become a powerful battering ram" to force future spending cuts.
There was no battering ram. Deficits ballooned, and not until this year was a surplus achieved through spending restraint, tax increases, increased tax revenues from a strong economy, falling interest rates that slashed the Treasury's cost of borrowing and good luck. The political promise of a big tax cut should not seduce House Republicans into embracing an old and failed strategy.

HEADLINE: PRIMARIES '98: THE POLITICAL VETERAN;
Last in Flash and Cash, an Underdog Pulls Ahead

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 31

 BODY:
For months, as he struggled against richer and splashier rivals for the Democratic nomination for governor here, Lieut. Gov. Gray Davis was Rodney Dangerfield, in perpetual quest of respect. But as he basked the other day in the support of Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco, the coolest cat in California politics, Mr. Davis, surely among the squarest, suddenly seemed hep.
"I don't want to say that Willie has a blank check," Mr. Davis said of his loyalties if elected, prompting a group of supporters outside San Francisco's elegant City Hall to explode in laughter at the thought of what the famously wily Mr. Brown could make of such a promise. "It wouldn't be cautious, and I'm supposed to be cautious." 
 Still, despite his reputation, Mr. Davis could not resist proclaiming himself "on the verge of a great victory" in the primary election on Tuesday, and indeed all the polls show that he has opened a commanding lead over his rivals, Representative Jane Harman and Al Checchi, the multimillionaire former co-chairman of Northwest Airlines. And that is the sweetest sort of vindication for Gray Davis, a 23-year veteran of state politics who is often dismissed by party insiders and pundits as aptly named.
"This has been a very trying election," Mr. Davis said at a meeting of the League of United Latin American Citizens in Long Beach on Saturday. "I've had more political pundits tell me that I was dead meat, couldn't win, road kill, forget it, give it up, sayonara, forget it, Charlie, go home. So it's particularly reassuring to know that even though I'm running against someone with more money than Fort Knox, and a very good Congresswoman that's got quite a bit of money herself, the candidate with the least money is in the lead."
There is more than a little irony in that, because Mr. Davis has had a reputation as a relentless fund-raiser in four years as Lieutenant Governor, eight years as state controller and four years as a state assemblyman from the West Side of Los Angeles. He will probably equal or break the record for spending in a primary for governor here, the $9 million that Kathleen Brown spent four years ago. Ms. Harman is expected to spend nearly twice that, and Mr. Checchi more than four times as much, in the all-time American record for a non-Presidential race.
But Mr. Davis is also benefiting from his years as an unabashed political networker, the sort of man who passes out his business cards at the Vanity Fair Academy Awards party and spends every weekend on the rubber-chicken circuit. He has won the support of labor unions, old-line liberals and party regulars like Mr. Brown, groups that can still help turn out voters in a fractured political climate almost completely dominated by television advertising. He and his labor allies are organizing joint get-out-the-vote efforts to defeat a ballot proposition that would require unions to obtain written consent of their members before using union dues for political purposes, and polls show that opposition to that measure has grown just as support for Mr. Davis has risen.
Then, too, with California on the rebound from years of economic, natural and social disasters, voters apparently find Mr. Davis's steady, well-honed resume appealing. He has maintained favorability ratings of 2 to 1 or better throughout most of the campaign, and he leads his Democratic rivals among virtually all ethnic and age groups. A recent Los Angeles Times poll found that voters preferred a candidate with years of elective experience by more than 2 to 1 over a contender, like Mr. Checchi, with no political experience but years in business.
"Voters overwhelmingly wanted experience all along," Mr. Davis's pollster, Paul Maslin, said last week. At various points, Mr. Maslin added, voters seemed unaware of Mr. Davis's candidacy, in part because he could not afford to begin television advertising as early as his rivals did. But the moment Mr. Davis did begin running commercials last month, with the slogan, "Experience money can't buy," he edged ahead of Mr. Checchi and Ms. Harman and has solidified his lead ever since.
As Davis strategists note, despite its go-go reputation, California has been governed for the last 16 years by stolid Republicans, Pete Wilson and George Deukmejian, who would never dominate charisma contests. Not since the days of Edmund G. Brown Jr., for whom Mr. Davis began his career as chief of staff in 1975, has the state had a media star in Sacramento. Garry South, Mr. Davis's campaign manager, likes to say that past governors "look a hell of a lot more like Gray Davis than Al Checchi or Jane Harman."
Although Mr. Davis, 55, has been a fixture in California politics -- courting Hollywood donors, playing golf with President Clinton, drawing criticism for crashing other politicians' events to find contributors and for sometimes blending fund-raising with his official duties -- he is a private and somewhat enigmatic figure. Despite his liberal reputation, he is considerably more conservative than Mr. Brown, having long supported the death penalty, for example.
Born Joseph Graham Davis Jr., the son of an advertising executive for Time Inc., Mr. Davis grew up in Connecticut and came to California at age 11 when his father moved west with the company. But his father was an alcoholic and his parents divorced in his sophomore year at Stanford University, and Mr. Davis joined the Reserve Officers Training Corps so he could afford to stay in school. It was an important decision, because Mr. Davis wound up as an Army captain in Vietnam, where he won the Bronze Star and was struck by the disproportionate number of minority members among the American troops there, an injustice that helped propel him into politics.
For years, Mr. Davis has been laying the groundwork for a bid for governor, but some party strategists have seen him as too pallid, with his perfectly combed gray hair and sometimes funereal demeanor, to compete effectively against the certain Republican nominee, State Attorney General Dan Lungren, a genial conservative in the Reagan mold. But Mr. Davis leads Mr. Lungren in hypothetical matchups in the polls, and in recent days, he has wasted no time in looking ahead to the general election.
In his speech to the Hispanic group in Long Beach, Mr. Lungren's hometown, Mr. Davis sketched out his rhetorical strategy against the Attorney General, who avoided military service in the Vietnam era because of a sports injury to his knee, warning, "Dan Lungren is in for the fight of his life; Dan Lungren has never been tested; Dan Lungren is going to run against a Vietnam veteran."
Asked afterward by reporters whether he intended to fault Mr. Lungren for his lack of military service, Mr. Davis said no, and then added in good-natured but evident frustration, "Look, you people think I'm some sort of..." before breaking off mid-sentence to add calmly, "You do not understand the level of trust that has been generated between the people of this state and me over 23 years."

HEADLINE: With a Hometown Embrace, Pataki Begins His Campaign

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: PEEKSKILL, N.Y., May 31

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki returned to his hometown today to kiss his mother, shake dozens of sweaty hands, recite his accomplishments and formally announce his campaign for re-election.
It was a euphoric moment for Mr. Pataki, who was largely unknown and struggled to be taken seriously when he emerged four years ago as the Republican challenger to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat of national stature seeking his fourth term. 
 As supporters shook signs bearing his name, Mr. Pataki discussed one of his favorite topics -- his modest upbringing as a mailman's son -- and reminded the crowd that "seemingly ordinary people" are "capable of extraordinary feats of greatness."
"We have unleashed the strength and the spirit of our people," said Mr. Pataki, 52, whose strength in suburbs and small upstate towns helped him defeat Mr. Cuomo in 1994. "That is why the great march of progress that began four years ago must march on for another four years."
Hundreds of families came to glimpse the Pataki family at the Peekskill Riverfront Green Park, which Mr. Pataki helped create when he was Mayor here in the 1980's. They ate watermelon, drank soda and listened to the chipper Peekskill High School band, which played Tchaikovsky's "1812 Overture." "Yonkers Loves Pataki" banners waved and "Start Me Up," a Rolling Stones song, blared as the Governor, his wife, Libby, and two of their four children climbed onto an outdoor stage.
Campaign workers scrambled through the crowd, urging people to wave their signs more vigorously and shout, "Four more years!"
The announcement came four days before the Republican State Convention in Manhattan, at which party delegates from around the state will officially nominate Mr. Pataki as the Republican gubernatorial candidate and Mary O. Donohue, an upstate judge, as his new running mate. Not coincidentally, it also came one day before his new book, "Pataki, an Autobiography," is to arrive in bookstores around the nation and Mr. Pataki is to appear on "The Montel Williams Show" to discuss the book.
But despite those early efforts to grab voters' attention, Mr. Pataki said today that he would not start campaigning in earnest until this summer. He said he would spend the next month pressuring the State Legislature to pass bills that are important to him, including one that would end parole for violent felons and another that would increase the number of poor children eligible for free health insurance.
"That's my focus," he said. "Getting through as much change as possible in the next three or four weeks while the Legislature is still in session, and then we're on to the campaign."
However, Mr. Pataki gave what could only be described as a stump speech today, talking for nearly 15 minutes about his changes to state welfare policy, his tax cuts and New York's booming economy. He said the state's welfare rolls had fallen by 500,000 people since he took office in 1995 and 300,000 more people had jobs. The Governor, known for his lack of charisma, sounded uncharacteristically spirited as he mentioned that violent crime statewide had dropped to its lowest level in 28 years, and that more state aid than ever was flowing into public schools.
At least two Democratic candidates -- Peter F. Vallone, the New York City Council Speaker, and Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney -- are scheduled to compete in the gubernatorial primary in September in hopes of challenging Mr. Pataki. Two others -- Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, who switched parties after feuding with Mr. Pataki, and James L. Larocca, a former state Transportation Commissioner, have said they will petition to get on the ballot.
But none of the four has the stature or financial resources of Mr. Pataki, who has an astounding $12 million in his campaign chest already. Much of that money was raised by United States Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York, a fellow Republican, who plucked Mr. Pataki from obscurity in 1994, when Mr. Pataki was a State Senator, and orchestrated his political ascent. Both men are seeking re-election this year, and in a role reversal, Mr. D'Amato is counting on Mr. Pataki's popularity to improve his own prospects in some parts of the state.
If Mr. Pataki felt giddy today, he probably felt even more so on Saturday, when Henry A. Kissinger, giving the commencement address at Albany Law School, said he expected to see Mr. Pataki's name on the presidential ticket in 2000. Although the Governor skirted reporters' questions about his national political aspirations today, he was clearly savoring Mr. Kissinger's remarks.
"It's very nice when someone with the stature of Henry Kissinger says you should be on a national ticket," he told reporters after his speech. "It is of course a compliment and I take it as such."
Lesser-known admirers of Mr. Pataki were just as eager to praise him today in Peekskill, about 30 miles north of New York City, describing him in words that would make his strategists glow and his opponents roll their eyes. This was friendly territory, after all.
"He's a guy you could trust to baby-sit your kids, just a sweetheart of a guy," crowed Bill Noel, an insurance broker from nearby Carmel whose wife volunteered for Mr. Pataki's 1994 campaign. "A simple Peekskill boy, no pretense, down to earth."
Bill Leavy, a retired police officer from Yonkers, said he had not personally benefited from Mr. Pataki's policies and described the Governor as "average." Nonetheless, Mr. Leavy said he would vote for Mr. Pataki in November because "he gets the job done." His daughter Laurie Leavy said she would vote for Mr. Pataki after watching him today.
"He kissed a lot of people," she said. "You've got to give him credit for seeming like a nice guy."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1715 words

HEADLINE: PRIMARIES '98: THE GOVERNOR'S RACE;
MONEY AND POLLS TAKE CENTER STAGE IN CALIFORNIA RACE

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 31

 BODY:
After the most high-priced and volatile primary campaign in California history, this state's voters will pick nominees for Governor on Tuesday in an election that has rekindled a debate over the potency of television commercials and underscored the perils for wealthy candidates who finance their own campaigns.
With Dan Lungren, the State Attorney General, facing token opposition for the Republican nomination for Governor, the Democratic race has overwhelmed the political landscape. Tussles over the dominant issues of education and crime have largely been submerged by a competition defined by huge sums of money and wild gyrations in the polls that have startled even jaded politicians. 
 In the past month or so, each of the three principal contenders for the nomination has at one point or another been in first -- and last -- place in the polls. Most spectacular has been the downward trajectory of Alfred A. Checchi, a political newcomer and the former co-chairman of Northwest Airlines. He has pumped roughly $40 million into his campaign -- more than any other non-Presidential candidate has ever spent on a primary and general election combined -- only to see his first-place position in the polls plunge to a distant third, behind Gray Davis, the Lieutenant Governor and front-runner, and Representative Jane Harman.
No matter the outcome on Tuesday, Mr. Checchi has heralded a new political dynamic in this state that pioneered the "virtual campaign," in which elections are fought only on the airwaves: the more money he pours into television commercials, the worse he seems to do.
"It's an extraordinary case of an inverse relationship between advertising and results," said Mervin Field, a veteran pollster here. "It's going to be the kind of story they'll put in advertising textbooks because everyone thinks if you put more money in advertising it sells more."
Besides voting for nominees to succeed Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican who is barred by law from a third term, and a challenger for Senator Barbara Boxer, a Democrat, Californians will decide two ballot initiatives that have far-reaching implications for the future of bilingual education and the power of unions in this country.
Beyond California, Tuesday will be one of the busiest primary days of the year. In a crucial test of the strength of religious conservatives, Gov. Fob James Jr. of Alabama will try to stave off serious opposition in the Republican primary. In Iowa, both parties are choosing nominees for the open Governor's seat, a post that will be particularly important in 2000 given Iowa's pivotal role in the Presidential primary season. Voters also go to the polls in Mississippi, Montana, New Jersey, New Mexico and South Dakota.
With the hardy economy taking the issue of jobs off the table in most states, many politicians find themselves turning their attention to education. Candidates have been wrangling over proposals to inject more money into rebuilding deteriorating schools, improving the standards for hiring teachers -- as well as proposals to give parents a wider choice of options in their children's education.
Here in California, polls show that the ballot proposal to end bilingual education appears headed for approval. But voters in recent days have begun to turn against the other initiative, strenuously fought by organized labor, that would require unions to get written consent from members before spending their dues on political campaigns. Governor Wilson has staked his political prestige, and possible White House ambitions, on passage of the measure.
The contest to succeed Governor Wilson may be the most consequential American election this year because it represents the Democrats' best opportunity to pick up a big-state governorship. The stakes are particularly high because if Democrats maintain dominance in the legislature and capture the Governor's office, they will control redistricting for 2002 in the state with the most House seats.
The small percentage of eligible voters who are expected to go to the polls will also have to sort through 87 candidates for statewide office and nine ballot initiatives. In San Francisco, the absentee ballot is the size of a small telephone book: 176 pages. There are so many choices, in fact, that election officials expect many voters to give up halfway through what may feel more like a painstaking ordeal than an exercise in democracy.
Another complication is that voting will occur in an utterly unpredictable new arena, California's first "blanket" primary, in which the names of all candidates for each office will appear on the same ballot. Voters will be allowed to select from all the choices without regard to party. Candidates are bracing for some mischief-making among voters who may bolt their party in an effort to elect an opposition candidate whom they perceive as a weaker contender in the general election.
Yet theories about the blanket primary have been dwarfed by the battle royal for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination among three contenders who were not particularly well known by California voters when the campaign began. As recently as a month ago, polls showed that Mr. Checchi (pronounced CHECK-ee) was the favorite, having built name recognition by saturating television markets since last November. Then Ms. Harman came along, channeling an estimated $15 million from her husband's smaller yet substantial stereo manufacturing fortune into the race, and overtook Mr. Checchi.
But in the closing days, Mr. Checchi and Ms. Harman, who represents the Los Angeles area, have stood on the sidelines as the solid but less flashy Mr. Davis, a 20-year veteran of state politics who had to scrounge for donations and could not even afford television advertising until six weeks ago, rocketed ahead. When he did buy advertising, Mr. Davis needled his rivals' spending with the tag line, "Experience Money Can't Buy." (The Davis campaign is spending about $9 million, which anywhere else would be considered a colossal amount.)
These spending sprees may drive the overall price for this primary, including statewide candidates and ballot issues, to more than $100 million. If Mr. Davis triumphs on Tuesday, as most analysts now predict, his candidacy may spur a national rethinking of the benefits of advertising blitzes -- and of campaigns that are financially driven by wealthy candidates. At a time when the economy is booming, it also may suggest and polls confirm, a waning in voters' appetites for outsiders from the business world with little Government experience.
Mr. Checchi's collapse in the polls may not be a case study in how money cannot buy voters anymore. In a sprawling state like California with immense media markets, a candidate cannot compete without millions of dollars. And by the standards of California politics, Mr. Checchi's commercials were relatively tame.
Instead, the lesson for Mr. Checchi -- who has spent well over half the sum Ross Perot lavished on his Presidential race in 1992 -- might be that money, in itself, cannot assure success if a campaign's strategy is fundamentally flawed. Analysts explained that voters, after initially being drawn to Mr. Checchi, objected to his decision to go negative at all because he had presented himself as an outsider who had no intention to engage in gutter-level politics.
Mr. Davis, who was heard confiding this weekend that "I am the most fortunate person on planet Earth," may also be the beneficiary of unintended consequences. Mr. Checchi took aim at Ms. Harman as she began to creep up in the polls. Surveys indicate that his advertising barrage damaged Ms. Harman severely but exacted an even greater toll on Mr. Checchi. Then Mr. Davis stepped in.
Governor Wilson, an adroit practitioner of slashing advertising who had weeks ago predicted Mr. Checchi would win, said in an interview that he had never seen such fluctuations in a primary.
"It's a reflection of the enormous amount of money that has been spent and the peculiar dynamics of this three-person race," he said. "Checchi has spent more money than anybody in history, and in a two-person race, probably his attack upon Harman would have been successful. The irony is, I'm convinced, that the people he drove away from Harman went to Davis because they had a place to go. And Davis, ironically, because he didn't have the money, was the beneficiary of his own silence."
In a noticeable departure for a campaign fought largely on the paid airwaves, the Democratic candidates for Governor took to the trail this weekend with last-ditch efforts to appeal to the undecided, and to those who are reluctant to come to the polls at all. Mr. Checchi, who can afford chartered jets and limousines, traveled in a shiny yellow school bus. And, stopping at a reception here Friday evening in a final burst of campaigning, Ms. Harman rejected the worrisome poll numbers for her. "With four more shopping days left," she said, "my own positive campaign is shining through."
The Checchi fallout may have spilled into the race between two Republicans who are vying to take on Senator Boxer: Matt Fong, the State Treasurer, and Darrell Issa, a car alarm entrepreneur. Some backers of Mr. Issa have complained that voters have become dismissive of his campaign because, at first glance, he fits the Checchi mold of being a business executive with no Government experience who is dipping into his own fortune to buy television advertisements.
Mr. Issa has spent about $10 million on the race, compared with about $1 million for Mr. Fong, but has been unable to gain much traction. While it has been obscured by the abrupt turns in the contest for Governor, the Senate contest offers the most suspense in these final days. The latest polls show that the outcome is too close to call.
Given the instability of the governor's race in particular, it might be imprudent for anyone to profess to knowing what will happen on Tuesday. Joseph Cerrell, a longtime Democratic strategist in Los Angeles, said he would not dare make any predictions.
"For a guy who's been doing this stuff for 40 years, this is the first time I stood there with a question mark over my head," Mr. Cerrell said, "which is almost embarrassing."

HEADLINE: For 12, a Hard Look at Death Penalty

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
An unemployed resident of Red Hook, Brooklyn, said that he believed the death penalty made criminals "think twice before committing heinous crimes," but that as a juror he would not automatically vote to execute every killer, because it "depends on how and why the murder was committed."
A medical technician from Bedford-Stuyvesant said that her first husband had been killed in a 1981 shooting, but that her decision on whether to impose capital punishment in a murder case "would depend on the evidence presented." 
 An administrative assistant from Bensonhurst with a doctorate in English literature, called her feelings about the death penalty "sobering," saying the "responsibility for someone's life is an awesome one."
The three Brooklyn residents are among the 12 jurors who are expected this week to begin determining whether a former jail guard, Darrel K. Harris, will be the first person sentenced to death under the law that reinstated capital punishment in New York State three years ago.
Their statements came from questionnaires they filled out and in replies to questions by the judge and prosecution and defense lawyers during jury selection for Mr. Harris's trial in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. He was charged with killing three people during a 1996 robbery at an illegal social club in Bedford-Stuyvesant, and on May 19 the jury convicted him of first-degree murder.
Now the seven women and five men on the panel must perform the second task that the 1995 capital punishment law sets out for them: sentencing the 40-year-old Mr. Harris to death by lethal injection or to life in prison without parole.
The life sentence is an option if the jurors find it warranted by so-called mitigating factors, which can include positive aspects of Mr. Harris's background and character, and his state of mind at the time he committed the killings.
A decade ago Mr. Harris was publicly honored as a hero for saving a fellow correction officer during an inmate riot at a Brooklyn jail. In the trial's penalty stage, which opened on Tuesday, his lawyers are offering this as one among several mitigating factors. Others include an argument that Mr. Harris is a seriously disturbed man whose murderous explosion was fueled by stresses stemming from his upbringing and his former work as a jail guard, combined with drug and alcohol abuse. His drug use ended his career with the city's Correction Department in 1991.
The mitigation testimony continues today before Acting Justice Anne G. Feldman, as arguments and testimony are also to begin in Poughkeepsie in the second death penalty trial under the 1995 law, that of Dalkeith V. McIntosh, charged with murdering his estranged wife and her daughter by a previous marriage. And jury selection began last week for the third death penalty trial, and the second in Brooklyn -- that of Jermaine Page, who prosecutors contend murdered a man execution style after robbing him.
At Mr. Harris's trial this week, after the defense finishes presenting witnesses -- who have included the jail guard Mr. Harris saved -- the jury will hear the prosecutors' arguments that any mitigating factors do not offset what they have termed cold-blooded killings committed to eliminate witnesses to Mr. Harris's robbery. He shot two victims -- Michael Harris (no relation) and Jerome Sims -- in the head and fatally stabbed Evelyn Davis after running out of bullets.
The jurors who will assess all this, whose identities the court has kept confidential, range in age from the 30's to the 60's and include five people in health related jobs, four in office or blue collar employment, a science teacher, a retired woman and the unemployed man who last worked as a truck driver. Five of the jurors have college degrees.
Racial influences on the jury that lawyers sometimes fear when the defendant and the victim are of different races, are not a factor in this case. Mr. Harris is black, as were all his victims. Eight of the jurors are black, three are white and one is Hispanic.
On their questionnaires, four of the jurors indicated a firm belief that some killings demand the death penalty, seven did not express vigorous feelings about capital punishment, one way or the other, and one, a medical technician from East Flatbush, simply said, "It is the law in New York State."
But all said that they would assess the circumstances of the killings, as well as Mr. Harris himself, and would consider both life in prison without parole and the death penalty.
For example, a 35-year-old office worker from East New York said on her questionnaire that she favored capital punishment "if a person willingly and knowingly plans to murder another person without any remorse whatsoever and for no reason." But she also said that she would want to know the "defendant's state of mind at the time of the murder, the reason for the murder and did the defendant think of the consequence."
Similarly, a 49-year-old laboratory assistant from Bedford-Stuyvesant, who wrote "open mind" when asked her current feelings about the death penalty, also said that in deciding a sentence she would want to know "the state of mind of the defendant at the time of the act."
The last execution in New York State was carried out in 1963, in an electric chair. In 1984 the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, declared the remaining provision of the state's previous death penalty law unconstitutional.

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
For a Day, Kingston Comes to Meadowlands

BYLINE: By STEVE POPPER 

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 31

 BODY:
As the names of the Jamaican national team were announced during pre-game introductions, the beating of the steel drums, as well as the public-address announcer's words, were drowned out by the raucous cheering from the crowd.
The 38,624 fans, nearly every one of them adorned in the bright gold of their team, grew even louder as the country's national anthem was played. And when the team, affectionately called the Reggae Boyz, scored against the Caribbean All-Stars, the crowd continued to give them a fervent send-off as Jamaica prepares to play in the World Cup for the first time. Its first game is scheduled for June 14 against Croatia. 
 Forget that it was their Brazilian coach, Rene Simoes, who gave the team its nickname or that seven of the team's players were hastily imported from England; the first goal was scored by one of those hired guns, assisted by another. Or that perhaps the best of the British imports, Dwight Yorke, was playing for the Caribbean All-Stars and that he scored a pair of second-half goals to hand Jamaica a 2-1 loss in its final tuneup for the World Cup. The crowd cared only that Jamaica would be there in France, the first English-speaking Caribbean team to qualify.
"Every time we are in the pitch, they are fanatical," said Fitzroy Simpson, who was born in England. But with both of his parents from Jamaica, he was one of the first British players to join the team. He added: "We're carrying not just the hopes of Jamaica, but the whole Caribbean. It's a great responsibility. It's been the same wherever we go. The whole country is behind us. Jamaicans hold very dearly to their country."
Jamaica did not show anything that will worry its World Cup opponents, but did exactly what the fans wanted on this farewell exhibition. Theodore Whitmore deftly handled the ball, entertaining the crowd. Paul Hall, another of the early British players to join the team, fed Frank Sinclair in the 34th minute and Sinclair, who joined the squad after it qualified for the World Cup, slipped past a defender and drilled a shot into the lower-left side of the goal.
But after taking the 1-0 lead into the half, Simoes cleared his bench, not choosing to risk an injury with a squad of 22 players, the number that the more established programs will have to reach by Tuesday, with little depth to find a fill-in if he lost one of his players. For this team, and especially for this crowd, Jamaica was happy to put on a show and then ready itself for the real games.
Five hours before the game began, the parking lot was crowded with cars, Jamaican flags sprouting from the radio antennas. The mood of the fans never changed with the score. The Reggae Boyz have become a phenomenon akin to a pop group; perhaps with the British flavor, the Beatles would be a better comparison than Bob Marley.
"That's the supporters," Simpson said. "We've kept our feet on the floor. Like a balloon, we know it can pop at any time."
Warren Barrett, the team's goalkeeper and longtime captain, said: "There is a bond through which we have united a country. Our country has problems of social and economic nature, but when we play football, the rich, the poor, everyone gets together."

HEADLINE: BOXING;
A Heavy Regulatory Presence in New York

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: PORT CHESTER, N.Y.

 BODY:
Compared with small boxing events in other parts of the country, the fights held here in April at the Capitol Theater looked like a police officers' convention. Clumps of men in sport coats with badges and New York State Athletic Commission emblems guarded the dressing-room doors. Corner inspectors in surgical gloves leaned over the ropes to monitor the fighters and their trainers between rounds, and were rotated at the bell, with a new inspection team for each bout.
That level of regulatory presence would be unthinkable in many states. But whether it is zealous, invaluable attention to fighter safety or wasteful extravagance is a question central to the debate about what New York taxpayers get for their money in boxing regulation. 
 Over the years, the state athletic commission has been criticized as a political patronage operation. Some boxing experts have recently questioned the credentials of the commission's doctors.
Still, when compared with other states, New York clearly requires more medical screening of fighters and operates with a budget that dwarfs those elsewhere.
The commission's budget, which was seriously cut during the economic recession in New York in the early 1990's, has ballooned since, despite no growth in the number of events. In 1992, for example, the commission spent $494,800 to regulate 31 boxing shows. Last year it spent $841,000 to oversee 30. A spokesman for the commission, Scott Trent, said most of the spending increases were due to staff salaries being restored to their former levels. But spending on supplies, materials, medical testing, travel and equipment purchases grew as well, according to commission budget documents.
Most noticeably, the question of just how serious an operation the commission is was underscored with the appointment of Floyd Patterson as chairman in 1995. The two-time heavyweight world champion, who is 63, has memory problems. He resigned in March, but had long been regarded within the sport as a $76,000-a-year figurehead.
"He was warm, friendly and hospitable, but I knew very rapidly that he was not really running the show," said Stanley B. Levin, an attorney and promoter for Roy Jones Jr., a supermiddleweight who fought in New York in 1996.
New York places more demands on fighters and promoters than most states do, in both medical tests and fees. The state requires each fighter to get a CAT brain scan, as well as an electrocardiogram and an EKG once a year. It also collects a 5.5 percent tax on tickets and a .55 percent tax on television rights. And boxers generally have to be in the state for several days before their fights.
The commission has been dogged by suspicions of excessive patronage. The commission's legal counsel, Lawrence A. Mandelker, who gets paid $52.10 an hour, also represents the State Republican Party. But even promoters who have been critical of New York say that putting the state in a national context is crucial.
"There are some commissions that are putrid, terrible," said Mike Boorman, a spokesman for Main Events, a large boxing promoter based in Totowa, N.J. "If you did a bell curve, New York would get an A."

HEADLINE: The White House Dismissed Warnings on China Satellite Deal

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH and JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
The caution signs made it evident that the application by Loral Space & Communications to export a satellite to China earlier this year was anything but routine.
Justice Department prosecutors warned that allowing the deal could jeopardize possible prosecution of the company for an earlier unauthorized technology transfer to Beijing. The Pentagon reported that Loral had provided "potentially very significant help" to China's military rocket program. And senior White House aides cautioned that the deal was certain to spark opposition from critics of the Administration's nonproliferation and human rights policies toward China. 
 But the White House pressed ahead, concerned about the financial costs to Loral of delaying approval of the deal and certain that it could defend the decision against subsequent criticism.
Rarely is the public given a detailed look inside the White House decision-making process on a matter of national security as sensitive as the export of a satellite to China. These records ordinarily remain sealed for years, buried under the Government's strict regime of secrecy.
But documents produced by the White House 10 days ago in response to a demand from Congress provide an unusually rich account of the evolution of a Presidential decision in which numerous warning signals were raised and then dismissed.
According to the records, the February decision by President Clinton to approve the Loral satellite launching was treated as an urgent matter not because of its importance to the national security, but because the company was facing heavy fines for delay.
Concerns about European competition for the satellite business and fears that denying the deal would damage the United States-China relationship overrode words of caution from other Government agencies.
The presumption throughout was that the deal would be approved, as had 19 previous applications under Presidents Clinton and Bush. The documents reflect the White House staff's search for a defensible rationale for the decision.
Federal and Congressional investigators are now examining what led the President to risk political embarrassment by creating the perception that he might be letting Loral -- headed by the Democratic Party's largest campaign contributor -- off the hook in a serious criminal inquiry into whether Loral executives helped China's missile program.
 
Decision Traced To a Satellite Crash
Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, had a preemptive answer in the decision memorandum he forwarded to the President on Feb. 12. The memo briefly noted the Justice Department's concerns and referred to the possibility that Loral might have significantly aided China's military rocket program.
But he urged the President to approve the deal regardless.
"In any case," Mr. Berger wrote, "we believe that the advantages of this project outweigh this risk, and that we can effectively rebut criticism of the waiver."
Mr. Clinton approved it with his distinctive backward check mark six days later.
Since 1989, the export of American satellites for launching on Chinese rockets has been suspended as a result of sanctions imposed after the killings in Tiananmen Square. A deal can go forward only if the President concludes that the export is in the national interest and issues a waiver.
President Bush approved all nine waiver requests that reached his desk; President Clinton routinely followed the practice in his first four years in office, signing 10 waivers with little internal debate or external controversy.
But the waiver Mr. Clinton signed on Feb. 18 was not routine. The roots of his unusual decision trace back two years when a Chinese rocket carrying a Loral satellite crashed into a village seconds after liftoff, killing and injuring dozens of civilians.
A few months later, Loral led an outside review team to help the Chinese figure out what had happened. The company says its officials did nothing wrong. But Loral also acknowledged serious mistakes in a June 1996 disclosure to the State Department, including an admission that it allowed the Chinese to see its lengthy review of the rocket mishap without prior Federal approval. Such technological assistance to the Chinese requires prior Government approval, which Loral had not received.
At virtually the same time that Loral made its disclosure to the Government, the company was seeking another Presidential waiver for a satellite. Its chairman, Bernard L. Schwartz, donated $100,000 to the Democratic Party four weeks before the waiver application was approved in early July 1996 by Mr. Clinton.
It is not known whether Loral's help for the Chinese was mentioned in the memorandum that went to the President because the White House has not released documentation on that decision.
It is known that the State Department had already alleged in a letter to satellite industry executives that there had been a violation of American export control laws in the accident review.
But as of July 1996, no criminal inquiry was under way. The Justice Department began its investigation only after the Pentagon completed an assessment of the accident review in May 1997.
That is the same month Loral applied for its most recent waiver, for the Chinasat 8 satellite.
 
Company's Concerns Reach White House
The first notice to the White House of unusual problems with the Chinasat 8 waiver application came in an early January memorandum from the State Department detailing the factors for the President to consider.
Although couched in careful bureaucratic language, the State Department document made it clear that this was no routine export license application.
The State Department pointed out that China's transfer of missile technology to Iran might prohibit the export of the Loral satellite or any other satellites or related items.
"Moreover," the State Department memo stated, "information about unauthorized defense services provided by Space Systems/Loral and another U.S. firm to China's Long March 3B Launch Vehicle" could lead to imposition of harsh sanctions against the company.
But the State Department and other agencies nonetheless recommended granting the waiver, because the deal would enhance the United States' leadership in commercial telecommunications, provide an incentive for China to adhere to international nonproliferation rules and improve trade ties with Beijing.
After virtually no debate at the White House, the State Department memorandum was rewritten as a decision paper for the President.
The State Department's concern about technology transfers to Iran appeared nowhere in the decision document, but a new element is inserted in the first and in most subsequent drafts. The President must act quickly, the draft states; any delay will cost Loral money.
"Due to severe contractual penalties which Loral will incur if it cannot begin technical discussions with the Chinese by next week, we recommend that you take action on this issue by January 20," read the first draft of the Presidential memorandum, dated Jan. 13.
A day earlier, Loral officials had made known to the White House their frustration at the slow Government response to their waiver application, which was submitted in May 1997.
A Loral letter found in White House files stated that unless the approval is granted within a week, the launching, scheduled for November, would be delayed by several months, costing the company at least $6 million. Any such delay would give the Chinese grounds for canceling the project, which would cost Loral $20 million, the company warned.
"Our competitors in Europe," Loral officials complained, "do not suffer delays due to export licensing or legal complications."
The company's concerns clearly were heard at the White House.
A senior aide at the National Security Council, Maureen E. Tucker, repeatedly pressed for a rapid decision in forwarding early drafts of the Presidential decision paper to associates at the council.
She described the memorandum and accompanying documents as "a very quick turnaround package for which I am seeking your clearance by tomorrow," she wrote on Jan. 13.
By Jan. 20, one frustrated aide scrawled on a draft of the memo, "Needs to go to POTUS today!!" POTUS is the White House jargon for President of the United States.
But the waiver request was held up by questions from Mr. Berger, who asked his legal aides to research the status of the Justice Department investigation and determine whether it would bar approval of the waiver.
Tellingly, Mr. Berger asked Gary Samore, the National Security Council's top weapons proliferation expert, in a handwritten note if the approval can be granted in phases "to get over immediate crunch."
Mr. Berger did not ask whether Loral's cooperation with the Chinese after the 1996 accident would require denial of the export license. Instead, he wonders in the note to Mr. Samore where there is "anything we can hang our hat on to characterize Loral's 'offense.' "
Mr. Berger's aides sought advice from officials at the State Department, who informed them that Loral's offenses appear to be "criminal" and "knowing." Ms. Tucker was told that the Pentagon investigated Loral's assistance to the Chinese after the 1996 missile explosion and concluded that the company provided "potentially very significant help" to Beijing's ballistic missile program.
 
Behind Decision To Grant a Waiver
The White House counsel Charles F. C. Ruff told a Security Council lawyer that the Justice Department's investigation mattered less than maintaining close diplomatic and business relations with China.
"Issue is not underlined twice impact on DOJ litig(ation)," the Security Council deputy counsel Newell Highsmith wrote in notes of his conversation with Mr. Ruff, "but whether bilateral U.S.-China concerns and economic factors outweigh risk of political embarrassment."
A principal argument behind Mr. Clinton's decision was that it would be unfair to penalize Loral by denying it a license if it was under investigation but had not been charged with any crimes.
The export law allows the President to deny a license if the license seeker has been indicted or if there is "reasonable cause to believe" the license seeker "has violated" United States export control laws. The White House documents show that some White House and State Department officials believed the latter, but Administration officials say they relied on a 1993 State Department memo which said that companies will be denied licenses only after indictment.
"In an ideal world we would wait until this matter is resolved," Malcolm R. Lee, a National Security Council aide, told other White House officials in an electronic message a month before the President's decision, referring to the pending Justice Department inquiry. But, Mr. Lee added, "that is impracticable."
A senior Administration official, speaking not for attribution, said that waiting for the results of the Justice Department investigation could delay the satellite launching for months, if not years.
And, the official added, "There were some imperatives to get a timely decision because of the penalties facing the company."
But the company acknowledges that no such penalties have been imposed and the launching is still scheduled for November, as it has been for the last year.
"We believe we will not incur penalties because we can work around the problem," a Loral official said late last week.
 
Pentagon Troubled By Loral's Role
The President did not receive a detailed assessment of the potential damage to American security caused by Loral's help to China in determining the cause of the 1996 launching failure. The Pentagon was troubled by Loral's technological assistance because the rocket science involved in putting a satellite into orbit is similar to that needed to deliver a nuclear warhead.
The Pentagon, relying on Air Force missile and intelligence experts, did not find grave damage but did conclude that the United States national security had been harmed, according to Administration officials.
A White House official said that the National Security Council never received the Pentagon report, which was prepared to assist the State Department. "We did the best we could in the memo for the President in describing what we understood to be the allegations," the official said. "We didn't beat around the bush."
White House aides overcame the major impediment to the waiver -- the concern of Justice Department prosecutors that it would jeopardize any possible prosecution -- by relying on the fact that "the Department had every opportunity to weigh in against the waiver at the highest levels and elected not to do so," as Mr. Ruff, the White House counsel, wrote on Feb. 13.
But Justice Department officials say that Mr. Ruff, in his discussion with Robert Litt, the top aide to the Deputy Attorney General, asked only about the impact of the waiver on possible prosecution -- not whether the department opposed the waiver.
It is not known how the Justice Department would have answered that question.

PUB-DATE: June 1, 1998

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 3092 words

HEADLINE: BOXING IN THE SHADOWS: A special report.;
Out of View, the Fight Game Is Thriving

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE

 BODY:
In a tiny back room at the Mix Factory nightclub, rock music pounded through the cinder block walls as a dozen boxers on the Tuesday night fight card lined up for physicals. Jerry Strickland slouched. This ritual was old hat for him: The doctor prodded his stomach, felt his facial bones, checked his heart and his blood pressure, and asked how he felt. "Fine," Strickland said.
"You're all set," the doctor pronounced, completing the 90-second examination. 
 Thirty minutes later, Strickland, 45, was doing what he has done repeatedly since his first fight in 1968: getting beat up. He has been knocked out at least 46 times, more times than some boxers fight in a career. On this night, he was sent sprawling to the canvas three times -- blows that left him down on all fours trying to clear his head -- before the referee stopped the fight. For this he was paid $300.
"It's a job," Strickland said, sipping a beer at the bar as the fight crowd of perhaps 100 people filed out. "Right now you can get killed out in the street for free. I prefer if you hit me, I make some money."
Boxing, a sport as old as human aggression, is growing again after years of stagnation or decline, but the numbers are not coming from the glamorous multimillion-dollar title fights on pay-per-view television in storied locales like Las Vegas, Atlantic City and New York. Boxing is instead growing in places where there has been little of it in the past, like Indian reservations, and anonymous bars and clubs where it barely gets noticed. And much of the growth is in states where safety regulations are weak or nonexistent.
The growth is driven by confluent forces -- from a booming economy that allows upstart promoters to take new risks, to the decline of televised boxing, which is forcing managers and fighters to compile records and recognition in other ways.
The results are diverse, too.
For fans in Pennsylvania, Indiana and Wisconsin, it means the most local boxing shows in a generation. For small promoters, it means opportunities -- local exposure for fighters, and relationships with bigger players like Don King, who is subsidizing many of the shows as a silent partner. For state regulators, it means a greater struggle than ever to oversee a sport that is almost nobody's highest priority. For boxers like Strickland -- part of a fighting family that travels to places like Nashville for $100-a-round bouts -- it means more paydays.
And so there is a new generation of boxing capitals, including the low-budget basement version here. Tennessee, which was not previously a boxing mecca and which has an athletic commission staff of one man and his secretary, had 64 boxing events last year -- more than Nevada or New Jersey and second only to California's 92. In Indiana, where a volunteer athletic commission oversees the sport, the number of boxing events is expected to double this year to 30, equal to New York's. Idaho, which had almost no boxing a decade ago, had 10 shows last year.
The level of attention and money that states commit to the sport's safety differs greatly. New York, which has some of the most exacting medical requirements in the nation, spent nearly $1 million to regulate 30 boxing shows last year, while Tennessee spent $56,008 to monitor more than twice as many events, not bothering even to do blood testing on fighters. Six states have no boxing regulations at all.
All of which sits fine with Jerry Strickland and his half brother, Reggie, whose 242 professional bouts have made him a legend on the Midwest and Southern fight circuits. Tennessee has boxing like it used to be, Reggie Strickland said.
"Tennessee is the greatest state for boxing," he said. "It used to be Kentucky, but now they've got some snot-nosed commissioner. They're trying to be hard on the fighters. Here, they're just great all the way around. You never have a problem -- they do what they're supposed to do, and fighters do what they're supposed to do."
 
Overseeing Safety
Different Budgets, Different Attitudes
Many state and Federal officials say the new trends make boxing, a sport that has always danced on the line of respectability and infamy, a disaster waiting to happen. In Congressional hearings last year that resulted in the first Federal law on fighter safety, witnesses told of boxers who were being knocked out one night and fighting the next, of fighters' boxing under false names, including those of dead men, and of promoters telling boxers to put rolls of coins in their pockets at weigh-ins so they could earn bigger paydays fighting heavier opponents.
Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, the chief sponsor of the Federal law, said the worst abuses and injuries were probably hidden because many fighters and managers were reluctant to testify. His investigators have not uncovered any ring deaths attributable to weak laws or inexperienced regulators. But the Senator said the result of a thousand blows to the head is cumulative, something that will only be revealed over years.
The legislation passed last year requires boxers to obtain a national identification card that must be presented before any fight. A national committee of state attorneys general is also looking at ways to further improve safeguards.
"We're beginning to see more injuries, and we're going to see even more," Senator McCain said. "It's almost inevitable, because there's an environment being created where the boxer is less protected. The sport is proliferating in places that have not known a lot of boxing before. It's become absolutely more dangerous."
State regulators in Tennessee and other places where boxing has surged say they believe the sport is being safely monitored. And several states, including Kentucky and Oklahoma, have recently tightened boxing supervision, to the annoyance of boxers like the Stricklands.
What national legislators do not understand, many state regulators say, is that it all comes down to money. Tennessee's boxing administrator, Tommy Patrick, said the issue of more medical testing comes up at almost every meeting of the Boxing and Racing Commission, but nothing is done. Its budget has no fat, he said. The $56,008 spent last year, for example, included payment for the time that Patrick and his secretary devoted to boxing -- between other duties like automobile racing regulation -- plus per-diem payments for inspectors and doctors.
"You're talking about fighters fighting for a $300 purse here, so they're going to pay for an AIDS test or a CAT scan or all this?" Patrick asked. "Certainly the boxing commission can't pay for it. Anybody hates to take the position that money rules the health of somebody, but you know, facts are facts. Somebody's got to pay for this stuff."
And there are also simply different levels of tolerance for risk in different regions of the country, an issue that is visible in everything from motorcycle helmet laws to day-care licensing. Patrick said the question of whether a fighter like Jerry Strickland, for example, should still be boxing in middle age, after scores of defeats and knockouts, is not something a boxing regulator here can or even should answer.
There are no age laws in Tennessee for fighters, and if someone can pass the physical and "adequately defend themselves," Patrick said, and the fight is not an obvious mismatch of skills, "there's really nothing in our law to stop anyone."
For big-budget fights of the sort held at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas or Madison Square Garden in New York, state officials can afford more rigorous medical testing and supervision, in part because the costs can be charged back to the promoters or added to ticket prices. But at the lowest levels of the sport, there is no such cushion.
"Our job has gotten a lot tougher," said Cletus Hansen, an official in the Wisconsin Department of Regulation and Licensing, which administers boxing regulation as well as licensing for cemeteries and real estate agents. Hansen said that because of the tougher standards from the new Federal law, which requires more extensive background checks, his staff gets bogged down just doing paperwork.
Perhaps as a result, fighters say that many of the old abuses -- fake names, fake identification cards, fighters back in the ring days after being knocked out -- are still going on. And some states do not always inquire too closely -- Tennessee, for one.
*One boxer who has fought three fights in Tennessee over the last six months said at least one was against an opponent fighting under another man's name and record.
*Another boxer fought in Nashville recently in violation of state laws that require mandatory days off. He had fought a 10-round fight only five days earlier, something officials failed to determine.
*Boxers at the Mix Factory show wrapped their hands before fights without any inspection by opponents or state officials, as is customary in higher-profile settings. Many fighters and managers say a hardened object concealed in a wrap can kill an opponent.
At the Mix Factory, where a ringside seat typically costs about $15, promoters say more regulation would eliminate jobs and opportunities for fighters.
Jim Westmoreland, the club's matchmaker, said regulations like New York's or Nevada's or New Jersey's would bankrupt a show like theirs in a day. "The medical costs alone would be more than our whole budget," he said.
But as it is, there is plenty of demand for journeyman fighters like the Strickland brothers, Reggie and Jerry. The two talk about boxing the way many people talk about their work, with a certain wry detachment. Reggie, 29, has the record of an old man: 242 professional fights, for a record of 44 victories -- including 5 knockouts -- 183 losses, 12 draws and 3 bouts in which no decision was rendered. Jerry says he has fought 300 professional fights, though his record according to Fight Fax, a company that tracks boxers, shows only 118, including 104 recorded losses.
And these days, the five-hour drive to Tennessee from their home in Anderson, Ind., has become like a commute to the office. Of Reggie's 37 fights since last fall, 20 have been here.
The Stricklands are both slight men, well under 6 feet and each typically weighing in at between 150 and 160 pounds. They share an edgy, often mordant humor. They do not worry about what they have done to themselves and their bodies, they say.
"I deal with reality," Reggie said. "And reality says if it's meant to happen, it's going to happen. So I live life to the fullest. Who can tell what tomorrow may bring, so I get what I can get today and worry about tomorrow tomorrow."
But for a journeyman fighter, tomorrow usually means another long drive to unmemorable places like the Chattanooga High School gym or to the gloomy third-floor lounge at the Mix Factory, where waiting boxers sprawl in booths by the bar. Fighters shadowbox by the pool tables, eyeing each other's moves.
There are apartments east of Nashville that Jimmy Adams, the Mix Factory's promoter, keeps for use by his stable of fighters, but the Stricklands prefer to arrive just before their fights, and head for Indiana by early morning.
Their story echoes some old boxing traditions in the Midwest and South. One boxer from Memphis, Sam Black, now apparently retired, fought more than 200 times professionally. Another boxer who regularly fights in Nashville, Danny Lee Wofford, has nearly 100 fights. For the Stricklands, family was the link and the reason. Another brother, Robert, also fights professionally, as does Jerry's son, Jerry Jr.
"I had an uncle who did a whole lot of time in Alcatraz," Jerry said. "When he came out, he said I was too quiet, that I needed to fight. Then he up and hit me right in the mouth. Made me bleed. I've been here ever since."
Reggie grew up watching Jerry. "One day I went to the gym with him and got beat up and liked it," he said with a laugh. "I've been doing it ever since."
The Stricklands say they have seen some of boxing's worst: fixed fights, decisions changed by the judges after a fight because of pressure from promoters. But they also, on some level, still believe.
Reggie feels he is owed at least a shot at one of the exploding number of championship titles, however marginally meaningful. "I figure after you've had so many fights, then you retire, there should be something there for you," he said. "I figure they should all just give me one chance for one good payday -- five, six grand. I ain't asking for much."
 
The Minor Leagues
'It's Just Basic Fighting'
Boxing has always offered a mix of maudlin emotion and coarse brutality. Tales of tough-kid up-and-comers, like the title character in the "Rocky" movies, are part of a whole misty-eyed subculture. And small-club boxing is where fighters have begun careers and built records for generations.
In places like the Mix Factory, all of boxing's primal emotions swirl: hope and ambition, nostalgia and greed. Some fighters here perceive a kind of purity, a place removed from the taint of big money and greedy promoters.
"It's like a church," said Ryan Wissow, a reed-thin 23-year-old novice boxer from Florida who has fought three of his five professional bouts in Nashville. Wissow pays his way here from his home in Fort Lauderdale, where he makes and sells customized golf clubs in his apartment. "It's no nonsense, right down to business, no frills. The vibe is wonderful. It's just basic fighting."
Patrick, the administrator of the Tennessee Boxing and Racing Commission, believes that what is happening in Tennessee, where boxing events have nearly tripled in the last two years, is not unlike the growth of grass-roots baseball leagues, an alternative for those disgusted with big-money sports and arrogant athletes.
"What we've got here are the minor leagues," he said, "a bunch of young boxers who are interested in building a record."
Others see only the sport's underbelly, a calculated churn of cheap paydays and occasional star turns by promising fighters looking to beat up the local talent on their way to title shots elsewhere.
They say that as the number of boxing organizations offering world title fights has grown -- there were 201 last year, compared with 35 or fewer in decades past -- the number of fighters who want to compete for titles and major prize money has climbed as well. That has created a demand among promoters and managers for matches that will build a fighter's record.
Others forces, by deliberate coordination or coincidence, are pushing more fights to the sport's lower rungs.
Big promoters like Don King have sharply expanded the number of fighters they send to once out-of-the-way places like Nashville. That has made the economics of running small shows more manageable, local promoters say, because the King organization picks up the costs and the pay for the fighters it sends.
The decline of boxing on television, which is at about its lowest level since the 1960's, is also pushing the growth of small-town events. Because the competition for television time is greater, boxers must build better records with more fights in order to get their fights broadcast. USA Network, which had a regular weekly boxing program, recently announced that it would cancel the show this summer, though Fox Network has mentioned adding a weekly boxing show that might replace it.
The result, promoters and managers say, is that smaller shows are easier to do financially now. In the 1970's and 1980's, when television time was ample, no one cared about the little clubs, said Nelson Fernandez, a New Jersey-based fight manager who regularly works with the King organization in sending boxers to places like Nashville. Now they have to, and money is flowing down from the top.
David Reyes, a boxing promoter who started his own small company 18 months ago in San Diego -- monthly boxing shows, $100 a round -- said local economics is the key, not the machinations of the television networks or big-time promoters.
"There are just more fighters now willing to fight for this kind of money," he said.
At the same time, boxing experts say, the sport is being decentralized geographically.
Five years ago, for example, a mid-size Philadelphia-based boxing promoter called Banner Promotions did about 20 boxing shows a year, with roughly 80 percent in Las Vegas or Atlantic City. This year, the company will do 30 shows, said Arthur R. Pelullo, the president, with two in Las Vegas, none in Atlantic City, and all the rest elsewhere in the country.
In 1988, more than 21 percent of the 682 boxing events held in the United States were concentrated in Nevada, New Jersey and New York, according to figures from Fight Fax and the National Association of Boxing Commissions. Last year, that total fell to 12 percent of 821 events.
"Atlantic City hotels are packed, so they don't need boxing, and Vegas is overhauling its image," said Bruce Trampler, a matchmaker for Top Rank, a Las Vegas-based promoter. And he said newer boxing sites, like the Indian casinos sprouting up across the country, are competing hard, paying big fees to get events.
In some parts of the country, there is also a vibrant ethnic flavor to the new boxing scene. In California, a half-dozen tiny promoters have popped up in recent years, doing small shows in Hispanic clubs and community centers in the southern part of the state, said Rob Lynch, the acting administrator of the state Athletic Commission. And in border cities in Texas, Mexican fighters are coming north, looking for a breakthrough, or at least a paycheck.
"All of a sudden, being more shows, it's helping the little guy a lot," said Eddie Garcia, a San Antonio-based manager and promoter who has worked with King and who is involved in the Hispanic boxing scene in Texas. One of Garcia's fighters, a 135-pound lightweight named Francisco Alberto Martinez, who was on the Mexican Olympic team, is using the club circuit as a way to try to become a contender in the United States. Martinez is hoping to compete this summer in a 15-city all-Texas tournament, a first for the state.
"It's an opportunity to try out for the major leagues," Garcia said.
In Nashville, Adams said he planned to stage his own title fights this summer. He is forming a new boxing organization, called the Global Boxing Association. It will have 17 weight classifications, he said, allowing for a different title fight, or maybe two, every week.
"Right now, I'm having my belts made," he said.

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
Clinton Backs More Money For Russian Debt if Needed
The United States would support new international financial aid to the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin if Russia could not meet its short-term debts, President Clinton said, because a meltdown of the ruble could threaten the stability the Government there. Mr. Clinton's statement appeared to pave the way for a new financial bailout of Russia by the International Monetary Fund. A1
 
The Prime Minister of Russia said in an interview that the country did not need emergency international loans to pull itself out of its financial crisis. But the interview with the Prime Minister was taped before the statement by Mr. Clinton, whose his support had been sought by the Russian Government. A8
 
Report Details Fate of Nazi Gold
Much of the gold looted by the Nazis was routed through Switzerland to pay other neutral nations for vital supplies that sustained Hitler's army in the last years of World War II, United States Government historians have concluded in a report. The report also doubles the American estimate of how much gold was in a Nazi account that received gold stolen from Holocaust victims. A1
 
India Appeals for Arms Limits
India called for early negotiations on a new global treaty limiting nuclear arsenals that would include India, Pakistan and possibly even Israel. India has made similar proposals before, but they were rejected by the five established nuclear powers: Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States. A1
 
Pakistan's nuclear scientists were hailed as national heroes as they returned from the remote desert where they had set off atomic explosions. Ninety-seven percent of Pakistanis support the testing, according to a poll by the Pakistan Institute for Public Opinion conducted for Gallup International in major cities. A6
 
Pakistan's nuclear tests required a global network of theft and espionage and the investment of millions of dollars. But the tests could not have happened without smuggled Chinese technology and contradictory shifts in American policy, say current and former United States officials. A6
 
Afghan Quake Kills Over 3,000
At least 3,000 people died after an earthquake shook northeastern Afghanistan, and many more bodies were feared hidden under rubble, aid agencies said. Officials said the quake, 6.9 on the Richter scale, affected 60,000 people in an area where more than 4,500 were killed by a quake three months ago. A7
 
Briefing on Iraqi Arms Planned
The chief United Nations arms inspector for Iraq plans to go to the Security Council this week with an unusually detailed technological accounting of what information Baghdad has failed to provide on biological, chemical and missile programs. The briefing is intended to counter Iraq's assertions that it has met all disarmament demands. A9

Issue in California Vote: Power of TV Commercials
California voters will pick nominees for governor on Tuesday in an election that has rekindled a debate over the potency of television commercials and underscored the perils for wealthy candidates who finance their own campaigns. A1

Clinton's Missile Decision
The February decision by President Clinton to approve the Loral satellite launching by China was treated as an urgent matter not because of its importance to the national security but because the company was facing heavy fines for delay, according to White House documents. Concerns about European competition for the satellite business, and fears that denying the deal would damage the United States-China relationship, overrode words of caution from other Government agencies. Einstein Letters Hint Spy Link
Letters written in 1945 and 1946 by Albert Einstein to Margarita Konenkova are to be sold at auction in New York. According to a book by a former Soviet spy master, Konenkova was a Russian agent whose mission was to introduce Einstein to the Soviet Vice Consul in New York. A10
 
New Strategy for Clinton?
President Clinton's lawyers are considering dropping his planned appeal of a Federal judge's rejection of his claims of executive privilege in the investigation into his relationship with a former intern. A13

South Dakota Tornado Kills 6
A tornado that struck South Dakota without warning wiped out most of a small farming community, killing six people and destroying its post office, fire station, library, bank and all four churches. The region was also pelted with hail the size of chicken eggs. A10

A crowded smuggler's powerboat that apparently lost its way in darkness and dense fog ran aground at an affluent New Jersey shore community, and its cargo of 22 Chinese men plunged into the surf, waded onto a beach lined with Victorian mansions and fanned out in search of freedom in America. The illegal immigrants were all arrested in shore towns 50 miles south of New York City, their intended destination. A1
