HEADLINE: April Sales Of New Homes Set a Record

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
Sales of new single-family homes rose to a record level in April and the United States index of leading economic indicators increased for the fourth consecutive month, signs that the economy will keep growing in the months ahead.
"This is just a very strong economy," said Ian J. McCarthy, president and chief executive of Beazer Homes USA, an Atlanta-based home builder. "We have good confidence and low interest rates -- a good combination for home building." 
 New-home sales climbed 5.2 percent in April to an annual rate of 888,000 units, after a revised 4.2 percent decline in March, the Commerce Department reported today. Booming sales in the South were enough to offset declines in other parts of the country.
In a separate report issued today, the Conference Board, a private research group, said that its index of leading economic indicators rose one-tenth of a percent in April. The index, intended to project economic activity over the next half-year, has not declined since April 1997.
The housing gains are helping to temper the effects of a slowdown in manufacturing, analysts said. And while the economy probably will not expand in the second quarter as fast as the 4.8 percent annual pace of the first quarter, the cooling of growth may keep the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates for the rest of the year, said Mark Vitner, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C.
"With the big run-up in inventories and the huge surge in imports we saw in the first quarter, we're going to see manufacturing activity slow a bit," Mr. Vitner said. "That's the part of the economy the Fed's focusing on."
Private forecasts that United States growth will slow this year by a half to a full percentage point because of Asia are reasonable, the San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank president, Robert Parry, said in a speech in Idaho today. "Still, the effects of Asia's economic crisis on United States growth so far have been less than expected," he said.
The housing report showed that April marked the eighth consecutive month the pace of new-home sales was above 800,000 units, the longest stretch since the series began in 1963.
"Given that existing-home sales have been in record territory for some time, strong new sales should not come as a surprise," said Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at HSBC Securities Inc. in New York. "With mortgage rates unlikely to rise for the foreseeable future, the strength in housing activity is unlikely to subside this year."
The average rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage was 7.15 percent in April, up slightly from 7.13 percent in March. Rates have recently fluctuated around 7 percent.
New-home sales rose 18.1 percent in the South to an annual rate of 418,000 units. In contrast, sales in the Midwest fell 9.2 percent, to 157,000 units at an annual rate; sales dropped 3.1 percent in the Northeast to 95,000 units, and dipped 0.5 percent in the West to 218,000 units.

HEADLINE: Russian Bond Auction: A $1.2 Billion Balancing Act

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
Raising the money that it needs each week to pay off debt that is coming due and finance its persistent budget deficit has always been a tricky proposition for Russia, given its tumultuous political and economic climate.
But the job will be particularly difficult on Wednesday, when the Government needs to raise $1.2 billion from the financial markets in the face of near panic among domestic and foreign investors about Russia's ability to maintain the value of its currency and honor all its debts. 
 The Government has failed in three previous weekly debt auctions to raise all the cash that it needs. Economists said it remained unclear whether this auction would fare better.
Although sky-high interest rates and a possibility of additional aid from the International Monetary Fund have somewhat reassured investors, economists and market analysts said Russia might once again be able to sell only part of the bonds.
That would force the Government to dip into its skimpy reserves to pay creditors, deepening the sense of crisis.
The Government has been pressing domestic banks and investors to buy the bonds as a sign of confidence in Russia's prospects. There were some reports today that domestic investors, who are required to place money in escrow with the Government the day before an auction if they want a chance to bid, had made bigger-than-expected deposits, suggesting that demand for the bonds could be better than expected. But analysts said that with the situation so unsettled it was difficult to predict any quick end to the turbulence, especially if foreigners remain wary.
"It's going to be another volatile day," a Russia specialist at Merrill Lynch in London, Dmitry Chernyak, said. "I don't see a lot of foreign investors returning to the market at this point."
Russia's main vehicle for raising money on its domestic financial markets is a bond known as a GKO that matures in less than a year. The country has $60 billion in GKO's outstanding, and because of their relatively short durations the Government is forced into a weekly scramble to redeem them and refinance the debt. Investors demand short maturities to minimize the risks of the ruble's being sharply devalued, eroding the return on the bonds.
By most estimates up to one-third of the GKO's are held by foreigners, with Russian banks holding most of the rest. The crisis in Asia had made foreigners skittish about investing in developing economies even before Russia's latest woes erupted. And since the Russian stock market began falling and the currency started coming under pressure, foreigners have been pulling their money out of Russia.
To make ruble-denominated investments more attractive and prop up the currency's value, the Russian central bank has pushed up the short-term annualized interest rates it controls, to 150 percent. The tactic has so far succeeded in maintaining the ruble's value.
But between the Government-controlled interest rates and the rates set by the market -- including those on the GKO bonds, which are around 65 percent on a yearly basis -- Russia's interest costs threaten to soar out of control. Nearly one-third of the Government's expenditures this year are projected to go to making interest payments. The comparable figure in the United States is 14 percent.
The projection is based on an assumption that the annualized GKO rates will decline, to 35 percent, economists said.
"If interest rates remain high, it exacerbates the budget problem and puts them, in effect, in a debt trap," said Desmond Lachman, head of emerging market economic research at Salomon Smith Barney, the investment firm in New York. "It's imperative that they get interest rates down quickly."
If rates remain at their current levels for the rest of the year, the budget deficit would be 8 percent of gross domestic product, compared with the 5 percent target agreed to last week by the International Monetary Fund and Prime Minister Sergei V. Kiriyenko, according to Erik F. Nielsen, an economist at Goldman Sachs in London.
Mr. Nielsen, who met on Monday with Mr. Kiriyenko in Moscow as part of a delegation of Western bankers, said Russia planned to try to lessen its dependence on the domestic GKO market by issuing additional bonds denominated in dollars and other currencies through financial markets in Europe. He said Russia was now hoping to raise up to $6 billion this year on the European markets, up from $3.5 billion under a previous plan.
Russia will need to finance the redemption of $50 billion in debt this year, Mr. Nielsen said.

HEADLINE: Pain Under Attack;
Explosion in Biotechnology Drugs Focuses on Arthritis

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
In the 20 years she has had rheumatoid arthritis, Veronica Lewandowski has undergone replacements of both hips, both knees and the knuckles of her right hand. She has tried virtually all the drugs available but nothing has really worked.
But in the eight months since Ms. Lewandowski, a 39-year-old resident of Worcester, Pa., began taking an experimental drug known as Enbrel, she is less fatigued and no longer has to descend stairs backward to spare her knees. And when her son fell off his bicycle recently, she astonished her two children, and herself, by running to him. 
 "They had never seen me run before," said Ms. Lewandowski, who had to give up her job in a chemical company laboratory because she could no longer operate the instruments. "Life is fun now."
Enbrel is the first drug produced by the two-decades-old biotechnology industry that is aimed at rheumatoid arthritis, which afflicts 2.5 million Americans and is the most severe of the diseases of the joints. What is more, other promising new drugs for rheumatoid arthritis are right behind it, a stark change for a disease for which there have been almost no new therapies for years.
"I've never seen this degree of activity in this field," said Dr. Michael E. Weinblatt, a professor at the Harvard Medical School. "I'm much more optimistic about controlling this disease than I was five years ago."
The new drugs are causing excitement on Wall Street as well as in the clinic because the potential market for them is estimated to be in the billions of dollars each year. The stock of the Immunex Corporation, the Seattle biotechnology company that makes Enbrel, nearly tripled in the last year, though it has recently fallen back to a level twice its 12-month low.
Two of the coming new drugs are involved in the big merger announced on Monday between the American Home Products Corporation and the Monsanto Company, promising to make the combined company a powerhouse in arthritis treatment. Immunex is 54 percent owned by American Home Products, which will help promote Enbrel in the United States and sell it overseas. Monsanto's pharmaceutical subsidiary, G. D. Searle & Company, is leading the way to develop a new type of painkiller for people with arthritis.
The new drugs appear to be as good or better than existing therapies but with fewer side effects. But they are not cures and just how much optimism is warranted will not be clear for some time.
Existing drugs can already control rheumatoid arthritis in 60 to 75 percent of the cases, especially if treatment is started early, said Dr. Doyt Conn, senior vice president for medical affairs at the Arthritis Foundation. He said the new drugs were likely to add to existing therapies, not replace them.
Immunex applied in May to the Food and Drug Administration for permission to market Enbrel. The company hopes for approval as early as the end of this year.
Centocor Inc. of Malvern, Pa., hopes to file for approval of a somewhat similar arthritis drug called Avakine within a year from now. But an F.D.A. advisory panel has just recommended approving Avakine for treatment of Crohn's disease, an intestinal inflammation. Once it is approved for that, doctors will also be able to legally use it for arthritis.
Also expected in 1999 are a new class of "super-aspirins" that treat pain and inflammation but without stomach bleeding and ulcers, which are estimated to cause several thousand deaths a year among patients who take existing painkillers.
Searle expects to file for F.D.A. approval in the third quarter of this year for use of such a drug to treat rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis and pain. Merck & Company is close behind, though it is first concentrating on osteoarthritis and pain.
Hoechst Marion Roussel, an American unit of Germany's Hoechst A.G., meanwhile, recently applied for approval to market still another new arthritis drug, called Arava.
Meirav Chovav, biotechnology analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said that Enbrel "could be a billion-dollar drug five years out." Sales projections from various analysts are even greater -- $2 billion or more -- for the super-aspirins.
The new drugs have their limitations. The super-aspirins, known as COX-2 inhibitors, do not even claim to halt the progress of the disease; instead, they are meant to relieve just the symptoms. Enbrel, Avakine and Arava probably will slow the destruction of joints but might not halt it completely, and they will not be able to heal already damaged bone and cartilage. Moreover, patients will probably have to take these drugs for life, possibly along with existing medications. But the new drugs, if started early enough, may allow sufferers to lead nearly normal lives.
"You can make it as controllable and tolerable as insulin-dependent diabetes or hypertension, where you have to take your medication but life goes on," said Elizabeth A. Tindall, clinical associate professor of medicine at the Oregon Health Sciences University in Portland. "That's a lot better than 'Buy your wheelchair now.' "
There are numerous types of arthritis, the most widespread being osteoarthritis, a wearing away of the cartilage that is associated with aging that affects about 20.7 million Americans, according to the Arthritis Foundation. But rheumatoid arthritis is the most debilitating. Half the victims -- many are women aged 25 to 50 -- must quit work because of disability within a decade, Dr. Weinblatt of Harvard said.
Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease, one in which the body's immune system, designed to fight bacteria and viruses, mistakenly attacks the body's own tissues, in this case the lining of the joints.
Until now, drugs for rheumatoid arthritis have been borrowed from other diseases like cancer or malaria. They either suppress the immune system in general or work in other ways not fully understood. And they can have serious side effects. The most commonly used is methotrexate, a generic cancer drug, which can cause liver and lung problems in a small number of patients.
There are also two dozen or so nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, which range from over-the-counter aspirin and ibuprofen to more potent formulations sold by prescription.
The newer drugs take advantage of the explosion of knowledge about the immune system. They are designed to be more specific in their activities, with the hope of producing better results with fewer side effects. "We are on the threshold of targeted approaches," said Dr. Conn of the Arthritis Foundation.
Consider the COX-2 inhibitors. COX, which stands for cyclo-oxygenase, is an enzyme involved in causing pain and swelling at injury sites. But one type of COX is also involved in protecting the stomach lining and in helping the kidneys function.
Existing nonsteroidal painkillers like ibuprofen inhibit both types of COX. COX-2 drugs block the action of the enzyme involved in inflammation but leave the type that protects the stomach intact.
Dr. Michelle Petri, who heads the F.D.A.'s arthritis advisory committee, said that Searle's data show its COX-2 inhibitor to be as effective as existing painkillers yet "the toxicity profile was the same as for people taking the placebo." But she said the committee still asked for more data, in part to make sure there are no effects on fertility, as an animal study suggested there might be.
The existing market for prescription nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for arthritis is $2 billion in the United States and as much as $5 billion worldwide, said Dr. Philip Needleman, president of Searle. "We think COX-2 inhibitors will take over that entire market," he said.
Immunex's Enbrel works by stopping the activity of tumor necrosis factor, or T.N.F., one of the major substances involved in mounting an immune attack. T.N.F. attaches to certain immune system cells at docking stations known as receptors. Enbrel consists of versions of this receptor that float in the bloodstream and act as decoys, getting the T.N.F. to bind with them rather than with the immune cells.
Immunex at first is aiming at patients for whom existing drugs have failed. In clinical trials, about 60 percent of such patients responded to Enbrel and 40 percent saw their condition improve substantially. Immunex has also shown that Enbrel together with methotrexate is better than methotrexate alone, said Peggy Phillips, senior vice president for pharmaceutical development.
But whether Enbrel will displace methotrexate is not clear because a direct comparison of the two drugs has not been completed. Moreover, a year's supply of Enbrel will cost between $5,000 and $10,000, Ms. Phillips said, and patients must inject themselves twice a week. Methotrexate is available in pills and a year's supply costs only about $1,000.
Competition could also come from Hoechst's new Arava, which will also be in pill form. Analysts consider it a conventional medicine rather than a biotechnology marvel, but it does work by a mechanism different from the existing drugs.
Another unknown is how effective and safe Enbrel will be over the long run, said Dr. James O'Dell, chief of rheumatology at the University of Nebraska Medical Center. Immunex's data extend only to 15 months.
Connie Johnson of Lake Oswego, Ore., began taking Enbrel in December 1996. "In the first year, I was literally cured, and it was astonishing," she said. But in the last few months, she said, some symptoms returned, though still nearly nowhere as bad as they were before.
Centocor's Avakine takes on T.N.F. not with a receptor but with a monoclonal antibody, a specially engineered version of the body's infection fighters.
For the most seriously ill patients who are not helped by any drugs, Cypress Bioscience of San Diego is applying this year for approval to market a device that filters antibodies from a person's blood.
Other companies -- including Amgen Inc., Autoimmune Inc., the Immune Response Company and Isis Pharmaceuticals -- are in clinical trials of drugs that work in various other ways. Some companies hope to stop the body from attacking itself to begin with. Anergen Inc., for instance, has reported some effectiveness in early clinical trials of an arthritis "vaccine."
But the immune system is complex and efforts to control it have had mixed results. Also, weakening the immune system can leave a patient more susceptible to infections. The Idec Pharmaceuticals Corporation and SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. last year suspended late-stage clinical trials on an Idec arthritis drug after some patients experienced declines in a key immune system cell. The companies have now started new trials with a reformulated drug.
Progress made in treating arthritis might also help in treating other diseases, particularly autoimmune ailments like lupus and Type 1 diabetes. Immunex is testing Enbrel for congestive heart failure and COX-2 inhibitors show promise in colon cancer.
In the long run, scientists hope to find the cause of the self-immune attack. The Arthritis Foundation is searching for the genes that make people susceptible to the disease. Because not all genetically predisposed people get the disease, scientists suspect there is some trigger, like a bacterium or virus, that sets it off. But that trigger, if it exists, has not been found.

HEADLINE: Canadian Colleges Look Across Border to Fill Their Classes (and Coffers)

BYLINE: By KALYANI VITTALA 

DATELINE: TORONTO, June 2

 BODY:
"You can study here and be home for supper," declared an advertisement for the University of Windsor published recently in The Detroit News.
But just in case that was not inducement enough, officials of the university -- in Windsor, Ontario, on the Detroit River opposite Detroit -- are lowering tuition for Americans beginning this fall. 
 "We think this is a tremendous deal for U.S. students," said Dr. Ross H. Paul, the university's president. "With this new tuition fee, we are offering young American men and women access to a solid education at a competitive price."
The price is $3,500 (United States) a year for American undergraduates, compared with about $6,500 for other foreign students and about $2,500 for Canadians. Information has been sent to more than 4,500 high school seniors in Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, eliciting several hundred inquiries. With only 10 American undergraduates out of 10,000 at the University of Windsor this year, administrators are hoping for a windfall by the September application deadline for the coming school year.
"What struck me was the small number of American students we have enrolled here now," Dr. Paul said. "Crossing the border both ways is an everyday occurrence for many people."
The aggressive marketing strategy comes in the wake of deregulation of foreign student fees by the Ontario government, along with severe cuts in money from Ottawa over the last five years. The cutbacks have forced a more corporate mindset, with the United States seen as a largely untapped market.
About 3,000 Americans study in Canada every year, compared with 23,000 Canadians in the United States. "The deregulation of international fees has really changed the climate," said David A. Scott, senior adviser for government and community relations at the Council of Ontario Universities.
While recruiting foreign students is not a new idea, Mr. Scott said, the strategy is. "Business tactics become fuzzy when talking about academic institutions," he added.
Other universities are also looking to the United States to increase their visibility, enrollment and income. In 1996 the University of Toronto teamed with McGill University in Montreal and Queen's University in Kingston, Ontario, for a 15-city marketing tour of the United States, visiting high schools and college fairs.
"It's simple economics," said Paul R. Beel, McGill's recruitment activities officer. "There is great opportunity for American students to come up to Canada. Our dollar makes it a lot less expensive, plus they can study in a foreign country without facing cultural shock."
Applications from American students were up by 30 percent this academic year. McGill now has the highest number of American students of any university in Canada -- 1,500, or 15 percent of students.
All three universities, among the most prestigious in the country, considered last year's marketing effort a success, and a similar endeavor is planned for this fall. But none intend to lower fees for non-Canadian students, though they are watching Windsor's experiment closely.
Some Canadian students are concerned about the shifting priorities. "This is nothing short of a cash-grab to make up for Federal Government cutbacks," said Brad Levigne, national chairman of the Canadian Federation of Students. "Part of the problem is that costs have become so prohibitive for southwestern Ontario residents that they have to turn to American students. They're just cash cows."
With government cutbacks of more than $7.5 billion for post-secondary education since the 1993-94 academic year, the proportion of a university's operating revenue financed through student fees has increased to 40 percent this year from 25 percent in 1992-93.
Tuition has always been regulated by Canada's provincial governments, largely because it has been so heavily subsidized by taxpayers. But two years ago the Ontario government deregulated foreign student tuition, allowing schools to set their own fees. It has just announced the deregulation of fees for graduate programs and professional colleges for the coming academic year.
While tuition for Canadian students has risen to $2,500 (United States) at most institutions from about $1,000 in 1991, fees for foreign students have remained stable at about $6,500 until Windsor's discount to Americans.
Dr. Paul, Windsor's president, is excited about the initiative, but he is not immune to a certain amount of hand-wringing over the changes that the university's decision signifies.
"We have to be really aware of the danger of focusing on the short term just to get bodies in here," Dr. Paul said. "If I denied there were strong market forces at work behind this decision, you wouldn't believe me. But we've watched the same thing happen in the United States and learned some lessons. When the arena gets more competitive you can over-subsidize students. You can almost buy them. But we know if we lose our academic integrity we are lost."
Tom Sees, assistant vice president of Wayne State University in Detroit, Windsor's closest competitor, says he does not feel territorial about a Canadian university dipping into the American student pool. Nonetheless, Wayne announced last month that it was lowering its tuition, to $2,500 from $7,000, for Canadians as well as for Ohio residents in four counties bordering Michigan. "We're looking at this as a sort of good neighbor policy," Mr. Sees said.
About 200 Canadian students attended Wayne this year.
"If you don't look at your students as consumers," Mr. Sees said, "you are not going to stay in business much longer."
This is exactly the kind of "Americanization" the students' federation fears. "With this market mentality, degrees will be devalued," Mr. Levigne said. "People should be concerned about the quality of their education, not what kind of bang they are getting for their buck."
David B. Young, president of the University of Windsor's Student Alliance, took a different approach.
"Any additional student we get is better than nothing," Mr. Young said. "It will help reduce the overhead, reduce the pressure for Canadian students' tuition to go up. And having more American students here will increase our cultural diversity. How can that not be a good thing?"

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Tells Businessmen To Help Out By Investing

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 2

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin gathered the nation's most powerful businessmen at the Kremlin today and pressed them to use their money to help steady Russia's financial markets.
"When our own investors do not put their money in, foreigners leave," Mr. Yeltsin warned the businessmen. "If you want foreign investors to put their money in, you must put in yours." 
 Russia's central bank will hold a treasury bill auction on Wednesday. The sale of the bills has emerged as an important bellwether for the Government, which worries that the failure to sell all of the bills will further unnerve jittery investors.
The Kremlin went out of its way today to underscore Mr. Yeltsin's appeal, which was made in a closed-door meeting. It was made public by a Russian news service reporter who was allowed into part of the session.
At the meeting, Mr. Yeltsin listened to the businessmen's pleas for lower rail and energy tariffs. Some bankers also urged the Kremlin to threaten bankruptcy proceedings against deadbeat creditors.
As Russia's financial crisis simmers, Mr. Yeltsin is striving to assure foreign investors and skeptical voters that the economic situation is under control.
Enlisting the support of Russia's hard-hit but still powerful businessmen is the key. Dispelling the impression that Russia is run by a part-time President is also an important part of the Kremlin's public relations campaign.
Today's meeting began with bit of political theater. As the financiers assembled before a cordon of television cameras, Mr. Yeltsin turned to Anatoly B. Chubais, the former Kremlin aide he sent to Washington last week to appeal for additional international financing.
"Did my telephone calls help?" Mr. Yeltsin asked, referring to an earlier appeal to President Clinton. Mr. Chubais dutifully agreed that they did.
Adopting the mantle of a strong leader, Mr. Yeltsin also promised to present an "anti-crisis program" by the end of the month. The plan will be disclosed at an unusual meeting in the Kremlin's Marble Hall. Mr. Yeltsin summoned deputies from the upper and lower houses of Parliament to the session.
Still, obtaining Western aid is vital to restoring the confidence of investors, Russian officials say. And weeks of deliberations and negotiations appear to lie ahead.
The United States and other Western countries are trying to hammer out an aid plan, but they are moving at a deliberate pace. The proposals under consideration include an $8 billion to $10 billion reserve fund administered by the International Monetary Fund to help Russia's central bank buttress the ruble.
Western officials are also discussing other financial arrangements, including one that would help compensate the Russians for the toll that declining oil prices have taken on Russian exports. As part of the aid effort, future World Bank disbursement could be also be advanced.
Just as critical are the economic reforms the Russians will be asked to undertake in return. American officials have made it clear that the additional financing will be "conditional," a stipulation that appears intended to insulate the Clinton Administration from criticism that it is giving the Russians something for nothing.
Not all the clouds were dark today. The Yeltsin Government received a rare bit of good news when shares on the volatile Moscow stock exchange rose 12 percent. But brokers played down the significance, noting that trading was very light.
"It is going down on zero volume and going up on zero volume," said Tom Ashead, the co-director of research for United Financial Group. "The significance of this is that the market does not know what to do and where to go."
Mr. Yeltsin's meeting with the businessmen lasted for an hour and 40 minutes. It brought together 10 power brokers, including oil company executives, bankers and the heads of major financial industrial groups. The heads of some of the financial consortiums included Vladimir Potanin of Interros, Mikhail Fridman of Alfa Group and Mikhail Khodorkovsky of Rosprom.
The business barons have often fought among themselves as they jockeyed to control the spoils of the former Soviet state.
Mr. Fridman said in an interview that his bank was doing its share to invest in Russia: it bought $100 million of treasury bills last week just before the I.M.F. disclosed that it planned to disburse the next $670 million installment of its $10 billion loan.
Mr. Potanin said in an interview that Mr. Yeltsin underscored the need to work together to cope with financial crisis.
"He made the point that we are in the same boat and that we have to coordinate because of the very serious situation in the economy," Mr. Potanin said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Some of Russia's efforts to halt the financial slide could be working. After dropping 10 percent on Monday, the stock market rebounded yesterday, closing 12 percent higher. Traders talked on the exchange floor. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Trump's Backers Trying to Sell First 2 Riverside Apartment Buildings

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
With Southeast Asia's real estate market in turmoil and New York's soaring, the Hong Kong investors who financed Donald Trump's Riverside South development in Manhattan are trying to sell the first two apartment buildings at the $2.5 billion project.
The New World Development Company, which led the consortium that bought the 75-acre waterfront parcel on the West Side of Manhattan in 1994, has hired Salomon Smith Barney to solicit bids for the two buildings. The consortium had hoped that construction would begin in 1995, but the project, which stretches between 59th and 72d Streets near the Hudson River, moved slowly and the first two apartment buildings are only now nearing completion. 
 Since then, interest rates in Hong Kong have climbed and real estate prices have plummeted as a recession rumbled through Southeast Asia. New World, unlike some other Hong Kong real estate companies, is not in danger of collapse, but with apartment rents and prices in Manhattan soaring, a sale in New York would allow the consortium to raise a pile of cash quickly. That money, in turn, could be used to finance the rest of the project.
Salomon Smith Barney has pitched the properties to the Resnick real estate family, the Related Companies, Vornado Realty Trust and several other real estate investment trusts, according to executives involved in the potential deal. The sale price could go as high as $350 million to $400 million, the executives said, but New World may still elect not to sell.
"New World is not under nearly the same pressure as some of the other real estate companies," said Jack A. Shaffer, managing director of international sales for the Sonnenblick-Goldman Company, a real estate investment bank. "But New World does need cash to do things here, particularly at the Riverside South project."
At the same time, Mr. Trump and the Hong Kong companies are continuing longstanding talks with CBS about selling a 10-acre parcel at the south end of Riverside South, near 59th Street, for $100 million. CBS would build a 1.5 million-square-foot television studio there, according to an executive who works with the Trump Organization. But the prospects of a deal are hobbled by a lengthy city review process, potential community opposition and CBS's interest in several other options.
The plans for Riverside South call for 5,700 apartments in 16 apartment buildings, 1.8 million square feet of commercial space and a 21.5-acre public park. Mr. Trump and his Hong Kong partners are just completing the first two buildings: a 40-story, 366-unit apartment house between 68th and 69th Streets and a 46-story tower between 69th and 70th Streets, with 440 condominiums, on what will be an extension of Riverside Drive. The condominium tower will probably be converted to a luxury rental building if it is bought by a real estate investment trust.
Mr. Trump has opened a rental office and is completing the condominium plan. Tenants, both retail and residential, are expected to be moving in by the end of the year.
New World has to decide whether to take its profits on the buildings through a sale or over time. For Mr. Trump, a sale might be a public relations setback, in that Riverside South would no longer be associated exclusively with his organization.
Whatever happens, the buildings should generate plenty of revenue. After taking a plunge in the early 1990's, the residential market has been white hot recently. In the last year alone, prices for apartments in Manhattan jumped 20.7 percent over all, and 40 percent on the west side, according to the Corcoran Group.
Two executives from different companies who talked with Salomon Smith Barney said that New World, rather than Mr. Trump, had initiated the process and "was calling the shots" on the potential deal.
Mr. Trump confirmed that the partners were exploring a sale, though he doubted that any potential buyer could match "the numbers we could get ourselves."
"We're looking at the possibility of selling the two buildings," Mr. Trump said, "because of the tremendous activity in the residential market."
Many Asian investors were drawn to New York real estate in the mid-1990's by bargain prices and a relatively stable market compared with the speculative fever in Hong Kong and Singapore.
The Lai Sun Group bought the Four Seasons Hotel on East 57th Street for $190 million, a great bargain considering that the hotel had cost $477 million to develop. But faced with large debts and falling property prices in Hong Kong, Lai Sun is now selling the hotel, albeit for nearly double the original purchase price.
Mr. Trump's Riverside South project was languishing in 1994 when New World and four other Hong Kong companies paid $88 million for a $250 million mortgage on the land that was held by Chase Manhattan Bank. Mr. Trump remained as the developer and got a 30 percent stake in the project after development costs. Under certain conditions, his stake could grow.

HEADLINE: Central Europe May Catch Russia's Cold, U.S. Warns

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin warned today that unless Russia's financial crisis is resolved, its economic troubles "could spread to Central Europe," placing two major regions -- Asia and Europe -- in simultaneous downturns.
In his first statement since President Clinton said on Sunday that the United States would support an international bailout of Russia, Mr. Rubin chose his comments carefully to avoid worsening the flight from Russian and Asian currencies. 
 "I think it would be fair to say that the situation facing the world today with respect to financial stability is unprecedented," Mr. Rubin told a group of executives on a Presidential export council. "Russia's a difficult situation. We have an obvious national security interest. There is also the risk, once again, of contagion that could spread to Central Europe."
Mr. Rubin has a clear political agenda: He has been trying for months to persuade a skeptical Congress to increase Washington's contributions to the International Monetary Fund by $18 billion.
He has met enormous resistance, with conservatives saying the fund interferes in free markets and liberals contending that it is saving wealthy investors by imposing austerity programs that make ordinary workers suffer.
Both Mr. Rubin and his deputy, Lawrence H. Summers, argue that Russia's latest crisis underscores the urgency of adding to the fund's war chest. American officials have said that if an aid package is put together for Russia, it would have to come from the I.M.F. and the World Bank, not directly from the United States.
At the same time, Mr. Rubin's warning today seems in stark contrast to his recent predictions that another major outbreak of trouble was unlikely.
Five weeks ago Mr. Rubin told the Foreign Policy Association in New York, "The probability of the crisis worsening or spreading, or of a major new crisis developing is low." He said essentially the same thing to Congress several weeks earlier, though some top aides winced at the time and declined to make the same prediction themselves.
Today, in a brief telephone conversation, Mr. Rubin said his earlier statements referred to "a systemic crisis that could have a material impact on our economy."
In his public comments today, he reiterated his belief that while the American trade deficit would rise "substantially" this year, the overall impact on the economy "has been relatively minimal."
"We're in a world right now where the only healthy economy, growing on a sustained basis, is the United States."
The Administration's concern, however, is that if economic contagion spreads beyond Asia, it will become harder and harder to insulate the United States.
At the heart of that issue -- and of Mr. Rubin's comments today -- is the question of how economic troubles in one part of the world worsen troubles elsewhere, a little-studied subject that has suddenly become a top challenge in foreign policy.
Some links are clear-cut. Southeast Asia's troubles, which began last summer, are being reignited by Japan's worsening recession, and in particular by the fall of the yen.
Japan is a major purchaser of Asian goods, so its downturn is an enormous weight on the region. The yen's fall only aggravates the problem, because it puts competitive pressure on other nations to let their currencies fall so the goods they make retain a price advantage over Japanese goods in other markets.
More tenuous is the connection between Asia's troubles and Russia's. Many view the link as primarily psychological: Investors are fleeing all emerging markets, regardless of their differences. In recent days, investors have not only fled Russia; they have gotten out of Brazil, Turkey and other, smaller markets. Each country has its own problems, but they are worsened whenever investors get skittish and flee to the relative safety of the dollar.
And Central Europe is still so closely tied to Russia that Moscow's troubles could quickly spread.
In Russia's case, the alarm bells are ringing in Washington, but not with enormous urgency. Deputy finance ministers from the world's largest industrial countries meet in Paris next week to discuss their next moves. Officials say it will probably take several weeks to put together a package of loans or emergency credits through the I.M.F., the World Bank and other international institutions. And the aid they are considering -- about $10 billion -- is about a quarter of what was promised to Indonesia, and a fifth of what was promised to South Korea.
At least that is the plan for now. In both South Korea and Indonesia, the problems increased dramatically while the fund and its members negotiated over what to do. The same could easily happen with Russia.
"When you are talking weeks, you are talking the vast unknown," one senior official in an international institutions dealing with Russia said today. "Several weeks is a very, very long time in the markets."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Merrill Lynch Settles Suit Brought by Orange County
Merrill Lynch has agreed to pay $400 million to Orange County, Calif., to settle claims that the firm helped push the county into bankruptcy in 1994 with reckless investment advice.
With the settlement, the county will have recovered more than $621 million, and may end up recovering more than $800 million over all, out of $1.6 billion lost. Page A1. 

Single-Family Home Sales Soar
Low interest rates and strong consumer confidence helped push sales of new single-family homes up 5.2 percent in April, to an annual rate of 888,000 units. In another report, the index of leading economic indicators increased one-tenth of 1 percent in April. Both are signs that the economy is expected to keep growing in the months ahead. D2.
 
Chrysler Sales Jumped 27% in May
Sales of Chrysler cars and trucks soared 27 percent in May, making it the best month ever for the No. 3 United States auto maker. D5.
 
Regulators Ponder Conrail Takeover
Federal railroad regulators are holding hearings today and tomorrow on plans by Norfolk Southern and CSX to take over Conrail. Although they are expected to approve the takeover, analysts say they will move cautiously because of the rail tie-ups that resulted from the merger two years ago of Southern Pacific with Union Pacific. D8.
 
Stocks Mixed as Nasdaq Rebounds
Blue-chip stocks slipped, but technology issues rebounded from steep losses Monday. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 31.13 points, to 8,891.24. The Nasdaq composite index, heavily weighted with technology issues, rose 14.97 points, to 1,761.79. D10.
 
Treasury prices slip. The 30-year yield rose to 5.79 percent from 5.77 percent. D10.
 
Rubin Warns of Russia's Impact
Treasury Secretary Rubin called for a resolution to Russia's financial crisis before its economic troubles spread to Central Europe. A10.
 
Disney Official Leaves for Comcast
Steven Burke, 39, was named as head of Comcast's cable television unit as it moves toward selling digital TV service and Internet access through cable lines. Mr. Burke had been president of Walt Disney's ABC Broadcasting division. He helped found the chain of Disney Stores, led the revamping of Euro Disney and was considered by some as a possible successor to Michael D. Eisner as chief executive. D6.
 
Litigator Said to Seek Intel Suit
The Federal Trade Commission's top litigator is said to have recommended that the commission sue Intel on charges of antitrust violations. The commissioners are likely to vote on the recommendation next week. D10.
 
Light-Truck Crash Tests Released
The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration released crash-test results that it said showed sport utility vehicles could inflict more damage on cars. Automotive industry officials said the results provided little if any new information. A12.
 
Sara Lee to Give Away Paintings
Some 40 Impressionist paintings and sculptures worth about $100 million will be donated by Sara Lee Corporation to 20 museums around the country. E1.
 
Pepsi Ends Bottler's Franchise Deal
Pepsico broke off a 32-year franchise agreement with one of its largest independent bottlers, contending that the bottler insisted on a number of demands or else it would enter into Pepsico's lawsuit against Coca-Cola on Coke's side. D9.
 
British Airways' No-Frills Upstart
Deregulation of the European airline industry has created competition among low-cost, no-frills companies, but the rivals are complaining about British Airways' Go subsidiary. D2.

HEADLINE: Panel Finds Medicare Costs Are Underestimated by U.S.

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
A bipartisan Federal advisory panel said today that the long-term costs of Medicare were likely to be higher than estimated by the Clinton Administration, because the program was likely to continue growing at a brisk pace.
That conclusion increases the pressure for major changes in the popular health program for the elderly. 
 The Administration had been assuming that the growth of Medicare spending per beneficiary would slow after 2010, just as the first baby boomers become eligible. But the National Bipartisan Commission on the Future of Medicare, at a two-day meeting that ended today, said it was just as plausible to assume that there would be no slowdown.
Medicare spending grows not only because the number of beneficiaries and their average age are increasing, but also because elderly people are receiving more health care and more costly services. The Administration assumed that the average annual growth in Medicare spending per beneficiary would gradually drop to about 4 percent, the commission said, but experience suggests that it could just as easily remain at around 6 percent.
Those differing assumptions lead to a difference of $760 billion a year in Medicare spending by 2030, the panel said.
The 17-member commission, created by Congress and headed by Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, has decided to assess the effects of all its proposals on Medicare spending under both sets of assumptions.
The panel is considering fundamental changes in the structure of Medicare, but has not yet made specific recommendations. The higher estimates of Medicare spending, considered more realistic by many commission members, accentuate the need for changes in the program to keep it solvent for 76 million baby boomers, born from 1946 to 1964.
One panel member, Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, said the estimates of Medicare spending could have a profound effect on the commission's recommendations, which must be submitted to the President and Congress by March 1, 1999.
Another panel member, Bruce C. Vladeck, former administrator of the Medicare program, said any forecast of Medicare spending beyond 10 years was "an exercise in comparative fantasy."
But most commission members said it was necessary to make such estimates because otherwise the panel would not see the huge effects of the baby boom on Medicare.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a commission member and former economic adviser to President Clinton, said history suggested that the Administration's estimates of future Medicare spending were, in fact, optimistic.
The Administration assumes that the growth of Medicare will slow so that costs per beneficiary eventually grow at about the same rate as the nation's economy, measured by the total output of goods and services per person. But Mr. Breaux and other commission members said this assumption was at odds with the history of Medicare because costs have generally increased faster than the gross domestic product.
Stuart H. Altman, a Brandeis University professor appointed to the commission by Mr. Clinton, said, "We are going to see a resumption of health cost increases in this country." If that coincides with the "tidal wave" of baby boomers reaching retirement age, he said, there will be immense pressure to restrict spending or to ration health care.
The advisory panel got a vivid reminder of the politics of Medicare when it convened today at the Library of Congress. In the audience were dozens of members of the Gray Panthers, an advocacy group for the elderly. They held up signs that said, "No more Medicare cuts!" They also demanded that the commission hold public hearings.
In an interview, Mr. Breaux said the commission would hold hearings on July 10 and 13 and seek public comment in other ways.
Commissioners agreed that they must also assess the overall fairness of the Medicare program and the adequacy of its benefits.
Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia, a member of the commission, said he hoped that the panel would not become entranced with cost projections. "If this commission is simply about solvency," he said, "I'd like to get that cleared up right now, because I'm not sure I belong on it."

HEADLINE: A Heated Hearing on Partner Rights

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

 BODY:
The City Council held its first public hearing yesterday on legislation that would give domestic partners the same rights as spouses, prompting about 150 opponents of the measure to storm out of the meeting, complaining that the bill's supporters were allowed to monopolize the time at the microphone.
By the City Council's tally, 24 people testified in favor of the bill during the three-hour hearing and eight spoke against it. But among the 200 that showed up for the hearing of the General Welfare Committee, the overwhelming number came to oppose the bill, many of them massing on steps of City Hall to continue their protest after they walked out of the meeting in frustration. 
 "We went upstairs and we've been waiting and waiting and waiting," said the Rev. Ruben Diaz, president of the New York Hispanic Clergy Organization, which is based in the Bronx. "The chairman is laughing in our face."
Councilman Stephen DiBrienza, a Democrat from Brooklyn and the committee chairman, said he allowed people who had pre-registered to speak first, as is customary. Many of the bill's opponents said they showed up early yesterday morning to get in line, not realizing they were already too late.
Gay and lesbian groups said the measure would provide a historic guarantee of their rights, but it would also apply to heterosexual couples who register as domestic partners with the City Clerk's Office. The bill would insure that the domestic partners of city employees would have the same rights as spouses and also guarantee the rights of domestic partners who live in city housing.
Despite fervent opposition from some religious groups, the bill has widespread bipartisan support on the Council, thanks in large part to the stances of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who proposed the legislation, and the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, its sponsor.
The committee plans to hold one more hearing on the bill before it is sent to the full Council for a vote later this month. But it was clear from the start of yesterday's hearing that there was broad support for the measure among some of the more influential Council members.
Mr. DiBrienza opened the hearing by calling the Mayor's championing of the bill "a courageous act."
The first witness was Randy M. Mastro, the Deputy Mayor for Operations, who said that Mr. Giuliani was keeping a campaign promise. Mr. Mastro also noted that most of the rights granted by the bill applied to domestic partners under executive orders already in place.
"It's about insuring that New York City law does the right thing by all of its citizens," he said. "The Mayor believes that this is the right thing to do -- that as a matter of fairness and equity, we should be codifying the letter and spirit of these executive orders." As Mr. Mastro began his testimony, a man in the audience, who would not give his name, shouted, "Giuliani is a liberal turncoat."
Paula L. Ettelbrick, the legislative counsel of Empire State Pride Agenda, a statewide lesbian and gay political organization, said the measure "insures that thousands and thousands of disabled, old, gay, lesbian and straight New Yorkers and our children will receive the economic, emotional and social support necessary for our families to thrive."
In the testimony he had prepared, Mr. Diaz of the Hispanic pastors' group said: "This law diminishes the meaning and sanctity of marriage. It eliminates the incentive for a couple to marry, motivating a life that goes against that which was established by God as stipulated in holy scriptures."
Mr. Diaz handed out copies of his statement before the meeting but left without reading his text because he had to wait so long to speak.
John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, used one of his Sunday homilies last month to warn of the bill's possible harm to society. No representative of the Archdiocese of New York appeared at the hearing, but at its request, the Cardinal's homily was placed in the hearing record and Mr. DiBrienza read one passage.
Councilman Thomas K. Duane, who is openly gay, was unapologetic that most of the speakers were in favor of the bill. "If on this one occasion, supporters of a civil rights bill for lesbian and gay New Yorkers got to go first, I don't think that's going to change the balance sheet in terms of public discourse," said Mr. Duane, a Democrat from Manhattan.

HEADLINE: From Vending Snacks to Venting Anger;
Food Sellers Are Set to Protest Partial Ban on Carts, but Retail Rivals Like It

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
Three decades ago, a rail-thin immigrant from Greece raised an oversized umbrella on the corner of William and John Streets and staked his claim to a piece of lower Manhattan concrete. From now on, the gesture said, George Markopoulos would be selling hot dogs and sauerkraut from this location.
Nearly every weekday since then he has plied his trade, presenting each foil-wrapped hot dog to the customer as though it were a gift. 
 But just up John Street, another Greek immigrant named Tom Tsolomytis has spent the last two decades running the Roxy Food Shop, a 24-hour diner that advertises its specials -- "shrimp-salad sandwich, $3.50" -- on paper plates. And he has no appreciation for the panache, or the plight, of street vendors, whose numbers have grown in recent years.
"The only thing I know is they hurt my business," Mr. Tsolomytis said, a toothpick nestled behind his ear.
The inherent conflict between rent-paying business owners like Mr. Tsolomytis and street vendors like Mr. Markopoulos will reach a crescendo today, when hundreds of vendors are expected to participate in a morning-long demonstration to protest the Giuliani administration's decision to ban food carts -- as well as vendors selling items like clothing -- from 144 streets throughout the city, beginning in July. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has said the ban is needed to ease congestion on busy sidewalks.
The vendors plan to meet at Liberty Park in lower Manhattan at 9 A.M., hold a news conference, then walk down Broadway to rally in Battery Park. As a result, protest leaders say, thousands of customers will have to do without their cheap daily sustenance of street-corner fruit, sandwiches or coffee. In addition, the organizers say, companies that supply the hot dogs and soda, along with the bakeries that supply the doughnuts and bagels, are shutting down to show their solidarity.
"It's a shutdown for the whole day, and it's going to be a great turnout," said Jeff Cicio, the president of the Big Apple Food Vendors Association. "We want the public to know that we have a serious problem."
In fact, many customers interviewed yesterday said that the vendors did no harm in their current locations. And they said they liked the low prices, tasty if nutritionally questionable fare, and New York ambiance that the food carts represent. "I've been coming here for two and a half years, two times a week," said Anthony Pepe, a city employee who frequents Mr. Markopoulos's stand. "I think it's terrible that he'd have to move. I've never seen a pedestrian problem as far as where he stands."
The ban focuses on many of the narrow streets in the financial district of lower Manhattan. On the city's map, for example, the intersection of William and John Streets has become an X over the livelihood of Mr. Markopoulos, 58, who is hunched from so many years beneath his cart's metal overhang.
Several business-improvement districts agree with the Mayor's contention that the restrictions are needed to ease congestion on the sidewalks. They emphasize that the number of street vendors is not being reduced -- only the number of places where they can operate. But Mr. Markopoulos countered that the city's argument defied basic economics: if hundreds of vendors moved to sanctioned, out-of-the-way locations, the combination of less traffic and more vendors would hurt business for everybody.
"You don't make any money, and I don't make any money," Mr. Markopoulos said. "After all these years, I don't want to go someplace else."
But Carl Weisbrod, the president of the Alliance for Downtown New York -- a business-improvement district that filed many of the complaints that led to the restrictions in lower Manhattan -- said that in addition to congestion, another element is at play in the debate: competition. "There is the ongoing issue of complaints from retail establishments that pay rent and property taxes and whose owners look outside to see vendors who don't," he said. "And they are in direct competition right outside their own stores."
And if the travails of Mr. Markopoulos have resonance, so too do the experiences of Mr. Tsolomytis. Every morning, he walks up John Street to see carts everywhere, poised to sell coffee, bagels and doughnuts at discount prices. By 11 A.M., he said, those carts are sold out -- and his unsold doughnuts are turning stale near the cash register.
Mr. Tsolomytis, 54, who says he has not taken a vacation in a decade, said that he used to sell 15 dozen bagels a day; now he sells about 4 dozen. The recollection brings to his face an expression that does not match the message on his plastic coffee cups: "We are happy to serve you."
The same tension could be found in midtown yesterday between retail owners and food vendors, all vying in the same market of feeding people cheaply. John Poulos, the owner of the Deli-Burger Restaurant, on West 45th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, called the impending restrictions "a miracle," then sounded a familiar refrain.
"This place costs me $6,000 a month in rent, I have six employees, and utility bills to pay," he said. "And those guys pay nothing. I have to compete with these guys selling coffee and a bagel for $1. I sell it for $1 and lose 20 cents every time. But what am I going to do? I can't sell it for more than them or nobody will come here.
"I don't mind seeing one guy here, and one guy there, as long as they are spread out," he added. "But on this street, they are everywhere. I hope the restrictions are going to go through and I hope that Giuliani will stick with them. It's a blessing."
But the restrictions are a curse for Mohammed Kueder, a hot-dog vendor who has stationed himself at the northwest corner of West 56th Street and Avenue of the Americas for the last four years. Like so many vendors, he pays no rent, but incurs other expenses that eat into his small profit margin. He said he saw no recourse but to protest.
"I have to take care of my family," he said. "Maybe Giuliani will listen to us if enough people show up. I don't think the protest will work -- the Mayor has probably made up his mind -- but I hope it does."
Judging by Mr. Giuliani's comments yesterday, it is doubtful that the protest will affect his opinion on the matter. "The fact is that there are some parts of the city that are too overcrowded," he said. "There have been some food vendors that have engaged in unsanitary conditions -- more than a few. So we need some changes."
Such comments by the Mayor -- particularly the references to "unsanitary conditions" -- infuriate Mr. Cicio, who is organizing today's protest. He said that Mr. Giuliani was trying to sway public opinion by portraying the vendors as "dirty, smelly terrorists running nontaxpaying businesses," when "in fact we're the heaviest-regulated business in the city."
He said that the vendors hoped the protest would prompt the City Council to enact legislation to create more balance in establishing the locations where the vendors can operate. Last night, two Council members, Stephen DiBrienza and Anthony D. Weiner, said they would present a bill to disband the Sidewalk Vendor Review Panel, which is controlled by the Mayor and developed the new restrictions.
Meanwhile, the vendors have only the sympathies of some customers to ease their concerns. "Giuliani does great things, but sometimes I think he gets carried away," said Miguel Diaz, stopping for a knish at a stand on Church and Vesey Streets that will be required to move. "These stands have been a part of New York since Day One."
Late yesterday afternoon, Mr. Markopoulos tucked away the wooden platform he stands on to reduce back strain. He closed the metal doors of his cart, and then rolled his livelihood -- which has a photograph of his 2-year-old granddaughter wedged between a soda-can display -- through the winding downtown streets to Rich Street, where he and a few other vendors keep their carts in a warehouse overnight.
He said he wouldn't be needing the cart until Thursday.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Race to Buy the Browns Has a New York Flavor

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Howard Milstein, the real estate developer, and Chuck Dolan, the cable television magnate, have three things in common: lots of money, businesses that are located in the New York metropolitan area and a desire to own the soon-to-be-revived Cleveland Browns.
The race to buy the expansion Browns is accelerating, with Milstein's and Dolan's groups among six to have applied to the National Football League. No price has been set -- estimates range from $400 million to the moon -- but it will most likely be the costliest sports franchise ever for several reasons: a lucrative lease at a new stadium where the team will start play in 1999; immediate access to $70 million a year from new TV deals, and a rabid fan base that seems certain to support the new Browns as it did the old ones before Art Modell shipped them to Baltimore in 1996. 
 "We're not here because this is a fundamentally great investment," Dolan, the chairman of Woodbury, N.Y.-based Cablevision Systems, said yesterday from Cleveland, his hometown. "We love Cleveland and we want to own the Browns."
Milstein, who is a co-owner of the New York Islanders, said Monday from Cleveland: "This will be a very good business. We expect to realize significant value from the team as a business. You have to look at the whole issues of winning football and restoring tradition."
The Browns' move to Baltimore, where they were renamed the Ravens, was the most wrenching team shift since the Dodgers moved to Los Angeles. As part of the N.F.L.'s approval of the move, the Browns' name, colors and logos remained in trust for the new franchise.
"We think of the Browns as the team for the next century," Milstein said. "We're going to get it."
Like the other potential applicants, the Dolan and Milstein groups paid $150,000 to enter the process, and are being investigated by the N.F.L. for their financial worthiness before they receive economic data upon which to base their bids. An owner is expected to be chosen in September.
Milstein was persuaded to join the bidding five weeks ago by Calvin Hill, the former Browns and Dallas Cowboy running back, and Paul Warfield, the Hall of Fame receiver for the Browns and Miami Dolphins. Robert Lewis, a lawyer for Milstein, is also part of the group.
"If the job is to re-establish a winning reputation -- one that goes back in Cleveland to the 1940's -- we can do it," said Hill, a consultant to the Cowboys. "We know both sides of the ball. We had wonderful careers as players, but since I retired, I've been a consultant and administrator." Warfield is in private business.
Dolan returned to his hometown yesterday, with his brother Lawrence, a lawyer in suburban Cleveland, to announce that the entertainer Bill Cosby had taken a 5 percent stake in their ownership group.
Cosby was not an investor in the Dolans' group when they declared their interest several weeks ago. Cosby said he was not added as a token, to be a prominent symbol for a league without black ownership.
"I thought about it," Cosby added, but he said that the potential size of his investment, $25 million if the team costs $500 million, placed him in a different category.
Lawrence Dolan said, "I don't see the appropriateness of tokenism when we're discussing Bill Cosby."
Hill said he did not want to speculate about whether the Dolans added Cosby because they felt their group needed a prominent African-American. But, he said: "The fact that Paul and I are black and Howard and Robert are white is wonderful. We're not just people who fit categories. It was about getting the best team."
For Chuck Dolan, the Browns would be a personal investment, separate from Cablevision's acquisition of Madison Square Garden, which owns the Knicks and the Rangers. He would provide the bulk of the money to buy the team.
"I can assure anyone who is seeking wealth to get a good education and have a brother like I have," Lawrence Dolan said.
The Dolans and the Milstein group appear sanguine that the league will not price the team into the stratosphere; Malcolm Glazer, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' owner, reportedly said the price should be $1.5 billion. In the N.F.L.'s last expansion, Carolina and Jacksonville paid $140 million entry fees.
"We're prepared to bid the value," Lawrence Dolan said. "But it's important the winning bid not necessarily be the biggest bid."
Milstein echoed the sentiment. "If all they want is maximum dollars," he said, "maybe it's not a good business deal."

HEADLINE: Ending Suit, Merrill Lynch to Pay California County $400 Million

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK with LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 2

 BODY:
Merrill Lynch & Company agreed today to pay $400 million to Orange County, Calif., to settle claims that the leading Wall Street brokerage firm helped push the affluent county into bankruptcy four years ago with reckless investment advice.
The settlement will largely close the book on the biggest municipal bankruptcy in the nation's history, a financial debacle that was unthinkable at the time and resulted in sharply reduced services ranging from public schools to health clinics. 
 The bankruptcy also shook the foundations of municipal finance across the country and illuminated how treasurers of local governments can deploy enormous sums of taxpayer dollars in exotic investments that can go awry.
The settlement by Merrill is one of the largest in any securities-related litigation and is by far the largest stemming from the 1994 bankruptcy, which set off a storm of lawsuits as the county sought to recover some of the more than $1.6 billion in losses from high-risk investments.
Merrill, which has consistently maintained it did nothing wrong, said it had decided to settle because the costs and distraction of the litigation did not justify the battle. Even though Orange County had sought $2 billion, the magnitude of the settlement was still considered huge and goes a long way to restoring much of what Orange County lost.
The county still has lawsuits pending against 17 Wall Street securities houses and a variety of other companies. But Merrill was clearly the main target because it was much more heavily involved than other firms in selling risky securities to the county-run investment pool.
Now that Merrill has settled, lawyers predicted that others would follow.
"We're very pleased with the result," said Bruce Bennett, a Los Angeles lawyer who has represented Orange County. "We think it represents a very substantial recovery for Orange County."
The settlement with Merrill brings the county's total recovery from legal settlements to more than $621 million. Analysts and lawyers said that based on today's settlement with Merrill, they expect the county could end up recovering $800 million to $1 billion over all.
Even without fully recovering all the lost money, Orange County's financial condition has improved sharply, particularly in the last few years. The fifth-largest United States county, just south of Los Angeles, Orange County has a thriving technology industry, tourist attractions like Disneyland and an unemployment rate below 3 percent. The recovery in California's economy in the last few years has helped the county restore most of the social services that were cut immediately after the bankruptcy. Municipal officials said the money recovered would probably go mainly toward restoring capital spending that had been planned, then suspended.
"This is more part of Orange County's history than its future," said James Doti, president of Chapman University, which is in the county. "The economy of Orange County is doing great, but this cloud of bankruptcy has been hanging over our head. This is the last page of an ugly story."
The losses were suffered by 200 school districts, municipalities and other public agencies that invested in the pool run by Robert L. Citron, Orange County's treasurer at the time. He was released in October after serving two-thirds of a one-year jail term for misappropriation of funds. His deputy, Matthew Raabe, was sentenced to three years in prison.
Because the money recovered from litigation goes first to schools and then the other public agencies and municipalities, school districts have already recovered 98 percent of their losses, said Paul Brady, city manager of Irvine and chairman of the Orange County Investment Pool Committee. Municipalities and other agencies will be able to recover more than 90 percent of their losses after getting the proceeds from the settlement with Merrill. The county itself, however, is only now starting to share in the recovery.
Merrill, the largest firm on Wall Street, has said the decisions on the investments that went sour were made by Mr. Citron and that he was fully aware of the risks.
"We are confident that we acted properly and professionally in our relationship with Orange County," Merrill said in a statement today. "However, after weighing the substantial costs and distraction of continuing to litigate, we determined that it would be in the best interests of Merrill Lynch and all our constituents to definitively bring this matter to a close and end the uncertainty inherent in any judicial proceeding."
Merrill said it had already set aside money for the settlement, which will not affect its earnings for the second quarter.
In addition to paying $400 million to Orange County, Merrill returned $20 million in collateral it had kept after the bankruptcy. Merrill also agreed today to pay $17.1 million to the Irvine Ranch Water District, which had sued Merrill over the bankruptcy. Last year, Merrill paid $30 million in a settlement with the county district attorney to assure that the county would not bring criminal charges against it. It also agreed last year to pay $1.9 million to settle a class-action suit brought by holders of Orange County bonds.
But Merrill is still not completely free of the legal consequences of Orange County's bankruptcy. The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether the firm violated securities laws in another role it performed for Orange County -- underwriting bond offerings. The S.E.C. is looking at whether Merrill adequately informed bond buyers of the risks involved, the company has said. The S.E.C. declined to comment today, but some lawyers involved in the bankruptcy predict that Merrill and the commission might also move toward settling.
The settlement with Merrill followed three weeks of mediation led by Judge John Davies of the Federal District Court in Los Angeles, who was not presiding over the case. The county's civil suit against Merrill had been scheduled to go to trial Sept. 15 in the Federal District Court in Santa Ana. Under the rules in the district, all cases heading to trial must go through mediation first.
The county argued that Mr. Citron had no authority to engage in some types of transactions he undertook with Merrill's help. The county also argued that some of the securities Merrill sold were inappropriately volatile for a government portfolio and that Merrill had prepared false and misleading sales materials. .
Some analysts said Merrill had an incentive to settle because, in contrast to some suits seeking huge damages, in this case the losses suffered by the investment pool were known. Had Merrill gone to court and lost, the damages could have been higher.
Zane Mann, publisher of the California Municipal Bond Advisor, a newsletter, said Merrill also had business reasons to settle. "Merrill hasn't been able to do business in Southern California since this thing broke," he said, alluding to Merrill's municipal bond business. "This is a calculation of what it's worth to get back into the bond market in Southern California."
Mr. Mann and some other analysts said the settlement with Merrill might have been a bit less than what the county wanted. But the county, too, did not want to do what Mr. Citron was accused of doing -- gamble with the public money by turning down a sure $400 million in hopes of getting more in a trial.
County officials said the county's net losses were actually several hundred million dollars less than the reported $1.6 billion because the risky investments had earned higher returns in some years before the bankruptcy. Moreover, they said, it is unreasonable to expect the county to completely recover its losses.
"The county was not blameless in these losses," Thomas W. Hayes, the former California State Treasurer who is in charge of the county's litigation effort, said in an interview.
Many of the suits against other brokerage firms are not active. One that is in the early evidence-gathering stage is against Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. So, lawyers speculated it might be next to go to trial. But Mr. Bennett, the lawyer for the county, would not identify the next target.
Mr. Citron, Orange County treasurer for 24 years, had sought to raise returns on the county's investments because a taxpayer revolt was putting a lid on property taxes. He invested in complex securities known as derivatives, which can rise or fall in value much faster than ordinary bonds do. He bet on lower interest rates, but rates kept rising, producing huge losses.
Merrill sold Mr. Citron many of those securities. The county also considered Merrill a financial adviser, though Merrill insists it was only a broker. Merrill also underwrote 4 of the county's 11 bond offerings over the period involved.
Despite the bankruptcy, the county never defaulted on its bonds, so the losses were confined to investors in the county pool, said Mr. Mann of the California Municipal Bond Advisor.
The county emerged from bankruptcy in 1996 and has an investment-grade credit rating from Moody's, though not from Standard & Poor's, which it is suing in connection with the bankruptcy.
Some say the brokerage firms are paying far higher penalties than the county ever did.
"There's plenty of blame on this to go around," said Joe Mysak, editor of Grant's Municipal Bond Observer. "Some might assign more blame to the county than Merrill, but this is not a perfectly moral universe."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert L. Citron, the official involved in losses of Orange County funds, at his sentencing in 1996. (Associated Press)(pg. D4)
 
Chart: "Paying a Price for the Failure"
The bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., in late 1994 led to a series of criminal and civil lawsuits as the county and its bondholders sought to recover losses. Here is the status of some of the major lawsuits and criminal inquiries.
 
CIVIL SETTLEMENTS
 
LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & McRae -- $45 million
Announced in April. The county sued the law firm over its role as a bond adviser.
