HEADLINE: Alabama Governor Forced Into Runoff in 3d-Term Bid

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 2

 BODY:
Gov. Fob James Jr. of Alabama, a party-switching Republican whose fervid support for school prayer has made him a national icon for religious conservatives, was forced into a runoff today in the primary for governor.
Although he finished first in a five-candidate field, Mr. James, 63, failed to win a majority and will face Winton Blount 3d, a Montgomery businessman and longtime Republican loyalist, in the runoff on June 30. 
 Mr. James, who is running for re-election to his third term (he served the first as a Democrat from 1979 to 1983), appeared close to avoiding a runoff with a late surge in opinion polls as he moved steadily toward the 50 percent threshold in the final week of campaigning. But the same dissatisfaction that lured four Republican opponents to challenge the incumbent apparently unsettled just enough voters to deny Mr. James a victory in the first round.
Mr. James and Mr. Blount now face the arduous task of turning out their voters for a midsummer runoff and competing for the support of the three other Republican contenders.
With 91 percent of the precincts reporting, Mr. James had 163,711 votes, or 48 percent of the vote, while Mr. Blount finished second with 139,941 votes, or 41 percent. Former Gov. Guy Hunt, who decided to run after being pardoned of the state ethics conviction that forced his resignation in 1993, finished third with 8 percent of the vote. Two other candidates, Lewis Leslie McAllister Jr., a Tuscaloosa businessman, and Phillip W. Williams, a former state finance director, shared the rest of the vote.
In the Democratic primary, Lieut. Gov. Don Siegelman easily defeated his top rival, Lenora Pate, a Birmingham lawyer. Mr. Siegelman enters the general election with more than $3.5 million in his campaign treasury, a team of experienced Democratic strategists and an eye-catching policy proposal borrowed from the popular Democratic Governor of a neighboring state, Zell Miller of Georgia.
Mr. Siegelman has promised to push for a state lottery to finance college scholarships, pre-kindergarten programs and school construction. That plan is sure to strike a chord with Alabamians desperate to improve the state's educational system. But, as was the case in Georgia, it has already stirred opposition from religious conservatives who view the lottery as a first step toward the legalization of other forms of gambling. The Republicans also plan to portray Mr. Siegelman as an unreconstructed liberal and a captive of the state's trial lawyers' lobby.
In neighboring Mississippi, meanwhile, voters in the Democratic and Republican primaries selected Congressional candidates who will vie in the general election in November. The most closely watched race came in the Fourth District in southwestern Mississippi, where a large field of candidates from both parties competed to succeed Representative Mike Parker, a Republican who is retiring after five terms.
On the Republican side, Delbert Hosemann, a Jackson lawyer, and Phil Davis, a banker from Magee, finished first and second respectively in a nine-candidate field, forcing a runoff on June 23. In the Democratic primary, Ronnie Shows, a regional commissioner for the State Transportation Department, won a majority against two opponents.
The Alabama governor's race has been depicted by Mr. James's strategists and by national leaders of the Christian conservative movement as an important electoral test for the religious right.
During the last 16 months, Mr. James has taken a number of provocative stands aimed at returning religious expression to public schools and courtrooms, a mission with substantial grass-roots support in this deeply devout, conservative and populist state. In each instance, Mr. James has assailed the Federal courts as the mortal foe of God-fearing Alabamians, a tactic used by his predecessor, George C. Wallace, when this state's deep-seated resentment of Federal intrusion was stoked more by race than by religion.
The Governor has threatened to call out the National Guard to defend the right of a state judge in Gadsden, Ala., to display the Ten Commandments on his courtroom wall. He also has waged an aggressive campaign to defend a 1993 state law that permitted voluntary, student-led prayer in the schools. A Federal judge rejected the law as unconstitutional, leading Mr. James to assert that the Bill of Rights does not apply to the states and that state officials need not obey Supreme Court rulings when they believe that the Court has overstepped its authority.
Those positions, and the perception that Mr. James has placed more emphasis on school prayer than on economic development and education, quickly alienated some of the state's business leaders, who rallied around the candidacy of Mr. Blount, a longtime Republican activist who owns car dealerships and other companies. Mr. Blount, whose father was Postmaster General in the Nixon Administration, finished third in the 1994 gubernatorial primary.
In recent weeks, Mr. Blount has attacked Mr. James for raising taxes during his first term as Governor, and for profiting from a family-owned landfill that does business with the state. All of the state's major newspapers endorsed Mr. Blount, and his strategists hoped that Mr. Hunt, a Primitive Baptist preacher, would siphon Christian conservative votes from Mr. James.
But Mr. Blount's momentum seemed to stall in the final week of the campaign, as Alabamians focused on the race and moved toward Mr. James, whose son, Forrest H. James 3d, was quoted in The Birmingham News this week as describing his father as "a God-fearing redneck."
In the last week of the race, Mr. James promoted his pledge not to raise taxes, a promise that Mr. Blount rejected as irresponsible. And Mr. James, who counts Ralph Reed, the former director of the Christian Coalition, as a consultant, won endorsements from many of the country's Christian conservative leaders, including Pat Robertson, Jerry Falwell, Phyllis Schlafly, James Dobson and Donald E. Wildmon.
One poll published on Sunday found that 56 percent of those who believe the Bible is literally true said they would vote for Mr. James.

HEADLINE: C.I.A. Study Details Failures; Scouring of System Is Urged

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
United States intelligence "needs to be scrubbed" from the top down, from its spies to its analysts to its chief bureaucrats, according to the author of a classified report on the intelligence agencies' inability to foresee India's May 11 nuclear tests.
The debacle disclosed chronic failures of imagination and personnel, flaws in information-gathering and analysis, and faulty leadership and training, the report's author, retired Adm. David E. Jeremiah, a former Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today. 
 He said his investigation, requested by the Director of Central Intelligence, George J. Tenet, had shown structural weaknesses in the Central Intelligence Agency and its sister services that go far beyond the question of India.
Among his conclusions were these:
*The C.I.A. had little or no "human intelligence," meaning spies, in India.
*The agency's ability to use people rather than machines to gather information is weak worldwide.
*The nation's spy satellites typically produce far too much information for overworked and undertrained intelligence analysts to handle.
*In India, satellites and analysts alike failed to focus on the nuclear test site, despite clear signs that a nuclear test was coming. Senior intelligence officials discounted those clues and did not order their subordinates to examine them.
Senior American policy makers and intelligence officials had an "underlying mind-set" that India would not test its nuclear weapons, Admiral Jeremiah told a group of reporters at the C.I.A.'s headquarters. That fixed idea was unaffected by the fact that India's newly elected Hindu nationalist leaders openly and repeatedly vowed to deploy the bomb. The United States never understood that India was driven by "national pride and pysche" to become a nuclear state, the admiral said. As a result, he added, its intelligence eyes and ears were blind and deaf to the test, which set off nuclear tensions and an arms race between India and its regional rival, Pakistan.
Admiral Jeremiah, a former commander of all American forces in the Pacific, described a kind of intellectual laziness at the intelligence services, on which the United States spends $27 billion a year.
"You fall into a pattern" and "you start to expect things to happen," he said. "You need to have a contrarian view."
The C.I.A.'s managers were passive, he said, instead of taking command and saying: " 'Who's in charge? Take charge. Make things happen.' "
The agency has talented people capable of great work, he said, and it "has had a startling number of successes" over the years. But it needs many more analysts with better training and sharper skills, he said. It should bring in outside experts to analyze major events. It must be "much more aggressive in thinking through how the other guy thought" -- breaking out of American political and cultural patterns to grasp the ways in which the rest of the world thinks.
Much of the criticism in Admiral Jeremiah's report has been voiced before. The House Intelligence Committee, for instance, reported last year that the C.I.A. and its sister services lack "the analytic depth, breadth and expertise to monitor political, military and economic developments worldwide." But rarely has a report commissioned by the C.I.A. drawn such swift and sweeping conclusions.
Other longtime intelligence officers concurred with Admiral Jeremiah's judgments.
Gordon Oehler, who retired last year as director of the C.I.A.'s Nonproliferation Center, said the group of intelligence analysts responsible for interpreting spy satellite photos was a far less skilled group than it was at the end of the cold war.
Mr. Oehler said the "contrarian views" that Admiral Jeremiah called for were sometimes disregarded by senior officials, which discourages fresh thinking. Clinton Administration officials dislike inconvenient facts about nuclear weapons, he said, and sometimes disregard information that does not fit "a preconceived view of what the world ought to look like."
Admiral Jeremiah, whose full report is not expected to be made public, said he would recommend that Mr. Tenet, the Director of Central Intelligence, make changes to improve the ways the C.I.A. and other intelligence agencies gather and analyze information, manage their employees and train new people.
Mr. Tenet, who said he discussed Mr. Jeremiah's report with President Clinton today, immediately accepted those recommendations.
Mr. Tenet said that in a perfect world, the C.I.A. would never again miss an event that changes the course of history.
"I hope I could say that it'll never again occur," he said. "But given the problems we face in the world, and given the kind of resources and commitments we have around the world, U.S. intelligence is stretched, and we have to do the best we can."

HEADLINE: CALIFORNIA PASSES MEASURE TO LIMIT BILINGUAL SCHOOLS

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 2

 BODY:
Californians today approved a ballot measure that would curtail three decades of bilingual instruction in the public schools here, paving the way for similar assaults on such programs around the nation, according to early election returns.
Strong majorities across major ethnic and racial lines expressed support in pre-election public opinion polls for the measure to effectively end bilingual education, though most Hispanic elected officials and all the major candidates for governor in both parties opposed it. 
 The measure , sponsored by Ron K. Unz, a multimillionaire software entrepreneur from Silicon Valley, tapped into widespread dissatisfaction among parents, politicians and educators. They argued that existing bilingual education programs, a legacy of the civil rights movement of the 1960's in which students are taught basic subjects in their native language while they also learn English, were not working well to prepare a huge new generation of immigrant students for the job market.
In another fiercely contested race, Lieut. Gov. Gray Davis, a 23-year veteran of state politics, rode a wave of support from traditional liberal constituencies to soundly defeat his richer rivals for the Democratic nomination for governor, Representative Jane Harman and Alfred A. Checchi, a multimillionaire businessman who spent about $40 million on his campaign, the individual record for any non-Presidential candidate in American history.
Mr. Davis declared victory just after 10 P.M. "My friends, this is truly an experience money can't buy," he told his supporters. Ms. Harman conceded defeat while Mr. Checchi was running a distant third. "Winning is more fun, but losing with honor ain't bad," Ms. Harman said.
Mr. Davis will now take on the Republican State Attorney General, Dan Lungren, who faced token opposition today in the state's new blanket primary in which the names of all candidates appeared on the same ballot regardless of party. They will compete for the right to succeed Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican who is barred from seeking a third term, in what promises to be a classic liberal-conservative contest over contrasting views of the Golden State.
At stake is a major beachhead of Presidential politics in 2000 and control of Congressional redistricting in the nation's most populous state for 2002.
Other races, including a fight for the Republican nomination for United States Senate between State Treasurer Matt Fong and Darrell Issa, another wealthy businessman, remained too close to call, as did a fight over a ballot measure that would require unions to obtain written consent from members before using their dues for political purposes.
Over all, it was the most expensive primary election campaign in the nation's history, with about $100 million spent on races for governor, United States senator and other statewide offices and on a handful of ballot propositions pro and con, including the bilingual initiative and the measure limiting the use of union dues.
With California on a sharp rebound from years of economic recession and natural disasters, voter interest was generally low in a state famous for political apathy, and turnout was predicted to reach no more than 40 percent of the state's 14.6 million registered voters. As usual here, most of the campaign played out in millions of dollars of television advertising, this year featuring charge and counter-charge by candidates in contested gubernatorial and Senate races.
The most contentious issue on the ballot was Mr. Unz's initiative, which will no doubt be subject to court challenges by opponents. It would essentially limit help for non-native speakers to a year of intensive English instruction, though parents could request a waiver if they believed their children needed special help. Its supporters contend it allows for flexibility and note that its only requirement is that instruction in general subjects be primarily in English.
But the measure's opponents, which included the California Teachers Association, the state Parent Teacher Association and President Clinton, contended that the measure would impose a rigid, one-size-fits-all solution on the state's diverse school districts, many of which have already chosen on their own to end or greatly modify bilingual programs.
The race for governor reflected intense volatility in voter sentiment, with each of the three Democratic candidates by turns taking first -- and last --- place in pre-election public opinion polls. But in the closing weeks of the race, Mr. Davis, 55, opened a clear lead over his rivals, Ms. Harman, 52, a three-term Representative from the beachfront communities on the south edge of Los Angeles, and Mr. Checchi, 49, the former co-chairman of Northwest Airlines, who was making his first run for elective office.
For months last year, most of the California Democratic establishment assumed that the the state's most popular politician, Senator Dianne Feinstein, would come home to run for governor and would be the overwhelming favorite to win the nomination. But despite encouragement from the White House to run, Ms. Feinstein announced in January that she would not, in part, she said, because she loathed the prospect of millions of dollars in attack ads from Mr. Checchi.
Ms. Harman entered the race on short notice, with her own private wealth and most of Ms. Feinstein's political team behind her, and promptly vaulted to the lead in the polls. But then Mr. Checchi began a barrage of televised attacks on her record and character that not only caused Ms. Harman to plunge in the polls but backfired on him as well. By May, half of all voters in the state viewed Mr. Checchi unfavorably, four times the level of February, according to a statewide poll by the Field Institute of San Francisco, and he never recovered.
Mr. Davis, meantime, who could not afford to begin television advertising until well after his richer rivals, benefited from their feud, appearing as a relatively unscarred, fresh face on the scene the moment he began airing commercials touting himself as the embodiment of "experience money can't buy." In fact, Mr. Davis is one of the longest-serving politicians in the state, with a career stretching back 23 years, to his days as chief of staff to Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.
On the Republican side, Mr. Lungren, 51, spent 10 years in Congress representing his native Long Beach. He is a classic California conservative in the Ronald Reagan mold, who as State Attorney General since 1990 has developed a reputation for toughness on crime. But he has also been faulted for ineffective handling of the state's ban on assault weapons and for being reluctant to join other states in litigation against tobacco companies. In addition, his strong anti-abortion stance has been seen by many political analysts as a potential vulnerability in a state whose Governor for the last eight years, Mr. Wilson, who is a Republican, supports abortion rights.
Even as Mr. Lungren coasted to the nomination, Mr. Fong, 44, and Mr. Issa, a multimillionaire car alarm entrepreneur, battled in an intense primary for the right to take on Ms. Boxer, 57, in November. Ms. Boxer, who was first elected to the Senate in 1992 after 10 years in the House of Representatives, had once been viewed as highly vulnerable this year, but recent polls have shown her leading both of her potential Republican rivals.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Bill Would Replace State Commerce Dept.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The State Department of Commerce and Economic Development would be replaced by a commission including business leaders under a bill introduced on Monday.
Under the bill, based on a proposal by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, policy for the proposed Commerce and Economic Growth Commission would be set by an 11-member board that would include the Governor, 5 cabinet members and 5 business leaders. Gualberto Medina, the State Commerce Commissioner, would be the commission's chief executive officer, said a co-sponsor, Assemblyman Kenneth C. LeFevre, a Republican of Egg Harbor Township. All 120 of the department's employees would be dismissed, and some would be rehired, but without civil service protection, Mr. LeFevre said. 
 Jeff Scott, a spokesman for the Communications Workers of America Local 1034, which represents the employees, said abolishing civil service requirements could reduce the commission to a patronage mill.

HEADLINE: Commencements;
Brooklyn College

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
If public colleges continue to lose the support of voters and legislators at the present rate, they could become like "dead spacecraft, with no new missions to fly," Vernon E. Lattin, the president of Brooklyn College, told 3,000 graduates seated in the leafy quadrangle of the Flatbush campus.
Despite the booming economy, he said, the 50 states "are now spending $23.1 billion less for higher education than they were 20 years ago." New York State, he added, ranks 49th in the financing of higher education for every $1,000 of personal income.
The danger, he said, is that public institutions will become "smaller, more-expensive, semiprivate colleges and universities for those who can afford the higher cost."
Mr. Lattin concluded by urging the graduates to "do what you can to make sure that others may have the opportunity that you have enjoyed." 
 An honorary doctorate of humane letters was also awarded yesterday to Harry Belafonte, who brought the audience to its feet with a resounding rendition of "Daaay-O! Daylight come and you graduate!" It was an adaptation of the Banana Boat Song that became his signature calypso piece in the 1950's. WILLIAM H. HONAN

HEADLINE: Why Must Farms Use Migrant Labor?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your May 31 front-page article describes the unsafe housing conditions faced by migrant farm workers in the United States. As you report, New York State is no different from the rest of the country. However, unlike any other classification of workers, farm workers in New York are denied many other rights: collective bargaining, protection from overexposure to toxic chemicals, minimum-wage parity, agreements outlining the terms and conditions of employment, and one day of rest each week. On smaller farms, workers are also denied the right to bathrooms in the field and unemployment insurance coverage. 
 To make matters worse, among Gov. George E. Pataki's recent budget vetoes was the major source of financing for legal services to the poor, including farm workers. All workers deserve full protection of the laws.
 
MARTIN A. LUSTER
Albany, June 1, 1998
 
Member of Assembly, 125th Dist.

HEADLINE: India's Strategic Misstep

BYLINE: By Stephen P. Cohen; Stephen P. Cohen, a policy adviser at the State Department from 1985 to 1987, will be joining the Brookings Institution this fall.

DATELINE: CHAMPAIGN, Ill.

 BODY:
In the three weeks since India conducted its nuclear tests, the tough talk of Indian leaders seems to have faded to a whisper. They are now proposing that their country and Pakistan sign a treaty agreeing not to be the first to use such weapons against each other. They have denied Pakistan's claim that India will conduct yet another nuclear test, and they have reiterated the country's longstanding call for global disarmament.
No one should be surprised by this abrupt about-face. As it turns out, the nuclear tests may have significantly hurt India's national security. 
 First, India may have reopened its competition with China, this time with a nuclear tinge. Indeed, the Indian opposition has charged that Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee has jeopardized years of painstaking negotiations with China that in recent years had begun to show dividends in trade and troop pullbacks along their disputed border in northeast India.
Now, this detente is at risk. China is likely to continue its flow of technical advice, military equipment and economic aid to Pakistan. And China may once again support Pakistan's position on the disputed state of Jammu and Kashmir. China could also pressure New Delhi rather easily, by redeploying troops along India's northeastern border. This would force India to send soldiers back to the Himalayas, thinning its forces in Kashmir and elsewhere.
Moreover, India has not developed the medium-range missiles that could reach Chinese cities, whereas it is vulnerable to Chinese nuclear attack.
As for Pakistan, its military has developed various nuclear responses -- from tactical weapons to an all-out attack on New Delhi and Bombay -- to counter any military movement by India across the border. Pakistani officials have also spoken of deploying the Ghauri missile, possibly with nuclear warheads. If that happens, the lives of Indians in New Delhi, Bombay and a half dozen other cities will depend on the Government in Islamabad -- a Government in which it is unclear who commands and controls the deployment of nuclear weapons.
India has also needlessly angered the Clinton Administration, contributing to President Clinton's greatest foreign policy disaster. Not only was his Administration caught off guard, but his hopes for Senate ratification of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty are dimmer than ever.
Nor is Congress likely to rescue India by lifting the economic and military sanctions that have now been imposed. Mr. Vajpayee had thought that American businesses dependent on the Indian market would rush to defend their interests. But India is now blamed for triggering a new round of proliferation, and Congress is unlikely to be sympathetic to any easing of the sanctions.
India's bombs were supposed to elevate it to the status of a great power. Instead, India finds itself with a worsening relationship with Pakistan, China and the United States. After the initial euphoria, it is clear that India must face reality and address the new strategic risks that it has created.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Alexander Gelman)

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
SMART, LOUIS EDWIN

 BODY:
SMART-Louis Edwin, of counsel and a former partner at the law firm Hughes Hubbard & Reed LLP, died on Monday, June 1, at St. Luke's Hospital in New York City. He was 74. Mr. Smart was born in Columbus, OH on November 17, 1923, and served as a lieutenant in the U.S. Naval Reserve from 1943 to 1946. He graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University in 1947. In 1949, he received his J.D. magna cum laude from Harvard Law School, where he was an editor of the Law Review, and became associated with Hughes Hubbard & Reed (then Hughes, Hubbard & Ewing) the same year. He joined the firm's partnership in 1957. During his tenure with Hughes Hubbard, Mr. Smart handled major corporate transactions for Bendix Corporation. He left the firm to assume the position of President of Bendix International in 1964. In 1967, he moved to Trans World Airlines, Inc. (TWA), and over the next decade he held the positions of senior vice president of corporate affairs, vice chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Smart served as chairman of the board at TWA from 1979 to 1985, and also served as chairman and CEO of Transworld Corp. from 1978 to 1987. He returned to Hughes Hubbard as of counsel in 1989. Mr. Smart has served as chairman of Hilton International Company (1978-86), as a member of the Board of Directors of the New York Stock Exchange (1982-88), and on the board of numerous major corporations, including Continental Corp., Sonat Inc. and the corporation formerly known as Flagstar Companies, Inc. In addition to his wife, Jeanie M. Smart, whom he married in 1964, Mr. Smart is survived by his sister, Esther Monteith, and her family; his three children, Cynthia S. Smart of San Antonio, Texas; Douglas E. Smart of Madison, CT; Dana G. Smart of Long Beach, CA; and five grandchildren. In lieu of service, a private reception for family, friends and colleagues has been scheduled for Monday, June 15, from 1PM to 3PM at the Marco Polo Club at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York City. Mr. Smart's family requests that expressions of sympathy be made in the form of memorial contributions to the L. Edwin Smart Lecture Series Fund at Ohio State University. Contributions should be directed to Chairperson, Department of Economics, Ohio State University, 410 Arps Hall, 1945 North High Street, Columbus, OH 43210.

HEADLINE: A Small Card Maker Finds Itself Atop the Web

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY 

 BODY:
THE appearance of the site www.bluemountain.com at the top of various lists of popular sites has left Web watchers scratching their heads. Blue Mountain Arts is a small greeting card company based in Boulder, Colo., and known for its sincere if slightly treacly sentiment. But on the net, the Blue Mountain site is beating out big names like Disney Online, the bookseller Amazon.com and the Hotmail free E-mail service.
The site, which attracted more than 5,085,000 individual visitors in April, offers electronic personalized greeting cards commemorating everything from first holy communion to the death of a pet. For those occasions when you care enough to click the Send button, you can send messages that can include a picture and room for a personal sentiment, some animation and music. 
 "It just goes to show how different the Web is from anything else before it, in terms of business," said Stacie Leone, marketing and communications manager at Media Metrix, a New York company that measures Web audiences and recently found Blue Mountain to be the most popular shopping Web site. "A site like this that doesn't advertise and doesn't make any money out of its Web site can skyrocket to the top."
Media Metrix found the site ranked 13th among home computer users and 15th among people using their computers at work. Relevant Knowledge, an Atlanta company that tracks a panel of Web users, ranked it 17th most popular among all domain names in April.
To send greetings to friends who have E-mail accounts, senders pick designs and messages, or write their own, fill out address labels and send the completed greetings to another part of the company's Web page. Recipients automatically get E-mail announcements, including a Web site address and a message number. Go to the Web site, plug in your number, see the picture and message, and consider yourself duly greeted.
James McQuivey, an analyst of on-line retail strategies for Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., explained part of the site's success. "They have this little secret going for them," he said. "When you use one of their cards and send it to a friend, he or she has to log into the site to receive it," thereby doubling the number of visitors.
Blue Mountain, which also sells cards on paper, has been able to find a market for electronic cards for Waitress Day, World Environment Day, the Jewish holiday of Shavuot and Eid Norouz, the Persian holiday.
"In the physical greeting card industry, you don't have the market there, but on the Web, it's not like those cards are taking up retail real estate," said Jared Schutz, Blue Moutain's director of business development. "We can offer cards for holidays we wouldn't necessarily offer in a store."
Blue Mountain's competitors include Greet Street, which charges 50 cents per greeting (greetstreet. com); the card is sent directly to the recipient's e-mail address. Another site, 123 Greetings (123greetings. com), offers messages grouped into categories like Kisses, Cats, Pizzas, Virtual Money (missives with pictures of bills; you choose the denomination) and Cuddly Tuddly, a collection of alarmingly cute stuffed animals. The site is slow, requiring the sender to go through nine screens to send a message.
Hallmark (www.hallmark.com) charges $2.50 for on-line greetings featuring animation and sound. The site requires customers -- even those ordering the free, lower-tech virtual greetings -- to sign in with a mailing address and password. The form asks, "Would you like to receive information about Hallmark products, services and events?" Not surprisingly, the default answer, Yes, is already checked.
(This is not the first instance of Hallmark's losing out to Blue Mountain Arts, which in 1986 successfully sued Hallmark to keep it from producing a line of cards copied from Blue Montain's line.)
Another site, based in Hong Kong (www.icard.com.hk), allows senders to add their own photos and sound files to greetings. An alphabetical listing of electronic postcards, from Angel Winks Heavenly Postcards to the Zodiacal Zephyr Card Shop, is available at www.wp.com/annag/ ecards.htm.
And check out the Amstel site there (www.amstel.nl/cam2.htm), with sendable views from a live camera in Amsterdam. What better way to say: "Having a wonderful time. Wish you were here"?

HEADLINE: House Proud;
Gothic Romance on the Hudson

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

DATELINE: NEWBURGH, N.Y.

 BODY:
A RIVER ran through them.
Clouds still linger on the craggy green cliffs overlooking the Hudson River. And if you stand on the wide Gothic revival verandas of houses that began a 19th-century design revolution here and squint past the subdivisions, it is possible to feel the kinship that Andrew Jackson Downing, Calvert Vaux and Frederick Clarke Withers had with this place. But the story has largely slipped into history's mists. 
 "This was the most ugly house you can imagine -- really nasty," Julian Hogan, a 48-year-old psychologist, said of the hilltop house she later learned was built in 1857 by a young architect named Vaux, who would meet Frederick Law Olmsted, a sometime farmer, on Newburgh's fertile ground and go on to design Central Park with him. "But something about the light was amazing."
After buying it she removed an inch and a half of wire-lathed stucco -- and uncovered an extraordinary, forgotten legacy. "I kept thinking, If people only knew."
Soon they will know. On June 6 and 7, this scrappy river city, home to one of the state's largest and most significant historic districts, will be the host of "Taste Makers of an Era," a two-day symposium and house tour that will examine the lineage of four 19th-century apostles of taste -- Downing, Vaux, Withers and Olmsted -- and the city that nurtured them. Among the featured scholars at the event will be Francis R. Kowsky, whose new book "Country, Park and City: The Architecture and Life of Calvert Vaux" (Oxford University Press) has prompted a reappraisal of the more silent partner in Olmsted & Vaux (the one whose name rhymes with fox).
Downing, Vaux's mentor and the son of a Newburgh wheelwright and nurseryman, became the leading taste maker of his generation, mostly through his writings. He drowned in the Hudson when fire broke out on a steamboat ferrying him to visit clients. It was 1852. He was 36. Vaux, the "clever young architect" Downing had plucked from obscurity in England and eventually made his partner, grimly identified the body. The coffin was laid out in the library of Highland Garden, Downing's house in Newburgh. "A terrific storm burst over the river and crashed among the hills," an observer wrote, "and the wild sympathy of nature surrounded that blasted home."
Downing had forged a naturalistic link between house and garden, a revolutionary idea that -- perhaps forever in America -- threw the corset of classical formality to the winds. Frederick Withers, another young English architect discovered and hired by Downing, would become a leading church designer and architect of wondrous Gothic revival buildings like the Jefferson Market Courthouse in Greenwich Village. The last collaboration between Vaux and Olmsted would be a park in Newburgh in Downing's memory.
Downing's historical timing was perfect. He appeared at a moment before the Civil War when a generation of home builders, the new American middle class, was seeking to define American style. It was in need of an oracle, an "apostle of taste," in the words of David Schuyler, an architectural historian.
In popular books and in The Horticulturist, his journal of "rural art and rural taste," Downing set forth his ideas about picturesque houses and gardens, advocating the Gothic revival style. He loved the Gothic for its "artistical irregularity." The variety of its forms, proportions, color, light and shade, Vaux later wrote, appealed to the eye "and through the eye to the mind."
An architectural evangelist, Downing told America's new middle class what it yearned to hear: that taste could be learned. At Highland Garden and other houses in and around Newburgh -- some of which, designed in partnership with Vaux and Withers, are on the tour -- Downing put his ideas about landscape into practice. (The houses were designed by Vaux and Withers; Downing had no formal architectural training).
From his property on the Hudson's steep slopes, he established a design firm catering to Newburgh's middle class; Vaux and Withers would continue the business for three years after his death. The grounds were poetry, with shadowy pathways, fragrant beds of moss and thyme and rustic log and bark shelters, so one could "linger and quietly communicate with the genius of the place," in Francis Kowsky's words.
Not surprisingly, Newburgh -- listed as one of the most endangered historic districts by the National Trust for Historic Preservation -- has a subculture of homeowners who consider themselves keepers of the flame. They have inherited french doors, breezy verandas, side porches, bay windows and quirkily placed chimneys. Like Downing, they tend to be messianic. This may be the only city in America where homeowners can quote verbatim from dogeared editions of "Cottage Residences," Downing's 1852 classic.
Lillie and Dan Hodge live in a house above the river that Vaux designed for William E. Warren, treasurer of the Delaware, Lackawanna & Western Railroad and deputy comptroller of New York City. Conceived as a platform for viewing nature, the house is subtly planned, its public front tall and ornamental, with a simple, more horizontal back that has a view of the river.
Though Vaux "didn't invent a style of architecture," Mr. Kowsky notes, he had an eye for spatial arrangement, adapting each house to its location and allowing those who lived there to feel intimate with the landscape. That talent would be extravagantly expressed later in Central Park in spots like Bethesda Terrace, where the views were from naturally elevated areas "in a manner analogous to the way Vaux sited his houses," he writes.
The house has been in the Hodge family since 1953. Mrs. Hodge still has some of Warren's books, including a Bible with a big silver clasp. Not long ago, the Hodges hired Tom Pope, a house painter from Chatham, N.Y., to paint the place, which was originally coated in stucco. Vaux was drawn to "soft, quiet tones," but because the exterior had been sandblasted to reveal the brick, Mr. Pope felt it was O.K. to "make it jump out a bit." He striped the tin canopies, spruced up the rosettes and chose what he calls "an Olana theme" -- an allusion to the painter Frederic E. Church's sensuous Moorish reverie farther up the Hudson, designed by Church and planned by Vaux.
The Hodges' house now has a whimsical air. Lillie Hodge feels herself admiring it, especially when cleaning her pair of ballrooms. "It's a museum -- that's how I see it," she said. "But it's well lived in. There's no furniture you can't sit on."
Downing's romantic presence is palpable even in the driveway that wends its way to the 23-room Downing-Vaux "cottage" owned by Linda Anderson Henry and Scott Henry. As it turns, the drive reveals a three-quarter profile of the house, its irregular roof lines deliberate echoes of the distant hills.
The house was built beside a stream after Downing's death in what Downing called "the Rhine style," and it has been an object of passionate -- some might say obsessive -- interest for the couple since they purchased it in 1993.
Mr. Henry, a freelance political consultant, and Ms. Henry, a psychologist, had a "coming out party" for their house, to which they invited leading Downing and Vaux scholars. Mr. Henry, who studied architecture at Brooklyn Tech, has made a career of researching the history of his property. He speaks grandly of "classic Downing effects."
Though few Downing landscapes survive, there is a strong suspicion among landscape historians that the Henrys' yard, with its tulip trees, Osage orange trees, European beeches and native specimens, may be among them.
NEWBURGH residents who own and love these houses seem determined not to be intimidated by their illustrious architectural pedigrees. Though they proudly show off the original drawings of their house, designed by Withers in 1859, Carla and Robert Decker were bent on making it comfortable. While they restored the parlor, with its original gaslight ceiling fixture, they let the rest of the house "kind of just be 1998," as Mrs. Decker put it.
Houses like the Deckers' are testaments to an optimistic era in which the towns along the Hudson boomed with the river. Recent history, however, has not been kind to Newburgh, whose depressed economy and high vacancy rates are taking their toll on the historic district. In 1977, Morningside, an 1859 Withers house, was in such disrepair that its Gothic revival library was removed and reconstructed in the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. (The house, on the June 7 tour, has since been restored.)
"Poverty is a preserver of sorts," said Winthrop Aldrich, the Deputy Commissioner for Historic Preservation in the State Parks Department.
Still, there are signs of a rebound. The National Trust has recently set up a nonprofit development corporation to create affordable housing in the historic district. And the 35-acre city park designed by Vaux and Olmsted in Downing's memory -- finished, poignantly, by their sons, including one named Downing Vaux -- has been rejuvenated by the Downing Park Planning Committee. Downing is buried nearby, beneath a medieval-looking gravestone designed, naturally, by Vaux.
"It's like having a wonderful painting you scratched and discovered was a Rembrandt," Mr. Henry said of the city's uncommon lineage. "So what do you do? You keep on scratching."
 
Tour of the Past
 THIS weekend, "Taste Makers of an Era: A Perusal of the Architectural Works of Andrew Jackson Downing, Calvert Vaux, Frederick C. Withers and Frederick Law Olmsted," takes place in Newburgh, N.Y.
A symposium on Downing and his disciples, featuring Francis Kowsky, David Schuyler and other scholars, will be held on Saturday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., with registration from 9 to 10 A.M. at 189 Montgomery Street (Clinton Street). The cost is $20.
On Sunday from noon to 5 P.M., there will be a film and tour of more than 15 homes and churches designed by the four men in the Newburgh area. Registration begins at 11 A.M. The cost is $20.

HEADLINE: In America;
The Sky Didn't Fall

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Finally the benefits of the nation's long-running economic expansion are reaching the folks at the bottom.
It was an article of faith not too long ago that an unemployment rate of 6 percent or less was bad news, a harbinger of runaway inflation and all the ills that accompany it. (Not surprisingly, this was never a doctrine advanced by the unemployed. It was a belief most fervently held by well-fed professors with tenure.) 
 Well, in April the jobless rate fell to 4.3 percent, the lowest level in nearly three decades, and the sky hasn't fallen with it. The numbers for May are not yet out, but over the past year or two there has been reasonably good news across the board for low-wage workers, and without a hint of accelerating inflation.
Jared Bernstein, an economist with the Economic Policy Institute in Washington, noted that from 1996 to 1997 the hourly wages of the bottom 20 percent of workers increased by 3.2 percent in real terms. That compared with a 1.5 percent increase in the top 20 percent of wage and salary workers.
"That's an example not only of strong wage growth, but stronger at the bottom than at the top," said Mr. Bernstein. "You couldn't find a 3.2 percent increase at any point in this recovery for workers at the bottom.
"That said, these workers are in such a deep hole that these conditions would have to persist for a long time if they ever hope to make up their two decades of wage declines."
Mr. Bernstein and others have cited three principal reasons for the recent wage growth: tight labor markets, continued low inflation and increases in the minimum wage.
Two years ago, when Bob Dole was running for President, it was an article of faith among conservative Republicans that an increase in the minimum wage would result in job losses for low-wage workers. According to this doctrine, large numbers of employers would rather let workers go than give them a modest raise.
Dick Armey, the House majority leader and holder of a Ph.D. in economics, denounced the Democratic proposal to hike the minimum wage by 90 cents an hour as "a cruel hoax on the least-advantaged workers in the system." He said the minimum wage should be abolished.
William Niskanen, chairman of the conservative Cato Institute, told a House committee, "It is hard to explain the continued support for increasing the minimum wage by those interested in helping the working poor."
Return with us now to reality. Mr. Bernstein is the co-author, with John Schmitt, of a rigorous study of the impact of the 1996-97 minimum wage increase. It found that the increase raised the wages of nearly 10 million workers, most of them adults and more than half of them women, without causing job loss.
The study said: "The benefits of the increase disproportionately help those working households at the bottom of the income scale. Although households in the bottom 20 percent (whose average income was $15,728 in 1996) received only 5 percent of total national income, 35 percent of the benefits from the minimum wage increase went to these workers. In this regard, the increase had the intended effect of raising the earnings and incomes of low-wage workers and their households."
I am still waiting for Mr. Armey, Mr. Niskanen and their brethren to explain how this is a bad thing.
"I'm excited about the way things are lining up," Mr. Bernstein said. He noted that even the groups facing the most difficult employment hurdles, including young and less-well-educated African-Americans, are experiencing some improvement.
"A 20 percent unemployment rate is still a Depression-level number," he said. "But it's better than 25 percent."
The challenge now is to keep the economy moving in a way that benefits everyone, not just those at the top. It won't be easy. When the April unemployment numbers were released, the inflation hawks got their usual jitters. Was it time to raise interest rates and curb this spreading prosperity? Were workers making 10 or 15 grand a year becoming a threat to the nation's millionaires? Wouldn't it be prudent, at least, to jack up the jobless rate?
Stay tuned.

HEADLINE: Demand Off, Boeing to Stop Making MD-11

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The Boeing Company announced yesterday that it would stop producing the MD-11 wide-body jet late next year and lay off some workers because of slumping demand for the aircraft.
Boeing, based in Seattle, said the move would not result in a special charge against earnings, as many analysts had feared. But it will reduce second-quarter earnings, though the company declined to specify by how much. 
 Boeing inherited the MD-11 last year when it bought the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for $16.3 billion. In November, Boeing announced that it was phasing out the MD-80 and MD-90, two narrow-body jets produced by what is now called Boeing's Douglas Products division.
Executives had hoped that they could continue to sell the three-engine MD-11, which has a passenger capacity ranging from 233 to 410, primarily as a freighter. But the financial crisis in Asia has forced many airlines there to shed older wide-body planes, which are expensive to operate, creating a large number of passenger jets that can be converted into cargo planes at a fraction of the cost of a new MD-11.
"Despite our best marketing efforts," said Ronald B. Woodard, president of Boeing's commercial aircraft division, "it became clear to us that there simply was not enough customer interest in either the passenger or freighter versions of this airplane to justify keeping the production line open."
Boeing said it had commitments for 22 more MD-11's and planned to deliver the last plane in February 2000.
The announcement leaves only the 717, a 100-seat, twin-engine jet formerly called the MD-95, as the remaining Douglas model in the Boeing stable.
About 3,000 workers at the former Douglas plant in Long Beach, Calif., now build the MD-11. An additional 600 workers build the plane's wings in Toronto along with 75 workers each in Salt Lake City and Melbourne, Ark.
Earlier this year, Boeing announced it would eliminate 6,200 jobs in Long Beach, most of that the result of phasing out production of the MD-80 and MD-90. But the company has more recently transferred some work on a new version of the 737, a narrow-body passenger jet, to Long Beach and is considering opening a line to assemble the 737 there.
Mr. Woodard said Boeing would do its best to find new jobs for the workers, adding, "But ultimately we will have to lay off employees for whom we do not have work."
The Canadian Press quoted George Capern, president of Boeing Canada, as saying that the Toronto wing plant, which employs about 2,000, would be phased out unless additional work was found.
But Sean O'Donnell, a Boeing spokesman, said, "We are looking to place additional temporary work in Toronto."

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 592 words

HEADLINE: Offices Money Can't Buy

 BODY:
If nothing else, the results of California's primary elections may cause multimillionaires to rethink their plans for midlife career changes. Never have so many spent so much to win so little. The businessman Al Checchi could have gotten a better return by spending his $40 million on Lotto tickets than by seeking the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. Representative Jane Harman, who finished right behind Mr. Checchi in the race, lost both her Congressional career and about $15 million of her husband's fortune. The car alarm magnate Darrell Issa spent $10 million of his own money chasing the G.O.P. Senate nomination, to no avail.
Like many elections so far this year, Tuesday's primaries were a rejection of checkbook politics and unrestricted spending. Lieut. Gov. Gray Davis, who beat Mr. Checchi, is a career politician who categorized his victory as "an experience money can't buy." Matt Fong, the State Treasurer, underspent Mr. Issa for the Senate nomination. Californians rejected Representative Jay Kim and his financial scandal. Mr. Kim, who recently pleaded guilty to accepting illegal campaign donations, was confined to his Washington home under a probation agreement. 
 The voters' contempt for rich newcomers has not been limited to California. Businessmen in Nebraska, Kentucky and other states outspent their opponents and sent overall campaign costs soaring, only to lose on primary day. Deep down, Americans may not really want to see their government run like a business after all. Mr. Checchi was not the first businessman-candidate whose history as a job-cutting downsizer came back to haunt him.
In another primary that was watched closely this week, the inability of Gov. Fob James Jr. of Alabama to win renomination outright was seen as the voters' effort to give the state a more reasonable image. Mr. James drew unwelcome attention to Alabama with his threat to call out the National Guard to defend a judge's right to post the Ten Commandments in his courtroom, and with his obsessive crusade for school prayer. Alabamans have good cause to believe that their real problems lie more in the direction of economic development and education. Mr. James's supporters may take heart in the fact that the upcoming primary runoff pits him against Winton Blount, a millionaire businessman. But Mr. Blount emphasized progressive policies, not bottomless pockets.
The most dramatic result of Tuesday's voting, however, involved not rich would-be governors but schoolchildren. Californians voted overwhelmingly to approve Proposition 227, which would drastically curtail bilingual education in public schools. The initiative's passage, which was apparently supported by many Latino parents, seemed to be more of a protest against the poor quality of public education than a reasoned analysis of how best to teach children who are not fluent in English. A more rational approach to the issue of bilingual education was passed by the California legislature this year. But it was vetoed by Gov. Pete Wilson, whose impulse to pander seems to grow as Presidential election time approaches.
Voters defeated another proposal that would have restricted unions' ability to use their members' dues for political campaigns. They apparently responded to ads claiming that the proposition was a plot to quell critics of unpopular special interests, like H.M.O.'s. Californians may have come to realize that legislating by the ballot box is a rough tool that is easily manipulated and seldom accomplishes what they might hope.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Russia at risk, and the I.M.F.'s prescription raises concerns.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
YET another emerging market economy has been forced to the brink by financial panic. And yet again the International Monetary Fund is riding to the rescue.
Only this time around the economy at risk is Russia, which is far more feeble yet far more important in geopolitical terms than the Asian Tigers. And the drumbeat is growing from critics of the I.M.F., which places an enormous premium on stabilizing currency exchange rates, sometimes at very high costs. 
 "Russia is being asked to crush the opportunity for economic growth in the name of short-term market stability," said Jeffrey D. Sachs, the director of Harvard's Institute for International Development.
President Boris Yeltsin gets a passing mark on economic reform only if you grade on a curve. True, much of the economy's industrial base has been privatized. Inflation is down to single digits. And though the budget deficit in the first quarter of this year -- at 4.6 percent of gross domestic product -- was high by Western standards, it was right on the track set by the I.M.F.
What has not been done, though -- or has been done badly -- haunts the Government. Mr. Sachs, for one, makes a big distinction between its rapid privatization of manufacturing and its sale of natural resources, notably oil and gas reserves. The former was a step forward, since the only hope for modernizing Soviet enterprises was to introduce free market incentives. But the "virtual giveaway of hundreds of billions of dollars in natural wealth deprived the state of desperately needed revenues and created a powerful class of robber barons," Mr. Sachs argues.
The search for revenue has compounded Moscow's problems, suggests Richard Medley, a New York adviser on financial risk management. Under pressure from the I.M.F., tax rates were set high -- "so high that no one can afford to pay them," Mr. Medley said.
While the proximate cause of the financial panic of the last few weeks was the failure of the Government to sell off the Rosneft oil enterprise for some $2 billion, no one doubts that the stage was set by the financial troubles in Asia. And to some, the Asian Tigers' continuing wobble suggests that the I.M.F. has prescribed the wrong medicine.
Robert Wade, a visiting scholar at the Russell Sage Foundation, argues that the high interest rates and tight fiscal policy that the I.M.F. has demanded as a means of restoring confidence in the Asian currencies is destroying indebted, but otherwise healthy, businesses. "The I.M.F. spends too much effort defending old orthodoxies -- not to mention the interests of Asia's foreign creditors," he said.
For such skeptics, the big question is whether the I.M.F. is again applying flawed priorities and policies in Russia. Over the last three years, Russia's domestic inflation has outpaced the depreciation of the ruble by about 35 percent, Mr. Sachs noted. Yet the I.M.F. is encouraging the Yeltsin Government to use its dwindling credibility and foreign currency reserves in a last-ditch defense of the exchange rate.
Mr. Sachs is convinced the effort will ultimately fail. But even if it does not, struggling Russian businesses could be shattered by the exorbitant interest rates the Government is paying to hold the line on the ruble. This week, the Government raised more than $1 billion in a debt sale that included one-week bills yielding just under 40 percent. To service this debt, the Government will have to shift some resources that otherwise could have gone to keeping pensioners fed and coal miners paid.
Trouble is, the major alternative, a sharp depreciation of the ruble, would also inflict a blow to the feeble Russian economy from which it would not easily recover. With Russian banks and enterprises owing roughly $30 billion on securities coming due in the next year, Rudi Dornbusch of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology reckons that letting the ruble go would ruin the banks.
"One way or another, Russia faces a big balance-sheet problem," Mr. Dornbusch said: either it will be devastated by high interest rates, or debtors will face huge liabilities in dollars they probably will not be able to repay.
If there is a lesson here, it is that short-term capital is no friend to emerging economies. Russia's anarchic capitalism may have little in common with the highly organized cronyism of Asia. But in both cases, "hot money" has proved an Achilles' heel, magnifying the impact of more fundamental institutional weaknesses and immensely complicating rescue efforts.
Genuine reforms, ranging from changes in the tax system to application of the rule of law, are surely necessary to get the Russian economy moving. As long as Russia depends on the good opinion of international capital markets, though, those reforms may not be sufficient.

HEADLINE: A Nonmanufacturing Index Shows Growth

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Activity rose at nonmanufacturing companies in May from April, according to a new monthly survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management released yesterday.
The nonmanufacturing activity index was at 64 in May, the first official month of the survey. That is up from 63 in April, according to previously unreleased data. The association has been conducting pilot surveys for the new index since July 1997, when the index was at 57.5. 
 The new survey complements the group's 68-year-old report on manufacturing, which investors study for clues to the direction of economic growth. The new index correlates to the production index in the association's manufacturing report and not to the manufacturing report's main composite index.
The manufacturing survey covers about 30 percent of the economic activity in the United States, the group says, and the new report is designed to cover the rest. Purchasing and supply management officers at 370 companies will be surveyed each month.
The index measures the number of companies that report increased production or said they had paid more for raw materials, not how much nonmanufacturing industries produced or prices changed.
The May increase in the activity index reflects "the continuing strength of the U.S. economy," said Ralph Kauffman, chairman of the nonmanufacturing survey and coordinator of the purchasing and supply program at the University of Houston-Downtown. "Over all in May, nonmanufacturing industries continued to grow and to increase their employment, while paying less for purchased materials and services," Mr. Kauffman said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Prices Close on Downside, With Dow Retreating 87.44

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Resilient concerns about weakness in the technology sector pushed stocks lower yesterday, with the Nasdaq composite index falling more than 1 percent.
The drops in technology shares contributed to a late-day selling spree that spread across the market. It was worsened by a wave of computer-generated sell programs, which erased a small gain in the Dow Jones industrial average and left it with a loss of more than 87 points. 
 The Intel Corporation, the bellwether semiconductor issue, led the declines among technology issues. It fell 3 5/16, to 65 15/16, its lowest level since April 1997.
The stock came under pressure after a research analyst, Robert Chaplinsky of the Hambrecht & Quist Group, lowered his second-quarter earnings estimate due to expectations of slowing sales abroad.
A rumor that Intel would warn that April-June earnings could disappoint -- coming in at 65 cents a share compared with the 70 cents widely forecast -- contributed to the decline.
Intel's problems illustrated investors' persistent concerns about the technology sector. Worries about the impact of Asia's financial crisis on earnings as well as dampening domestic consumer demand have pressured chip makers, computer companies such as Dell Computer and software companies such as Hewlett-Packard.
Investors are worried that disappointing earnings from technology shares, which have been among the leaders of the current rally, could signal similar declines in other sectors, said Anthony Conroy, a managing director for Bankers Trust Global Investment Management in New York. Such concerns have heightened investors' unwillingness to buy stocks, continuing a recent trend in which early market gains evaporate into declines by the day's end.
"It's still a kind of skittish market and there's no real trend," said Charles W. Washington, head equity trader for Blaylock & Partners in Baltimore.
"The market is not capitalizing on the good news," said William E. Barker Jr., chief investment strategist at Dain Rauscher. He noted that recent planned merger deals such as Tellabs purchase of Ciena and American Home Products' joining with Monsanto had failed to excite investors and cause strong gains in those stocks.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which traded higher briefly during the day, closed down 87.44 points. One sell program during the last 40 minutes of trading took 80 points off the blue-chip index, according to to Birinyi Associates, a Greenwich, Conn., research firm.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 10.49 points and the Nasdaq plunged 19.48 points, to 1,742.31, a 1.11 percent decline.
However, the long-term sentiment remains bullish with analysts like Goldman, Sachs's Abby Joseph Cohen forecasting that earnings growth will resume later in the year and propel stock prices higher.
Stocks are currently priced at fair value, Mrs. Cohen said in a recent market comment. The current climate of low interest rates and attractive fundamentals, such as the Federal budget surplus, well-managed corporations and solid financial institutions will be the catalysts to push prices higher, she said.
And investors like Mr. Barker and Alan Bond, chief investment officer at Bond Procope Capital Management, said they were ready to pick up stocks like Intel if their prices continued to fall.
"Intel looks pretty cheap here," said Mr. Bond, who recently sold some shares of the stock at a price above $80 a share.
"I would be a buyer on weakness, but I would make darn sure the company has visible earnings growth and a reasonable valuation," Mr. Barker said.

Treasury Prices Gain
By Bloomberg News
Treasury prices rose yesterday in slow trading as investors were reluctant to buy before tomorrow's report on May employment, which is expected to show the economy is strong.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 6/32, to 104 29/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.78 percent, from 5.79 percent on Tuesday.
"We're in a wait-and-see mode," said David Johnson, who helps manage about $30 billion in bonds at Van Kampen Capital Management in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill. Concern "that we may be running out of workers," may make the Federal Reserve more likely to increase interest rates, he said.
The report will probably show the jobless rate stayed near a 28-year low in May, economists said.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said the labor market was "remarkably resilient" at a private meeting yesterday with central bank chiefs from Germany, France, Britain and Austria, according to a banker who heard his remarks.

HEADLINE: Korean Air, Bucking a Trend, Will Buy 27 Boeing 737 Jets

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Korean Air, bucking a trend that has seen many Asian airlines delay orders for new airplanes as a result of the region's economic crisis, plans to announce next week that it is buying 27 new Boeing 737 passenger jets valued at $1.35 billion.
The new order is expected to be announced Tuesday during the state visit to Washington of South Korea's newly elected President, Kim Dae Jung. It is good news for the Boeing Company, which said only last week that weakening demand from Asia would force it to cut production of the 747 jumbo jet next year. 
 Since the Asian economy went into a tailspin last summer, airline passenger traffic in the region has plunged as well. In the last week alone, Malaysian Airline System said that it would delay delivery of several Boeing 747 and 777 airplanes and Taiwan's Eva Airways, dropped plans to buy at least six long-range A340 aircraft worth $900 million built by Airbus Industrie, Boeing's archrival.
Boeing is also concerned that an order it is expecting to get from China during President Clinton's state visit there later this month will be smaller than the company had hoped.
"We are extremely pleased that Korean Air is exercising leadership in Asia by stepping forward, even during difficult times, with this order," said Carie Cable, a Boeing spokeswoman.
But selling the single-aisle, twin-engine 737 is not nearly as lucrative for Boeing as selling wide-body models like the 747 and 777. And Boeing apparently gambled that by the time Korean Air begins taking delivery of the planes in the year 2000, Asia's economic crisis will be over.
Yang Ho Cho, Korean Air's chief executive, said in an interview that the airline, which is a subsidiary of the Hanjin Group and is already heavily in debt, has had trouble borrowing overseas since South Korea's economy collapsed last year. He said Boeing was willing to accept a smaller down payment for the new planes, giving the airline time to arrange financing later.
"We believe by the year 2000, when our economic situation improves, financial institutions will offer to finance it," he said.
Until then, Mr. Cho added, Korean Air, too, may have to consider delaying its purchase of new wide-body jets. The airline plans to receive a total of 10 747's and 777's and Airbus A330's this year and a combination of 11 more in 1999.
"We are looking at right now," he said. "It depends on the economic situation. We have the option to delay."
Mr. Cho said that the new 737-800 and 737-900 aircraft will replace 26 older Fokker and McDonnell Douglas narrow-body jets. They will be flown domestically and on routes to China, Japan and destinations in Southeast Asia.
Korean Air already flies to dozens of cities in China and it is betting heavily on China's future economic growth. Mr. Cho said that with the completion of a new international airport in Inchon in 2000, South Korea had the potential to become a major hub connecting travelers from North America to China.
The new airplanes, which have a longer range and are more fuel efficient than Korean Air's current narrow-body fleet, will also lower the airline's maintenance costs and give it more flexibility. Right now the airline must use a 250-seat Airbus to fly from Seoul to Ho Chi Minh City because it does not have a smaller plane that can fly the distance.
Some analysts suggested that the order was a way for South Korea to thank the United States for supporting the $50 billion bailout the country received from the International Monetary Fund. Mr. Cho said that the timing of the order and President Kim's visit was "just a coincidence."
But, he added, "Probably President Kim will be proud to talk about this with President Clinton when they meet."

HEADLINE: Despite Furor Over China, Clinton Defends Trade Status

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
President Clinton announced today that he would renew China's trading privileges, signaling that he would not back away from his policy of engagement despite the rising Congressional clamor over whether the Chinese Government illegally contributed to his campaign and used protected American technology to improve its missiles.
In a Rose Garden ceremony, Mr. Clinton argued that links with China supported a range of American economic and security interests. And he called trade "a force for change in China, exposing China to our ideas and our ideals, and integrating China into the global economy." 
 While Congress is expected ultimately to approve China's trade status after the President returns from a visit there later this month, Republicans made clear today that they intend to exact a high political price. The House and Senate have 90 days in which to reject Mr. Clinton's formal recommendation of what is known as "most-favored-nation status" for China.
The threat of revoking the trade status -- the benefit that the United States grants to almost every country in the world except those it regards as terrorist states -- is one of the main instruments Congress uses to show its displeasure with China over human rights abuses and other problems, and with the Administration's policy toward Beijing. The threat has been raised repeatedly through the Bush and Clinton Administrations, although the United States has never actually revoked it.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, has said he is reconsidering his long-held support for extending the trade status. Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, said today: "I think the current circumstances make this a very difficult vote. While most of us embrace trade as something that's healthy for the peoples of all countries, we really have a serious group of national security concerns before us."
House Speaker Newt Gingrich threw his support behind renewing China's trade privileges. "Seeking to keep China open to the West has proven to be the most effective way to advance our democratic values in this turbulent region of the world," Mr. Gingrich wrote in a letter to the President today that was also signed by two other Republicans, Bill Archer of Florida, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and Philip M. Crane of Illinois.
Yet even as they pledged to work with Mr. Clinton in a "bipartisan manner" on China trade, the three Congressmen indicated that they would look into the charges against him. Rehearsing what they called disturbing accusations, they promised full investigations.
Republicans have accused President Clinton of risking American security by permitting the Chinese to launch satellites for a company that contributed heavily to the Democrats. They have said that some technology may have been transferred that could have permitted China to improve its missiles. Congressional committees and the Justice Department are investigating whether the Chinese Government illegally contributed money to the Democrats during Mr. Clinton's re-election campaign.
As a candidate in the 1992 campaign, Mr. Clinton derided the policy of engagement with China, but as President he came to accept and then embrace it. Today he praised it as a means of assuring security.
"Our engagement with China serves American interests," Mr. Clinton said, citing "stability in Asia, preventing the spread of weapons of mass destruction, combatting international crime and drug trafficking, protecting the environment."
Mr. Clinton said that cooperation with China had become even more important in light of the nuclear standoff between India and Pakistan. He appeared in the Rose Garden today with Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, who was preparing to depart for a meeting in Geneva among five nuclear powers to discuss South Asia. The meeting is to be run by the Chinese.
Warning that developing nuclear weapons would make the Indian and Pakistani people "poorer and less secure," the President said, "The international community must now come together to move them to reverse course and to avoid a dangerous arms race in Asia."
Later, in a briefing at the State Department, Ms. Albright acknowledged past Administration concern that the Chinese helped Pakistan develop its nuclear capacity. But she said that "in recent years they have changed their behavior vis-a-vis the Pakistanis" and "are not providing any assistance to unsafeguarded projects."
In their one-day meeting, the five nations -- the United States, Britain, China, France, and Russia -- hope to draw up joint proposals on India and Pakistan. The Administration wants to persuade both nations not to arm missiles with nuclear warheads or to engage in more provocative rhetoric or military activity.
"Right now, the most important thing both sides can do is to cool it and take a deep breath and to begin to climb out of the hole they have dug themselves into," Ms. Albright said in the Rose Garden.
American trade with China now amounts to about $75 billion a year, with China vying with Japan as the nation contributing the most to the American trade deficit. While the United States imported $62.5 billion in goods from China last year, it exported only $12.8 billion in goods to China.

HEADLINE: Calling All Lifeguards! (Even Nonresidents)

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
This one has city officials stumped: Why are there not enough lifeguards to staff New York City's seven beaches and 55 outdoor pools, despite an aggressive recruitment initiative?
"We're simply not optimistic," said Alan Moss, the first deputy commissioner for the Department of Parks and Recreation, the agency that recruits the expert swimmers. "There's a genuine shortage of qualified lifeguards." 
 Even though his agency has the budget to hire 1,200 lifeguards each summer, the city has hired only about 400 this year, with summer less than three weeks away. As a result, since the Memorial Day beach openings, large sections of the city's beachfront have been closed, presenting a hardship for bathers and vendors alike.
The situation is so dire that for the first time the city is allowing nonresidents to apply for the lifeguard jobs, which pay $8.64 an hour for 48-hour weeks. Furthermore, the Parks Department has recruited in high schools and colleges in New Jersey, Connecticut, Long Island and Westchester.
Mr. Moss said that with the robust economy, high school and college students could be finding more lucrative jobs that also give them more leisure time. He also said that there may be a shortage of candidates because high schools do not emphasize swimming the way they used to.
But J. D. LaRock, a spokesman for the Board of Education, pointed out that there has been an increase in the number of swimming teams in city high schools, up to 74 this year from 68 last year. Still, only 29 of the city's 208 high schools have swimming pools.
Besides placing ads in 12 local newspapers and magazines and having the Mayor announce openings on his weekly radio program, the Parks Department arranged a tie-in with a "Baywatch" event on April 22 in Washington Square Park, in which two of the show's stars, Michael Bergin and Angelica Bridges, made appearances and urged people to try out for the city's lifeguard positions.
Still, the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, who held a news conference yesterday on the Coney Island Boardwalk to criticize the city's failure to prepare the beach for summer, said he did not think the Parks Department was doing enough to combat the lifeguard drought.
"It's been a dismal failure," Mr. Golden said. "On Memorial Day, 10 out of 22 bays were closed here in Coney Island. What's needed is borough-wide, year-round recruitment."
At the news conference, in which he complained about the condition of Coney Island's boardwalk and public restrooms, Mr. Golden advocated moving lifeguard hiring from the Parks Department to another agency, perhaps the Board of Education.
"They don't seem to be able to get their act together," he said of the Parks Department. "They should provide training year round for people interested in the job."
Chuck Reichenthal, the district manager of Community Board 13, which covers Coney Island, said the lifeguard problem has hurt business for local vendors.
"We get complaints from people in the community and businesses," he said. "What was the point of replenishing the beaches? We have long, clean beaches waiting for swimming. People from Staten Island like one section of the beach and when people come and find out the section they like is closed, they get upset. If they have to walk seven blocks to the beach because a section is closed, they might not come back."
In order to qualify for the city's weeklong, 40-hour lifeguard course -- passing it guarantees the job -- one must be at least 16 years old, able to swim 50 yards in 35 seconds, have at least 20/40 to 20/30 unaided vision, and have a doctor's note stating that he or she is in good physical condition. To pass the 40-hour course, applicants have to be able to swim 440 yards in 6 minutes and 40 seconds for beach patrol, and be able to swim 440 yards in 7 minutes and 40 seconds for pool patrol.
"We won't compromise public safety," said Henry J. Stern, the Parks Commissioner.
He said that the Parks Department only hired 870 lifeguards last year, so parts of some beaches were closed. "But there was no drowning on our watch," he added.
