HEADLINE: Merrill Makes Strategic Move In Ending Suit

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE with ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
From the day, more than three years ago, when Orange County, Calif., shocked the world of finance and filed for bankruptcy, to the announcement this week that Merrill Lynch & Company had agreed to pay $400 million to settle litigation for its role in that matter, Merrill has maintained its innocence.
In fact, until it agreed to write this check, Merrill had kept a combative stance -- refusing to oust any employees involved in the Orange County disaster, hiring platoons of lawyers to defend itself and keeping up a public relations campaign. 
 But in the intervening years, much has changed, even though Merrill continues to assert its innocence. Those changes, some say, explain why Merrill, around a month ago, signaled to Orange County that it was ready to negotiate in earnest to head off a scheduled September trial in a $2 billion lawsuit brought by the county. The lawsuit contended that Merrill had sold speculative securities, in violation of California law, to a county-run investment pool that lost $1.6 billion after making a wrong-way bet on interest rates.
For starters, Merrill was finding itself shut out of much municipal business in California and its reputation as a municipal bond underwriter and financial adviser was tarnished throughout the country by this episode. A trial with headlines that would put the phrase "investment losses" in the same sentence as Merrill Lynch would only rekindle much of this bad publicity just as it was beginning to die out.
In addition, at a time when the financial services industry is being reshaped by multibillion-dollar mergers of Wall Street brokers, like Merrill, and banks and insurance companies, Merrill would find it easier to be a player in this merger game, either as a buyer or seller, with no major lawsuits still outstanding.
Under its chief executive, David H. Komansky, Merrill has been a leading lobbyist in Washington for legislation that would eliminate many of the regulatory barriers to these mergers and allow them to proceed more easily. "From Merrill's point of view, the more publicity that they would get from Orange County, the worse it would get for them," said Raphael Soifer, an analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman. "They were facing the publicity of a long trial and, also, the uncertain outcome of a hometown jury. It seems like settling would be the reasonable thing to do."
James Spiotto, municipal finance attorney at Chapman & Cutler in Chicago, added: "Right now, Orange County is far enough in the memory for lots of people that it's like water over the dam. Merrill wants to keep it behind them."
Settlement talks between attorneys for Merrill and for Orange County began in earnest around three weeks ago, after the country had already gained $172 million from three lesser defendants, KPMG Peat Marwick, Credit Suisse First Boston and LeBoeuf, Lamb, Green & MacRae. Mediation talks, under local rules in Federal court in California, are mandatory, but are not binding on the parties. In those talks, however, Thomas W. Hayes, the former California state treasurer who heads Orange County's litigation effort, said it "became clear it was a difficult lawsuit that could go either way before a jury."
George Schieren, Merrill's general counsel, said: "The question for us was whether you are better off with the certainty of a negotiation or risk the uncertainty of a trial. This has nothing to do with how we feel about our conduct. A jury could see it differently. We made a decision that we were much better off with the certainty of a settlement. We took the mediation process seriously."
A settlement, even as large as $400 million, clears Merrill to proceed more easily in the emerging financial marketplace -- freed from having to go before shareholders and boards of directors of companies they might wish to acquire or join and provide guesses of their dollar exposure in Orange County and, again, explain their behavior.
"There's the argument, and it's all very speculative, that Merrill is folding its cards quickly to clear the decks," said Samuel G. Liss, an analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston. This year, Merrill has taken new strategic steps, spending $7 billion to acquire Mercury Asset Management, a London-based firm, and taking an equity stake in the former Yamaichi Securities in Japan.
According to Merrill, the $400 million payment will not hurt earnings, nor will it affect employee compensation. Mr. Schieren said that reserves had already been set aside to fully cover this and that any impact on earnings had already been felt.
Still unresolved, however, is a potential Securities and Exchange Commission action against Merrill. Merrill has confirmed the S.E.C. has authorized its staff to bring an enforcement action over allegations of lax disclosure in Merrill's role as an underwriter of Orange County debt. Merrill has already paid $30 million to Orange County to settle a separate criminal case -- and, now, is fighting to keep all documents related to that case out of the public domain.
Michael Stamenson, the Merrill securities salesman at the center of the scandal, is still employed at Merrill's San Francisco office. "He's working full time on the litigation," Mr. Schieren, Merrill's lawyer, said.
For some in Orange County, the settlement is good news, especially since a strong Orange County economy has softened the blow of the investment losses. "It's a major settlement," said Paul Brady, city manager of Irvine, Calif., "It far exceeds our expectations when we first got into it. And, when we look at the county four years later, it's basically business as usual."

HEADLINE: Shunning the Art of Spin, Bahrain Seeks Investors From U.S.

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
In his first visit to the United States in seven years, the Emir of Bahrain came this week not to buy American military hardware or ask for more protection against Saddam Hussein, but to woo American investors.
Quietly. 
 That's because Sheik Isa bin Salman al-Khalifa doesn't like to play rainmaker. The Emir did not stop by New York's citadels of capitalism the way President Jiang Zemin of China did last year, when he visited the New York Stock Exchange and I.B.M. Instead, during his stopover in New York, the Emir chose to recover from jet lag and meet privately with the Secretary General of the United Nations, Kofi Annan.
The man who has been Bahrain's monarch for 36 years did not give one speech, grant one interview or hold one news conference during his brief stay. There was no opportunity for reporters to ask questions either before or after his meeting with President Clinton on Monday. A two-and-a-half page joint statement was released instead.
Bahrain has loyally acted as host to the Navy's Fifth Fleet for decades and even accepted more American troops and equipment during the recent crisis with Iraq.
But the Emir did not demand a state dinner, with flags flying along Pennsylvania Avenue and a 21-gun salute on the White House lawn, as a payoff. He settled for a less lofty "official" two-day visit instead, which at least gave him lodging at Blair House, the residence across the street from the White House.
By contrast, President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea, who will come to the United States next week on an official visit, will be honored at a black-tie dinner given by Mr. Clinton at the White House. The Emir got lunch. For most countries, the art of commercial diplomacy is to get out and tell your story. And if Bahrain had more oil, perhaps the Emir's reticence wouldn't make much of a difference.
But Bahrain is the smallest, the least wealthy and the most crowded of the six monarchies on the Persian Gulf. Seventy percent of its population is under the age of 27.
Over the years it has survived by building itself up as a service-based economy, the banking center of the Persian Gulf and an oasis for Saudi-based Westerners who can drive across the causeway from Saudi Arabia to relax and drink alcohol.
Now it wants to diversify beyond oil and aluminum.
"Oil money is not enough anymore for the new generation in every gulf country," said David M. Ransom, who was the American Ambassador in Bahrain until last year. "The Emir came to Washington this time to project his Government not just as a staunch friend in security matters but as an attractive destination for business and investment."
So why not tell your story?
"The problem with the Bahrainis is that they just don't have the P.R. gene," said an American businessman with long ties to the country. "They don't understand how to project their image. Poor guys."
The Emir did rub shoulders with corporate America at a dinner given by six corporations -- Caltex, Turner Broadcasting System Inc., Lockheed Martin, Citibank, Chevron and Leo Daly -- at the Four Seasons Hotel on Monday night. He made a few opening remarks, but left it to his Finance Minister to give a speech on why Bahrain is such a good place for American investors.
"We would welcome more U.S. financial institutions to join us in the Middle East's pre-eminent financial center," said the Finance Minister, Ibrahim Abdul-Karim, in his speech.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Are Highest Since 1986

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 3

 BODY:
The nation's auto industry reported that May was the best month for car and truck sales since September 1986, with sales totaling 1,511,661 cars and trucks, a 12.1 percent increase from the corresponding period last year.
Moreover, fueled by hefty price discounts, the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for light vehicles reached 16.3 million cars and trucks last month, the highest level since October 1987. 
 Sales of both cars and trucks increased though truck sales showed a higher rise. Car sales totaled 793,066 units, up 6.9 percent; light-truck sales topped 718,575 units, up 18.4 percent.
"The fundamentals of the economy are very strong," said Michael DiGiovanni, the chief forecaster at the General Motors Corporation. "A lot has been written about the industry slowing down, but frankly it's hard to see that happening because of low unemployment, low interest rates and high consumer confidence."
Sales, however, were buoyed by attractive incentive programs. Auto makers spent as much as $1,600 a vehicle on incentives in May, up from about $1,100 a year earlier, analysts said. In mid-April, G.M. sent certificates worth $500 to $1,000 to previous buyers of G.M. products to use toward the purchase of 50 different models, above and beyond other cash rebate and low-interest loan incentives.
The program was an effort to rebuild G.M.'s market share in the United States, which had dropped to below 30 percent earlier this year. In May, G.M.'s share of the United States car and truck market rose to 32.5 percent. The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation matched G.M.'s Loyalty First program with their own customer loyalty plans and agreed to accept G.M. certificates. G.M. did not agree to take Ford and Chrysler coupons. The loyalty programs run through July 2.
General Motors said today that it sold 484,168 cars and trucks in May, an increase of 12.4 percent over May 1997. G.M.'s truck sales increased 19.2 percent, to 226,114 vehicles, the third consecutive month G.M. has set a record for truck sales, pushing G.M. well ahead of Ford in truck sales. G.M.'s car sales also increased, up 7 percent at 258,054 units.
Ford reported today that it sold 353,270 cars and trucks in May, up 1.2 percent from May 1997. Car sales totaled 141,558, down 5.5 percent; truck sales were 211,712, up 6.2 percent from last year. Chrysler said Tuesday that it had its best month ever in May, selling 250,031 cars and trucks, a 27 percent increase.
Also reporting higher sales this week were Honda, Mitsubishi, BMW, Volkswagen, Audi, Land Rover, Kia, Mercedes-Benz and Subaru. Nissan sales were off 12 percent at 52,992 cars and trucks. Volvo, Mazda and Hyundai also reported lower sales.
Based on May's strong performance, G.M. and Ford said they expect sales for the full year to come in at the high end of their original forecasts, about 15.2 million cars and trucks. G.M. and Ford had predicted full-year sales would total 14.7 million to 15.2 million cars and trucks.
While auto makers and analysts predict a healthy year for vehicle sales, the quick pace of spring sales may have borrowed sales from the second half of the year. "The terrific numbers in May aren't sustainable," said David Healy, an auto analyst with Burnham Securities Inc. in New York. "The coupons are bringing in car and truck sales from the second half into the spring. But at some point, the auto makers will have to start paying the piper."
The highly competitive vehicle market is likely to keep the level of consumer incentives relatively high throughout the year, analysts said.

Moreover, it lists industry sales and U.S. market share figures during both May 1997 and May 1998 for vehicles sold in the United States. (Source: Ward's Auto Info Bank)(pg. D2)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Japan Braces For Arrival Of 'Big Bang';
Financial Services Industry Is Opening to Foreigners

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 3

 BODY:
The Great Japan Money Rush is on.
With $9 trillion in private savings up for grabs, international banks and money managers are hurtling into Tokyo to stake their claims. Japan's "Big Bang" market liberalization, which began in April, is breaking down the barriers and luring the likes of Travelers Group Inc., which this week bought a 25 percent share of Nikko Securities, the country's third-largest brokerage firm. 
 Merrill Lynch & Company and the GE Capital Corporation have already picked up ailing Japanese institutions or their branches and are now trying to rescue them with Western-style management and marketing techniques. And still other American companies will be making a giant push over the next few months, in part because by December foreign institutions will be allowed for the first time to sell mutual funds in partnership with Japanese banks.
In their struggle to win a larger share of the market in the world's second-biggest economy, the Americans are redrawing the rules of the financial playing field here and sending shock waves down the halls of their Japanese competitors. And though foreigners have stumbled in the dark for years in Japan, this time the prize is too big to ignore.
"I don't think there's any other opportunity in the world three, five, ten years from now that's a larger opportunity than Japan in the asset management business," said John R. Alkire, a managing director who heads Morgan Stanley Asset Management in Japan, a unit of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "If you want to stake out your house in this gold rush, you want to make sure you get your pegs out there as far as you can."
It is not just the Americans who are rushing in; the Swiss Bank Corporation, for example, has formed an asset management venture with Japan's Long-Term Credit Bank. But while other Western institutions are also prospecting here, it is the Americans who have put down the most claims.
The goal is a chunk of the savings of people like Megumi Narita, a young training consultant who keeps her money in a neighborhood bank -- earning less than 1 percent interest. The Japanese are enormously conservative investors, leaving the bulk of their savings in banks and the postal savings system, but young people like Miss Narita are increasingly fed up with the dismal interest rates.
"I often see middle-aged men on the train reading the stock market tables in the newspaper, and I want to buy, too," Miss Narita said the other day, discussing investments with friends. "But as a young woman, I've always been a bit embarrassed to do so. And I never can figure out what the tables say anyway."
The challenge for the Americans will be to persuade Miss Narita, and millions more like her, to take the first step and actually make new investments. Indeed, the money management and insurance landscape has proved to be a minefield for starry-eyed foreign companies in the past. For years, foreign companies banged on doors here, trying to break into this intensely clubby, closed and secretive market.
Merrill Lynch opened three branches in the late 1980's and 1990, only to close them in 1993. Fidelity Investments, the giant mutual fund arm of the Boston-based FMR Corporation, has had an office here since 1969, but its sleepy business did not get very far, until recently. Likewise, after winning its first pension management account in April 1990, Mercury Asset Management Japan Ltd., a unit of Merrill Lynch, had to wait two years before it got a second.
What is different now is that Japan's Big Bang is liberalizing the arcane rules that have fettered the financial industry. Under international pressure to revive its sinking economy and its rigid markets, Japan seems willing to let foreign companies acquire its institutions, or pieces of them, to gain a place on an inside track.
In short, the Americans are now knocking on doors that the Japanese Government appears eager to open.
"For the last 50 years, we have been relatively isolated, insulated from the rest of the world in terms of information technology and finance," said Eisuke Sakakibara, Vice Finance Minister for international affairs. "That has to change."
For that reason, American companies are betting, as they roll out their new marketing strategies, that profits will pile up. After all, many of them remember just how well they did after London's Big Bang in 1986 and New York's May Day liberalization in 1975. Those efforts led to a broad restructuring of the financial markets in Britain and America, and now Americans and Japanese alike are hoping that the liberalization will do the same for Japan.
Yet Japanese companies are also petrified by what they call the Wimbledon phenomenon: since Britain opened up its national tennis tournament to foreigners, few Britons have won the title. Similarly, while Britain's Big Bang made London a major international financial center, British companies wound up playing only a minor role.
It is far too soon to say that the same thing will happen here, but one trend seems clear: American companies are competing with Japanese institutions on their home turf and, in the process, changing the way the market works.
"Foreigners have been a catalyst for change in Japan," said Clifford J. Shaw, president of Mercury Asset Management Japan. "Whatever way it happens, we are going to get from here to there. We are going to get a more efficient financial system."
Certainly, Japanese and American companies have been tying the knot in droves through alliances, partnerships and cooperative ventures in asset management and insurance. The Bankers Trust New York Corporation is forming a business arrangement with Nippon Credit Bank, for instance, while American International Group is interested in acquiring Aoba Life Insurance. And in discussing his company's deal with Nikko, Sanford I. Weill, chairman and chief executive of Travelers, said that a similar arrangement with a Japanese insurance company might be next.
Other American companies are increasing their marketing efforts, and the response has been promising. When Fidelity ran color advertisements in Japanese newspapers last December, telephone inquiries came tumbling in, even though the first ads did not include a phone number. When Fidelity did display its number this spring in two more ads, there was a flood of several thousand calls.
For several companies, business is already rolling in, along with nice fees. Goldman Sachs Investment Trust Management Japan Ltd., a unit of Goldman, Sachs & Company, began selling investment trusts just over two years ago, and now it has $6 billion under management. Similarly, within four months from opening its first trust in December last year, Merrill Lynch brought in $2.5 billion and had to slow sales. Alliance Capital Investment Trust Management Inc. has gathered $5 billion in 17 months.
The competition, of course, is going to become extremely fierce, the profit opportunities are likely to shrink and not everyone, including the operations run by foreigners, may survive. For now, though, there should be enough business to go around, especially because there are so few formidable players.
And while the rules have already been relaxed in pension management, regulations will soon allow companies to offer new and varied kinds of trusts that are similar to American-style mutual funds.
Japanese investors are wary of their own stock market, which has been depressed since the early 1990's, so they have shied from Japanese investment trusts, which tend to put money in domestic stocks and bonds. But many Japanese are now flocking to foreign-run trusts that invest in overseas stocks and bonds because they believe -- sometimes mistakenly -- that the foreign managers have more expertise and better results. Indeed, in April, foreign companies for the first time sold more investment trusts here than the Japanese did.
It is not clear that Japanese customers fully understand what they are getting into, for foreign investments often carry a currency risk, namely that a rising yen will wipe out profits earned abroad. It could take just one bad wave -- a turn in exchange or interest rates -- and the Japanese might go running back to their friendly local brokers, who have visited them in their homes for years and worked hard at forging strong relationships.
Last year, Nomura Securities was caught in a financial scandal and some of its businesses were suspended for up to five months. Commercial customers fled to other underwriters, including Merrill. But now Nomura has recovered and nearly all of that newly won business has disappeared, Merrill says.
"We don't underestimate the value of relationships that Japanese banks have had for many, many years," said John P. Sievwright, the new president of Merrill Lynch Japan Ltd. "They don't fall apart overnight, and they certainly won't fall apart because of Big Bang."
But those relationships are at least fraying, and the American companies are preening their different colors and jockeying for position to catch the stray cash.
Merrill is taking over 33 branches and 2,000 employees from Yamaichi Securities, a fraction of the operations of Japan's fourth-largest brokerage firm, which filed for bankruptcy last fall. Merrill estimated that it would incur net costs of $125 million for leases, furniture, salaries, technology and market development this year. This summer, Merrill will operate the largest non-Japanese brokerage-firm network in the country, though it says its branches will look pretty much the same as when Yamaichi was running them.
There will be important differences, though, aside from new products and the absence of uniforms that female employees had to wear when Yamaichi was in charge. Merrill's employees will be trained as financial planners to offer advice to customers, rather than merely act as brokers. Still, when it opens its doors this summer, Merrill is counting mainly on the old Yamaichi customers to provide business.
As for Fidelity, it is taking a different approach, one much like its direct strategy at home: reliance on the telephone. In addition to a small phone center it has already set up, Fidelity may use a piece of land it recently purchased on the outskirts of Tokyo to build a larger telemarketing operation. So far, it has gathered nearly $3 billion to manage, up nearly 40 percent from the end of 1997.
GE Capital spent $575 million to take over 500 sales offices and the new business of the Toho Mutual Life Insurance Company -- without the debt and other demons from the Japanese company's past -- and has already hung its signs on the doors. Analysts hailed the deal as a smart way to gain entry.
But GE Capital is wary of overconfidence, and it says that to win business it will simply have to do a better job than its Japanese counterparts. It brings with it a few ideas to lower costs, such as centralizing the back-office processing activities and standardizing credit decisions.
"We don't come here and find we can walk all over them, by any means," said K. Rone Baldwin, president of GE Capital Japan. "The fact is that Japanese companies have an enormous capability to improve and change. When challenged, they have been historically able to rise to the occasion."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Mayumi Ohata, above, talks with a customer in Tokyo about buying mutual funds from Fidelity Investments. (Stuart Isett for The New York Times); The challenge for foreign firms will be to make investors of people like Megumi Narita, right. (Kaku Kurita for The New York Times)(pg. D6)
 
Chart: "Teaming Up"
As Japan has opened its financial markets, many foreign investment firms have worked out deals recently to sell through Japanese institutions.

HEADLINE: Russia Passes a Test In Critical Auction Of Treasury Bonds

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 3

 BODY:
Russia's unsteady economy survived a critical test today as the Government sold nearly $1 billion in Treasury bills without paying the colossal interest rates that the bonds traded at just a week ago.
Anxious foreign investors, fearing the Treasury bill auction would fail to draw enough investors, breathed a sign of relief. While the auction did not raise all the money the Government sought, it was judged a moderate success. Stock prices rose in Russia for a second day. But a more skeptical bond market was mixed. 
 Russia also sold $1.25 billion in long-term bonds, so-called Eurobonds, to international investors mostly in Europe and the United States.
But today's auction also illustrated Russia's economic predicament. Since the Government did not raise all of the money it needed to cover debts that are coming due, it will be forced to dip into its reserves.
And the auction raised the question of how long Russia will be able to stagger on without billions of dollars in additional financing from the International Monetary Fund. But President Boris N. Yeltsin has been busy this week lining up support for his policies from business leaders. Page A12.
"They have done well so far," said Al Breach, an economist at the Russian-European Center for Economic Policy. "But this has been a very hairy week, and each week is going to be hairy until investors have more confidence."
Another 5.5 billion rubles in Treasury bills, or about $900 million, comes due next week. The following week still another 8.1 billion rubles, or $1.3 billion, in Treasury notes matures. That has led many investors to argue that billions of dollars in additional loans from the monetary fund and other international organizations are needed to help Russia keep its currency stable and restructure the cost of its short-term debt.
In today's auction, the interest rates ranged from 40 percent to 54 percent.
Russia depends on the sale of Treasury bills to finance its huge budget deficit, which last year was 6.1 percent of the country's gross domestic product. The goal is to reduce the deficit to 5 percent this year through a combination of spending cuts and tax increases. Reducing the deficit is a crucial goal because interest payments on the debt amount to about a third of total spending, more than double the level in the United States.
"The Russian Government cannot carry on paying 50 percent interest rates for a long period of time," said Mr. Breach. "It will kill the budget."
As Russia's markets have been pounded by the global economic crisis, the Yeltsin Government has been desperately trying to reassure investors both at home and abroad.
Foreigners own about about a quarter of the Treasury bills, making Russia's financial stability vulnerable to the calculations and whims of far-off investors who have a tendency to abandon a distressed country just when the money is needed most.
Russia had been making progress pushing down the Treasury bill interest rates when the currency crisis erupted in Asia. As investors lost confidence in emerging markets, however, rates began rising as they began cashing in Russian Treasury bills for rubles.
The investors had contracts with Russian banks that allowed them to convert the rubles into dollars, creating a surplus of rubles and weakening the value of the ruble against the dollar.
Today's auction followed several failed attempts to raise enough funds to pay short-term maturing debt. The auction actually involved three types of Treasury bills known as GKO's. One type matured in 343 days, another in 126 days and another in 7 days -- the shortest Treasury bill Russia has ever issued.
To stir up demand, President Yeltsin summoned Russia's 10 leading businessmen and financiers to the Kremlin on Tuesday and told them they had a duty to invest in Russia.
In selling the bills, the Finance Ministry was determined to hold down its borrowing costs. It was operating on the expectation that investors will soon regain confidence in the market or that interest rates will drop after the monetary fund leads a bailout.
The ministry sold the seven-day bills with an average interest rate of 40 percent. The other bills had an average interest rate of 54 percent.
While those rates are very high for an economy in which inflation is running at about 12 percent, they are a far cry from the 80 and 90 percent interest rates of last week. They are even a bit lower than the interest rates paid on Tuesday by the secondary market in Treasury securities.
But holding down interest costs also meant that the Government did not sell all the bills it offered. The Finance Minister, for example, was ready to sell 2.5 billion rubles worth of seven-day bills. It sold half a billion rubles worth.

HEADLINE: PRIMARIES '98: THE SOUTH;
Gov. James, in Runoff, Tries Body Blows

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 3

 BODY:
After forcing Gov. Fob James Jr. into a runoff in the Republican gubernatorial primary on Tuesday, Winton Blount 3d today cast his coming four-week duel with Mr. James as a chance for Alabama to stop electing leaders who "continually embarrass us."
Several hours later, Mr. James rose to the bait in a news conference performance that Mr. Blount will undoubtedly use to illustrate his point. In essence, the Governor responded by saying that Mr. Blount is fat. 
 Mr. Blount, a wealthy and, yes, portly businessman, had backed up his criticism of Mr. James by recalling moments like the Governor's threat to call out the National Guard in support of a judge's insistence on posting the Ten Commandments in his courtroom. He also referred to the day several years ago when Mr. James mocked the theory of evolution at a state school board meeting by "walking across the stage like a monkey," with his shoulders hunched and arms hanging limply in front of him.
And so when Mr. James, a former college football star who made a fortune in the barbell business, was asked at a news conference to respond to Mr. Blount, he said: "Well, I'm a monkey that's in good shape. I'm not a fat monkey."
Mr. James was asked whether he was saying that Mr. Blount was fat.
"I leave that to you," the Governor replied, "but if he says I'm a monkey, I'm not a fat monkey and I'm not a monkey whose daddy has put $2.5 million in my campaign, either. Make of that what you want to. If he says I'm a monkey, I must say: 'Well, I'm a pretty slim monkey. I'm not a fat monkey.' "
Mr. James's comments were not the first references to Mr. Blount's physique made today by a member of Alabama's first family. Early this morning Mr. James's wife, Bobbie, told reporters for The Birmingham News and The New York Times Regional Newspaper Group that she did not care for Mr. Blount's attacks on her family's ownership of a landfill that has received some business from the state. "He's a big, fat sissy," she told the reporters.
Today the Blount campaign manager, Sonny Scott, said his first instinct was to laugh at Mr. James's remarks.
"But then you realize that this is the Governor," Mr. Scott said. "Governing is supposed to be serious."
Mr. James, whose fervid support for school prayer has made him both a conservative icon and an object of derision, finished first in a five-candidate field on Tuesday, but failed to win the majority needed to avoid a runoff. He took 48 percent of the vote, while Mr. Blount got 41 percent. Former Gov. Guy Hunt, who decided to run after being pardoned from the state ethics conviction that forced his resignation in 1993, finished third, with 8 percent.
The Republican primary has been depicted by Mr. James's strategists and by national leaders of the Christian conservative movement as an important electoral test for the religious right. Until the June 30 runoff, at least, the test remains inconclusive.
In the Democratic primary, Lieut. Gov. Don Siegelman easily defeated his top rival, Lenora Pate, a Birmingham lawyer, by winning 78 percent of the vote. Mr. Siegelman enters the general election with more than $3.5 million in his campaign treasury and the luxury of watching his Republican rivals attack each other for another month.
Tuesday's primary, while posing the potential to divide Republicans in November, proved a landmark for the party in Alabama. The statewide Republican primary turnout of 358,757 shattered the record, of 215,046, set in 1996. For the first time, Republican turnout exceeded Democratic turnout, although by only 1,420 votes.
Mr. James, 63, attributed his runoff to the growing pains of a newly vigorous party. He said he had prevailed in primary runoffs in both of his successful races for governor, one as a Democrat, and would do so again. He urged voters to focus on the state's low unemployment rate, his pledge to reject tax increases and his efforts to improve schools.
Mr. Blount, 54, whose campaign has received $2.5 million in loans from himself and various family members, clearly hopes to make the runoff a referendum on Mr. James. Like many business leaders in the state, he argued that Mr. James's provocative positions on school prayer and his pitched battles against the Federal courts had damaged the state's reputation and handicapped its economic development efforts.
Speaking of Mr. James's recent assertion that the Bill of Rights does not apply to the states, Mr. Blount said, "These are things that bring up images of the past that just aren't as good as we are as a state."
But Mr. James defended his leadership style. "I think he's out to lunch on that," the Governor said of Mr. Blount. "I think my behavior is every bit a gentleman."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Iowans Pick Nominees for Governor
 Jim Ross Lightfoot, the most conservative of three Republicans vying to succeed Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa, easily won his party's nomination in a primary on Tuesday. State Senator Tom Vilsack, the more liberal of two Democrats, won as well, and will oppose him in November.
Mr. Branstad, the nation's longest-serving Governor, is retiring after four four-year terms. Democrats have not held the Governor's Mansion in Iowa for 30 years, and analysts say the Republicans once again go into the fall with big advantages, including Mr. Branstad's continuing popularity.
In the Democratic primary for governor in New Mexico, Martin J. Chavez, a former Mayor of Albuquerque, topped a field of six to win a spot on November's ballot against the first-term incumbent Republican, Gary E. Johnson.
Two House races in New Mexico drew national attention.
In one, State Attorney General Tom Udall, a nephew of former Representative Morris Udall, won a chance to carry his famous family name back to Washington, winning the Democratic primary for the House seat held by Representative Bill Redmond, a Republican freshman.
In the other, for the seat of Representative Steven H. Schiff, a five-term Republican who died in March, the primary winners were Heather Wilson on the Republican side and State Senator Phil Maloof on the Democratic side.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

From South Korea, Boeing To Get $1.35 Billion Order
Despite the Asian economic crisis and declines in airline passenger traffic in the region, Korean Air plans to announce an order next week for 27 new Boeing 737 passenger jets valued at $1.35 billion.
The order is good news for Boeing, which only last week said that weakening demand from Asia would force it to cut production of the 747 jumbo jet next year. Page D3. 

Boeing will stop producing the MD-11 wide-body jet and lay off some workers because of reduced demand for that plane. D3.
 
Stocks Fall on Technology Slump
Declines among technology shares, led by a 4.8 percent drop in the price of Intel on fears of lower earnings, helped push the stock markets lower. The Nasdaq composite index fell 1.1 percent, to 1,742.31. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 87.44 points and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 10.49 points. D7.
 
Treasury prices rose in slow trading. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 5.78 percent, from 5.79 percent on Tuesday. C7.
 
Test of AIDS Vaccine Is Approved
The F.D.A. gave VaxGen Inc. of South San Francisco approval to conduct the world's first full-scale test of a vaccine to prevent infection with the AIDS virus. A1.
 
Approval was also given to a combination of two antiviral drugs to treat liver-destroying hepatitis C. The treatment, known as Rebetron, is made by Schering-Plough. A14.
 
A Talent Manager for Las Vegas
Some lavishly produced shows in Las Vegas, like those including Siegfried and Roy's $50-million-a-year live-animal act (left), are obviously successful. But Steven A. Wynn, the chairman of Mirage Resorts, wants to alter the type of entertainment seen in the gambling resort city. He has hired a top talent manager, Sandy Gallin, to start new theaters, arenas and cabarets, hoping to create shows that will end up on Broadway. D2.
 
Quickening Pace on Madison Ave.
The pace of deals involving interactive advertising accelerated with the announcement of three acquisitions and affiliations involving five New York firms and one in Palo Alto, Calif. Advertising. D4.
 
Some Sighs of Relief in Moscow
Russia's economy survived a critical test as the Government sold nearly $1 billion in treasury bills without paying the colossal interest rates it settled for just a week ago. Anxious foreign investors breathed a sigh of relief. A1.
 
Skeptics wonder if the I.M.F. is applying flawed priorities and policies in Russia. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. D2.
 
Clinton Vow on China Trading Rights
President Clinton announced that he would renew China's trading privileges, signaling that he would not back away from his policy of engagement despite the rising Congressional clamor over whether the Chinese Government illegally contributed to his campaign and used protected American technology to improve its missiles. A10.
 
Ciena and Power of the Marketplace
Solid relationships with big customers represent one factor driving Ciena's acquisition by Tellabs Inc. The company has very good technology but was starting to feel as if doors were closing. D3.
 
More AT&T Managers Retiring
AT&T said it would take a larger charge than expected in the second quarter because more managers than predicted are taking early retirement. But, expecting the charge to be more than offset by gains from the sale of businesses, the company chairman, C. Michael Armstrong, called the results good news. D7.

HEADLINE: House G.O.P. Leaders Agree to End Timber Road Subsidy

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
After years of bitter debate over logging on public lands, House Republican leaders have agreed to end one of the Federal Government's longstanding subsidies for the timber industry.
For decades, timber companies that harvest logs from national forests have been able to offset the costs of roads that they first must carve into the woods. In compensation for those road-building expenses, the Forest Service has given the companies credits that have been used to reduce the price for trees taken from public lands. 
 For years, environmental advocates and opponents of the Government subsidies have fought the practice as economically wasteful and ecologically foolhardy.
The arrangement, which linked logging and road building in a rebate system in which money spent on roads could be counted as partial payment for timber, was seen by environmental advocates as reinforcing two activities that wreak compound damage on forests. Quite apart from the logging, the forest roads break up wildlife habitat and promote erosion that scars the land and fills clean streams with sediment, environmental groups say.
Republican lawmakers on both sides of the debate have decided it was time to concede victory to the industry's opponents and to accept the Clinton Administration's proposals to end the subsidy program, which is known as the timber purchaser road credit.
As part of the compromise, which aides said was endorsed by Speaker Newt Gingrich, the two sides agreed not to propose or support any other amendments relating to forestry when the annual spending bill that pays for the Forest Service's operations comes to the floor this summer.
This tactic is designed to foreclose an effort by environmentalists to cut other road-building programs from the agency's budget.
The proposed accord among Republicans brings together some of the logging industry's most loyal allies and some of its persistent adversaries, as well as chairmen of the House committees that deal with forest policy. Thus, it could effectively snuff out the forest debate.
That is why the deal has nonetheless upset some environmental advocates who oppose all forms of Federal support for logging and have been working for broader reductions in logging on public lands, especially in areas without roads.
The agreement was pushed mainly by Representative John Edward Porter, Republican of Illinois, and it demonstrated the continuing influence of a bloc of 30 to 50 moderate Republicans with pro-environment leanings. It also suggests that the House leadership has little stomach for divisive environmental debates in the last few months before Congress adjourns for elections this fall.
"Congressman Porter regards this as a major victory for environmental common sense as well as a fiscally sound change in policy," said Dave Kohn, Mr. Porter's spokesman. "This is a major victory for the environmental wing of the party."
Among the Republicans who met last Thursday in Mr. Gingrich's office to shake hands on the agreement, aides said, were Representatives Don Young of Alaska, the chairman of the Resources Committee; Helen Chenoweth of Idaho; Ralph Regula of Ohio, chairman of the Appropriations Subcommittee on the Interior; Sherwood Boehlert of upstate New York; H. James Saxton of New Jersey; George Nethercutt of Washington, George P. Radanovich and Wally Herger of California and James C. Greenwood of Pennsylvania.
Although only Republicans have endorsed the deal, it appears likely that they have the numbers to prevail in the House, even if some Democrats object. The Senate would have to agree, as well, for the plan to become law.
Last year a spirited debate on the issue split the House and the Senate in two narrow floor votes, with the industry barely prevailing to protect the road-building program.
Industry officials contend that the program is not a subsidy at all, in the sense that without the road credits loggers would simply offer to pay less for the logs they remove.
"The purchaser road credit has created a lot of controversy, and I think it is unnecessary controversy," said James English, president of Idaho Forest Industry Inc., which runs sawmills in and around Couer d'Alene, Idaho. The company has about 500 employees and annual sales of about $180 million.
"We are not a big company, and it will cost us some money up front, but over all the important thing is to be able to get into the Federal forest to get the timber," Mr. English said. "If we can eliminate this environmental conflict, pitting the environmental movement against us and using the road credits to do it, then I think it is best to get rid of them."
He said his company used to get almost a third of its timber from Forest Service land but it now gets only about 5 percent, as the Forest Service has cut back its sales in the area.
The Forest Service says the dollar value of the credits program has declined in recent years. In 1996 it was worth $41 million. In that year, timber companies bid $450 million for logs from the agency's forests.
The agreement does not, however, mean that no more roads will be built to haul timber from public lands. The Forest Service continues to have its own budget for building and maintaining roads. And timber companies will still build roads, using their own money, to take logging trucks and other equipment into the woods.

HEADLINE: PRIMARIES '98: THE OVERVIEW;
The Tried and True in California Triumph Over the Rich and New

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 3

 BODY:
Despite record spending by a handful of wealthy candidates, Californians embraced the established political order in their primary election on Tuesday and set the stage for a fall contest between two conventional career politicians, the Democratic Lieutenant Governor, Gray Davis, and the Republican State Attorney General, Dan Lungren.
But for all the signs of contentment with the status quo, voters sent a powerful signal of dissatisfaction with a long-standing feature of the once-renowned California public schools, decisively passing Proposition 227, a ballot measure to curtail three decades of bilingual instruction. The initiative was opposed by President Clinton and much of the state's educational establishment, and today a coalition of civil rights groups announced that it had filed suit to block it as unconstitutional. 
 Still, the overwhelming message was one of relative satisfaction in a state that has rebounded sharply from economic and natural disasters, with two-thirds of voters saying California was generally moving in the right direction, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls by The Los Angeles Times and CNN.
Mr. Davis defeated his richer Democratic rivals, who relied almost entirely on their personal fortunes to wage their campaigns, by a ratio of nearly 3 to 1, and even ran slightly ahead of Mr. Lungren, who faced no real opposition for his party's nomination Tuesday.
 A similar dynamic emerged in the race for the Republican Senate nomination, where the State Treasurer, Matthew Fong, staved off a self-financed $10 million challenge from Darrell Issa, a multimillionaire car alarm manufacturer, to win the right to challenge United States Senator Barbara Boxer. And in an election that drew only about 4 in 10 registered voters, a $20 million campaign by organized labor defeated Proposition 226, another ballot measure. Sponsored by Republican Gov. Pete Wilson, it would have required unions to obtain written consent from members before using their dues for political purposes.
"I think collectively Californians are saying, 'Don't rock the boat,' " said Mark DiCamillo, director of the statewide Field Poll in San Francisco. "They do want to make some changes in the direction of the state, but pretty much they're not looking for radical change this year, and that has a lot to do with the health of the state's economy after years of problems. Cautious optimism is the byword now."
It was a striking comeback for Mr. Davis, 55. Just months ago his candidacy was dismissed by many party insiders and pundits, who argued that he could not hope to compete against Al Checchi, a multimillionaire businessman who was making his first run for elective office and spent some $40 million of his own money, the all-time record for a non-Presidential race in the United States. That worked out to about $59 a vote for Mr. Checchi, compared to about $5 a vote for Mr. Davis, who still managed to tie the old record of $9 million for spending in a primary here for governor. Representative Jane Harman spent about $16 million, most of it her own money, for about $24 a vote.
But Mr. Checchi's campaign was today widely viewed as a cautionary tale about the limits of seemingly limitless spending, and the risk that attacks on one rival in a three-candidate field can easily create an opening for the third candidate -- in this case, Mr. Davis.
Throughout the state, it was mostly a day of triumph for familiar faces, including former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., who won 59 percent of the vote to become mayor of Oakland without a runoff, and for former Representative Robert K. Dornan of Orange County, who easily defeated two Republicans to win the nomination to challenge Loretta Sanchez, the Democrat who defeated him in 1996 by just 984 votes.
The sole incumbent to lose his seat was Representative Jay Kim, a Republican from Diamond Bar who pleaded guilty last year to accepting illegal campaign donations and had to campaign long-distance from Washington, where he must wear an electronic surveillance device. He was defeated for the nomination by State Assemblyman Gary Miller.
"The amateur hour is over," Mark Mellman, a veteran Democratic pollsters said of the voters' preference for experienced politicians over untried newcomers.
With 99 percent of precincts reporting in unofficial returns, Mr. Davis had 1,880,030 votes, or 35 percent of the total in the state's new open primary, in which the names of all candidates appeared on the same ballot regardless of party. Mr. Lungren had 1,830,591 votes, or 34 percent, with Mr. Checchi trailing with 682,012, or 13 percent, just ahead of another self-financed millionaire, Ms. Harman of suburban Los Angeles, who drew 663,151 votes, or 12 percent.
Mr. Davis's strikingly strong finish could be a bad omen for Mr. Lungren, 51, a conservative former Congressman from Long Beach. Though Mr. Lungren enjoys support from the state's Republican establishment, he could not muster a stronger turnout, despite spending some $4 million, most of it on television advertising, in an effort to establish a presence against the Democrats' early attacks. At the same time, surveys of voters leaving the polls showed that nearly two-thirds think it is time for a change in control of the governor's office, which has been held by Republicans for the last 16 years, and for 24 of the past 32 years.
"I am overwhelmed by the vote last night," Mr. Davis told supporters at a brief Democratic unity rally this morning in downtown Los Angeles, at which Mr. Checchi and Ms. Harman both pledged their support in the fall campaign.
But he added: "I'm under no illusions. This will be a real challenge, and we'll be tested time and again."
In the Senate race, Mr. Fong, 43, the State Treasurer since 1995, defeated Mr. Issa by a margin of 22 percent to 19 percent, or 1,158,391 votes to 1,028,682. Ms. Boxer, the Democratic incumbent, drew more votes than both her rivals combined, or 2,322,517 for 44 percent of the total.
Overall, according to the voter surveys, Democrats appeared to turn out in higher numbers than Republicans, apparently energized by the campaign against the union dues ballot measure. Nearly 4 in 10 voters belonged to union households, according to The Los Angeles Times/CNN survey.
"That's just extraordinary union turnout," said Bill Carrick, a veteran Democratic strategist who worked for Ms. Harman this year and said he did not believe labor had turned out in such force here since a right-to-work measure was on the ballot 40 years ago.
In the state's last primary for governor, both parties turned out in equal numbers.
Mr. Davis's strategists, taking a gentle victory lap at the party rally this morning, said their surveys had shown throughout the year that Mr. Davis's 23 years' experience in state government, beginning as chief of staff to Mr. Brown, would resonate with voters. His challenge was to get his message ("Experience Money Can't Buy") out over the blizzard of Mr. Checchi's television commercials, many of which harshly attacked Ms. Harman.
"He was what the voters were looking for," said Mr. Davis's media consultant, David Doak. "Sometimes voters just get in a mood, and I told him months ago, 'They're in the mood for you.' "
The one thing voters seemed determined to change was the existing system of bilingual education, in which non-English speakers are taught basic subjects in their native tongue while also learning English. The program, a legacy of the civil rights movement of the 1960's, has been widely denounced as ineffective in preparing a huge new generation of immigrant children for the job market, and pre-election polls had shown majorities of all ethnic and racial groups supporting it, despite the opposition of much of the state's political leadership, including all four governor hopefuls.
The measure won 61 percent to 39 percent in unofficial returns, though black and Hispanic support for it fell below 50 percent. According to The Los Angeles Times/CNN survey, fewer than 4 in 10 Hispanic voters and just under half of blacks backed the measure, while nearly 6 in 10 Asian voters and nearly 7 in 10 whites supported it.
"We won a tremendous victory against overwhelming obstacles," said Ron K. Unz, a multimillionaire software entrepreneur from Silicon Valley who sponsored the measure, which would essentially limit non-English speakers to one intensive year of instruction. "The California immigrant population has also won a victory."
But this morning, a group of Hispanic and civil rights groups announced that they had already filed suit in San Francisco to block the measure as unconstitutional.
"Parents, including immigrant parents, should have the right to make basic choices about their children's education," said Deborah Escobedo, a lawyer with Multicultural Education, Training and Advocacy, one of the groups that sued today. "Proposition 227 takes away these basic rights."

HEADLINE: Federal Court Upholds City Zoning Law to Curb Sex Shops

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's efforts to mold New York City into his vision of a more civil metropolis received a major boost yesterday when a Federal appeals court upheld a zoning law intended to curtail and isolate the scores of X-rated businesses in the city.
Emboldened by language in the ruling that said the law "may be enforced forthwith," city officials quickly announced plans to dispatch inspectors to sex shops throughout the city's five boroughs, beginning this morning. But the officials were forced to rein in their ambitions just minutes later, after learning that the decision would not become official under Federal court rules for up to 21 days. 
 That technicality gave breathing room to lawyers for the sex shop owners in their increasingly desperate attempt to block the zoning law, which bans strip clubs and X-rated book and video shops from operating within 500 feet of residential areas, schools, day care centers, houses of worship -- or each other.
In its unanimous ruling yesterday, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit said that the free speech issues raised by the shop owners had been fully heard and upheld by New York's highest court and that there was no need for the Federal courts to conduct their own review.
But the lawyer for the shop owners said he would now ask the full appeals court to take up the issue. "I have never for a moment lost confidence in our constitutional claims and intend to pursue them all the way to the Supreme Court if I have to," said Herald Price Fahringer, who represents 107 adult-entertainment business owners.
But one more delay in the protracted legal battle did not still the joy of Mayor Giuliani and his aides, or of City Council members like Walter D. McCaffrey, who first proposed the ban.
Mr. Giuliani called the ruling a "particularly significant victory" in his ongoing "quality of life" campaign, and said it should silence critics who contended that the zoning law violated the First Amendment rights of owners.
"This would now be 13, 14, 15, about 16 or 17 separate judges who have looked over this plan and come to the determination that the plan is legal," he said, referring to the series of state and Federal court challenges that the law has faced since it was enacted in 1995.
In fact, the legal avenues available to the store and club owners are rapidly dwindling. While the owners can seek a hearing before the full panel of the Court of Appeals, such appeals are seldom accepted.
Their lawyers could then seek the intervention of the United States Supreme Court, but again there is no certainty that the nation's highest court would agree to hear the case. City officials said that the law would affect 146 of the city's 164 X-rated businesses, although civil and criminal proceedings may delay the closings by as much as a year.
"We expect that many of these establishments will realize that they have to shut down and will do so on their own," said Randy M. Mastro, Deputy Mayor for Operations. "This is the last dance for sex shops."
But some shop owners said they would adapt, not close.
For example, Richard Kunis, the owner of Manhattan Video on West 39th Street, has spent the last several weeks building shelves and accumulating horror movies, war movies and even family-oriented movies, including "On Golden Pond," "Oh God! Book II" and "Holiday Singalong With Mitch Miller."
And Milton Anthony, the owner of Billy's Topless, a bar in Chelsea, said bikinis would provide his performers with the legal cover to dance uninterrupted.
For the Giuliani administration and the City Council, the issue hinged on the impact that strip clubs and adult-entertainment shops have on the city's neighborhoods and economy, from Times Square and Chelsea to stretches of major boulevards in Queens.
"It's a simple proposition," Mr. Mastro said. "We want to keep sex shops away from our neighborhoods, away from our schools, away from our churches."
But the owners of adult-entertainment businesses and several gay rights groups have framed the debate as an attempt to stifle free speech, and, as one sex shop owner said, to "Giuliani-ize the city," eliminating or restricting legal and longstanding ventures that the Mayor finds distasteful.
"This is another example of the new New York City, which is increasingly authoritarian and repressive," said Norman Siegel, the executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, which represents the store's customers.
As the dispute wended through the court system -- with the city prevailing at every turn -- it spawned curious sideshows along the way. In April, for example, 30 strippers and lap dancers staged a provocative protest in City Hall Park, where they and dozens of other demonstrators chanted: "Giuliani, scared of sex, who's he going to censor next?"
The Mayor also eagerly entered the fray. He recently told listeners to his weekly radio program that people who live near sex shops could hurt the businesses by photographing their customers; the suggestion prompted an outcry from civil rights advocates.
And some comments that the Mayor made at a news conference -- that the law would reduce the number of sex shops in the city to as few as 20 -- prompted the owners to charge that Mr. Giuliani actually intended to kill the adult-entertainment industry.
In writing yesterday's decision, Judge Jose A. Cabranes suggested that the Mayor's comments were isolated and did not significantly change the overall complexion of the city's plan, which includes more than 500 relocation sites for businesses that do not conform to the zoning laws. But the owners assert that the sites are impractical because they are in industrial zones in the far reaches of the city.
In a 27-page decision joined by Judges Ellsworth A. Van Graafeiland and Thomas J. Meskill, Judge Cabranes said the shop owners and their customers were not entitled to a new hearing in Federal court on the ground of free speech, given that the New York State Court of Appeals, the state's highest, had already rejected that argument in upholding the law's constitutionality last February.
The judge also found that the state appellate court had applied the same standards as those used by the Federal courts in assessing whether the city had provided enough alternative sites for the sex shops.
As news of the ruling reached City Hall, final victory seemed, for a few hours, to be within the city's grasp. Mr. Mastro, the Deputy Mayor, wielded an appropriate prop -- a baseball bat -- as he summoned reporters to his office to explain how the city would enforce the law.
"City inspectors will hit the ground running tomorrow morning," Mr. Mastro began, resting the bat on his shoulders. "They will be in all five boroughs over the next two weeks. They expect to complete inspections of all of the sex shops of the city."
The Deputy Mayor went on to say that any owner found to be in violation will receive a criminal summons and could face a $5,000 fine and 90 days in jail. He also said the city would file civil lawsuits to secure the shutting down of businesses that defy the law.
"This is the day that we have prepared for," Mr. Mastro said.
Minutes later, city officials learned that they would have to wait at least a few weeks more.
If nothing else, the pause gave Mr. Kunis of Manhattan Video more time.
"We've built all the shelving that's necessary," he said. "And we're prepared to fill the store with violence and horror to make it legal."

German Train Derailment Leaves Scores Dead
A high-speed passenger train roaring through northern Germany hit a concrete bridge pillar and killed at least 80 people, possibly including children on a school excursion. Hundreds more were injured. A1
 
Spy Case Questions
The exoneration of a German career intelligence official accused of spying for Russia has not ended a controversy surrounding the matter in either Germany or the United States, where the case has raised new questions at the C.I.A. about the possible betrayal of American secrets. A1
 
Russia's Bond Sale Successful
Russia's unsteady economy survived a critical test as the Government sold nearly $1 billion in Treasury bills without paying the colossal interest rates at which the bonds traded just a week ago. A1
 
Report of Catholic Complicity
A State Department report says Roman Catholic priests in Rome helped Croatian leaders, who sent as many as 700,000 Serbs, Jews and others to death camps during World War II, hide in Italy after the war and later flee to South America. A9

The Albanian Government said there were signs indicating that the Serbian army might be preparing to enter Albania to hunt separatist rebels from Kosovo Province, in Serbia. A12

Mexico told the United States that it would prosecute American Customs agents and informers who carried out an undercover money-laundering operation on Mexican soil, and that it would seek the agents' extradition to face criminal trial in Mexico City. A5
 
Rewards for Political Killings
Eugene de Kock, one of the apartheid era's most notorious killers, testified that he received medals and was congratulated by generals and at least one Cabinet minister for his work in killing political opponents. The former police colonel appeared in the contempt trial of P. W. Botha, the former President who said he never sanctioned such activities. A11

President Clinton announced that he would renew China's trading privileges, signaling that he would not back away from his policy of engagement despite the rising controversy over his China dealings. A10

Students in Jakarta turned out in force in motorcades of buses and cars to demand, in the happiest manner possible, the downfall of the Government. A10

AIDS Vaccine Approved For Full-Scale Testing
The Food and Drug Administration gave a California company, Vaxgen, approval to conduct the world's first full-scale test of a vaccine to prevent infection with the virus that causes AIDS. The tests will seek to determine how effective the vaccine can be in protecting people exposed to H.I.V. because of high-risk sexual practices or drug use. A1

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Enterprise Zones Named

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
The Brooklyn Navy Yard was among 12 sites in New York designated yesterday by Gov. George E. Pataki as enterprise zones.
The new zones were for areas of the state that had lost jobs because of military and defense cutbacks. Previously, the zones were designated simply because the areas were economically depressed. 
 Enterprise zones provide incentives to businesses like wage tax credits, employee tax credits, capital investment tax credits, sales and local tax relief as well as low-cost power agreements with utilities.
Now, there are about 100,000 New Yorkers employed at more than 2,000 businesses in the state's enterprise zones, which have attracted more than $2.7 billion in investments since 1987.
The other zones designated yesterday are in Clinton, Seneca, Oneida, Herkimer, Albany, Orange, Suffolk, Broome, Montgomery, Tioga, Onondaga and Chautauqua Counties. NICK RAVO

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Internet Service Planned

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Bell Atlantic Corporation of Manhattan will offer high-speed Internet access in Washington, Pittsburgh and Philadelphia in September as it taps into demand for fast Internet connections.
Bell Atlantic will extend the service to the Hudson River area of New Jersey in October, and New York and Boston next year. It will sell the service to consumers and people who work at home for $70 to $190 a month for unlimited use. 
 Bell Atlantic said the technology it will use transmits information over phone lines as much as 250 times faster than the typical modem.
The move to provide high-speed Internet services follows the GTE Corporation, the No. 3 local phone company, which said in April that it would offer such services in 16 states. The Internet-access market will grow to $38 billion in 2002, from $6 billion last year, according to Forrester Research, a technology market data researcher.
