HEADLINE: THE N.B.A. FINALS;
Stern Talks Lockout, Questions Patriotism

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY, June 4

 BODY:
David Stern stopped short of calling them unpatriotic, but he did question the wisdom of players who are considering boycotting this summer's world championships in Athens.
"If the individual players decide to trash their country, that's going to be their decision," Stern said today during his annual address. 
 Flanked by the league's deputy commissioner, Russ Granik, Stern spent much of the news conference at the Delta Center detailing the growing labor strife between the players and the owners. The league is expected to lock out the players July 1 if the two sides cannot agree on a revised collective bargaining agreement.
Patrick Ewing, the union's president, has been advising members of the United States team not play. And Michael Jordan supported that stance today.
"In a heartbeat," Jordan said. "I would be in favor of not playing in the world championship games. If you're going to try to handcuff one side, we have to retaliate."
Granik warned that such a boycott could influence the United States' chances for automatically qualifying for the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney, Australia. Granik, who is also the president of USA Basketball, said if the United States did not win the gold medal in Athens it would have to qualify by playing in a qualifying tournament possibly during the 1999-2000 N.B.A. season.
"Wearing the USA Basketball hat, I have concern," Granik said. "We have not gotten any notice or anything from players that they're not going to play, but people obviously have read the reports that it's being discussed. It will certainly damage USA Basketball in its international relations and its standing in the international community."
Billy Hunter, the players association executive director, said the union was investigating whether the United States could receive a bye because it won the gold medal at the Atlanta Games in 1996 and has never failed to qualify for an Olympics He said he was mindful of the players possibly being betrayed as unpatriotic if they boycotted the games.
Among the league's stars, the team includes Grant Hill and Gary Payton. The possibility of sending college players has been discussed, but no formal decision has been made. "We're always worried about our public image," Hunter said. "I am definitely worried about that. Depending upon what the circumstances are, though, David Stern is in the catbird's seat. We hope we can reach an agreement with the N.B.A. to head off the action."
Because players signed contracts with USA Basketball, Stern is mostly wringing his hands when it comes to the league's involvement. But Hunter added, "We could argue we think USA Basketball is the alter ego of the N.B.A."
The boycott talk is merely the latest salvo fired in the labor battle between the two sides. The players canceled a meeting with the owners in New York on Monday, claiming their proposals were unrealistic.
The key issue over which both sides will haggle this summer involves the league's desire to implement a hard salary cap that would put a ceiling on how much teams can spend each season. Such a proposal would most likely do away with the Larry Bird exception, a rule by which teams can pay their own free agents any amount of money to retain their rights.
"They want a hard cap," Dikembe Mutombo, an executive committee member, told The Atlanta Journal-Constitution over the weekend. "They want to get rid of the Bird exception. They want to tax teams who spend more. We can't live with that."
The owners exercised their right to reopen the existing deal in April after a revenue split amounted to the players' receiving more than 57 percent of basketball-related income. Once the threshold topped 51.8 percent, the owners were allowed to exercise their option.
While the union does not want a ceiling on player salaries, the league is afraid the enormous contracts of a few have severely hampered its economic system.
"It's really very simple," Granik said. "Under our current system too much money is being paid out in salaries. And we need a new system that will bring salary growth in line with revenue growth."
Asked where the two sides are in negotiations with only 27 days left to make a deal before business is interrupted, Hunter said: "I think it'll come to a head when it's apparent there is going to be a lockout. It's incumbent on the N.B.A. to come up with a process or a system that we feel is beneficial to us. We're farther apart now than when we started."

HEADLINE: Let Vendors Pay for Sidewalk Space

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A free-market alternative to the Giuliani administration's ban on street vendors from a 144-block area of Manhattan (editorial, June 4) is to ration congestion by renting sidewalk space to vendors. Take the south side of 42d Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues: If the Sidewalk Vendor Review Panel determines that no more than five vendors should be on that block, it could give those spots to the five highest bidders. This would decrease congestion and bring the city millions in revenue. 
 Why should vendors use prime locations at no cost when store owners have to pay high rents? Like the store owners, if the vendors cannot afford the rent, they should move somewhere else.
 
STEVE SLAVIN
Brooklyn, June 4, 1998
 
The writer is an economist.

HEADLINE: Let Vendors Pay for Sidewalk Space;
Another Pushcart War

 BODY:

To the Editor:
New York City's contention with food vendors (editorial, June 4) dates back to New Amsterdam. Laws banned peddlers -- traditionally immigrants -- from city streets as early as the 1680's. 
 "Dear Mayor McClellan," wrote Harry Plotkin, president of the East Side Vendors Association in 1906, "please do not forget that we are poor people, that peddling is our only means of earning our bread, and that unless you will grant us this right to peddle, we will fall burdens to the city and to the charitable institutions."
It is sad that in the age of workfare, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wants to put some of the hardest working New Yorkers out of work.
Fifty years ago, Fiorello H. La Guardia orchestrated a similar campaign that led to a 1938 law virtually outlawing pushcart markets. It put many people out of work during the Depression.
 
SUZANNE WASSERMAN
New York, June 4, 1998

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
Ethnic Albanian Refugees Flee Yugoslav Army
President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia has unleashed the largest military operation in the Balkans since the end of the war in Bosnia, driving thousands of ethnic Albanians from the border area with Albania and reducing their villages to rubble. A1 

The United States suspended part of a military aid program for Bosnia because its Muslims and Croats refused to cooperate on issues of joint security. A4
 
Indonesian Economic Accord
Indonesia and a group of foreign bankers agreed on a framework for rescheduling nearly $80 billion in debt that has become one of the biggest barriers to restarting the nation's economy. The agreement offers hope that Indonesia's currency could begin to recover, that cash will start to flow again, that companies will not be crushed by their debts and that the country's export industries will flourish once more. A8
 
Plea to Pakistan and India
The United States, Russia, China, Britain and France called on India and Pakistan to freeze their nuclear weapons development and agree not to test nuclear missiles or arm them with warheads. A8
 
Former Official Criticizes China
A former senior Chinese official, Bao Tong, speaking nine years after Beijing's crackdown on civilians in Tiananmen Square, criticized the Government and then challenged it to respect his right to speak out. In Hong Kong, China's newest citizens gathered by the tens of thousands for a vigil to honor those who died. A8
 
Rumors of Mideast Agreement
Two Israeli newspapers published details of what they said was an American plan that would finally restore negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians. Neither American nor Israeli officials would confirm the authenticity of the reported plan, but they did say an agreement could be reached in days. A9
 
Briefings on Iraqi Compliance
Two days of technical briefings on the information that Iraq has been withholding from arms inspectors ended with Richard Butler, the Special Commission's executive chairman, preparing to go to Baghdad with a list of steps Iraq must take if sanctions are to be lifted. A9
 
Swiss Banks Offer Settlement
Switzerland's three major commercial banks were said to have offered a settlement totaling more than $1 billion to end suits brought by Holocaust victims and their survivors, who assert that the banks failed to return their assets after World War II. A9
 
German Trains Out of Service
German authorities, acting a day after Germany's worst rail crash in more than 50 years, pulled scores of express trains out of service after the discovery of a broken wheel and track damage that could have figured in the accident. A3

HEADLINE: Foreign Banks to Allow Indonesia More Time to Repay $80 Billion in Debts

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 4

 BODY:
Indonesia and a group of foreign bankers agreed today on a framework for rescheduling the repayment of nearly $80 billion in corporate and bank debt, which constituted one of the biggest barriers to restarting the economy.
While the agreement is simply a framework for renegotiating the debt on a case-by-case basis, the unexpectedly quick action by 13 foreign banks meeting with Indonesian officials in Frankfurt gives Indonesia the best economic news it has received in months. 
 It is also a boost to the new Government of President B. J. Habibie, who is struggling to assert his legitimacy in the face of calls for an early election.
The agreement provides for a three-year suspension of principal payments on perhaps $60 billion of debt. It also sets up a government debt agency to buffer fluctuations in currency-exchange rates.
In individual cases, borrowers and banks have until December to work out payment plans and submit them to the debt-restructuring board.
It is hard to predict just how much relief the new repayment structure will provide to borrowers, but it will be considerable and prompt. At the start of this year the Government estimated that $35 billion of debt was falling due this year.
The agreement offers hope that the nation's weakened currency could begin to recover, that cash will start to flow again, that moribund companies will not be crushed by debts and that crucial export industries could grow again, turning around the country's deep recession.
In the political turmoil here, economic activity has come to a virtual halt as the banking system reels from bad loans, interest rates have soared, lending has all but stopped, and cash has become scarce.
The intertwined political and economic crises present Indonesia with a perilous outlook in the months ahead. On a visit here today, Stanley Roth, the top official for Asian affairs at the State Department, said the most important factor in economic recovery now would be the restoration of political stability.
Bankers cautioned that the framework was a prelude to individual negotiations and may be only a guide for stretching out loan repayments. "It's not a magic pill," said an official at one bank involved in the pact.
The pact was spearheaded by a committee involving the Chase Manhattan Bank, the largest American lender to Indonesian companies; Deutsche Bank and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi.
For hundreds of Indonesian companies, the framework provides a three-year period in which they would only pay interest on their loans. After that, there is a five-year period in which borrowers can make loan payments presumably at renegotiated interest rates and other terms. It gives banks up to four years to pay some $9 billion in debts owed to other banks that now are generally being deferred by informal understandings. As part of the agreement, Indonesia agreed to pay more than $1 billion in bank debt and trade financing that had been in arrears. And to jump-start trade, the pact provides for financing by foreign banks.
Indonesia also agreed to set up a Government office, the Indonesian Debt Restructuring Agency, that will provide sufficient availability of dollars, marks and yen for repayment of foreign loans and protection against currency-rate fluctuations.
One of Indonesia's biggest problems is that its currency has fallen to about 25 percent of its value against the dollar compared with a year ago. As a result, borrowers have watched their foreign loan payments skyrocket, and many have found it impossible to make repayments.
Indonesia had formally halted debt repayments at the beginning of this year, pending an agreement with international banks.
But economists cautioned that the country's economic and political problems are so severe that there is little chance of a quick turnaround. Inflation this year is expected to climb to 50 percent or more, and unemployment to as high as 20 percent. Overall economic growth is projected to contract by at least 10 percent and perhaps as much as 20 percent. By contrast, the country's economic growth averaged 8 percent a year for the last decade.
Financial analysts said today's agreement was far more complex than previous debt-rescheduling accords reached with Mexico in 1995 and South Korea this year because of the large number of Indonesian banks and corporations and weak financial-reporting requirements.
Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, which recently negotiated a $40 billion Indonesian bailout, praised the bank pact for giving "breathing space to recover." He said it would "have the immediate effect of relieving the pressure on the foreign exchange market, and will help to revive international trade and economic activity."
The Jakarta stock exchange rose by 3.5 percent today on news of the agreement. But reflecting a broad discouragement with the country's economic prospects, the Indonesian rupiah showed little response, remaining at 11,550 to the dollar.
Robert Strong, chief credit officer of the Chase Manhattan Bank, which took a lead role in the talks, cautioned that a recovery was still a long way off. "It's going to be a long process," he said., adding that the banking framework is "a very large step, but just one step on a path that will require a lot of work on everybody's part." He also said the pact gave the banks considerable flexibility in deciding which loans to renegotiate, and which trade financings to extend to which companies.
Under today's agreement, the three-year grace period for corporate borrowers on principal payments would begin in December. .
The Indonesian central bank will administer the new debt-restructuring agency, which will operate like a state trust fund. In providing risk protection and the availability of foreign exchange, it will not subsidize exchange rates. Its role is to provide a limited cushion against fluctuations of the rates.
Government officials estimated that companies owing $60 billion would take part. Another $20 billion is owed by companies that are either too damaged for rescue or strong enough to proceed on their own.
For Indonesian banks, the four years that may be used to repay $9 billion in loans applies to borrowings due through next March. The central bank will guarantee the repayments.
Indonesia will ask international banks to make their "best efforts" to maintain trade financing for one year at the levels that existed at the end of April. The Government estimates that such a deal could release financing for $4 billion to $6 billion in trade for Indonesian companies.
Individual debtors and creditor banks must proceed on their own to reach "an amicable agreement" on repayments, said an American banker in Jakarta. "If the Indonesian company still expresses its inability to repay debt, the bank can start bankruptcy proceedings," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Indonesia in Debt Pact With Foreign Bankers
Indonesia and a group of foreign bankers agreed on a framework for rescheduling nearly $80 billion in corporate and bank debt that has become one of the biggest barriers to restarting the nation's economy. 
 The agreement offers hope that Indonesia's weakened currency can begin to recover, that cash will start to flow again, that moribund companies will not be crushed by debts and that crucial export industries will flourish again. Page A8.
 
Swiss Offer on Holocaust Claims
Switzerland's three major commercial banks have reportedly offered a settlement of more than $1 billion to end suits brought by Holocaust victims and their survivors. A9.
 
Stocks Climb on Economic News
Stocks rebounded as investors were soothed by reports that the economy remains resilient. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 66.76 points, to 8,870.56; the Nasdaq composite, 1.59 percent, to 1,769.95, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, 1.1 percent, to 1,094.83. D6.
 
Bond Prices Are Jolted
In the bond market, Treasury prices dropped sharply, with the yield on the 30-year bond rising to 5.82 percent from 5.78. The market weakened on signs of a strong economy and the Bank of England's surprise move to raise its benchmark lending rate by one-quarter point, to 7.5 percent. That raised yields on British debt securities, making them more competitive. D6.
 
New Oil Agreement Raises Prices
An agreement by Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico to reduce oil production sent oil prices up 2 percent in the futures markets. D6.
 
Warning on Worldcom-MCI Merger
The top European regulator reviewing the proposed $37 billion Worldcom-MCI merger said MCI's proposed sale of part of its Internet business might not be enough to allay his antitrust concerns. D2.
 
Labor Productivity Growth Declines
Growth in the productivity of American workers lapsed to an annual rate of 1.1 percent in the first three months of the year, the Government said. Factory orders rose 1.2 percent in April, the biggest increase in five months. And the number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits surged 30,000 last week. D2.
 
Big, Big Boat Takes to Sea
The Grand Princess -- twice the size of the Titanic -- is on her maiden voyage. The world's largest cruise ship, she cost $450 million and is 50 feet taller than the Statue of Liberty. The cruise industry has several more vessels, just as large or larger, on order from the Italian shipbuilder Fincantieri. A4.
 
Call for Action on Internet Privacy
Civil liberties advocates and children's groups urged the White House to abandon its hands-off stance to Internet privacy regulation. D2.
 
Panel Backs Europe on Tariffs
A World Trade Organization panel, reversing a ruling that favored the United States, said European Union nations can continue to impose tariffs on computer-networking equipment exports ahead of a July 1, 2000, deadline for eliminating all such tariffs. D4.
 
A Credit Card Is Born
The theater industry is stepping up efforts to market itself with the debut of a "Live Broadway" credit card. Advertising. D5.

HEADLINE: Commencement;
Queens Graduates Urged to Press for Change

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Speaking critically of cutbacks in social programs, Allen Lee Sessoms, the president of Queens College, urged about 3,800 graduates of the institution at its 74th commencement yesterday to "use your advantage to change things for the better."
The challenges of today, he declared, are "different and in some ways more insidious" than those of the 1960's when he was a student. He cited as examples legislation to restrict immigration, reduced financial support for public higher education, efforts by some groups to impose their religious beliefs on others, welfare reforms that do not provide positive alternatives and the denial of access to higher education for young, single parents. 
 Speaking at the quadrangle at the center of the campus on Kissena Boulevard, Mr. Sessoms concluded by warning that if enlightened graduates did not participate in the transformation of society, "I can assure you that others, who may not be as forward looking as you, will."
The student commencement speaker was Nikola Duravcevic who fled the draft by the Serbs in the former Yugoslavia in 1991, and made headlines when he led the Borough of Manhattan Community College chess team to twice wrest a chess championship from Harvard.
An economics major and a member of Phi Beta Kappa, Mr. Duravcevic has accepted a position in investment banking at Credit Suisse First Boston Bank.
Mr. Duravcevic praised the Queens community for its hospitality to him and other immigrants, and said he had learned that the purpose of higher education was "to stretch the mind beyond one's own imagination."

HEADLINE: Steinbrenner Warns Vallone to Drop Bid For a Stadium Vote

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Opening a new front in the political battle over the future of Yankee Stadium, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the team's principal owner, all but threatened last night to leave New York City unless Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, abandoned his push for a referendum on whether city money should be used to help build a new ball park.
Mr. Steinbrenner's comments came only hours after City Council leaders, in a rare act of defiance toward Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, unveiled their own plan for the city's next budget. For the last several days, the Mayor and the City Council have been deadlocked over the budget because of Mr. Giuliani's refusal to consider any changes proposed by the Council unless Mr. Vallone gave up his call for a public vote on the stadium issue. 
 In his statement, Mr. Steinbrenner accused Mr. Vallone of using the referendum to bolster his campaign for governor, and added: "Politics has driven more teams from New York City than any of us care to remember, most recently the football Giants and Jets to New Jersey. I do not want to move the Yankees from New York, but I must warn: he is bringing us dangerously close."
The Yankees owner's words were the strongest he has used so far on the subject of the team's future home, and they came a month after he stated that he would make no decision on whether the team would leave its storied home in the Bronx until the end of the season because, he said, the issue had become too emotional and politicized.
Colleen Roche, a spokeswoman for the Mayor, said she had been unaware of Mr. Steinbrenner's five-paragraph statement, which echoed many of the criticisms of Mr. Vallone that Mr. Giuliani and his aides had voiced hours earlier. But aides to the Council Speaker accused the Mayor of pressing Mr. Steinbrenner to issue the statement.
Mr. Steinbrenner's spokesman, Howard J. Rubenstein, said Mr. Steinbrenner had no contact with the Mayor's office before issuing his statement.
Last night, Mr. Vallone responded to Mr. Steinbrenner's comments, saying: "Yankee Stadium is a good debate and everyone should have a say in it. But it's appalling that Mr. Steinbrenner would insert himself into the city budget process on behalf of Rudy Giuliani."
Mr. Vallone has contended that the voters should have a say in whether to use hundreds of millions of dollars in public money for sports stadiums. Mr. Giuliani has said such a vote would galvanize opposition to the idea of building a new stadium on the West Side of Manhattan and push the Yankees owner to look for a new stadium site in New Jersey.
For his part, Mr. Steinbrenner said in his statement that Mr. Vallone was using the Yankees as "a political baseball in what certainly seems like a move he thinks will aid him in his race for governor."
"Mr. Vallone," he said, "is attempting to block the city from even considering Manhattan's West Side as a potential site for a new Yankee Stadium even though an in-depth study commissioned by the city, the state and the Yankees suggested it was the most viable option."
The war of words came at the close of a day in which Mr. Vallone and the Mayor wrangled aggressively over the budget and its tangled connection with the stadium issue.
With the negotiations stalled over the budget, the Council offered its own proposal that is expected to be approved today. That plan, at $34.08 billion, was actually $49 million less than the budget the Mayor proposed a few weeks ago, and contained a few hundred million dollars in changes that, in a year of a $2 billion record surplus, could be expected to be ironed out easily through the usual give-and-take of budget talks.
Nevertheless, the two sides spent the day warring and accusing each other of fiscal recklessness and political duplicity.
"I'm a politician," Mr. Giuliani said. "I understand what's going on. This budget is not about governing the city for the next year. It's about Peter Vallone running for governor. That's what the budget is about: Peter Vallone trying to make a statement in his campaign for governor."
Presenting details of his plan to reporters, Mr. Vallone shot back, "This will be a historic event." Of the stadium question, he said: "This will be the first time a Mayor took an issue and made it an overriding issue more important than the budget. The politics of it are from that side of the hall, not this side."
The Council has never adopted its own budget since acquiring the power to do so under the City Charter revision of 1989. And if, as expected, the overwhelmingly Democratic Council approves the Vallone budget, the action is likely to trigger a series of legal battles with the Mayor, possibly beginning with a veto within the next five days.
A vote for a separate budget would abruptly end a long period of fiscal harmony between the city's two most powerful politicians, whose annual budget negotiations have been complicated this year by Mr. Vallone's gubernatorial ambitions and Mr. Giuliani's desire to secure a new home for the Yankees.
Both men were able to work out painful cuts during the recession a few years ago; this year, New York's current financial boom has given them ample room to propose costly, and competing, projects.
At first, Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Vallone predicted a compromise that would accommodate their personal goals. But budget talks collapsed on Monday.
The Mayor, who wants to use $600 million over the next few years to help pay for new ball parks, including a possible Yankee stadium on Manhattan's West Side, demanded that the Speaker drop his push for a referendum that would ask voters whether taxpayers' money should be used for ball parks. Mr. Vallone, one of several Democrats hoping to oppose Gov. George E. Pataki in November, refused even to discuss the topic.
At the same time, the Council Speaker pushed for steep cuts in the city's personal income tax, a proposal intended to give him a strong selling point on the stump and to pre-empt any criticism that he has supported tax increases in the past. Mr. Giuliani opposed these tax cuts, asserting that the city could not afford them.
The cuts, which would cost the city about $201 million in revenue in the next budget and more than $500 million a year after that, could also jeopardize Mr. Giuliani's plan to use at least $600 million from a commercial rent tax to help pay for new stadiums, especially if Wall Street's torrent into the city coffers turns into a trickle.
Council leaders included the tax cuts in the spending plan that they released yesterday. That plan also seeks to retire $165 million in debt; it restores cuts by the Mayor and finances some new programs, including recycling, library services and after-school programs.
In the spending plan, the Council said it could finance its goals by cutting $112 million from various city agencies, and by recalculating savings the city would get from reduced welfare rolls, lower interest rates paid on its long-term debt, and other areas. City officials described these assumptions as risky.
"When you look at the actual budget document that they have cobbled together, said Randy M. Mastro, Deputy Mayor for Operations, "you should be asking yourselves how much spending increases are really there, how much illusory spending decreases are really there that will have to be painful in future years, how much they've increased the out-year gaps to fund a feel-good election-year budget."
Mr. Mastro declined to say whether Mr. Giuliani would veto items from the plan or veto it entirely. Although the Council could then override his veto, the Mayor has said that he would impound city funds to spend on programs.
As the city government prepared to deal for the first time with a nonconsensus budget, some officials bemoaned that the breakdown would ultimately hurt taxpayers. Councilman Sheldon S. Leffler of Queens said: "Passing our own budget is a prescription for ineffectiveness. The Mayor will hold back spending in many areas, and that will deprive people of what they want. This is not in the interest of the public."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
10 Years After First Sale, Co-op Makes Comeback

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Sales are expected to restart next month at Turtle Bay Towers, putting the 337-unit co-op at 310 East 46th Street back in the market for the first time in a decade.
The plan -- reached by the co-op board and the Rockrose Development Corporation, the sponsor -- is to improve the 26-story structure and sell the 245 unsold apartments, many with terraces and greenhouses. Prices are expected to range from $135,000 to $400,000 for the studio lofts and one- and two-bedroom apartments, with 550 to 1,600 square feet. Those prices, on average, are about 5 to 10 percent higher than what the units sold for in 1988, when they originally went on the market. 
 Market-rate mortgages will also be available to buyers through American Home Mortgage, overcoming a financing difficulty often faced by purchasers in buildings where fewer than 51 percent of the units have been sold. About 95 units are expected to come on the market this year, starting with as many as 18 next month. The wedding-cake style structure, between First and Second Avenues, was converted in 1988 from a rental that Rockrose had reshaped 13 years earlier from a 1929 office and light industrial loft building that had been damaged by a natural gas explosion in 1973. Only 28 percent of the apartments were sold before the recession hit and the market soured, as did the relationship between the co-op board and Rockrose, whose headquarters are in the building's ground-level commercial space.
Several lawsuits between the sponsor and the board further splintered their relationship. Meanwhile, the unsold apartments were rented out.
There are 68 apartments that are leased to rent-stabilized tenants, who are allowed to remain in their units at regulated rents. An additional 177 apartments that are also owned by Rockrose are rented to tenants who replaced residents who had been living in the building when it became a co-op. Tenants in these apartments are not protected by rent regulations, and the market rents that they pay had given Rockrose little incentive to sell their units because the rents exceeded the monthly maintenance charges.
Last fall, Rockrose and the co-op board, encouraged by Manhattan's strong sales market, set their sights on the same goal: selling the unsold units. After seven months of negotiations, they devised a refinancing and building-wide renovation program to make the building more attractive.
The building's $25 million mortgage was refinanced at a lower interest rate in April after Rockrose, which held the mortgage, agreed to waive all but $500,000 of an $11 million prepayment penalty. The new $30 million loan is at a fixed interest rate of 6.63 percent for 20 years instead of the original 10.53 percent, said Andrew J. Singer, chairman of the Singer & Bassuk Organization, which arranged the financing for the co-op. The lender was PruExpress, a subsidiary of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, which is based in Newark.
"This loan indicates that lenders are willing to finance underlying mortgages in less than substantially sold co-ops -- which they had avoided because of the troubles of sponsors in the late 80's -- if the buildings are otherwise financially sound," Mr. Singer said. "As a result, lenders of loans to co-op buyers are following suit."
For Turtle Bay Towers, the new loan will enable the co-op board to make repairs and reduce monthly maintenance fees by 10 percent. The projected monthly fees will range from $800 to $2,200 on most apartments, though they will be as high as $2,700 on a few units.
"This deal took a dead-end situation in terms of refinancing the underlying mortgage and turned it into a positive," said Naomi C. Gardner, a lawyer for the co-op. She said the co-op also borrowed about $3 million to make repairs to the building's facade as well as to unit owners' terraces and greenhouses.
Wayne W. Reckhow, president of the co-op board, is optimistic about the changes. "This is the most significant step taken to improve the building's situation," said Mr. Reckhow, who has owned his apartment for 10 years but has rented it out since 1992. "Now I feel better about the prospects of obtaining a satisfactory sales price."
Rockrose, among other things, also will pay its share of the building's improvements and sell the units a few at a time to people who want to live in the building rather than in a bulk sale to investors.
In exchange, the co-op extended Rockrose's lease on the commercial space, hired the company to manage the building and agreed to the improvement program.
"Along with managing the building, we get $25 million from the payment of the mortgage," said Kevin P. Singleton, vice president and general manager at Rockrose. Rockrose filed an amendment to its offering plan earlier this week with the New York State Attorney General's office. If it is accepted, which is expected within 30 days, sales will begin. Tenants buying apartments, which feature 10- to 12-foot-high ceilings, will be given priority, but not a discount from the asking prices. The units are to sell at an average price of about $250 for each square foot of space.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The co-op board at Turtle Bay Towers and the Rockrose Development Corporation have a new plan to sell the building's 245 unsold apartments. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: AMERICAN LEAGUE: ROUNDUP;
Gooden Wins First For Indians

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:

Indians 3, Twins 2
Dwight Gooden, the former Yankee and Met, won for the first time with the Cleveland Indians, making Jim Thome's three-run homer stand up in a 3-2 victory at Minnesota.
Gooden (1-2) allowed one run and six hits in six innings, allowing the lone run to score on Marty Cordova's second-inning home run. 
 Gooden, a 33-year-old right-hander, was making his third start of the season after opening the year on the disabled list because of biceps tendinitis in his pitching shoulder.
 
Red Sox 9, Orioles 1
Bret Saberhagen allowed one run in seven innings and Darren Lewis drove in three runs as host Boston rebounded from its only shutout loss of the season with a victory over Baltimore.
Red Sox reliever Dennis Eckersley, 43, was placed on the 15-day disabled list yesterday because of a sore right shoulder. Reliever John Wasdin was recalled. Wasdin is 3-2 with a 6.28 e.r.a. in his second season with Boston.
 
Athletics 6, Rangers 1
Rickey Henderson homered for the third time in three games and Jimmy Haynes and Bill Taylor combined on a five-hitter, leading host Oakland.
 
Blue Jays 9, Tigers 6
Shawn Green and Carlos Delgado each hit two-run homers and Ed Sprague had a three-run double as host Toronto beat Detroit.
Sprague's bases-clearing hit in the fifth gave Toronto a 7-2 lead. Then Toronto had to hold off a comeback sparked by Tony Clark's two-run homer and Joe Randa's two-run double that cut it to 7-6 in the seventh.
 
White Sox 7, Royals 1
Jamie Navarro pitched a complete-game eight-hitter and Jeff Abbott hit a three-run home run to lead Chicago at Kansas City.
Navarro (5-6) snapped a personal three-game losing streak. He benefited from inning-ending double plays in the first, second, sixth and seventh.
 
CLEVELAND
The Indians quickly raised $60 million yesterday by selling out all 4 million shares of common stock at $15 each in about one hour. After the offering sold out, the stock was trading in the $14.75 to $15.25 range.
 
SEATTLE
The new $417 million ball park for the Mariners will be called Safeco Field, club officials said yesterday. Under an agreement signed Wednesday, Safeco, the nation's 15th largest insurance and investment company, will pay the Mariners about $40 million -- $1.8 million a year for 20 years with annual inflation adjustments -- plus hundreds of thousands of dollars annually in community projects and other promotional work on behalf of the American League club.

HEADLINE: Motorola Says It Will Cut 15,000 Jobs

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 4

 BODY:
Motorola Inc. announced late today that it would eliminate 15,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, and take a $1.95 billion charge against second-quarter earnings, the direst indicator yet of tough times in the semiconductor industry.
Motorola also warned that it would report an operating loss for the second quarter, its first plunge into the red since the semiconductor industry slump of 1985. 
 The forecast quickly took its toll on the shares of Motorola, which is based in Schaumburg, Ill. After rising 68.75 cents during the day, to $51.50 on the New York Stock Exchange, the share price fell as low as $49 in after-hours trading.
Analysts had already slashed their consensus earnings projections to 20 cents a share from 43 cents after Motorola announced in April that the quarter had begun poorly. But Motorola said then that it expected to finish close to the 23-cents-a- share profit it earned in the first quarter, so today's projection of a loss was a shock.
"Some people have downplayed Motorola's repeated earnings disappointments because of the problems in their communications businesses, but this clearly shows the semiconductor industry is suffering from overcapacity exacerbated by the economic crisis in Asia," said Charles Hill, director of research at the First Call Corporation, a Boston-based firm that tracks corporate earnings estimates of Wall Street analysts.
Indeed, Motorola's bad news merely put an exclamation point on what others in its industry had been reporting. National Semiconductor warned investors early in the spring that Wall Street's projections for its recently completed second quarter were too high. (Those figures have not yet been reported.)
Last month, Analog Devices, a chip maker; Applied Materials, a leading supplier of semiconductor manufacturing equipment, and AMP Inc., the world's leading supplier of connectors and other passive components used on chips, issued similar warnings.
Robert L. Growney, Motorola's president and chief operating officer, said today in a written statement: "It is clearly time to accelerate the implementation of our renewal plan. We are determined to return our financial results to acceptable levels as soon as possible."
Mr. Growney's statement meant things have gotten so bad that it was time for Motorola's largest layoffs and write-offs ever.
The company has suffered a double whammy. Demand in Asia has slowed for many of its cellular phones, pagers and other products, most of which contain Motorola semiconductors. At the same time, there is heightened competition from Asian manufacturers that are desperate for sales and can cut prices without sacrificing profits because their currencies have been devalued.
It has been difficult to offset those problems in the developed world, in part because Motorola has fumbled the move from analog to digital wireless phone technology and the once-rapid growth of its domestic paging business has slowed.
Once the overwhelming leader in cellular phones and systems to serve them, it has lost ground to companies like Lucent Technologies, Nokia, L. M. Ericsson, and Qualcomm.
"The positive side of this is that Chris Galvin has been given an opportunity to take drastic corrective steps and it looks like he's taking it," said Mark McKechnie, an analyst at Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, referring to Christopher B. Galvin, the company's chief executive officer.
Motorola said that the job reductions, associated plant closings in semiconductors and paging operations, and plans to sell poorly performing businesses should eventually save $750 million annually.
The job reductions will take place over the next 12 months. Motorola declined to comment on where the layoffs would be concentrated. The domestic semiconductor operations are based primarily in Arizona.
Mr. Galvin was unavailable for interviews before the company's conference call with analysts, scheduled for Friday morning. In his written comments, he emphasized that the company would continue to invest in growth opportunities and singled out plans to introduce new digital phones in the third quarter. He said that the communications sector of the company had begun to improve and that overall performance should be better "given stabilized economic conditions in Asia."
Motorola earned $180 million on sales of $6.9 billion in the first quarter of this year. Earnings have been slumping since 1995, when they topped $2 billion for the year.
Semiconductor business cycles are nothing new for Motorola. It suffered deep earnings plunges in both the 1970's and 1980's. Motorola has already taken numerous steps in its attempts to cushion the impact of the current downturn and reinvigorate sectors like the cellular phone business, where its own errors have compounded its problems.
The company is in the process of closing a pager factory in Puerto Rico. It also said recently that it was ending a $12.9 billion project to create a network of 66 low-orbit satellites for carrying Internet traffic in favor of investing $750 million for a 26 percent stake in Teledesic, a consortium planning to launch 288 satellites aimed at the same market.
So far, none of those steps have done much to encourage investors who have suffered through the stock's long slide from a peak of $90 last summer. Some analysts predicted shares could fall to the mid-40's after today's news.
 

CORRECTION-DATE: June 6, 1998, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about job reductions planned by Motorola Inc., misstated the number of low-orbit satellites the company had envisioned for a network that it is now abandoning. It was 63 low-orbit satellites, not 66.

HEADLINE: Rainy Season Starts, but Mexico Fires Roar On

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 5

 BODY:
The first showers of the rainy season have fallen across parts of Mexico and Central America but have failed to quench many wildfires that are destroying virgin forests and feeding a smoke cloud that is drifting across the southern United States, officials said today.
Mexican and American officials predicted that some fires, which have consumed millions of acres of forest and grassland across the region, may continue to rage for several weeks. About 150 fires, 23 of them large, very destructive blazes, were burning this week. 
 Agricultural Secretary Dan Glickman, who led an American delegation that flew over vast blazes roaring through one cloud forest in the states of Oaxaca and Chiapas in southern Mexico on Thursday, described them today at a breakfast with reporters here as "a catastrophe." Another senior American official said they were the worst he had seen.
"This disaster in Mexico has to be the most serious of its kind in the world, including Indonesia," said Brian Atwood, director of the Agency for International Development. "The duration of these fires, the complexity of fighting them and the danger to the firefighters, it's the most serious that we've seen."
The United States delegation visited Mexico to coordinate a $5 million assistance program, which includes a heavy-lift helicopter and radios, as well as boots and other safety equipment for 3,000 Mexican forest rangers. Many Mexican firefighters have been wearing straw hats and sandals while battling flames with buckets of water.
Despite the new equipment, Mr. Glickman said that because many fires were raging across virtually impenetrable mountain ravines and ridges "rainfall will have as much to do with extinguishing the fires as anything else."
Some of the fires began in January, then flared into an international conflagration in late April with the beginning of the traditional agricultural burning season. So far, seasonal rains that began this week have not been heavy enough.
"Light rains have begun in some areas but they're not sufficient to extinguish these fires," Mr. Atwood said. A spokesman for Mexico's Environment Ministry agreed today with that assessment.
The American officials praised Mexico's battle to control the fires, in which more than 60 firefighters have died this year.
"They're doing an outstanding job fighting this thing," Mr. Glickman said. Those comments and praise by other American officials contrasted with statements by Mexican conservationists, who have argued that the Mexican and American Governments have been slow to react.
In an interview today, for instance, Homero Aridjis, a prominent Mexican environmentalist, called the Mexican Government's response to the wildfires "really exasperating."
"At first the policy was to minimize the fires," Mr. Aridjis said. "And now that much of our ecological patrimony has been destroyed, the Government is still waiting for rains to put them out. This is like waiting for Godot."
The Environment Secretary, Julia Carabias, defended herself and other officials today against a barrage of similar recent criticisms, saying her Government "took precautions, sounded the alert, acted vigorously and continues to act."
President Ernesto Zedillo, standing at Ms. Carabias's side on a visit to a mountain park burned by recent wildfires that roared through a Mexico City suburb, said, "Our country has suffered what I would characterize as a true ecological tragedy."
He said many, perhaps most, of the blazes had started as out-of-control agricultural fires, set by peasant farmers who prepare their fields for planting by burning the previous year's stubble. Also, forests have been set afire to clear plots for growing marijuana or opium, he said.
"There have been fires caused by narcotics traffickers," Mr. Zedillo said.
A report that the American officials handed out describing fires in the region said Nicaragua had suffered the most. More than 13,000 fires there have seared nearly 2 million acres of land, compared with about 900,000 acres in Mexico. Managua's airport has been closed for eight days in the last three weeks because of smoke, the report said.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Minefield Of What to Do

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
"Thinking the unthinkable" is how the nuclear priesthood refers to it. The Indian and Pakistani nuclear tests have reignited fierce debates over doctrine. Do nuclear weapons make the world a more dangerous or a safer place? Can or should the United States try to prevent other nations from acquiring nuclear bombs?
"A profound test is under way of classical theories of deterrence and international relations," said Michael Krepon, president of the Henry L. Stimson Center, at a packed seminar on the subject in Washington this week. 
 From the moment the United States exploded the atomic bomb in 1945, a small group of American military intellectuals -- the "thermonuclear Jesuits," as Fred Kaplan, in his 1983 book "The Wizards of Armageddon," called them -- quickly understood that nuclear weapons made much of earlier American military thinking obsolete. Beginning at Yale University and later shifting to the Rand Corporation in Southern California, Bernard Brodie, a political scientist and naval strategist, invented nuclear strategy, the military establishment's new catechism.
For the four years that the United States had a nuclear monopoly, it could afford the luxury of visionary ideas. Shortly after the war, it proposed the abolition of nuclear arms, but that was vetoed at the United Nations by the Soviet Union.
In "The Absolute Weapon," published in 1946, Mr. Brodie wrote that the main function of nuclear weapons was deterring wars, not fighting them. Nonetheless, he, Albert J. Wohlstetter, Herman Kahn, Thomas C. Schelling and others soon began systematically contemplating their use. In the 1950's and early 60's, they coined the chilling phrases "counterforce" and "second strike" for the nuclear doctrines they devised.
One of the first public policy expressions of the new strategic thinking surfaced in 1957, says Professor Schelling, a professor of economics and public affairs at the University of Maryland. That year, the Gaither Commission warned President Eisenhower that American nuclear weapons were highly vulnerable to a surprise attack from Moscow. Hence, the panel argued, the Soviets might be tempted to strike first in the hope of wiping out the American bombers that could carry nuclear bombs to their targets. To deter such an attack, the United States needed to make sure it could hit back with a second strike.
So the United States upgraded the Navy's Polaris submarine program and replaced its Atlas and Titan missiles. The new Minuteman missiles, smaller and solid fueled, were theoretically less susceptible to attack because they could be protected in underground silos and fired instantly.
Washington also began a national civil defense program that had children diving under their desks in "duck and cover" drills and what Professor Schelling calls the "fall-out shelter-in-the-backyard craze."
As President Kennedy's Secretary of Defense, Robert S. McNamara raised the contentious issue of how many nuclear weapons were enough to deter an attack. In succession, he gave two different answers that led to the doctrine of deterrence that still dominates much of American strategic thinking.
In a speech in Ann Arbor, Mich., in 1962, Mr. McNamara said that American strategic forces should be aimed at Russian forces, not cities. This counterforce doctrine ushered in the era of what was known as flexible nuclear response and the end of all-out destruction or "massive retaliation." Two years later he refined, or as some said, backed away from that doctrine, however, by urging President Lyndon B. Johnson to insure that if the Russians launched a surprise counterforce strike, the United States would still have enough forces to destroy the Soviet Union's military controls, 30 percent of its population and half its industrial base. What he called "mutual assured destruction," was quickly derided by critics by its acronym, MAD. But for Mr. McNamara, it was the only hope of limiting the military's insatiable appetite for more and more arms and of providing a stable balance of nuclear terror.
 
A New Concern About Other Powers
 In the late 1960's and early 70's, says Spurgeon M. Keeny Jr., the president of the Washington-based Arms Control Association, military analysts grew concerned not just about the arms race between the superpowers (known as vertical proliferation) but also about horizontal proliferation, the spread of nuclear weapons to nonnuclear countries. To counter vertical proliferation, the superpowers signed the so-called SALT II agreement and the ABM Treaty in 1972, which capped the growth of strategic missile launchers and effectively banned missile defense systems. Defense systems were not only exorbitantly expensive but dangerous as well: if a country was sure that its own arsenal was shielded from attack, it might be tempted to take out its opponent's.
To deal with the horizontal problem, the United States signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty in 1968 and imposed export controls on the sale of nuclear technology. Under the treaty, nations pledged to forgo developing nuclear weapons in exchange for help with their civilian nuclear energy programs. They also agreed to international inspection of their nuclear facilities. Only five countries -- the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China, those that had already tested nuclear weapons -- were recognized under the treaty as declared nuclear weapons states.
When the cold war ended, some arms controllers argued that even more progress could be made to curb both vertical and horizontal proliferation. At first those hopes seemed justified, argued William C. Potter, director of the Monterey Institute's Center for Nonproliferation Studies in California. The Russians and Americans signed two more arms control treaties. Meanwhile, by the time some 185 signers met to debate and approve the permanent extension of the Nonproliferation Treaty in 1995, Belarus, Ukraine, and Kazakhstan had agreed to forgo nuclear weapons development and to remove nuclear warheads from their soil. South Africa had given up its seven nuclear devices. Argentina and Brazil had also relinquished a nuclear option, and international inspection standards of atomic sites were strengthened.
Dr. Potter says such accomplishments prompted a "false sense of security." What many analysts now fear is what Dr. Potter called an "erosion of the basic consensus underlining the Nonproliferation and Test Ban Treaties: that having nuclear weapons does not enhance a country's security."
Jayantha Dhanapala, a Sri Lankan disarmament expert and a senior United Nations official, argues that horizontal and vertical nuclear weapons policies are linked. He cites the Canberra Commission on the Elimination of Nuclear Weapons, on which he served, which said in 1996 that stopping proliferation was "inextricably linked to the continued possession of nuclear weapons by a handful of states." As long as the nuclear powers resisted disarmament, as opposed to arms limitation, Mr. Dhanapala said, the perception that nuclear arms enhanced political status and security would remain what he called a source of fatal attraction. He says all nuclear nations should disarm.
Some theoreticians and policy makers agree that horizontal and vertical proliferation are linked but come to the opposite conclusion. Kenneth N. Waltz, an American political scientist who teaches at Columbia, defends nuclear weapons as having deterred a nuclear war for more than 40 years. He argues that their spread would also deter atomic conflicts between other countries -- if it works here, it will work elsewhere.
"The hypocrisy of the America's position is astonishing," he said. "We tell Pakistan and India, neither of which ever signed the NPT and therefore is violating no international commitment, that nuclear weapons are bad for them and that it's bad to test, when we and the Russians have done far more tests over the years than we had any scientific or technical reason to do."
John J. Mearsheimer, a political science professor at the University of Chicago and a Waltz disciple, said that while he was not in favor of the Indian and Pakistani tests, "I would argue that a conflict between them is less likely if they openly have nuclear weapons than without them."
Mr. Schelling says most military theorists and policy makers reject the Waltz-Mearsheimer thesis. "Even if the occurrence of conflict may be less likely," he said, "the consequences of failure would be horrendous." But equally unrealistic, he maintains, are calls for the nuclear powers to relinquish all nuclear weapons, as the Canberra Commission urged and as the writer Jonathan Schell advocates in a new book, "The Gift of Time," (1998). "I live in the real world," said Mr. Schelling, who adds that countries under the United States nuclear umbrella have felt secure even without their own nuclear weapons.
 
Failing to Consider A Lapse of Reason
 Mr. Potter argues that the fatal flaw with respect to deterrence and proliferation theories is that both depend on rationality. "You assume cool and calculating determinations of how your interests are maximized," he said, "which discounts the probability of miscalculation, accident or sheer panic."
Richard Betts, a political science professor at Columbia, echoes the consensus that emerged at the Washington meeting, that neither deterrence doctrine nor the treaties and agreements would be radically affected in the short run by India's and Pakistan's tests.
But Mr. Betts argued that the tests had highlighted the contradiction between the written American pledge to disarm (in the Nonproliferation Treaty) and the longstanding commitment not to disarmament but to arms reductions.
The tests could also reopen long-simmering cold war debates, like whether the United States now needs ballistic missile defenses in a proliferating world. "In some ways, the situation for India and Pakistan is comparable to where we were with the Russians in 1950," he said. Thus their choices could have profound implications for the future of arms control. "If they choose proliferation and the debates lead to international paralysis or inaction," he said, "I would bet we'll see some defections among those who have renounced nuclear weapons in the next few years."

HEADLINE: Toll Reaches 96 as Hunt for German Crash Victims Nears End

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, June 5

 BODY:
With rescue efforts virtually ended after Germany's worst rail crash in more than 50 years, officials said today that the death toll stood at 96.
The train, Inter City Express 884, slammed into a steel-reinforced concrete overpass at 125 miles an hour on Wednesday in the north German town of Eschede. Rescue officials said today that there was an increasing belief among investigators that a broken wheel flung the train from the tracks as it passed over a switch just before it hit the road overpass. 
 On Thursday investigators found damage to the tracks about three and a half miles south of the crash, suggesting that the wheel broke at that point.
Rescue officials in Eschede said today that only 19 of the dead had been formally identified. In many cases, even traditional methods of identification were proving impossible because of extensive head injuries. The police say they want to spare relatives from seeing the mangled bodies until the authorities are sure of their identities.
The authorities withdrew 60 of the 104 high-speed Inter City Express trains from service on Thursday so that they could be inspected for fatigue in their undercarriages. Ten returned to service today. The withdrawal of the trains left Germany's vaunted rail service in chaos.
Some people in Hamburg -- the scheduled destination of Inter City 884 from Munich -- and in Hanover, 35 miles south of the wreck, placed flowers next to the tracks.
Veit Steinle, a spokesman for the Transport Ministry in Bonn, said that investigators had discovered debris along the track before the overpass and that there was evidence that the train had finally swayed out of control some 300 yards before Eschede. But officials said it could take weeks or months before an official inquiry reported on the cause.
Klaus Wurster, a rail expert from Technical University in Berlin, told German television that the failure in the wheel was "completely inexplicable" because the rolling gear of the Inter City Express trains is routinely checked by ultrasound examination every four days. The stricken train had been inspected the day before it crashed, officials said.

HEADLINE: Former Korean Dissident Returns to Land of Exile as Head of State

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, June 1

 BODY:
Fourteen years ago, Kim Dae Jung was a pro-democracy activist living in exile in Washington, struggling with his English and with American officials who saw him as a pest.
"I was an irritant that the State Department and the President wanted to do without," Mr. Kim wrote about the Reagan Administration in his unpublished autobiography. "The White House consistently rebuffed my direct approaches and my request for a meeting with the President." 
 When President Kim of South Korea returns to the United States for a nine-day state visit beginning on Saturday, he will get better treatment. This time he is to stay in Washington at Blair House, the American Government's official guest residence, and address a joint session of Congress.
Mr. Kim, the onetime dissident who became South Korea's President in February, will also get a state dinner at the White House, receive a human rights award and pick up an honorary degree at Georgetown University.
Yet, asked if he was tempted to pick up the telephone at Blair House and place an "I told you so" call to some of the former gate-keepers who used to fend him off, Mr. Kim paused only a moment to savor the idea. He grinned and demurred, but he said he did draw some lessons from his reversal of fortune.
"You have to live long," he said with a sparkle in his eye.
Mr. Kim has indeed lived long -- he is 74 -- and he credits his survival in part to American intervention when Korean dictators planned to kill him. That makes his state visit an especially poignant moment, diplomats and Korean officials say.
Moreover, Mr. Kim in some ways trumpets what are often called American values even more than Americans do.
"The fact that the United States so frequently speaks out on human rights issues in other countries, sometimes to the disadvantage of its own national interests, that is what makes the United States great, that is what makes it earn respect from around the world," Mr. Kim said in an hourlong interview this week in Blue House, the presidential mansion in Seoul.
Still, Mr. Kim acknowledged that in some respects he is now in the position of the officials who fended him off when he was a dissident. Asked if he sometimes faces a choice between his moral principles and the dictates of statecraft, when he ponders whether to speak out on issues like human rights in China, Mr. Kim nodded.
"I am faced with that dilemma," he said. "And certainly I cannot say at this point whether I will or will not make a public statement about that. But I do have a great deal of personal interest in what happens in China and Myanmar, especially Myanmar," he added, referring to the country formerly known as Burma.
These days, Mr. Kim has emerged to some extent as a spokesman for the region and not just his country. The state visit to America will add to his stature and to this regional leadership role, a role that he seems to relish.
"As painful as the current situation is, we wish to use it as much as we can to push through economic reforms, to make our democracy stronger, so that we will be a model for the Asian region, a model that says that you have to promote democracy and the free market in parallel, and that the future of Asia lies in this model," Mr. Kim said.
Yet for Mr. Kim to sustain his role as a model for the region, he will first have to overcome South Korea's economic crisis. And that too is a reason for the state visit: Mr. Kim will begin his visit in the financial capital of New York, not the political capital of Washington, and he will emphasize South Korea's efforts to restructure its economy and woo investors.
"It is of utmost importance that we win foreign investment," Mr. Kim said. "With the capital that comes in with foreign investment, we can pay back our debts. With the foreign capital will come new ways of management, making our management more rational and breathing new life into our economy."
After arriving in New York on Saturday and helping open the Korea Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and speaking to several organizations, Mr. Kim is to go to Washington on Monday for a meeting with President Clinton and his speech to Congress. On Thursday, he will travel to California and deliver a speech at Stanford University and visit Silicon Valley. On June 12 he will go on to Los Angeles, a center for Korean-Americans, and will leave for home the next day.
Mr. Kim was hailed at home as virtually a savior when he took office, even as he lectured his nation on the need to accept the pain of layoffs and restructuring. But in recent weeks, some business analysts have said the steam has gone out of his initiatives.
Mr. Kim disagrees. He said he is concerned about rising unemployment but still confident that South Korea is on the right track to recreate itself as a more open and market-oriented economy.
"What gives me hope is that we are probably over the worst phase of the foreign currency crunch," he said, adding that foreign exchange reserves have risen from $3.8 billion last December to $34 billion today. Interest rates have dropped and a trade deficit has turned into a substantial surplus, he noted.
One concern for foreign investors has been the militancy of South Korean unions, which have been hostile to layoffs and have turned to strikes and sometimes violence to resist restructuring. The unions have agreed to postpone strikes until Mr. Kim's return from the United States, however, and Mr. Kim argues that the worst is over for the labor unrest. He also promises to crack down on unions that break the law.

HEADLINE: House Approves Budget With Deeper Cuts In Spending and Taxes Than in 1997 Deal

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
The House narrowly approved a plan today to cut taxes and spending far more deeply than last year's bipartisan balanced budget deal. The move put Republicans on another ideological collision course with the White House over the size and role of the Federal Government.
Despite the defection of nine moderates unwilling to support spending reductions of the magnitude called for in the budget outline, the Republican leadership succeeded in pushing the measure through by a 216 to 204 vote after a contentious debate and intense arm-twisting. 
 The House plan calls for about $100 billion in tax cuts in the next five years, offset by spending cuts of the same amount. The primary tax cut would be a reduction in the so-called marriage penalty, the provision in the tax code that requires many two-income couples to pay more than they would if they were single.
The plan must be reconciled with a version passed by the Senate that calls for $30 billion in tax cuts and keeps spending largely on the path agreed to by Congress and President Clinton in last year's balanced budget deal. Even after the House and Senate have resolved their differences, the resulting budget plan will not become law but rather will serve as a general guide for drafting spending and tax bills.
The House decided today to increase military spending slightly before accounting for inflation, but to reduce domestic spending substantially. The plan did not specify what programs would be cut from the budget, which will total $1.7 trillion next year, and postponed most of the reductions until later years.
Speaker Newt Gingrich, who worked the House floor until the final moments to insure that wavering moderates voted "yes," said it was clear that the House would have to move in the Senate's direction, diluting somewhat the party's ideological message. House members were also under pressure from many governors to soften provisions that would cut promised welfare block grants to the states.
"We'll be maybe slightly less conservative by the time we're done with the Senate," Mr. Gingrich said after the vote. "The Senate will be a good bit more conservative by the time they're done with us."
But a split-the-difference compromise with the Senate, yielding tax and spending cuts of about $60 billion over the next five years, would put the Republicans into a potentially bruising fight with the White House and Congressional Democrats heading into the fall election campaign.
Despite the prospect of huge budget surpluses for years to come, the two parties were having much the same argument they had two years ago when they expected deficits as far as the eye could see.
In his budget proposal early this year, Mr. Clinton called for more than $100 billion of new spending programs in education, child care and health care, paid for in part by revenues that the White House hopes will be generated by anti-smoking legislation that may pass Congress. Mr. Clinton's budget called for $20 billion of narrowly specified tax cuts.
"After a tough, tight and successful balanced budget plan that is clearly working, this plan reflects an arbitrary desire to cut key areas like education, health care and the environment with little if any analysis of what could really be negative impacts on key priorities," Gene Sperling, the White House economic policy adviser, said of the House proposal.
Moreover, Democratic strategists said, today's vote could give Democrats potent ammunition in their effort to win back control of the House by putting some moderate Republicans in crucial districts on record as favoring what their Democratic opponents in the mid-term elections will portray as extreme cuts.
Still, conservative Republicans seemed to be spoiling for another ideological fight. After having seen their fervor for smaller Government dissipate last year under pressure to reach a budget-balancing compromise with Mr. Clinton, Mr. Gingrich and his lieutenants were eager to reassert their conservative credentials before the elections.
"We don't want to forget the reason people sent us here," said Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the chairman of the Budget Committee and the main author of the Republican plan. "We came to make the Government budget smaller and the family budget bigger."
Mr. Kasich said the spending cuts in his plan amounted to "a penny on the dollar" and were essential to break Washington's tax-and-spend culture.
But Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the senior Democrat on the Budget Committee, said the proposed cuts would fall almost entirely on social programs.
And Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader, said the Republican budget was a replay of the 1995 plan that led to a showdown with Mr. Clinton and a shutdown of the Federal Government. The Republican proposals, Mr. Gephardt said, were "expired milk poured into new cartons."
The most conservative Republicans had pressed for $150 billion in tax and spending cuts. Although the Republican leadership came up with the needed votes, some moderates said they were voting for the plan only reluctantly, fearing that the combination of big tax cuts and unspecified future spending reductions imposed too much of a strain on legitimate Government programs and risked the nation's newfound fiscal health.
"It's like taking out a 30-day note to pay for your dream house that you want to live in for the rest of your life," said Representative Amo Houghton, Republican of New York.
In the floor debate, Mr. Gingrich appealed to party loyalty and warned potential dissidents not to distance themselves from the party's accomplishments of the last few years.
"If you vote against the Kasich budget, you're voting against the team that reformed welfare, the team that cut taxes, the team that balanced the budget, the team that brought discretionary spending under control," he said. "And I think that's wrong."

HEADLINE: Finances Worry Neutrino Researchers

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE 

DATELINE: TAKAYAMA, Japan, Saturday, June 6

 BODY:
As Japanese and American scientists basked in the glow of their monumental discovery of neutrino mass, announced here on Friday, a financial cloud that could hamper future research hung over the 120-member team today.
Through the team's leader, Dr. Yoji Totsuka, the scientists appealed for the Japanese Government's reconsideration of major cuts in financing for the Kamioka Neutrino Observatory, where the discovery of neutrino mass was made. Many of the 300 physicists attending an international neutrino meeting here predicted privately that the discovery could eventually be rewarded with one or more Nobel Prizes. 
 But the Government has been unsympathetic, Dr. Totsuka said in an interview. Faced with severe budget problems, he said, the Government has reduced the Kamioka group's spending by 15 percent and threatens another 15 percent cut next year.
"This may mean shutting down the detector for up to six months, which would have devastating effects on our research," Dr. Totsuka said.
The experiment announced on Friday demonstrated that neutrinos, created by the impact of cosmic rays on the earth's upper atmosphere, "oscillate," or change from one type to another as they reach the ground and pass through the earth. With this discovery, the observatory demonstrated beyond reasonable doubt that neutrinos have mass.
That will require revision of the generally accepted theory of the structure of matter, which is made of quarks, leptons and force-carrying particles. Depending on how large the still-unmeasured mass of neutrinos may be, they could prove to be a significant proportion of the mass of the universe, perhaps accounting for some of the "dark matter" that has not been seen directly but exerts large gravitational effects.
An American member of the Kamioka research collaboration, Dr. James Stone of Boston University, said its big underground neutrino detector, Super-Kamiokande, was investigating a range of major physics problems other than the search for neutrino oscillations on earth.
One project explores the possibility that protons -- building blocks of matter -- may decay. Super-Kamiokande, essentially a water tank the size of a 10-story building deep under western Japan's mountains near here, is also looking for an explanation of the deficit in neutrinos detected from the sun, a problem not solved by Friday's announcement.
The detector also continuously looks for bursts of neutrinos coming from supernova explosions and peculiar explosions called "gamma ray bursters," which may be the most violent events in the universe.
In 1987, the nearest supernova in 400 years exploded in a nearby galaxy, and at almost the same moment that the supernova appeared as a dot of light visible from the Southern Hemisphere, a neutrino detector in Ohio and the Kamioka observatory in Japan picked up a strong neutrino pulse.
The achievement marked the debut of neutrino astronomy.
Dr. James W. Cronin of the University of Chicago, one of the Nobel laureates at the neutrino conference here, called the cuts in financing for the Kamioka observatory alarming and said he would join in an appeal to the Japanese Government.
Another Nobel Prize winner here, Dr. Sheldon L. Glashow of Harvard University, said support for physics research was endangered in many countries.
"Sweden is threatening to withdraw from CERN for financial reasons," he said, "and that could have a ripple effect reducing the financial commitment of other European nations to the coalition."
CERN, the acronym for Europe's high-energy-physics consortium, is building what will be the world's most powerful accelerator, the Large Hadron Collider, in a circular tunnel near Geneva. Congress canceled an even larger accelerator that had been under construction in Texas, but, with American scientists still hoping to work at the cutting edge of particle research, the United States has become a partner in building the European collider.
Major reductions in support of CERN by European nations could delay the new accelerator and other large programs, including those designed to explore the question of neutrino oscillations and mass. One such experiment would direct an intense beam of neutrinos from one of the CERN accelerators near Geneva through the ground about 450 miles to a neutrino detector inside a vehicular tunnel under the Gran Sasso Mountain in northern Italy. The idea is to see whether any neutrinos change type during their long trip through the earth's crust.
"Sometimes the accidents of politics and economics help science," said Dr. Barry C. Barish of the California Institute of Technology, who uses a detector in the Gran Sasso tunnel. "The tunnel was built because local politicians persuaded the Government to appropriate a large sum for infrastructure, and there was a problem finding something to spend it on. The tunnel proved to be a boon for physicists who needed the mountain above it to shield their experiments from unwanted cosmic rays."
American members of the Super-Kamiokande team said they planned to send a letter to the Japanese Government pleading for steady support of the observatory.
"American scientists greatly benefited from the Japanese Government's generosity," Dr. Stone said. "Japan paid for most of the $100 million construction cost of Super-Kamiokande, and the United States put up less than 10 percent, and yet American physicists make up half the research force. We hope the Japanese Government will allow uninterrupted operation of this great scientific instrument."
