LENGTH: 637 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Rally Sharply On Vibrant Economy News
The stock market roared back to life yesterday after the Government said that economic growth remained robust, despite the problems posed by Asia's slowdown. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, after weeks of sluggish trading, rose 167.15 points, or 1.88 percent, to close at 9,037.71, its biggest surge in four months. Broader market indicators also shot higher. Page D3.
 
Consumer Borrowing Surges
The pace of borrowing by consumers more than doubled in April to $5.5 billion, compared with a month earlier, to total $1.25 trillion, the Federal Reserve reported. D2.
 
G.M. Workers Strike
A strike over job security by 3,400 General Motors workers halted work at a components factory in Flint, Mich. The strike could cripple production at 17 of G.M.'s 29 North American production factories within a week. The two sides, which faced a similarly tense labor showdown in 1997, when seven different strikes were staged at factories across the country, were scheduled to negotiate today. A7.
 
Shift in Internet Control
The Clinton Administration said it would turn over the management of the Internet's address system to an international nonprofit group. The decision would remove the last vestige of control by the United States Government over the structure of the global computer network. Management of Internet addresses has become the focus of heated debates and litigation. A1.
 
House Passes Deeper Tax Cut Plan
The House narrowly approved a plan to cut taxes and spending far more deeply than last year's bipartisan balanced budget deal. The House plan calls for about $100 billion in tax cuts in the next five years, offset by spending cuts of the same amount. The primary tax cut would be a reduction in the so-called marriage penalty, the provision in the tax code that requires many two-income couples to pay more than they would if they were single. A9.
 
VW Backed for Rolls Purchase
Shareholders of Vickers voted overwhelmingly to sell Rolls-Royce Motor Cars to Volkswagen for $703 million, rejecting bids from BMW and a group of Rolls enthusiasts, who had hoped to keep the famed luxury car brand in British hands. The deal still needs the approval of Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the aircraft engine company, over use of the Rolls name. D2.
 
No Further Cuts, Motorola Says
The chief executive of Motorola, Charles Galvin, said it did not expect any additional job cuts beyond its announced plans to eliminate 15,000 positions, or 10 percent of its work force, in the next year. Mr. Galvin also said the company, a leading maker of cellular phones and pagers, expects the semiconductor market to shrink by 2 percent this year, a sharp contrast to forecasts of a 17 percent growth rate at the beginning of the year. D3.
 
Belgian Bank Bidding Brawl
Fortis Group raised its bid for Generale de Banque to about $13.4 billion, topping a $12.6 billion offer from ABN Amro Holding N.V. The move elevated the intensity of an unusual bidding battle to form one of Europe's biggest financial services companies in advance of European monetary union next year. D2.
 
Vivendi Sells Electrafina Stake
Vivendi, the French municipal services, media and telecommunications conglomerate formerly known as Compagnie Generale des Eaux, sold its 24.6 percent interest in Electrafina, an energy and communications company, to Groupe Bruxelles Lambert for $1.2 billion. D14.
 
Auto Makers Criticize Crash Tests
American, European and Japanese auto makers told a safety conference that increasingly high-speed Government and insurance industry crash tests were preventing auto engineers from designing sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and large cars that would be less dangerous to other motorists. A7.

HEADLINE: Spending Plan Council Adopted Is Similar to Mayor's

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Except for huge personal income tax cuts, the $34.08 billion budget that the City Council passed yesterday -- the first in the city's history that was approved without the agreement of the Mayor -- included relatively modest changes from a plan Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed only weeks ago.
The Democratic-controlled Council made the tax cut the highlight of the budget -- which passed 43 to 7 -- slashing $201 million next fiscal year and more than $500 million in the years after that. 
 Budget experts said that the greatest impact of the Council's plan will be on the city's long-term fiscal condition, because the tax cuts would permanently eliminate a significant source of revenue.
Mr. Giuliani said the Council's plan would hurt the city's health into the new millennium because it would widen the gap between revenues and expenses.
But Speaker Peter F. Vallone trumpeted many of the changes that the Council, at his urging, implemented for the new fiscal year, which begins on July 1.
Holding up a battered wooden seat from a public school, Mr. Vallone said he thought it was more important to replace students' chairs "than worrying about where and what kind of seats we're going to have and what kind of luxury boxes we're going to have in Yankee Stadium."
The Council's plan added $4 million to buy furniture for public schools. The Council also increased appropriations for a host of other agencies, including $22 million for libraries, $28 million for the Administration for Children's Services, $18 million for cultural affairs, $7.6 million for parks and about $5.5 million each for city hospitals and for the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
In a separate budget for capital projects, the city would borrow $100 million to buy gas furnaces for public schools with coal furnaces. To finance that project, the Council killed several of the Mayor's capital projects, including a $65 million contribution to the privately owned Museum of Modern Art.
However, the budget could change over the next few weeks. While the Mayor can veto part or all of the spending plan the Council approved, Mr. Vallone demonstrated yesterday that he clearly had the support to override a veto, an action that would require a two-thirds vote of the Council's 51 members.
But Mr. Giuliani has also said he is prepared to impound city funds, if necessary, to block the Council budget, a move that would likely end up pitting the two sides against one another in court.
Last night, just hours after Council members gathered to cheer their new budget in the City Hall rotunda, Mr. Giuliani showed how his mayoral powers can throw the Council's plan in disarray.
Under the City Charter, the Mayor reveals what the city can expect in non-property tax revenues only after the Council adopts a budget. Essentially, that means that the Mayor can determine how much money the city will have to spend next year. In its budget, the Council was forced to use tax revenue estimates that the Mayor included in a plan he proposed a month ago.
Last night, the Mayor announced that he expected the city to receive less in taxes than he had anticipated a month ago, a move that could force the Council to agree to spending cuts or to raise the property tax, the one tax it controls.
Council officials accused the Mayor of acting purely out of political vindictiveness, adding that all government fiscal monitors reported that they expected higher tax revenues than the Mayor predicted last month.
"If the Mayor reduces revenues -- contrary to what the City Comptroller and the State Comptroller and the other monitors say -- he's putting the city at fiscal risk," said Bruce R. Bender, Mr. Vallone's chief of staff.
The Mayor has trained his criticism at the plan's long-term impact. City spending is growing faster than revenues, and Mr. Giuliani said the Council's budget means widening deficits by more than $2.2 billion in the years 2000 to 2002. . He added that the Council had tried to cover those future gaps through an unrealistically rosy prediction of the tax revenues the city will collect through 2002.
"This assumes that Wall Street continues to function precisely the way it is and grows over the next three to four years," the Mayor said, "that there is no drop, that for the first time in the history of Wall Street or America, there will be no downturn in our economy at all, at any time in the next three to four years.
"This newest thing that they've done, where they just start pulling revenues out of the air on the assumption that the economy is going to continue to grow at record levels, is a highly irresponsible thing to do," Mr. Giuliani added in a news conference, clutching at the air with his right hand.
Alan G. Hevesi, the City Comptroller, said the Council's plan would increase the deficits, but by about $767 million.
Council officials said future deficits would actually shrink under their plan.
Douglas A. Criscitello, director of the city's Independent Budget Office, said that, except for the personal income tax cuts, the Council's plan hewed to Mr. Giuliani's proposal from a month earlier. The Council's budget calls for about $49 million less in spending than the Mayor's.
"It's not a huge departure from what the Mayor proposed," Mr. Criscitello said. "It's close to what a negotiated budget would look like if negotiations had occurred."
The Council's budget drew praise from many lobbyists and advocates who have been milling inside City Hall this week.
"The Council should be commended for their first budget, which clearly puts children first and encourages working families to work and raise their children in New York City," said Rose Anello, associate executive director of the Citizens' Committee for Children. "It enhances programs that support family life, like after-school programs that will enable working parents to work and not worry about their children."

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Up Again

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
Borrowing by United States consumers grew at a faster pace in April than it did in March, the Federal Reserve reported today. Borrowing rose $5.5 billion in April, to $1.250 trillion, after rising a revised $2 billion in March. Previously, the Fed had said that March borrowing was up $1 billion. Before today's report, analysts had expected an increase of $4 billion for April. Consumer credit has moderated considerably from high levels that persisted from late 1993 through most of 1996. Credit card borrowing rose $2.3 billion in April, after increasing a revised $500 million in March, previously reported as a $600 million rise.

HEADLINE: Jobs Surged By 300,000 Last Month

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
Despite Asian tremors, stock market jitters and fears that America is running out of workers, the economy is still booming. In May, the Labor Department reported yesterday, employers added nearly 300,000 new jobs, unemployment held steady at an almost unbelievably low 4.3 percent -- the lowest rate in 28 years -- and pay continued to rise.
"The U.S. economy has never performed as well," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. "Asia is taking a big bite out of U.S. exports, but domestic demand has stayed very strong." 
 Investors focused on the optimistic side, reasoning that such a show of economic strength bodes well for corporate profits. The stock market rallied yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average up nearly 2 percent, its best gain in four months.
The May jobs figures are only the latest evidence that the economy remains far more robust than most experts expected. Spending on everything from new homes and cars to business equipment has been soaring in recent weeks.
Indeed, the surge in hiring surprised economists who were expecting the unemployment rate to tick up in May and payrolls to rise only modestly. What is more, the Labor Department reported that the job market was stronger in March and April than had previously been reported.
The best labor market since the go-go 1960's is a boon for most Americans who are now enjoying signing bonuses, more frequent raises and, not least, the luxury of choice. The quit rate -- a measure of how confident workers are that they can trade their old job for a better one -- has been hovering close to its highest level since the beginning of the economic expansion seven years ago
Although a tight labor market also increases the possibility that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates to cool the economy, wage inflation is hardly surging. Hourly earnings are now 4.3 percent above their level a year ago. After rising 5 cents in April, earnings edged up another 4 cents, to $12.73.
The sole weak spot in the job market is in industry. Asia's problems have been hitting American exporters hard since the beginning of the year, contributing to a big buildup in inventories and cutbacks in production.
As a result, manufacturers have started to rein in head counts. Factory payrolls, which grew by more than 300,000 in the last two years, shrank for the second consecutive month -- by 26,000.
Indeed, all of the hiring -- 332,000 jobs -- last month was by the dominant service sector, which includes everything from Wall Street and shopping malls to trucking and management consulting firms.
What is fueling the demand for workers -- including, increasingly, the young, inexperienced and least educated -- is not much of a mystery. American businesses and households are on a spending spree that shows few signs of abating and promises to keep the job market tight for the foreseeable future. Consumers are spending more freely than ever, as jammed parking lots at shopping malls and the latest reports from merchants confirm. Just this week Detroit's auto makers reported that May was their best sales month in a dozen years. On Thursday, big retailers reported a 7.1 percent rise in May sales after a gain of 10.2 percent in April, the best monthly increase in 10 years.
It is no surprise, then, that retailers added 89,000 new jobs in May, the second big consecutive increase.
Americans are also buying houses. April home sales were the strongest in history. And furniture, hardware and other items for the home are moving briskly. The decline of 9,000 jobs in construction in May probably reflects the unusual weather patterns of the last few months and comes after builders hired 204,000 workers between October and April.
There is no sign that households are tapped out. Partly because of that hot job market, household income is swelling at a rate that is unusually high by historical standards, nearly 5 percent a year. With inflation running close to 1 percent, if that, "a dollar is a dollar" these days.
The other spur to spending is coming from the stock market, which has quadrupled in value over the last eight years. Half of all Americans have some stake in the market, and they are the ones with most of the disposable income. An economic rule of thumb holds that consumers spend approximately 3 percent of their increase in wealth. That rule seems to be holding now. The personal savings rate has declined from 6.5 percent to 3.5 percent in the last five years; that is an indirect measure of the wealth effect -- $200 billion-plus in extra spending.
Businesses are also spending as if there were no tomorrow. Purchases of new equipment and structures have been booming almost since the beginning of the expansion and show no signs of slowing.
One reason for all the investment is that high stock prices and low interest rates make it more affordable. Equipment orders suggest that investment spending, while it may have slowed a bit from its rise of 27 percent at an annual rate in the first quarter, is still increasing at a double-digit rate.
But while there is no evidence yet that domestic demand is slowing, some drags on growth are already visible. The trade deficit -- which shaved 1.5 percentage points off the economic growth rate in the first quarter -- is expected to widen from the aftereffects of the Asian crisis. "We're going to have a slowdown but there's no reason for it to happen quickly," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at Primark Decision Economics.
The unemployment rate of Americans with college degrees has been hovering around 1.5 percent for some time, but the biggest decline in joblessness over the last year has been among high school dropouts. "They're the only ones left to hire," said David Wyss, chief economist at Standard & Poor's DRI, an economic forecasting firm.
Slower economic growth may not mean that it will become harder to find a job or to get a raise. With the pool of unemployed dwindling and growth in the labor force slow, unemployment is likely to stay low even if the economy expands at just half the recent pace. Thus, said Robert Mellman, chief economist at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, "people will still feel great."

HEADLINE: Rising Storm in the Balkans

 BODY:
President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia is incorrigible. Forced to accept peace in Bosnia, he is now uprooting thousands of ethnic Albanians from the Serbian province of Kosovo. His military campaign, the largest since the end of the Bosnian war, threatens to ignite a wider conflict in the Balkans. America and its European allies urgently need to increase the pressure on Mr. Milosevic to desist.
For the last week, Serbian security forces using helicopters and heavy artillery have terrorized ethnic Albanian civilians near Kosovo's border with Albania. Their ostensible objective is to cut off escape routes used by the Kosovo Liberation Army, an ethnic Albanian guerrilla group that has gained strength in proportion to the brutality of Mr. Milosevic's repression. Kosovo's 1.8 million ethnic Albanians make up 90 percent of the province's population. They have been denied civil rights since Mr. Milosevic revoked Kosovo's autonomy in 1989. 
 Mr. Milosevic's brutal tactics could draw Albania into the conflict. Macedonia, with a large Albanian minority, could also face pressure to intervene. It is even conceivable that Turkey and Greece might enter the conflict as well. American security interests could quickly come into play in such a Balkan brawl. Washington must proceed promptly to reinstate the sanctions it lifted a few weeks ago when Mr. Milosevic agreed to meetings with Kosovo Albanian leaders. It is now clear that he had no intention of conducting those talks in good faith.
Unfortunately, because of Russian sympathies for Serbia, the international sanctions are mild and may do little to persuade Mr. Milosevic to refrain from further violence. America and its European allies need to consider stronger measures. President Clinton has properly declined to rule out a military response if the violence escalates.
Mr. Milosevic's habit is to maul his opponents as long as the rest of the world lets him. When the pain of economic sanctions becomes severe and the threat of force is real, he thinks about retreat. He should know from the NATO bombing campaign that forced him to the peace table in Bosnia that Washington's patience is not infinite.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Return to the Old Ball Game;
Minor Leagues Capitalize on Nostalgia for Sport as It Was

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 5

 BODY:
They filled the brand new Yogi Berra Stadium tonight to watch a team that did not exist until this year and that plays in a league few have even heard of.
No matter. The game was baseball, and for the fans who turned out to see the fledgling New Jersey Jackals take on the Albany-Colonie Diamond Dogs, that was enough to fill every seat. 
 Minor league baseball, a game that used to evoke images of languid summer afternoons on pine board bleachers in some smiley rural corner, has moved in force into the teeming suburbs of metropolitan New York. It is nourished by nostalgia for a simpler version of a game dominated by major league millionaires, and is financed by wealthy businessmen with time and money to play out a childhood dream.
Since 1994, 15 professional minor league teams, of widely varying quality and affiliation, have been formed or have moved into the populous region loosely bounded by Albany, Hartford and Trenton.
At their home opener tonight, the Jackals had Mr. Berra himself, the baseball sage and their stadium's namesake, to throw out the first ball. But he was perhaps the only link to the more famous franchise in the Bronx, and that seemed to suit the fans just fine.
"I'm 15 minutes from home, I bought a season ticket for $8 a game and I'm practically sitting on the field," said George Rauth, who brought his 8-year-old grandson. "It would cost me $8 just to park at Yankee Stadium." (It's $6, to be precise.)
In fact, major league owners helped create the minor league boom by forcing their farm teams to acquire newer, safer stadiums or move. Municipalities, eager for new tax revenue or just hoping to put a few more people on downtown streets after dark, have courted the new teams with money and tax breaks.
Nine new stadiums have been built in the region since 1994, and if Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani gets his way, two more teams -- farm clubs for the Yankees and Mets -- will move into new $20 million stadiums in Coney Island and Staten Island.
It does not seem to matter to fans if the level of play is often short of major, with a mix of aging journeymen and talented but inexperienced youngsters filling the rosters. It doesn't even matter if the noble sport of Maris and DiMaggio, Hodges and Alou has to share billing with the noisy hucksterism of the Dizzy Bat Race, the R.W. Auto Tire T-shirt Slingshot and the Jiffy-Lube Lucky Seat Giveaway.
"I think the response bears out the notion that this region was underserved until now," said Michael McGuire, executive director of the Northeast League, of which the Jackals are a member.
"People will generally drive about 20 miles to go to a minor league game, and when you look at New York and New Jersey and Connecticut, you can find millions of people living that close to a ball park," he said. "From a business perspective, it's like putting in a retail chain."
So the Hudson Valley Renegades, in Fishkill, N.Y., sold out every game last year except for one on Labor Day, even though they had one of the worst records in the New York-Penn League, which has ties to the majors. The Trenton Thunder, which moved to New Jersey from London, Ontario, in 1994, have been first or second in attendance in the double-A Eastern League for the last three years, drawing 446,000 fans last year.
Nationally, the 172 minor league baseball clubs affiliated with Major League Baseball sold 34.7 million tickets last year, compared with 30 million in 1950, when there were 400 teams.
Yogi Berra Stadium was built by Floyd Hall, the chairman of the Kmart Corporation and a resident of Montclair, who spent $15 million on the ball park and an attached complex of two ice rinks. The ball park is on the campus of Montclair State College, whose baseball team will use the stadium in the spring, before the Jackals begin their 84-game season.
Only five of the region's 15 new teams -- the Trenton Thunder, the New Jersey Cardinals, the Hudson Valley Renegades, the Norwich Navigators and the New Haven Ravens -- are affiliated with the major leagues, which has trademarked the term "Minor League Baseball." The others belong either to the three-year-old Northeast League, or this year's rookie, the Atlantic League, whose five teams have only three stadiums among them. The affiliated teams are somewhat disdainful of the independent teams, while the majors insist that none of the lower-echelon teams draw fans away from big league play.
Why the sudden interest? Team owners and club managers point to a robust economy, the bargain basement admission prices and easy access. Above all, they credit the mood of baby boomers as their nests fill up.
"I don't want to sound too philosophical, but for years our society had gotten away from the family doing things together, and people want to get back to that," said Peter Kirk, a partner in three minor league teams in Maryland who is recognized as an expert in marketing minor league baseball. "It's nostalgia for the old ball game, and minor league baseball is just tapping in to that. It's something the family can do together."
A 1990 crackdown by major league owners on aging minor league ball parks also played a part. That year, the majors adopted the Facilities Standards Rule that spelled out in detail what a minor league stadium should look like, from the design of the grandstands and the location of concession stands down to the brightness of field lighting and the number of toilets. Teams that could not comply were forced to move, and as a result Albany lost the Albany-Colonie Yankees to Norwich, Connecticut, where they became the Navigators.
Almost all affiliated minor league stadiums now have picnic areas and playgrounds for restless children, for example. A simple rule like requiring that access to the area under the grandstands be closed to the public suddenly relieved parents of a major worry about letting their children wander off alone, Mr. Kirk said.
"Prior to 1985, when people really started thinking about minor league ball parks, the parks in this country were community facilities that were built for the purpose of playing ball, and not much else," Mr. Kirk said. "The fan portions of these parks were very Spartan -- typically a bleacher section and a few restrooms and food service tucked underneath."
Baseball realized that the old parks were fine for die-hard baseball fans, Mr. Kirk said, but not much more. "We started to realize that there was a whole segment of our communities that were not coming out to these minor league games, or only occasionally, because they were not terribly interested in baseball," he said.
So the leagues began to do some market research. They asked people if they were baseball fans, and almost everyone said yes. Then they asked the self-described fans more probing questions -- to name other teams in their hometown league, for instance, or the pitchers on an opposing team's roster.
"The true fans could do that, but most people couldn't," Mr. Kirk said. "So we knew that if you're a casual fan, you want a ball park that is clean and comfortable, and where, if your kids get antsy after about the third inning, you feel fine about letting them wander around. There is nothing under the grandstands, and you can sit in your seat and watch your kids, or you can go to playgrounds and hang out at the edge of the swings and still watch the game."
What the casual fans get for the $2 parking and $8 box seats is an intimate ball park with seating for 4,000 fans that is so close to the game that the manager's hollering reaches the stands, along with an atmosphere intended to have almost as much circus as baseball to it. Children race the clumsy mascot around the bases between innings (the mascot always loses), comedy acts like Myron Noodleman, professional nerd, or Brackney's Mad Cap Mutts entertain during the seventh-inning stretch, and commercial promotions erupt at all times under the guise of crowd participation games.
So Trenton Thunder fans clapped heartily Wednesday when Joe DePastino hit a home run against the woeful Reading Phillies -- but they screamed and leaped to their feet when Thunder personnel got ready to slingshot a tire company's T-shirt into the seats.
"A lot of what we do here is comedy, because to tell the truth, a lot of the people we get are not really baseball fans -- that's what I've found," said Tony Torre, general manager of the New Jersey Cardinals, a farm team of the National League's St. Louis Cardinals, which moved to New Jersey from Hamilton, Ontario, in 1994.
"They come here and they see a dog catching Frisbees between innings" -- that would be Mr. Brackney and his dogs -- "and you give all the kids a baseball bat and that kind of makes it for them," he said.
Some fans at tonight's game in Montclair also brought bitter memories of the 1994 baseball strike and its canceled World Series. Winfield and Tracy Parsons, sitting in the $6 bench seats, came in part to show their sons Scott and Daniel a game played by hungry young dreamers earning an average of $900 a month.
"I have absolutely had it with the majors, a bunch of overpaid crybabies," said Mr. Parsons, who teaches at Montclair State College. "I want my kids to start getting their baseball experience in a place like this."
Mrs. Parsons favored the practical. "Where else can I take my family out for an evening of good, clean fun for $26? The movies cost more than this."

Moody's Plans to Review Its Ratings for Malaysia

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it might cut Malaysia's credit ratings, warning that the nation's economy will contract this year and cause bad loans to surge amid higher interest rates. The ratings company in New York placed Malaysia's foreign currency rating for bonds and notes and rating for bank deposits on review for possible downgrade. 
 Any lowered rating will make it more expensive for Malaysia to raise money overseas. Malaysia's economy shrank 1.8 percent in the first quarter, its first contraction since 1985.

HEADLINE: Let U.S. Companies Use Chinese Rockets;
Not NASA's Fault

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Gregg Easterbrook (Op-Ed, June 2) is justified in chastising the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for failing to develop low-cost space launchers. But that has little or nothing to do with the launching of United States commercial satellites on Chinese rockets. Chinese rockets are cheap because China still does not operate as a free-market economy. Thus China's agencies can -- and do -- charge whatever they please for products or services they wish to promote. 
 Also, our satellite builders use commercial rockets like those from China because NASA hasn't been permitted to launch any commercial satellites since 1986, after the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, not, as Mr. Easterbrook says, because of NASA's high launching costs.
 
JERRY GREY
Reston, Va., June 3, 1998
 
The writer is a director of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics.

Even as the end of the cold war has brought a decline in Government sales of tanks and jet fighters, the private trade of small arms is booming, Government records show. From annual sales of $2 billion to $3 billion during the cold war, private shipments by American companies rose past $25 billion in 1996. A3

HEADLINE: About New York;
Camera Shy, But on Stage For 3 Brands

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
THE Mendez triplets from Woodside, Queens, are camera shy. This is unfortunate, because their father loves photography. It is also too bad, because their names have a certain quality that courts exposure. In fact, although they just graduated from college yesterday, their names are already in lights and on billboards throughout the world.
And on a few million cameras, too.
They are their own camera club: Konica, Leica and Minolta Mendez. 
 Before they were born 20 years ago in the Philippines, their father, Manuel, so liked a fine German camera that he picked the name Leica for a daughter. When triplets arrived, he added Konica and Minolta to the mix. Nikon was a brief contender, but grandma nixed it. You wonder what would have happened if he had liked, say, the Three Stooges or three-card monte.
It's a little easier for them to live in Queens, where their German, Japanese and Spanish names are just a few more exotic monikers in the melting pot. At least they're not saddled with the expectations placed on two brothers who were named Winner and Loser, according to a police officer who swore he worked with them in upper Manhattan years ago. Imagine, forever knowing which one mom liked best.
The Mendez sisters suffer no such envy.
"He thought we were special because we were triplets," Leica said. "It's like a double joy to have triplets, so he named us after something he liked."
The triplets said they were living in Bahrain when they first got an inkling their names were different. Their father had moved the family there to take a job in graphic design. They were about 10 years old when they were given what was otherwise a routine project.
"In school, we were asked what the meanings of our names were," Leica said. "We were named after products. That annoyed me a bit because I couldn't go up in front of the class and talk about what my name meant."
The sisters got used to the reaction, which in some cases was quizzical, but not for the expected reason.
"The problem was that everybody knew what Konica and Minolta was, but not Leica," said Leica, she of the high-end name. "I used to be bothered by that."
Her sisters nodded, then they broke into one another's sentences as in a tag-team interview. "In the Philippines," Minolta said, "I had more renown as a photocopier."
There was a different reaction when they moved to Woodside a few years ago and enrolled in Queensborough Community College. In a consumer society, people know from brands. Konica and Leica, fine arts majors, had to put up with incessant cracks from classmates who wanted to know if they were into photography.
Said Leica: "I hate cameras."
Minolta became a business and marketing major, naturally, since she had been pitching a product since birth. But brand recognition often led some teachers to assume she was Japanese.
"My economics professor, the first time he heard my name, he didn't stop talking about the Japanese economy," Minolta said. "When we talked about the economy of Japan, they always talked about products like Minolta cameras. It's funny, but my sales and marketing teacher never mentioned anything to me about my name."
AMONG themselves, they call one another Koni and Mini, although Leica is short enough. All in all, the sisters said their names had given them the advantage of making an unforgettable impression on whomever they met.
"It's cool," Minolta said. "People say if they have triplets they would name them after products like Mercury, Ford and some other car."
But there have been those times when they longed for something just a little plainer. Konica is partial to Marie or Claire. Minolta was keen on Mary for a while. That just might be what they call their children someday.
"Normal names," Leica insisted. "They're not going to go through having some weird names."
When the sisters graduated yesterday, many shutterbugs in the audience toted their namesakes. Their father, however, did not, since he replaced the Leica that inspired his imagination. "He uses a Contax now," said Leica, who wants to go into advertising after finishing college. "They say it's better than a Leica."
With that, she displayed the kind of brand loyalty that will serve her well when she starts her advertising career.
"I want to give Leica a kick in the butt, for lagging behind," she said. "What's up with that? Keep up your reputation."

HEADLINE: D'Amato Stirs State G.O.P And Borrows Some Themes

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
Six years after vowing not to run for office again, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato accepted the unanimous nomination of state Republican Party leaders for a fourth term yesterday, then launched into a rousing speech salted with traditionally Democratic themes and appeals to crossover voters.
On the concluding day of the party's two-day convention in Manhattan, Mr. D'Amato's high-test performance seemed intended to energize party workers who had grown bored with the crisply orchestrated event and to remind his supporters about the dangers of complacency, particularly when the top of their ticket, Gov. George E. Pataki, is well ahead in opinion polls. 
 Still, Mr. D'Amato seemed supremely confident, strutting into the convention hall like a triumphant homecoming king to the brassy strains of the theme to "Rocky."
Then, as party operatives led raucous chants of "Six more years" and "Al gets it done," Mr. D'Amato recounted a list of accomplishments that he said made him the most effective Senator in Congress -- from getting mass transit funds for New York City to helping women with breast cancer to closing a polluting incinerator in Nassau County. It seemed clear from his speech and those nominating him that effectiveness would be a core theme for his campaign.
"Day in and day out, people are saying: 'You know what? We may not agree with Al D'Amato on lots of issues -- even my mother doesn't -- but you want to know something? He is a fighter, he cares for the people, he makes a difference,' " said Mr. D'Amato, who discarded his prepared text to speak extemporaneously for much of the speech.
Also yesterday, the delegates unanimously nominated Bruce A. Blakeman, the Presiding Officer of the Nassau County Legislature, for state comptroller.
On Thursday, the convention nominated Mr. Pataki for a second term as Governor; Mary O. Donohue, a State Supreme Court justice, for lieutenant governor; and Dennis C. Vacco for a second term as Attorney General. Unlike the Democrats, who are facing primaries for every statewide seat except comptroller, the Republicans will have none.
Though the hall at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers was filled with party officials from across the state, Mr. D'Amato's remarks in many ways seemed intended for an audience outside the building: the centrist, suburban swing voters who could determine the outcome of a close race.
His 30-minute speech was notably devoid of any attacks on the Democratic Party or the three Democrats seeking to run against him -- Geraldine A. Ferraro, Mark Green and Charles E. Schumer. Though he made passing reference to traditional Republican issues like crime and taxes, he talked more emotionally about fighting for the environment, against insurance companies and on behalf of women. There was no mention of abortion, which Mr. D'Amato would ban, and no attacks on the New York State United Teachers, the powerful teachers' union, which he had made a target months before.
"I don't care whether it's Democrats or Republicans that I have to work on, and with," he said. "Party politics should not stop us from doing the business of the people."
But Mr. D'Amato's would-be Democratic rivals derided the Republican's bipartisanship and centrist talk as hollow opportunism. Mr. Schumer, a Congressman from Brooklyn and Queens, accused Mr. D'Amato of aligning himself with "right-wing extremists" in Congress to cut Medicare and education funding and block gun control. Ms. Ferraro, the former Congresswoman and Vice-Presidential candidate, described him as "squarely in the pocket of the special interests."
And Mr. Green, the New York City Public Advocate, said, "We need a senator who thinks that economic security is more than an overflowing campaign war chest." Mr. D'Amato has raised more than $17 million for his campaign.
Mr. D'Amato called the attacks on his ethics "nonsense."
"Al D'Amato helps his friends -- oh, shocking," he said with mock horror to the delegates. "That must be something that is anti-American. Well let me tell you something. If a friend comes and if an industry that is vital to New York and to this nation needs help, you better believe it I'm going to stand up."
Having said near the end of the grueling 1992 campaign that he would not run again, Mr. D'Amato was asked today if this was his last race. "I'm never going to say that again," he replied, laughing.

LENGTH: 663 words

HEADLINE: Tangled Web

BYLINE: By David Pogue; David Pogue is a columnist for Macworld magazine. His latest book is "Palm Pilot: The Ultimate Guide."

 BODY:

SPEEDING THE NET
 The Inside Story of
 Netscape and How It Challenged Microsoft.
 By Joshua Quittner
 and Michelle Slatalla.
 323 pp. New York:
 Atlantic Monthly Press. $25. 
 A fascinating story lies behind Justice Department-embattled Microsoft's trouncing of the Netscape Communications Corporation, the scrappy software start-up whose groundbreaking Navigator program helped popularize the World Wide Web. Unfortunately, that tale doesn't begin until at least halfway through "Speeding the Net," an expert but long-winded account by the husband-and-wife team of Joshua Quittner and Michelle Slatalla.
The book's first half details the rise of Marc Andreessen, Navigator's pudgy primary programmer. He and his workaholic hacker friends make entertaining, if cliched, characters. Their cars are filled with greasy fast-food wrappers. They rail in E-mail flame wars. They spend weeks at their keyboards with little in the way of showers, exercise or items from the fruit-and-vegetable food group.
Both Quittner and Slatalla are computer columnists: he writes for Time magazine, and she is a contributor to the Circuits section of The New York Times. They do their best to enliven this protracted prologue, writing in a colloquial, thriller-like style and striving to turn software demos into drama and buttoned-down executives into emotion machines.
While this technique may have worked in their previous nonfiction collaboration, "Masters of Deception: The Gang That Ruled Cyberspace," the story this time isn't about on-line skulduggery; at its heart, "Speeding the Net" is about boardroom meetings, stock options and the fundamentally boring process of typing computer code.
As a result, the excitement often has a tacked-on, hyperbolic ring. The Microsoft Corporation's relatively easy ride to Web dominance is called "one of the great corporate battles of the century." The Internet itself -- a forum actually frequented by only a minority of Americans (and even smaller populations elsewhere) -- is billed as "a ubiquitous cultural and economic phenomenon."
When Netscape itself finally appears, the authors hit their stride. Conflict, in the form of Bill Gates, triggers a chain of events that merits the novelistic prose. Over the course of four desperate years, Netscape scrambles to resist Microsoft's onslaught. James L. Barksdale, Netscape's C.E.O., sics the Justice Department's antitrust investigators on Microsoft. The Netscape board gives away stock to its employees as a motivator to improve flagging sales. Finally, hoping to diversify itself out of a Web-browser showdown with Microsoft, Netscape spends millions to acquire other software companies.
The authors clearly sympathize with the panicked crew at Netscape, yet they ignore the possibility that the company may have brought about some of its own problems. In tacking its acquired software onto Navigator, for example, Netscape bloated its crown jewel and may have spread the company too thin. Nor do the authors consider that Netscape lost the war because Microsoft simply created a better product: Microsoft's browser, Internet Explorer, was stable, fast and free, whereas Netscape's $49 Navigator program was buggy.
THE book ends with Netscape's March 1998 last-ditch ploy, in which the company released the source code for Navigator to the public. The slim hope is that independent programmers will refine the software, extending its life in the marketplace despite Microsoft's dominance.
Aside from painting Microsoft as the villain, the authors offer no analysis; "Speeding the Net" is an exercise in pure reporting. At their best, they deftly demystify both the technology and the forces -- legal, economic and personal -- that drive the software business. But by the time the tale is over, the reader is left feeling like Netscape's college-kid programmers: depressed that Microsoft has seemingly squashed yet another innovator, and not quite sure what went wrong.

HEADLINE: Swords Into Plowshares

BYLINE: By Serge Schmemann; Serge Schmemann is The Times's bureau chief in Jerusalem.

 BODY:

THE PROCESS
 1,100 Days That Changed
 the Middle East.
 By Uri Savir.
 Illustrated. 336 pp. New York:
 Random House. $27.95. 
 Uri Savir was a fast-rising career diplomat when he was tapped in May 1993 by Shimon Peres, a remarkable visionary who had held virtually every important post in Israel since its founding, to meet secretly with the Palestine Liberation Organization. Those clandestine meetings in Oslo evolved into a series of agreements on a phased exchange of land for peace, which are to culminate in a final settlement in May 1999. Only 40 at the time, though already Director General of the Israeli Foreign Service and a former consul general in New York City, Savir led Israel's negotiating team through the 1,100 arduous and agonizing days that produced the dramatic agreements -- the "process" of the book's title.
But there is more than one process here. First, of course, "The Process" is an insider's story of how bitter contenders for the same tiny patch of parched land struggled to disentangle their mutual hatreds, grievances and claims. The Oslo agreements were like no other in history, requiring detailed negotiations on everything from Yasir Arafat's title to the positioning of an Israeli security agent at the Allenby Bridge border crossing between the West Bank and Jordan. Given the uncertain future of the Oslo agreements today, politicians, reporters and historians are certain to sift through Savir's detailed account to buttress their continuing arguments. The revelation that Yitzhak Rabin envisioned giving the Palestinians up to 50 percent of the West Bank in three further stages while a final settlement was being negotiated has already made headlines in Israel as counterpoint to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's insistence that an inch over 39 percent would pose a grave security threat to Israel. Savir also confirms that Rabin was prepared to cede the Golan Heights in a deal with Syria.
Some passages in the book seem specifically intended to counter the charges with which Netanyahu successfully attacked Peres in the 1996 campaign. Thus, to the devastating accusation that Peres had "subcontracted" Israeli security to the Palestinians, Savir describes how he firmly declared to the Palestinians: "We will not yield on security for Israelis. We will not make you responsible for it."
Such poking about in the compost heap of recent events would already give "The Process" a respectable place in the huge history of Middle East politics. But there is another process here, a far deeper and far more human one. This is the process by which the Israelis and Palestinians involved in the intense negotiations -- Rabin, Peres and Arafat included -- gradually rose above their deep resentments and hatreds, above the profound habits of suspicion and mutual demonization, to achieve if not always friendship, then at least a recognition of a partnership in a common predicament. The central story of this process is the development of a deep friendship between Savir and Ahmed Qurei, better known as Abu Ala, the chief Palestinian negotiator, and their families. There is also the mutual respect that gradually develops between Rabin and Arafat, and the many other amazing interactions between people only recently sworn to the other's destruction.
The development of that partnership and that wisdom is the real and lasting story of the Oslo talks. The primary focus of this account is the enormousness of the internal transformation required of one Israeli, Uri Savir, and, by implication, of Israelis in general, whose entire history militates against accepting that the Jews may be not only victims but also victimizers, not only David but also Goliath. It is this process that makes Savir's book critical for those -- in Israel and abroad -- who sincerely want to appreciate the real requirements for peace and the real obstacles to it. This is especially important now that Netanyahu and his Government have reverted to treating the Palestinians solely as a conquered nation, negotiating only among themselves on what they are prepared or not prepared to cede, and showing no apparent recognition of the yearnings, sufferings or differences of the Palestinians.
The son of a diplomat, Savir writes that he entered the process already imbued with his father's conviction that "talking to the enemy and influencing his attitudes . . . would not only cure this enmity but help us heal ourselves." Yet it is a long road from the inherited wisdom to Savir's appreciation of the full import of its truth. In the beginning, Savir follows Rabin's lead in couching Israel's motives solely in terms of its own interests: "Israel is a great success story, but the occupation is corrupting our youth."
As the process unfolds, the Israeli negotiators increasingly come to appreciate that their occupation was also corrupting the Palestinians through humiliation and economic degradation. Gradually the Palestinians come into focus as people, as humans, and not as the impersonal "Arab."
A turning point arrives with a fierce outburst by Peres, a man who appears throughout the book several legions ahead of his fellow Israelis in his vision of what can be. During an internal discussion of a deal on Hebron, Israeli military officers express their concern at how the militant Jewish settlers will react. " 'I'm fed up with your fear of what the settlers will say. What gall!' he bellowed. 'You want 150,000 Hebronites to remain under our control because of 400 Jews? . . . I'm telling you that we can break Arafat, if that's what you want. But then we'll be left with Hamas, an intifada and terror.' " The blast took political courage, because it was certain to be leaked to the press -- and was. But what Peres had come to understand was that the success of the negotiations required sensitivity not only to Israeli politics but to Palestinian politics as well.
Soon after, Savir describes his own coming of age in a remarkable passage: "These negotiations, over the powers Israel had exercised for a whole generation, opened an entire world before me. Over the years Israelis had cultivated a self-serving myth that ours was an 'enlightened occupation.' I knew this was a contradiction in terms, but I did not know -- and I think few other Israelis did -- how thoroughly we had invaded the lives of our Palestinian neighbors. We repressed this knowledge as we may have been the first conquerors in history that felt themselves conquered. . . . During 28 years of occupation, about a third of the Palestinian population in the territories had, at one time or another, been detained or imprisoned by Israel. And the whole of the population had, at some time, been grossly humiliated by us."
Despite the confessional tone of this passage, and some bitter sallies at Netanyahu and his right-wing allies, Savir is not a polemicist for a political cause. For all his profound and sometimes emotional involvement, he is never blind to the limitations and failings of the Palestinians, and he is relentless in his denunciation of Arafat for failing to curb terrorism. Savir is a professional diplomat, striving on every page to be fair and factual, and keenly aware of the failings of the peace process, not least the failure of the Labor Government to spread the real message of the Oslo accords among the Israelis. The fact that he wrote this book in English, his second language, seems only to give the account a greater directness.
Savir is not among those who console themselves with assurances that "Oslo is irreversible." Describing the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin by Yigal Amir, a religious nationalist, he muses: "As I write, it is still too soon to tell whether Amir succeeded in killing the peace as well. Those who sang 'The Song of Peace' sit on the opposition benches today, while some of those who chanted 'Rabin is a traitor' are in power." Yet Savir and his new friend, Abu Ala, emerge convinced that the larger understanding they initiated cannot be destroyed. "Shaking hands and building a partnership," he says, "meant not only the renunciation of past hostility but a break with traditions deeply ingrained in each of our societies." On the Israeli side, Savir cites Peres's definition of the Oslo agreements as nothing less than the second stage of the Zionist revolution, "an effort to remove the ghetto from the Jewish ethos decades after it had disappeared from Jewish history."
Those who perceive the Oslo accords as a betrayal of the Jewish people are not likely to give Savir a sympathetic ear, while others are likely to brandish his story as proof of an opportunity missed. But if his father was right, the key to resolving Israel's internal dispute is in looking past the myths and grievances, and seeing the other for what he is.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 36; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 893 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Scott Veale

 BODY:

 Naked
 By David Sedaris. Back Bay/Little, Brown, $12.95.
This funny, venomous and at times sad collection of 17 autobiographical essays focuses on the author's many bizarre experiences, like a week at a nudist trailer park, as well as on his family, particularly his witty, acerbic mother. "Even the bleakest of them contain stuff you shouldn't read with your mouth full," Craig Seligman wrote here in 1997.
 
 The God of Small Things
 By Arundhati Roy. Harper Perennial, $13.
A 31-year-old woman returns to her formerly elegant home in southern India to be reunited with her haunted twin brother, whom she hasn't seen since a calamitous event drove them apart and blighted their lives almost 25 years earlier. Part political fable, part psychological drama, part fairy tale, this first novel is a devastating meditation on the decline and fall of an Indian family. The quality of Roy's narration "is so extraordinary -- at once so morally strenuous and so imaginatively supple -- that the reader remains enthralled all the way through to its agonizing finish," Alice Truax said in the Book Review last year.
 
 The Trouble With Prosperity
 A Contrarian's Tale of Boom, Bust, and Speculation
 By James Grant. Times Business/Random House, $15.
A chronic bear warns that Americans are far too smitten with the stock market, and with an eye toward past economic cycles, he argues that what goes up must come down. The result is "a witty and informative" book, John Rothchild wrote here in 1996. In The Big Ten: The Big Emerging Markets and How They Will Change Our Lives (Basic Books, $14), Jeffrey E. Garten, a former top trade policy adviser to President Clinton, argues that 10 countries -- ranging from India to Turkey -- are rapidly becoming major forces in the world economy. Last year, our reviewer, Alan Tonelson, said that even if the power of these nations is exaggerated, the book "is a welcome . . . corrective" to the Administration's Pollyanna-ish views. The moguls behind today's global communications empires are the focus of The Highwaymen: Warriors of the Information Superhighway, by Ken Auletta (Harvest/Harcourt Brace, $13). The author of this collection of 17 profiles, which has been updated and features a new chapter on Microsoft, "is a superb reporter and seems happiest explicating the nuts and bolts of a company," Judith Newman said here in 1997.
 
 Life Without Water
 By Nancy Peacock. Bantam, $10.95.
A young girl named Cedar, growing up on a primitive commune in North Carolina, describes how she and her mother survived the false utopias of the 60's, and in the process digs deep beneath the peace and love platitudes of the time. In 1996, our reviewer, Francine Prose, called this a "deft, sly, unassuming first novel."
 
 Alvin Ailey: A Life in Dance
 By Jennifer Dunning. Da Capo, $16.95.
This unflinching portrait of the brilliant but deeply tormented choreographer is also a study of black dance in America during much of the century and a social history of the turbulent theatrical world of the 1960's, 70's and 80's. The author, a dance critic for The New York Times, has written a "compassionate and painstakingly reported biography," Mindy Aloff wrote here in 1996. The same publisher has issued another profile of a legendary dancer and choreographer, All His Jazz: The Life & Death of Bob Fosse, by Martin Gottfried ($16.95). The outsize figure that emerges here was furiously driven and immensely gifted in both dance and filmmaking but was also tormented by depression and self-loathing. "The cardinal virtue" of this account is the author's "intimacy with the show-business scene that was Fosse's chrysalis," Ronald Bryden said in the Book Review in 1990.
 
 The Bounty
 By Derek Walcott.
 Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $12.
This volume of poetry ranges from an elegy on the poet's mother to fresh visits to such old haunts as New England, Europe and his home island, St. Lucia. While generally unimpressed with the author's longer works, William Logan said here last year that "Walcott is a master of . . . easy, careless abundance" and admired "the stunned eloquence of his lines." The same publisher has issued another retrospective volume by a major poet, History of My Heart, by Robert Pinsky ($12), which includes portraits of the author's family and boyhood neighbors, among others. "Pinsky has a rare gift . . . for action, character and atmosphere clearly and buoyantly proportioned," R. W. Flint wrote in these pages in 1984.
 
 The Club Dumas
 By Arturo Perez-Reverte. Translated by Sonia Soto.
 Vintage International, $13.
Lucas Corso, a cynical Spanish mercenary specializing in hunting down rare books, gets into trouble when he agrees to authenticate both a missing chapter of "The Three Musketeers" and a 17th-century manual for summoning the Devil. The result is an "intelligent and delightful novel," Margot Livesey said here last year.
 
 Don't Erase Me: Stories
 By Carolyn Ferrell. Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $12.
The eight tales in this debut collection focus on urban young people, describing, for example, the survival techniques of a gay black teen-ager and a woman's path to becoming H.I.V. positive. "It's intimate in the way you used to hope a good book could be," our reviewer, Katharine Whitemore, wrote in 1997. Scott Veale

SECTION: Section 6; Page 84; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 561 words

HEADLINE: Ashamed Of The Boom;
Let's Go on A Guilt Trip

BYLINE: By Denise Dowling; Denise Dowling is a writer based in San Fransisco.

 BODY:
It's spring break, and Karen Bashour, 17, is visiting Tijuana, Mexico, with 14 other students from her high school in Northern California. It's not exactly a vacation, though: at the moment the students are inhaling sewage-runoff fumes from an industrial plant, one of nearly 700 maquiladoras (foreign-owned companies) based in the city. They're also getting a lecture about dismal working conditions from Cesar Luna, an environmental lawyer from San Diego.
The United States' economy is booming, but we're not thinking about the other side, he says. Countries come here, exploit workers and leave a legacy of pollution. Now, what do you plan to do with this information? The students study their shoelaces. We're feeling guilty because we live in luxury, says Andrea Stark, another student. Stark and her friends are all from the Sacred Heart Preparatory School in Atherton, bordering Silicon Valley, a $13,000-a-year private academy catering to kids of the high-tech elite. They're in Tijuana on a reality tour created by Global Exchange, a San Francisco nonprofit group that takes kids and adults on trips like this to inject social responsibility. 
 It may sound like a parody of hurry-up self-improvement, but there's also a likable idealism to the concept, which was hatched by Medea Benjamin, a former nutritionist for the United Nations who co-founded Global Exchange in 1989. The students deserve credit just for showing up. They could be skiing somewhere; they chose to do this.
Called What Do You Mean, Free Trade? the tour is a fast look at the residual miseries of roaring international capitalism. Kicking off on Easter Sunday, the students start at toxic-waste sites in Silicon Valley, explore East L.A. and then head south.
On their first day in Tijuana, they tour a factory run by Smith Corona, a place that reeks of the sulfuric smell of hot plastic. Inside, a teen-age worker wearing a Just Do It T-shirt gives the group a sullen glare. I feel stupid staring like they're in a zoo, whispers Stark. But I don't think the workers resent us. I hope they know we're here to help.
That night's assignment involves trying to interview migrants who plan to sneak into San Diego through the border fence, 14 miles of corrugated steel painted with the words Todo en frente y nada detras (Everything in front and nothing behind). A Mexican official shoos the students away, and the vans haul everyone back to the hotel for reflection.
It struck me how much we have and don't appreciate, says Hannah Scherzer. Like, before, I really wanted my sister's room. I worried that my room is too small.
This 'guilt trip' concerns me, Luna frowns. Once you become proactive, emotions like guilt start to fade. What's our obligation as consumers? That's the big question, of course: what to do. At Niketown in San Francisco the next day, Gardner Loulan, a sophomore, sounds flummoxed. There's so much I want to do, he sighs, but kids don't really have any power. Later, back home, he will briefly feel like "an idiot for eating at McDonald's. Then I thought: This is your life, Gardner. It's not your fault you live in an upper-middle-class family in a first-world country.
For her part, Julia Riechert leaves the trip thinking big. I've always said that when I make millions, I'll go to Mexico and make it better, she says. Now I think, why wait?

HEADLINE: Consumed By The Boom;
All Money, All the Time

BYLINE: By Michael Lewis; Michael Lewis is a contributing writer for the magazine. Ken Kurson, who compiled the statistics throughout this issue, is the author of "The Green Magazine Guide to Personal Finance."

 BODY:
A few years into the current boom, I was invited by a money manager to spend a night in the Connecticut countryside. As I had passed most of that day with him in a Park Avenue office, it did not strike me as especially forward of him to invite me home. But by midnight his wife had gone to bed and it was just the two of us, alone in his living room, with the clackety-clack of the crickets and the squeakety-squeak of a corkscrew opening a bottle of wine. We had arrived at a moment of genuine financial intimacy. Money had become personal. The money manager handed me a full wineglass and said, "I'm going to tell you about some stocks you need to buy." In the next two hours this man described in detail four small companies that could change my life. He had researched them fully. Each one sounded better than the last. I tried to look relaxed about the whole thing, but I did not feel relaxed. As the deals became sweeter and sweeter, I twisted with desire in my chair. At 2 in the morning, having transformed me into a greedy pretzel, the man lowered his voice. "Mike," he said, "this fifth company, it's special." Pause. "This is for you and your family." Pause. "Buy it, put it away and let it make you rich." Pause.
"Molten Metal Technology." He then went on to describe in great financial detail what it was that Molten Metal Technology did, as if that mattered. Meanwhile, I was trying to determine exactly how much of my retirement account I could sink into it. The next morning I called my broker and bought the stock at $19 a share. In the next few weeks Molten Metal Technology leapt from $19 to $29, then from $29 to $36, then from $36 to $41. Then it collapsed. To $2. A few months later the company declared bankruptcy. 
 There was a time not long ago when my financial reaction to that evening would have been of no formal interest to people who study money and human behavior. Academic economists have long assumed that insane financial acts cancel one another out: for every fool who drives up the price of Molten Metal Technology on a cold tip, there is another to drive it back down. And, in any case, observers of high finance have tended to confine their interest to the rich.
But in the past decade or so a couple of trends have rendered the financial madness of jes' plain folk not merely interesting but science. A new subspecies of economics has sprung up, calling itself behavioral finance. Its theorists argue that humanity's strange attitudes toward money find their way into markets, generally. Most economists take grim pleasure in proving markets boringly efficient; these new theorists delight in the bizarre things people get up to with their money. They point out, for instance, that the stock with the ticker symbol MCI, which belongs to a closed-end investment company, moves whenever new information appears about M.C.I., the phone company. (Some shrewd investors capitalize on this phenomenon, buying the fund when the phone company announces good news.) They point out, also, that people overvalue information they receive privately and undervalue information they receive publicly. That is, had I read about Molten Metal Technology the next morning in The Wall Street Journal, I wouldn't have thought twice about it.
The other trend that has dignified the financial emotions of the average citizen might be called trickle-down finance. Credit cards, closed-end mutual funds, open-end mutual funds, I.R.A.'s, employee stock plans, adjustable-rate mortgages -- it is no longer just the very rich who make complicated financial decisions. It's Claude and Maude. About the time they opened their Merrill Lynch cash-management account, and learned all the funny tricks their $43,582.49 should perform, they developed a series of neurotic twitches previously confined to the rich.
Broadly, there are two attitudes toward money: the winner's and the loser's. At the moment, the winner's mentality is on the rise. "If you're so smart, why aren't you rich?" is a phrase that has long been on the tip of the American tongue. In the current boom it has acquired a cousin: "I'm so smart, it is inevitable that I become rich." In the sea of social class, money remains our Great Barrier Reef. It distinguishes people from one another, more than religion, even more than race. People tend to spend time, and everything else, in the company of others who possess roughly similar sums of money. But we Americans do not fully acknowledge this. We exhibit a surprising tendency not merely to envy but also to identify with our economic superiors. The winner gazes across the room at Molten Metal Man, who has many millions more than he ever will, and thinks, I can be rich, too! That swelling sense of well-being you feel in the presence of the guy higher up the money tree contains a delicious, unspoken perception -- you can be he!
The winner is driven by his greed, of course, but also by his fears. He fears, first, not having enough money. His is not the justifiable anxiety of the poor, or of the sinking middle class. It is the tightfisted neurosis of a more or less prosperous human being. Like the very fat person who is obsessed with starving, the winner has lost his ability to distinguish psychological from material need. Oddly enough, the winner also fears perfect satisfaction. He worries that without the desire to make more money he will lose his purpose, like a racing dog that has finally caught up to the mechanical rabbit. His whole life is scheduled on the assumption that he does what he does every day to get even more money. And then -- surprise! -- it turns out that money was just an excuse to avoid thinking very much about the life he was living. Money gives winners a reason to go to work in the morning, even when they shouldn't.
The loser suffers from the opposite neurosis: he uses the world around him to reinforce his conviction that he is destined for financial failure. Even in the current boom there are still people alive who believe that money avoids them as surely as the pole of one magnet avoids another. When the loser encounters someone who obviously has more money than he does, he does not think, Here's my role model. He thinks, I'm not at all like him. He may do this justifiably, because he belongs to that great swatch of lower- and lower-middle-class America that has been untouched by the boom. Or he may do this because his imagination prevents him from doing anything else.
Winner and loser are not synonymous with rich and poor. There are poor winners and rich losers. As a dinner companion, one is not necessarily preferable to the other, although one is more likely to pick up the tab. The loser can be charmingly self-deprecating. Or he can exude bitter hostility toward the whole enterprise of free-market life. In either case he usually exhibits at least a trace of masochism: at some level he enjoys being tortured by money.
Necessarily, I oversimplify. The mentalities of winner and loser often jostle for supremacy in the same mind. Two years ago, for instance, when I bought Molten Metal Technology, I found myself thrown back and forth by the horns of opposing sentiments. When the stock began to rise, my first emotion was relief that it did not fall. Soon followed self-celebration: what a genius I was to have coaxed such advice from the money manager. But immediately after glee rushed guilt: what exactly had I done to deserve this good fortune? Nothing.
In the end came terror, waving its summons. The more money I made, the more reason I had to be punished. My retirement years were no longer my own; they belonged to Molten Metal Technology. Three months after being driven to this singular act of money madness, I began to fear for myself, and my family. And moments before Molten Metal Technology came a cropper, with the stock at $40 a share, I sold it.
The tale thus ended on an enriching note, though at no point was I motivated by anything that could be said to be good or pure. At no point did I have an intelligent thought about Molten Metal Technology. I never did figure out which metals the company molted, or why. It was merely the sum of a rattlebag of impulses and neuroses that spurred me on. Those impulses and neuroses happened to have led me to make a lot of money. That's what makes it a story for our time.

GRAPHIC: Photos: No sooner does Joe America learn what tricks the $40,000 in his Merrill Lynch cash-management account can do than he develops the neurotic twitches once confined to the rich (p. 62); Some basic facts of the bull run: The volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange has quadrupled since 1990. From 1982 to 1997, the S&P 500 gained 1,026% (with dividends reinvested). Last year, $609 billion was invested in equity mutual funds, almost 9 times the amount in 1987 and about 30 times the amount in 1984; that $609 billion represented more money than the mutual funds' total assets just five years earlier. In 1981, American I.R.A.'s held a total of $26 billion; in 1996, $1.3 trillion. And how does the average American feel about the boom? In a recent survey, 78% of the respondents said that they believe "the rich get richer and the poor get poorer," and 43% said that they feel "left out of things going on around them." (p. 62) (Photographs by Geof Kern)

LENGTH: 1178 words

HEADLINE: Shrugging At The Boom;
Where's The Outrage?

BYLINE: By Michael Kazin; Michael Kazin as a professor of history at American University. He is the author of "The Populist Persuasion."

 BODY:
Back in the gilded age, wall street was a synonym for economic turpitude. Cartoonists for the Hearst and Pulitzer chains dipped their pens in acid before depicting a stock tycoon; the bloated plutocrat in a tight suit checkered with dollar signs, diamond stickpin gleaming from his cravat, became a turn-of-the-century cliche.
In those days, a politician could rise to prominence by bashing the money power -- shorthand for an evil amalgam of financial speculators and investment bankers. We are not opposed to that wealth which comes as the reward of honest toil, explained William Jennings Bryan during his 1900 campaign for President. "We draw the line between honest wealth and predatory wealth." 
 Well, sometimes the past really is past. Whatever happened to outrage against the investing class? It's not as if the old complaints have been resolved. Today's bull market has made wealthy Americans filthy rich -- while average wages have barely crept upward. While more Americans than ever now own stock, a full 60 percent of us have none whatsoever. The United States still has the most unequal distribution of wealth of any major industrial nation.
Yet hardly anybody is riled up about all this. Why not?
In order to understand the relative absence of protest now, it is necessary to look back at the heyday of discontent toward the money power. In Bryan's day, most Americans made their living with their hands. Women and men typically learned a skill in their youth -- and stuck with it for life. Millions of wage earners and small-business people, on farms and in the cities, viewed themselves proudly as "producers." This was, at base, a moral identity: only those who created wealth in tangible ways could be trusted. The Bible seemed to agree. Hadn't the Lord commanded Adam, "In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread? What made J. P. Morgan think he could behave differently?"
This producer ethic helped inspire a variety of mass movements, all of which bore a grudge against men who prospered merely by fiddling with numbers on paper. In the 1880's, the Knights of Labor signed up more than a million wage earners and small-trades people -- but categorically excluded speculators and bankers as being no more than gamblers. The People's Party and labor groups beckoned the toiling masses to fight back against plutocrats. And fight back they did: in 1919, more than four million people -- one-fifth of the total work force -- went on strike.
But by the 1930's, Americans were becoming less sure that battling "the money power" would enhance their well-being. A society of independent-minded producers was giving way to a nation of employees who worked to consume. The typical worker no longer cared so much how the rich became richer -- as long as he had the money and time to enjoy the vaunted American standard of living.
Assaults on the "money-changers" of Wall Street began to sound increasingly anachronistic. On occasion, a populist tried to stir up working Americans. In 1962, Rep. Wright Patman of Texas railed, "Our country belongs to the people. . .not to the huge financial houses and commercial banks." But fewer Americans than ever shared his anger.
The shifting nature of American jobs had something to do with it. Service and clerical work came to overshadow labor in factories, on farms and in mines. And data-entry clerks and janitors tended to be cut off from the cultures of manual labor that once had generated waves of producer protest.
The result was a labor pool full of people who floated from counter to cubicle, at firms where unions seldom penetrated. The nature of the jobs -- burger-flipping, keyboarding -- do not inspire a sense that one's work is the wellspring of a decent society and an authentic democracy.
Meanwhile, the old fear of Wall Street has been replaced by familiarity. The NASDAQ index is reported as often as the weather -- and with the same air of inevitability. In suburban malls, storefront investment outlets have sprung up next to pet shops. What was mysterious has become banal.
More important, the rich whose names we recognize are quite different from the WASP titans of the industrial age. They're a diverse, and rather likable, group. Instead of robber barons, today's rich are entertainment impresarios like Steven Spielberg and Oprah Winfrey, computer wizards like Bill Gates and Steve Jobs and financial prophets like Warren Buffett. Public relations is in their blood, and it's rare that one of the new rich (like Philip Knight of Nike) is branded an exploiter of labor.
It helps that Americans have long been ambivalent about the rich. We alternately envy and satirize the wealthy but feel they differ from the rest of us only in having more ingenuity or good luck. Even during the Gilded Age, workers didn't resent the rich merely for having money. To elicit mass hostility, the Carnegies and the Morgans had to flaunt their power and privilege -- by smashing a strike with a private army or giving an obscenely lavish party at Delmonico's. Otherwise, many Americans believed they were just a big break or two away from joining the top ranks themselves. That's still true today.
Not every American buys into the Horatio Alger myth. Yet it's hard to hear dissent amid the clamor of rising market averages. The collapse of Communism remains a powerful argument against any vision of what bygone radicals called a "cooperative commonwealth." And the top economists now argue that every human action tries to maximize individual self-interest -- and ridicule dissenters as whining Luddites.
The critics deserve better. Today's investment culture has invaded our imaginations and distorted our values. In a society where the Dow Jones average is king, it's not surprising that cleverness trumps diligence, and the glitter of instant wealth outshines achievements grounded in the manufacture of useful goods and the delivery of vital services.
A century ago, many prosperous Americans at least felt a twinge of guilt about the gap between their swelling bank accounts and the single-digit daily wages paid to manual workers. Today, that twinge is gone. Few rich Americans seem troubled that their pile rests on the hard, anonymous labor of thousands of people, here and abroad, who often lack access to good health care and education for their children.
At times like this, one needs to voice an old-fashioned protest: there is something immoral about striking it rich by playing the Wall Street wheel of fortune while people with little or no savings clean your clothes, harvest your food, fix your car and care for your children. We have forgotten a maxim our ancestors took for granted: the separation of labor and wealth is the seedbed of corruption.
William Jennings Bryan would never have been mistaken for a social philosopher. Yet he did have a fitting response to those, in his time and ours, who worship the raging bull of speculation. Money is to be servant of man, he once said, and I protest against all theories that enthrone money and debase mankind.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Few rich Americans seem troubled that their hoard rests on the hard, anonymous labor of thousands. (Photograph by Geof Kern)
