HEADLINE: Missing The Boom;
Some of My Best Friends Are Rich

BYLINE: By Matthew Klam; Matthew Klam lives in Washington. His fiction has appeared in The New Yorker.

 BODY:
These are boom times -- for my friends. Like me, they work hard, and boy, is it paying off. They're getting rich. Their lives are becoming more and more perfect. They're shopping, eating and sleeping in places where I can't go. They've vanished behind a curtain and sailed over the rainbow -- and life is easier in that other world, because the future is secured. Bad things can't touch them.
Or maybe it just seems that way to me because I don't get together with them as much anymore, because they are gone most of July and August, or have moved to an incredible $4,000-a-month loft I've never visited, or to the suburbs -- to the exact house I would have built, down to the kitchen with polished stainless-steel appliances. While many of my friends negotiate financial packages of staggering amounts, pondering one offer over another while planning their next vacation to Bali -- or while hitting $7 golf balls into the ocean off their front lawn in East Hampton -- I'm praying my checks won't bounce. 
 You see, short stories are my bread and butter -- and the market for my commodity is flat. There was the year I made $21,000 selling stories and a proposal for a book I have yet to finish. Then there was the year after that when I made peanuts teaching grad students.
I close my eyes and see my cousin Jonny, pulling up last Thanksgiving in his white Range Rover, and later unrolling the blueprints for his gigantic new house across the dinner table. Or my buddy Lloyd, who, 10 years ago, had a play produced in a small theater in Manhattan but now works on Wall Street. His wife has an emerald-cut diamond the size of a Chiclet on her ring finger, and I can still picture him eyeing the engagement ring on my fiancee's finger. Lara's diamond is more like a Tic-Tac than a Chiclet; I was ashamed of its size in comparison.
I gave a reading a while ago in a library basement, and my friend Peter showed up. (These moments are often ego boosts for me; they help balance out my feelings of inadequacy.) Like Lloyd, Peter abandoned writing a few years back. It was good to see him and we got to chat, since the audience was slow to arrive. He'll finish law school this summer, and then he's moving to Los Angeles for a job in entertainment law. I was happy for him -- and even though between the two of us, I'm the successful writer, achiever of dreams (while he quit!) -- he stood there grinning. He was grinning because he's glad he isn't me, waiting to see if enough people show, in a room that smells like mold.
Right then I wanted Peter's life so badly I felt like crying; I didn't want to wait to see if anyone else came to my reading; I wanted him to take me along to his law firm in Los Angeles. I wanted a suit like his, and I wanted to wear it driving a convertible in the California sunshine while those bad memories of never having any money faded away.
Why do these little moments stick with me? There's my friend Bill, who spent $400 at the supermarket last Sunday night because he was hungry; Chris, who flew himself to France to ride in a bicycle race (counting the equipment, the support vehicle and transportation -- and the cigars he brought back -- he spent 12 grand in six days); Karen, who bought a $3,000 Italian mahogany table because she likes to have dinner parties; Bill's wife, Samantha, who yesterday spent $1,200 on some -- very nice -- plants; Abby, who moments after her fiance Scott's most recent pay raise bought him $250 worth of underwear in fantastic colors; Elliott, who just got back from kayaking in Cabo (wherever that is); Nick and Linda, who went to Crate and Barrel and furnished their new apartment in three hours flat.
There are more reports like this than there used to be. In fact, the reports keep coming in. They're in! I'm out. These silly anecdotes have become like ghosts that follow me wherever I go, reminding me of what I am: a financial joke. I don't fit in. I don't make enough. You know how it is when you get together with old friends, and not a second is lost, everything is still the same? Well, it's not still the same. I don't feel like one of the guys anymore. What's a stock split? What's a data point? What's a Top Driver? Why is it revolutionizing the industry? I'm like a stranger in my own native land. I imagine this is how the Amish feel.
They aren't plain old middle-class pals anymore. These are actual rich people. My college chum Russ sets up initial public offerings and runs money into funds and everything is ramping nicely and he's bummed because his hedge-fund buddy recently bought a Lear jet. And I'm schlepping around, he says, in business class. He's 34. He's about to buy a yacht. Some days, to ease the undercurrent of tension when we talk, he pretends to envy me. You write because you have no choice, Klam, he says. It's your calling, so stop complaining. Your whole day could be spent in a bathrobe.
I graduated from college in 1986. The heartwarming film "Wall Street" came out around that time, and many of my friends went directly into banking. I'd majored in philosophy, and had absolutely no ideas, no goals, no plan for life. I felt inspired and wrote poetry -- and then, in romantic fashion, I drove around the country for years, writing lousy stuff and making no money until, eventually, I found the tiniest nibble of success.
As awful as it sounds, I liked this life, wandering from place to place with a bank balance that hovered around $60. But things are a lot different now from when I dreamed this profession up at 22. I wasn't raised to be poor, or to be patient and have faith. Now I'm 33 and I go through terrible bouts of hating myself, when I wake up with regrets, 11 long years into Not-Being-Legitimate. The shame stays with me all day.
But, wait, you say, he's an artist. Where has the pride gone? Well, the heady times when I've felt like Jack Kerouac -- when having my name in a national magazine meant more than anything -- ended in a hurry. The look on people's faces when I tell them what I've been up to, the envy they felt for my freedom, that's over. They envy nothing now. They worry instead. Or they don't want to hear about my sorry money woes. It makes them. . .uncomfortable. They don't notice, when we go out to a restaurant, that I worry about who orders what, and why should they? It's not their problem.
I'm sitting across from the host of a dinner party in Georgetown; he's wearing a great suit with a gleaming crisp shirt, French cuffs, a bright tie; he looks athletic and well rested. He's very happy to meet a real writer, he says. He used to be a writer himself. He wrote stories all through college and still reads everything being published. He runs his father's investment firm now, but the more we talk, the more he's thinking of retyping a story he wrote in college and showing it to me. He wants to know what it's like to write all day and where the ideas come from.
I've had two giant glasses of gin and I'm tired and I don't like him but maybe that's because he seems to be employing a fake British accent. "The bloody thing about fiction writing," he says, "is that it has to be true, but you have to make it up." There isn't one stick of furniture in the entire three-story brick town house that I could afford except the salad bowl, but who cares? We're talking about what I do, and I'm the star of the moment. "Have you ever met Norman Mailer?" he asks. Bingo! I met him just the week before and I say so. My host's envy is pouring into me, and his eyes are boring holes in my eyes. He envies my life, my privileges, the secret places I've been able to get to, the stuff I've got. For the first time in a long time, I feel jealousy. It feels great.
This is how i get by: when the phone bill with the threatening red stripe arrives, then I pay it. When the credit card maxes out, I retire it. I don't ever talk about money with the friends who are loaded. If, as I suspect, my old buddy Spleef is worth $20 million, I don't want to know. I hope he doesn't tell me. Why would he want to depress me like that?
I've been engaged now for four months, to a professional woman with a growing psychotherapy practice and financial expectations -- and if I had any secrets before, well, the vault that holds the deepest wells of humiliation has been violated. We haven't pooled our money yet but we're getting ready to, and around our kitchen table I've had to answer for my absurd economic realities, all those money issues I kept privately to myself (so successfully from myself) all these years:
Lara asks, "How much do you need per month to live on?"
"I don't know."
"What are you going to do this summer?"
"Leave it up to whimsy."
"What if that doesn't work out?"
"In that unlikely event, I'll be broke."
"But," she says, "two days ago you said you were rich."
"I know. I was. I've spent that."
I mention other moneymaking ideas, like a TV pilot I've discussed with a friend who works for UPN. She likes it. "I don't care about your money," she says. "You need it for yourself."
"Why do we have to talk about this now?" I say.
"It's good practice," she says.
I hate it. I want to have money -- I want to be able to offer us all kinds of options, I want her to be able to quit working if she feels like it and go buy houseplants. I want to surprise her with a thick reddish cashmere coat with a hood, like one she saw in a magazine; it would look really good with her wrapped inside it. I want to pick up the phone and call on some real-estate agent so that we can go house hunting in his Lexus -- he'll offer us coffee from a little thermos while we drive around -- but I can't, because I don't have the dough.
"Eventually," I say. "I'll make more."
"It's O.K.," she says.
"Right now we don't need money," I say.
"We could live on sunlight," she says. "Like plants. How are we going to have children if you can't talk about money?"
"Children?" I say.
She mentions a funny movie we saw the other night, about these clever roommates who plot to murder one another for some money they stole, and adds: You could've written that. Why can't you write something like that?
I know she's just trying to help, and she's right. In the last few months I've done ghostwriting, advertising, business writing -- it all pays better than fiction, but on the tip of my tongue is a suggestion that we take her 12,000 pairs of shoes and start a museum and charge admission. I want to have this talk about the future without the money component, no money fights ever, me handling everything and taking care of business, and we'd just be two lovers living on sunlight, plenty of green.
It's not a crime that she has a lot of shoes, or makes a decent living. She's not the only one. Many of my friends who weren't even interested in money have reached a point now of making a pretty good wage. I know a dentist who's 33 and has just built a $750,000 house on a lake. He bought a speedboat, and the boat has such a big motor it goes across the lake in five seconds, and then he has to turn back.
But to have his life, I'd have to be a dentist. I wouldn't want to be a dentist.
I don't want anybody else's life. And yet I think about quitting writing every 20 minutes. I'm sure my money problems are tied to my father's. He struggled with it his whole life. Not that he was poor -- he actually made money -- but he was all messed up by it. He managed a team that sold invisible financial products, like estate planning, pensions, insurance for corporations. It didn't mean anything to him. He got more satisfaction from shining his shoes at night than from running an insurance agency. What he really enjoyed was being outdoors -- in the garden, on a horse, in the woods -- or walking around the pool, every summer weekend, in nothing but a terry cloth hat. Business wasn't the right environment for my dad. He didn't have the heart of a money guy. And so he begged me, without saying so, to do something else -- to make something, though I'm sure he didn't think I'd be doing it for almost nothing.
I grew up in a really nice 250-year-old house in Katonah, N.Y., with a pool, a tennis court and two horses. My parents would have cocktail parties; groups of men with a pool, a tennis court and two horses in their yards would stand next to one another, uptight and cranky, acting like peevish kids, complaining because they had no friends. Living in Westchester County, we were surrounded by stories of families falling to pieces -- and money was always part of the crackup. I remember the Mercedes-Benz our neighbor bought his wife, as a last-ditch peacemaker, and then quit payments on; and the horse she said she had to have -- her final demand -- but only a $20,000 one would do.
Growing up in this strange environment, where it all looked like excess, money began to seem toxic. I'm not cut out for it -- the cashing in. The whole thing scares me.
I had a college roommate, Carl, who upon graduation took a job doing the exact same thing that caused my father all that misery: selling life insurance. We said goodbye and I shook my head, watching him head off in his new Nissan Sentra -- poor sellout! He was doomed, flying off like a projectile in the wrong direction. In his first week he made $3,800 in commissions on top of his regular salary, and in his second week he made $16,000 and immediately got a promotion. No more tuna subs for Carl. A year later he went on to sell computer memory modules for mainframes. He owns valuable company stock. He's one of the best salesmen in his company's history, and if he felt like it, he could retire tomorrow.
I remember once in college rallying him to pitch in for a letter-writing campaign for Amnesty International. Carl wasn't worried about torture victims in Siberia. He had to get through the sports section first. And anyway we were in rural New Hampshire. No torture victims there. That's Carl -- he's a great athlete, he'll do anything for a laugh, he's charming, he graduated with a near-perfect G.P.A., he's not stuck up. Work, like everything else, is a game to Carl. He usually wins, and has fun doing it. Being a success works fine for Carl, because he does what he wants. He made a choice and he's happy. I made a choice, too. I wanted to write, so I write.
There are, however, a couple of other things I want, to help alleviate my pain.
I want. I want Campagnolo Super Record components for my road bike. I want this suede-looking Armani silk suit with a tiny waffle weave. I want a big front lawn overlooking the ocean. I want a 1970 Oldsmobile Cutlass 442, dark green with a white rally stripe, convertible roof, black seats. I want a live-in cook and a new pair of cleats for baseball. I want a Psion Series 5 hand-held computer so that I can input data while I'm waiting on the checkout line at the Safeway. I want a Breitling Tag Heuer Bell and Ross organic titanium chronograph scuba diving watch. I want a big black stereo with one button on the front and a glowing red light. I want a plain-paper, all-in-one fax, color copier and printer. I want a hands-free wireless telephone headset. I want a one-gig Zip drive, a platinum wedding band and a ski house in Idaho. I want my fiancee to be able to walk into H. Stern Jewelers on Fifth Avenue and mill around for an hour, and I want to pay for it, and not have to worry too much about what she got. I want an electronic nosehair trimmer, something that literally rips the hairs out at the roots. I want to be able to buy for this 13-year-old who lives on my street some sterling silver widgets for the Irish flute he's learning to play. I want parabolic downhill skis. I haven't even gotten to the kitchen stuff. I want some Bernardaud porcelain plates in the Olivier Gagnere pastel patterns. And I want some ridiculous things that I'm embarrassed to mention.
I should be able to buy this stuff. I keep waiting to figure this out. It just seems to me, well, I'm as smart as my rich friends. I'm at least as smart as any of them. I'm the smartest person in the world!
I had all the opportunity. I still do. I could have done anything. I could have gone into law -- and right now I'd be working with Ally McBeal, flirting with her, wondering if our tactics were ethical, eating takeout, pouting our lips; she'd have on a skimpy skirt, I'd be in a big suit.. . .But I didn't. I shunned the jobs that make good money. It's my fault. I'm indefensible. Some guys want to make money, so they make money. In them, I already see these trends: too much drinking, outbursts of rage, profound aimlessness. I guess I like to watch. Mine is a good job -- witness to my generation. It's a damned dilemma that in this culture it's totally up to me whether I become a financial killer or a financial failure. To actually have this choice -- to be rich or poor -- this psychological mind-set, is a particularly modern ambivalence. But the fact that I'm moving down from where I started seems to me most unforgivable.
"You'll be so glad when you finish your book," my friend Jodi says. She's an elementary-school teacher. Her husband, Rich, runs some mysterious business that makes a lot of money. "Because writing is more like a hobby. Then you can go get a job."

HEADLINE: Opting Out Of The Boom;
Why More Blacks Don't Invest

BYLINE: By Glenn C. Loury; Glenn C. Loury is a professor of economics and director of the Institute on Race and Social Division at Boston University.

 BODY:
The greatest bull market to hit wall street since the 1920's has everybody talking about money these days. Such talk puts me in mind of my late and beloved uncle, patriarch of the extended household where I grew up in the 1950's and 1960's on Chicago's South Side. Uncle Moonie, whose large round eyes protruded like half-moons beneath his often-furrowed brow, spent most of his waking hours worrying about money: how to get it and, if truth be told, how to stop his wife from spending it. A tenacious businessman, he achieved what for his generation of blacks was an impressive degree of financial security.
But as a child of the Depression and a veteran of the pre-civil-rights racial climate, my uncle had some rather peculiar ideas about investing. Year after year, he stuffed the accumulated profits from his small business into dozens of old fruit-juice cans, kept under lock and key in his bedroom closet. Once, when I questioned this strategy, he informed me flatly that he didn't "believe in" banks, nor in the "white folks" who ran them. Luckily, fortune smiled on our family. No burglar or fire ever found those precious cans. But then, neither did the fruit of Uncle Moonie's labors ever find its way into the financial mainstream. 
 My uncle's alienation reflected the racially segregated economy of his day. But the effects of that bygone era continue to distort the economic experience of blacks. For example, among a sample of households polled by the Survey Research Center at the University of Michigan, only 14 percent of blacks owned some stocks or mutual fund shares in 1994, the most recent year for which data are available. The overall rate was 41 percent. Another striking finding: More than half of black households had no balances in either a checking or a savings account, compared with just one-sixth of other households.
My uncle Moonie was not big on racial integration. I can remember him back in the 1960's, saying: "I don't give a damn about living next to those white folks. You call me when they start talking about integrating the money!" Well, here we are, some 30 years down the road, and that conversation has yet to begin. Some writers, inclined to minimize the problem of racial inequality in America, are quick to stress that the income gap between blacks and whites has narrowed over the past generation. Stephan and Abigail Thernstrom, authors of "America in Black and White," have made much of the fact that married black couples outside of the South are now at about 90 percent of income parity with comparable whites.
But the wealth gap between the races tells another story altogether. In the Michigan survey, only 4 percent of blacks -- compared with 25 percent of nonblacks -- were worth $170,000 or more. Indeed, half of black families had a net worth below $8,400, while the median for other families was over $63,000. What this means is that while most blacks would have trouble paying cash for a used car, most whites could afford to purchase a new car outright, help a child with the down payment on a first home and still have funds left over.
With blacks having so little disposable income to invest, it is no wonder that they are scarce among equity holders. But their absence from the market has profound implications. For decades to come, wealth created by growing stock values will be sending children to elite colleges, underwriting small-business start-ups and securing a comfortable retirement for American families. And yet, even the newly emergent black middle class is missing out.
How, then, are blacks choosing to manage their money? A 1998 Yankelovich survey probed the investment habits of 1,232 black and white households with annual incomes of $50,000 or higher. The survey found that blacks considered real estate to be the best overall investment
vehicle, while whites chose stocks. Moreover, high-income blacks put a larger percentage of their retirement savings in life insurance, a notoriously low-return investment, than whites did. And they were more likely than whites to express doubts about whether they could trust a financial adviser.
What could account for this psychological gap? Marcus Alexis, an economics professor at Northwestern University and a former chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, noted: "For the vast majority of high-income black families, this current generation is the first to have any real money to invest. Many of them are, perhaps understandably, averse to taking risks."
Alexis also stressed that factors of history and sociology gave blacks more familiarity with -- and easier access to -- certain relatively low-yield investment vehicles. "The selling of whole life-insurance policies in black communities was done heavily by black agents," he said. "There was a time when this was the best job many talented blacks could aspire to. They went first to their relatives and friends. Something like one-third of the premium in the first couple of years would accrue as commission to the agents."
This affection for insurance drives John Rogers, the founder and president of Ariel Capital Management, to distraction. Twelve years ago at Ariel, Rogers started the first black-managed mutual fund in the nation. Reached in his Chicago offices recently, he talked excitedly about "the huge, untapped market for investment services" among the 1.1 million black households with an annual income of $50,000 or more. Ariel has recently joined forces with the brokerage firm Charles Schwab, holding educational seminars aimed primarily at black audiences in a dozen cities across the country. The seminars are drawing enthusiastic crowds. This is a rather different approach than sending someone's brother-in-law around to hawk a garden-variety life-insurance policy.
My own conversations with black professionals suggest that such efforts are much needed because, even among well-educated people with high incomes, many blacks lack knowledge of (or confidence in) today's variegated financial instruments. One man, who covers the information-technology beat for a major newspaper, seemed embarrassed to admit that he does not know the rate of interest being paid on the funds he routinely deposits each month in a passbook. "I haven't invested in stocks or mutual funds, even though I know I should," he said. "Partly, I'm suspicious of the market, and wonder if I'd lose my pitifully small stake. Then again, I think to myself, I don't have enough money to make it worthwhile. I know this probably isn't true, but there you are."
A somewhat different story was told by a couple, both with advanced degrees, who work for major nonprofit institutions. With a net worth over $300,000, they are wealthier than 99 percent of black families. The husband holds a $150,000 cash-value life-insurance policy sold to him by a childhood friend. Until five years ago, he invested virtually nothing in the market. After attending a financial seminar sponsored by his employer, he began making the maximum contribution to his 401(k). That's it, however. "By the time we finish giving to financially needy people in our respective families, there's not a lot left to invest," he said.
Ultimately, investing one's money means drawing on social, as well as financial, capital. It requires the investor to be conversant with and -- what Uncle Moonie could never do -- to "believe in" the institutions of modern finance: the trading accounts, margin calls, the no-load mutual funds. These institutions now constitute part of the decision-making apparatus of everyday life. Familiarity with them is requisite to full participation in our society. Until this happens, blacks will remain outside the warp and woof of American life. It's time to integrate the money.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
A Case of Island Madness

BYLINE: By John Tierney; John Tierney, a staff writer for the magazine, is the co-author of the novel "God Is My Broker."

 BODY:
For Tom Ortez, Black Friday came on Oct. 15, 1999. The Dow had already fallen 5,000 points in the preceding 10 months, but until that morning he had been able to persuade himself that the Crash of '99 was just a temporary inconvenience. He had even tried arguing that it was good for his company. "In these uncertain times," he told one reporter, "the sophisticated customer knows that a $1,100 Durata handbag is an investment that will last."
An investment -- the line that had worked so well for him through the 90's. His famously durable handbags, made of tent fabric that had withstood a blizzard atop K2, had the patina of practicality demanded by bull-market winners who wanted to pretend they were beyond the excesses of the 80's. Tom, who had grown up in Queens, imbued the company with a vaguely Milanese cachet by naming it Durata and embossed each purse with a discreet insignia of a mountaineer's ice ax. It became the Range Rover of purses. Sales fell off after the Crash, but Tom didn't panic until that Friday, when his chief retail outlet, a chain of high-end clothing stores, filed for bankruptcy. 
 Durata's stock plunged that morning from 46 to 21, which halved Tom's net worth and put him below the magic number he needed for the co-op. He still had plenty of cash to buy it, but that would not be good enough for the co-op board at the Ascotshire. The board, which prided itself on having the highest rejection rate on Central Park West (the building was known among real-estate brokers as the Ask-Not-Here), required liquid assets at least three times the price of the apartment.
It was all slipping away, Tom thought, as he stood at his office window, staring across the midtown rooftops. No bonus this year. No park view for himself and Lily. Maybe no Lily. She affected disdain for her parents' Fifth Avenue values, but now that they were engaged the breeding was showing. She was taking great pains, whenever he was introduced, to mention that the Ortez family had emigrated from Spain, not Latin America. She claimed she was joking about the Ascotshire being on "the wrong side of the park," but she refused even to look in less-exclusive buildings.
Tom opened the window and climbed onto the fire escape. It was the only remaining place for his vice. Cigars had been on the way out even before the Crash, and now they were anathema to any executive in touch with the new, lean Zeitgeist. Tom was puffing furtively when he heard his secretary's frantic voice.
"Tom, what are you doing out there?" He tried to hide the cigar, but she saw the smoke. "Oh, you had me worried for a moment," she said. She smiled at the pitiful sight. "I thought you quit."
"I did," he said. "I was just feeling, I don't know, a little nostalgic."
At noon Tom got his first bit of good news: his banker was free for lunch. On the sidewalk outside his building, he tried to avoid the picketing Durata employees, but it was hard to ignore the old lady in the wheelchair. "Give me back my pension!" she screamed at him. "Give me back my life!" A news crew was recording the confrontation.
In the first months after the Crash, reporters had desperately searched for evidence of a new Great Depression, but except for New York, whose economy was in free fall, the country seemed to be experiencing a relatively normal recession. Americans were living pretty much the way they had lived in 1995, the last time the Dow was at 5,000. Economists tried explaining that disaster was not inevitable, that the Great Depression had been caused not by the Crash of '29 but by stupid banking and trade policies -- none of which interested reporters on deadline. They wanted victims.
Ruined stockbrokers were not sufficiently heart-rending. Nor were most of their clients, although reporters tried a few angles: children forced to transfer to public schools, retirees suing cruise lines to get back their nonrefundable deposits. Jerry Springer created a sensation when a guest on his "I Could Just Kill My Broker!" show took the theme a little too literally, but any sympathy for the murderer vanished when it came out that he owned a $350,000 cabin cruiser.
It was not until the Widows March on Wall Street that the popular anger found its voice. The president of the New York Stock Exchange had to apologize to retired Americans for "the cruel tarnish besmirching your golden years." Jesse Jackson called for corporations to pay "reparations" to retired workers. Steve Forbes proposed refunding all the capital-gains taxes they had paid.
The lady in the wheelchair yelling at Tom had been one of the first seamstresses hired at Durata's factory in the Bronx. When she retired in 1998, collecting $270,000 of Durata stock, it was Tom who handed her the certificates, basking in the image of himself as an enlightened capitalist. Now she was calling the stock-option plan "the hoax pension."
Tom fled around the corner to the restaurant, where he was surprised to recognize the new maitre d'. Last year she was on the cover of Durata's catalogue. Now she was apparently a victim of the Great Model Surplus. She was much friendlier this year. So was the owner of the restaurant, who personally escorted Tom and his banker, Jeffrey, to a prime banquette. They sat down and looked around at the empty tables.
"I guess grocery stores must be doing all right," Tom said. "Anybody else?"
"The bond traders are happy," Jeffrey replied. "My loans outside New York are still performing. But here in the former capital of the world----."
"Come on," Tom said. "New York always bounces back. They wrote us off 10 years ago, and then came the boom."
"All a mirage. Wall Street, real estate, tourism -- the whole economy was built on out-of-towners' money. We were the Disney city, living off strangers who rushed in when they were flush and New York looked hot."
"So now some of them are rushing out," Tom said. "But they'll need us again."
"They need us about as much as they need purses designed for K2. How's your cash flow?"
"Fine," Tom lied. "Your loan is safe. That's not why I called you. I need a personal favor." He explained that he needed to show more liquid assets to the co-op board. "I want to remortgage my place in Southampton and put the cash into the bank."
Jeffrey shook his head. "I can't add to our real-estate portfolio now. We've had three developers and a hotel default this week."
"But it's oceanfront property," Tom said. "When New York gets back on its feet----."
"When New York gets back on its feet, call me."
Tom phoned Lily, who refused to give up on the co-op. She and their broker arranged for Tom to meet privately that afternoon with Abby Green, the president of the Ascotshire's board.
Entering Green's apartment, Tom was not surprised to find peeling paint and crumbling plaster. Green was an heiress who had devoted most of her fortune to the Project for Urban Justice, a foundation that she and her husband ran. The walls of her study were decorated with plaques honoring her as "the Conscience of the Upper West Side."
The Crash, whatever damage it had done to her trust fund, had been good for her career. During the 90's, social activists had become quaint anachronisms, railing against capitalist injustice while the city boomed. Now they were once more in the vanguard, leading the fight for the downtrodden. Green's foundation had just joined with the municipal workers' union to get an injunction preventing the city from using welfare recipients to clean up the city.
Green and Tom had an awkward chat about Durata's picketing employees before they settled down to go over the numbers. "How much would you be paying for the apartment?" Green asked.
"They'd take $3.3 million."
Green looked chagrined. The apartment Tom was trying to buy, a classic nine-room, was in the same line as her own. "God, last year another one in this line went for over five. That's a steal. Well, the board would require $9.9 million in liquid assets." She studied Tom's financial statement. "There's not even $7 million here. I could try to bend the rules a little, but" -- she sighed and lowered her voice to a genteel whisper -- "I'm afraid this won't quite work."
Tom felt angry, humiliated -- but he couldn't help admiring Green's arrogance. The co-op market had collapsed and the Ascotshire was still throwing his money back in his face. It was the foundation of New York's economy, that smug confidence that there would always be more people clamoring to get in, always another buyer willing to pay for a view of Central Park. Tom glanced out the window and sadly contemplated the view of the Great Lawn he couldn't have.
"This is a little awkward," Green said, "but I'd like to say something off the record. Our kids are at the age where they need a yard. We hate the idea of leaving the city, but we'd consider selling this place for $3 million."
Tom assumed she wanted to bargain. They both knew that according to the board's rule, even $3 million was out of Tom's reach. They also knew that this ramshackle place wasn't worth it. "The one for 3.3 has a lot more amenities," Tom said. "It would cost at least a million to bring yours up to that level."
"Oh, I think you're overestimating," Green said, and then she gazed at Tom intensely. "The price is firm. Remember the amenity this one comes with: guaranteed board approval."
So Green would waive the rules for a price. The Conscience of the Upper West Side could be bought. The businessman in Tom appreciated Green's directness. It seemed not a bad deal -- a reasonable price to pay for Lily and the park and the rest of his Gotham aspirations -- but something in Green's eyes bothered Tom. Why was she so desperate to get out of town? If she was willing to sell her apartment -- and her soul -- how many other rats were abandoning ship?
He took another look out the window. He thought he saw sheep gamboling across the Great Lawn, then realized that they were white clumps of garbage blowing in the wind. Maybe he ought to be considering a yard of his own. Westchester would be just as close to the factory in the Bronx. But then, why did he need that factory anyway? There were plenty of workers in Asia who would gladly make his purses, and they wouldn't be able to bother him at lunchtime. He didn't want to abandon the city, but he had to cut costs somehow. His banker was right: who needed a $1,100 purse anymore? Who needed a $3 million apartment? Who needed New York? If, like the 90's stock market, it was all one giant Ponzi scheme. . . .
Tom turned to Green and lowered his voice to a genteel whisper: "I'm afraid this won't quite work."

LENGTH: 2201 words

HEADLINE: Where Melville Paid Homage to a Mountain

BYLINE: By W. D. WETHERELL; W. D. WETHERELL is the author most recently of "North of Now: A Celebration of Country and the Soon to Be Gone" (The Lyons Press).

 BODY:
IT'S a brave and poignant thing to dedicate a novel to a mountain. Brave to match up an imperfect, man-made creation against one of nature's masterpieces; poignant to be so disenchanted with your fellow humans that a hillside seems your one and only friend. Both qualities were evident in Herman Melville's decision in 1852 to dedicate "Pierre," his seventh novel, to the mountain that dominated the view from his study window at Arrowhead, the 18th-century farmhouse in Pittsfield, Mass., he had purchased two years before. Having dedicated his previous novel, "Moby-Dick," to the American writer he valued most, his Berkshire neighbor Nathaniel Hawthorne -- having found Hawthorne's famous shyness nearly impossible to crack -- Melville may well have felt that he had no one human who could understand the wild, tormented novel he had just now completed.
"To Greylock's Most Excellent Majesty," the dedication is headed. "In old times authors were proud of the privilege of dedicating their works to Majesty. A right noble custom, which we of Berkshire must revive. . . . since the majestic mountain, Greylock -- my own more immediate sovereign lord and king -- hath now, for innumerable ages, been the one grand dedicatee of the earliest rays of all the Berkshire mornings, I know not how his Imperial Purple Majesty . . . will receive the dedication of my own poor solitary ray. . . ." 
 It was exactly this irony and tension between the disappointments of human companionship on one hand and the solace of nature's beauties on the other that was to mark the 12 years Herman Melville lived at Arrowhead. In a small upstairs study on the north side of the house, Melville had completed work on "Moby-Dick," facing a window that commands a perfectly framed view of Greylock dominating the ridges to the north.
Greylock, the highest mountain in Massachusetts (3,491 feet) is double humped and surprisingly massive, suggesting in summer -- even without "Moby-Dick" to act as a very large hint -- a green whale breaching through the mist. Today, almost 150 years after he wrote his masterpiece here, it's easy to picture him getting up stiff after a long morning's work, tearing himself away from the great inescapable thing on his writing table, going over to the window, stretching, rubbing his eyes, staring long and hard at the great inescapable thing on the horizon, finding a moment's solace in it, then -- glancing lower to appraise the corn he had planted that spring in the north meadow -- going back to his table to write some more.
For Melville, buying Arrowhead was the consummation of a love affair with the Berkshires that had begun as a boy. His Uncle Thomas had a farm south of Pittsfield (which survives today, enlarged, as the Pittsfield Country Club) and Melville's boyhood visits there during the 1830's, when he was allowed to roam freely over the meadows, woods and hills, were always among his happiest memories.
The Berkshires seem to be the one place this famous traveler felt whole; descended from a famous old New York family on the one side (the Gansevoorts, of Revolutionary War fame), and a venerable New England family on the other (his paternal grandfather was one of the participants in the Boston Tea Party), Melville may have found that these two hereditary halves coexisted best in this border country where New York and New England join edges and meet.
In 1850, having already begun "Moby-Dick," heading a young growing family that included not only his wife and baby son but also his mother and sisters, and tired of Manhattan with its incestuous literary life and bustle, Melville decided on a whim to buy the old farmhouse and its 160 acres (for $6,500) on the southern outskirts of the market town of Pittsfield. He was still young and strong enough that he could face the hard physical toil of farming with confidence. And there was another factor in his decision, a large one -- the presence of Hawthorne just south in Lenox, the promise, at least in Melville's mind, of establishing a fast friendship.
Arrowhead was named by Melville for the Indian souvenirs he found while tilling the fields. After the confusion of moving in, he soon established the routine he was to follow during his years here, which he described in an early letter to Hawthorne (as quoted in the first volume of Hershel Parker's wonderfully comprehensive biography).
"Do you want to know how I pass my time? -- I rise at eight -- thereabouts -- and go to my barn -- say good-morning to the horse, and give him his breakfast. (It goes to my heart to give him a cold one, but it can't be helped.) Then, pay a visit to my cow -- cut up a pumpkin or two for her and stand by to see her eat it -- for it's a pleasant sight to see a cow move her jaws -- she does it so mildly and with such a sanctity. My own breakfast over, I go to my work-room and light my fire -- then spread my M.S.S. on the table -- take one business squint at it, and fall to with a will . . . "
Summers were always the best times at Arrowhead. Melville liked to picnic, there were frequent guests from New York (with better rail service in 1851 than exists today), and excursions were always being arranged to Pontoosuc Lake or Stockbridge Bowl or the steep slopes of Greylock. Melville, along with his writing, had care of the farm, and at the end of the day would sink exhausted in a rocking chair on the narrow porch he had built on the north side of the house, a locale immortalized in "The Piazza Tales."
"I have been ploughing and sowing and raising and printing and praying," he wrote in another letter to Hawthorne, "and now begin to come out upon a less bristling time, and to enjoy the calm prospect of things from a fair piazza at the north of the old farmhouse here."
The winters were especially hard on everyone -- they were more isolated, and between the never-ending work of running the farm, the crushing disappointments that came when literary America began to ignore his books, the pressure of living in a small house with an expanding family (three Melville children were born at Arrowhead), the Berkshires eventually lost much of their charm. Then, too, Hawthorne had moved away in 1851, taking with him much of the literary allure. In 1863, faced with crushing economic pressures and too ill to care for the farm, Melville moved the family back to New York.
Melville's lawyer brother, Allan, took Arrowhead as part of a house swap in 1863, and it remained in the family until the 1920's. (Melville himself visited there well into his old age.) In 1975, the house was obtained by the Berkshire County Historical Society, which maintains it as a shrine to Melville and as a base for its own activities. Visitors can begin their tour in the old barn, where a video places Melville in the context of the wider Berkshire artistic scene and a small gift shop sells books by and about the author. After this, led by a volunteer guide, you proceed into the house itself -- a modest New England farmhouse that seems even more cramped when you remember upwards of 11 people were living here at any one time.
Dominating the downstairs is the massive black chimney that is the central "character" in "I and My Chimney." ("Some say that I have become a sort of mossy old misanthrope, when all the time I am simply standing guard over my mossy old chimney.") Sometime after Melville's own residence, probably at his brother's suggestion, lines from this story were inscribed on the chimney's stone facing, and though they're smoky, a bit hard to read, they remain the most vivid memento of the family's habitation and evidence of the pride they took in Herman's accomplishments.
The house is simply furnished, with a few pieces from Melville's day, family portraits, and at least one real curiosity: the dress Elizabeth Shaw Melville wore as a baby when she sat on the knee of the visiting Marquis de Lafayette in 1824. Upstairs is the main family bedroom; across from it, along a narrow hall, is Melville's study, with a small brass plaque reading: "In this room Herman Melville wrote Moby Dick or The Whale 1850-51."
Preserved with the house, the reconstructed piazza overlooks the cornfield Melville once plowed. A nature trail that starts behind the barn winds its way up the gentle slope through the woods. Walking here on a bright summer day it's easy to block out the encroaching suburbia and imagine what it must have been like when meadows ran uninterruptedly on all sides, guests were piling into the carriage and Herman Melville, free for an afternoon of both his writing desk and the farm chores, was jumping up into the driver's seat with the lithe agility of a foretopman, ready for another voyage, if only to the quiet shores of Pontoosuc Lake.
Arrowhead is one of three Melville shrines in the Berkshires. In the center of downtown Pittsfield is the Berkshire Athenaeum, with its Herman Melville Memorial Room, a priceless collection of mementos from his life and career. This is holy ground for the Melville lover; included are such rarities as the desk he wrote "Billy Budd" on, his wife Lizzie's own writing desk, a pipe he bought on his honeymoon, family portraits and, most poignant of all, the little official badge he wore as a customs inspector on the New York docks during the long years of his literary eclipse.
The third shrine is something very different, a place that has hardly changed at all since Melville's day, one where you can quite literally tread in his footsteps. Monument Mountain is a steep little peak ("a headless Sphinx" Sophia Hawthorne called it) rising above the Housatonic Valley in Stockbridge, a short drive south of Arrowhead. Here, on Aug. 5, 1850, occurred the most famous short hike in American literary history, when a party that included Melville, Hawthorne and Oliver Wendell Holmes ascended through the mountain laurel to the summit for a joyous picnic. This was the first time Hawthorne and Melville had ever met; they were caught by a thunderstorm on top, and took shelter under the craggy boulders. Once the rain left off, as one of the party later described, Melville "bestrode a peaked rock, which ran out like a bowsprit, and pulled and hauled imaginary ropes" like a sailor.
There is much in Melville's life that was unutterably tragic and dark; it's easy to focus too much on the evil kind of enchantment that seems to have taken hold of him after the completion of "Moby-Dick." Here, standing atop Monument Mountain, or bending slightly to peer out the study window at Arrowhead, it's good to remember that other Melville, the writer at the height of his power, the vivacious friend who -- everyone agreed -- could tell stories better than anyone, the athlete who could still lead the others scampering across the rocks.
Here in this Arrowhead study he is at the peak, with the Berkshire winter coming again and he back at work at his desk. The world that is building in him is miraculously reflected by the world he can see outside; Greylock out his window matches the whale inside his head, so when he reaches for his simile it's right there: " . . . and in the wild conceits that swayed me to my purpose, two and two there floated into my inmost soul, endless processions of the whale, and midmost of them all, one grand hooded phantom, like a snow hill in the air."
 
If you go
Arrowhead is a short distance off Routes 7 and 20 at 780 Holmes Road, Pittsfield, Mass. 01201; (413) 442-1793. It is open this year through Oct. 31, from 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M.; the first tour leaves at 10 A.M., the last tour at 4 P.M. During off-season months, visits may be arranged by calling ahead for an appointment. Admission is $5, $4.50 ages 65 and over, $3 ages 6 to 16, under 6 free. There is a small museum shop in the barn where the video is shown.
The Berkshire Athenaeum, Pittsfield's public library, is at 1 Wendell Avenue at Park Square. Opening hours for most of the year are Monday through Thursday from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M., Friday until 5 P.M. and Saturday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Starting June 29 until around Labor Day, reduced summer hours are Monday, Wednesday and Friday from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Tuesday and Thursday until 9 P.M.; Saturday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. The library is closed Sunday year round. The Melville Room is open to visitors who inquire at the local history desk, (413) 499-9486; on the table as you go in to the collection is a pamphlet with a numbered key explaining the various exhibits. The room also houses a research collection for use by scholars.
Monument Mountain is a short drive south of Stockbridge on Route 7; the parking lot is directly across from the Monument Mountain Regional High School. There's a trail marker on the bottom that points two ways, "Easy" to the left, "Steep" to the right. On our visit, we went up Steep -- about a half hour's hike for those in shape -- and came down on Easy -- a gentler but longer stroll through shaded woods.
Every year on the first Sunday in August, the famous Melville-Hawthorne hike up Monument Mountain is commemorated by a festive group hike (on the Easy route) to the summit that is open to all comers; call Arrowhead for information.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Nesconset, L.I.;
A Quiet Smithtown Hamlet

BYLINE: By VIVIEN KELLERMAN 

 BODY:
FOR several years after World War II, the hamlet of Nesconset at the southeastern border of the Town of Smithtown tottered on the brink of turning into a rural slum. It was a dying area dotted with tarpaper shacks and tiny bungalows.
But a housing boom in the 50's to accommodate veterans and their families changed all that. By the 70's home buyers flocked to the hamlet, drawn to its attractive wooded landscape, accessibility to major roads, availability of shopping including the new Smith Haven Mall, now a million square feet, and a well-regarded school district. 
 Today, with only a few remaining parcels to develop, these same features continue to draw new residents, making for a brisk real estate market.
"It's a very hot seller's market," said Arlene Schwartz, the manager of Coldwell Banker Sammis Realty in Smithtown, "and houses are in short supply."
She said that many homes put up for sale were on the market only a day or two and often received multiple bids. When the agency holds an open house for brokers, she said, 50 or more people show up.
Prices for single-family homes range from about $100,000 for a two-bedroom cottage on a quarter-acre, she said, to about $425,000 for new colonials and Victorians on a half acre.
There are five apartment rental complexes in Nesconset, with a total of 578 units. Rents range from about $800 for a one-bedroom unit in an older building to $1,350 for a two-bedroom in a newer building.
The community's lone condominium complex, the Woods at Smithtown, with 56 two-bedroom units, has a pool and clubhouse. Prices range from about $140,000 to $180,000 depending on the size and location of the unit.
Although most new developments have just five or six houses, Winwood Oaks at Old Nicols and Moriches Roads has 52 lots. There are two Victorian models, both with four bedrooms and two-and-a-half baths; one is 2,730 square feet, the other 2,963 square feet. Houses range in price from $290,000 to $320,000 and just six lots remain to be sold.
There are about 100 stores in small shopping strips mostly along Smithtown Boulevard and Lake Avenue, said Al Hornberger, president of the 90-member Nesconset Chamber of Commerce.
The chamber sponsors and annual craft fair/flea market and a festival called Nesconset Day, which this year will be held on Sept. 20. Initiated in 1989, Nesconset Day is held at Nesconset Plaza, which has 24 stores and restaurants and a public library branch. Mr. Hornberger said that there would be craft vendors, amusement rides, a petting zoo, marionette shows and a parade.
A craft fair/flea market is held each May at the Story Book Homes parking lot on Route 347. In addition, Mr. Hornberger said, there is a Christmas tree lighting and a Menorah lighting ceremony in December.
"For a hamlet that does not have the defined borders of a village, it has a lot of community spirit," said Mr. Hornberger.
Among the community's popular restaurants are Sun Dried Tomato, which serves Italian food, Acropolis, with Greek cuisine, and Kasu for Japanese food. All are in Nesconset Plaza.
MR. HORNBERGER, a developer who is a 10-year resident of Nesconset, said that he had chosen the hamlet as a place to live because it is quiet and offers so much to families.
All Nesconset students attend schools in the Smithtown Central School District, which has eight k-5 elementary schools, one middle school and one high school and a total enrollment of 8,023.
Enrollment in the district peaked in the 70's, with 15,000 students in 19 buildings. Over the years, as enrollment declined, several buildings were closed, schools were merged and some were sold. But, said Dr. Christopher Gallagher, district assistant superintendent, a rising enrollment has forced the district to make adjustments.
Only a few years ago, said Dr. Gallagher, it closed two middle schools and one high school, and reorganized them into one junior/senior high school. But as the youngest children move up the ranks, the district now thinks it will have to reopen both of middle schools by 2004.
"We certainly considered selling some of those surplus buildings," Dr. Gallagher said. "Now, we're glad we didn't."
Next September, the Great Hollow Middle School in Nesconset, which had been closed in 1992, will reopen. To pay for the expense of adding space, voters approved a $28 million, 30-year bond issue last year.
Eighty-five percent of last year's 535-student graduating class has gone on to higher education. Two students who were semifinalists in the Westinghouse Science Competition had been enrolled in the high school science preparation program begun in September 1996. The district offers 13 advanced placement courses as well as French, German, Spanish and Italian language courses.
A gifted-and-talented program is available to pupils beginning in grade 3. And Smithtown has joined 15 other districts statewide in a pilot program that integrates technology and math into science instruction in one third- and one fourth-grade class at the Tacken Elementary School in Nesconset.
The state's Cleary School for the Deaf in Nesconset has an enrollment of 75 students ranging in age from three months to 21. The nondenominational day school on five acres has been in Nesconset for 73 years. Sister Catherine Fitzgibbon, superintendent of the school, said that since Cleary is the only school for the deaf in Suffolk County, students come from as far away as Montauk to attend classes.
The public-school system was one of the main reasons Philip and Tammy Kulina chose to live in Nesconset. "My husband grew up in Smithtown, and we wanted our children to go to its schools," said Mrs. Kulina, a hair stylist in Commack, about 15 minutes away. The couple have one son, Tyler, 2.
Mr. Kulina, a Xerox account representative, is frequently on the road, traveling mostly in Nassau County, but Mrs. Kulina said there had never been any question about moving closer to his work.
After looking for about nine months, the Kulinas found a 28-year old, three-bedroom, two-bath ranch on one-quarter acre in Nesconset a year ago. They paid $169,000 for the house, which needed a lot of work, Mrs. Kulina said.
"We like it here," she said. "It's safe and quiet, there are lots of small children, and there's lots for them to do."
In addition to several small pocket parks, there are two larger parks open to town residents with a free parking sticker. The 8.75-acre Sprosera Park on Brown's Road, has four softball fields and a playground. The 6.25-acre Andreoli Park on Gibbs Pond Road has four basketball courts, a horseshoe court and a playground. There is also a freshwater pond where fishing is allowed. No permit is needed.
The 115-acre Lake Ronkonkoma County Park, a nature preserve with walking paths, is also in Nesconset.
UNTIL the beginning of the 20th century the hamlet of Nesconset did not exist. Most of the area was wilderness, heavily forested and virtually impenetrable. The first homesteaders at the turn of the century had to clear these forests for homes and roads.
In 1908, the community was named Nesconset, a modified version of Nesataesconsett, chief of the Nesaquake Indians, who deeded their lands to Richard Smythe, who secured two Smithtown patents, in 1665 and 1677. In 1909, the first post office was opened. Soon after some local businesses sprang up, including two general stores, a florist, candy store, gas and service station.
Because of its proximity to Lake Ronkonkoma, a bustling summer community just to the south, Nesconset enjoyed some of its overflow visitors, who built and rented tiny cottages within its borders. When this summer population dwindled after World War II, Nesconset's economy was quickly affected and the area began to go to seed.
Once development began again, however, population growth seemed unstoppable. Between 1960 and 1970 alone, the population tripled from 3,070 to 10,048.
John Reardon, a Manhattan stockbroker, grew up in nearby Centereach. When he married in 1991, he and his wife, Maureen, looked all over the 140-square-miles of Smithtown, finally finding a small three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath house in Nesconset.
"It was what we could afford, and we liked the area," said Mrs. Reardon.
As their family grew, they decided they needed more space, and in April 1995 they moved into a new 11-home subdivision less than two miles away. Their five-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath Victorian is on .75 acre.
"We never thought of moving anywhere else," said Mrs. Reardon, mother of three young boys. "It's close to everything, the specialty stores in Smithtown, the Costco Price Club, the mall, and all the parkways. We're very happy here. We haven't found a downside yet."

THE GIFT ARMORY: For the last four years, there has been an ongoing debate over what to do with the Nesconset Armory, built in the 50's. The state handed over the 22,000-square-foot building on 7.8 acres to the town in 1994 in exchange for a dollar. An additional 35 acres surrounding the site is also owned by the town. Some say the several plans submitted so far, varying in cost from $3.5 million to $5 million, are too expensive and will create too much traffic and are too expensive. Others argue that they will preclude development of the property. The town is currently considering renovating the building for Recreation Department offices, community meeting rooms, and recreational facilities. A baseball field, tennis courts, a skateboard park, a jogging/walking trail and Olympic size swimming pool are also proposed. Eighteen acres would remain undeveloped. A public hearing on the proposals will probably be held later this month, said Town Councilman Michael Hollander.

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
It Started With a Yen for Grilled Salmon

BYLINE: By DEBRA GALANT 

 BODY:
ALL I wanted was to be able to create fire, in my own backyard, without the help of a man. I was thinking grilled salmon -- on weeknights. Roasted red peppers, Vidalia onions, corn -- anytime I desired.
Nine years ago, when we moved to the suburbs, my mother-in-law offered us, as a housewarming present, the backyard grill of our choice. I had no strong opinions then. But my husband, a self-proclaimed charcoal purist, did. He envisioned hickory briquettes, the authentic smells and flavors of barbecues past. Plus, he was a little scared of propane (not lighter fluid, though). We wound up with a plain charcoal grill in a charming 1970's shade of avocado. 
 It served us well for eight New Jersey summers. We grilled salmon, red peppers, Vidalia onions, corn. But not on weeknights, not anytime I desired. The one time I was put in charge of the fire, I stood there baffled, newspaper in one hand, cell phone in the other. "Where do you put the newspaper?" I whimpered. "What about the lighter fluid? Do you close the lid?"
Lighting the grill was, in my opinion, a Hansel-and-Gretel operation. You practically had to climb inside to get it going. In the end, I chickened out and flagged down the first male neighbor I could find.
Over the years, I discovered that we knew people on the other side of the charcoal/propane divide. The wives told me that starting a gas grill was as simple as turning on a switch. Moreover, they had kept propane in their backyards for years without anything ever blowing up. So when the Internal Revenue Service decided to bestow its generosity on me this year, I knew exactly what I wanted. A gas grill.
Luckily -- or so I thought -- I still had a subscription to Consumer Reports Online. One day, when I should have been working, I printed out the most recent feature on gas grills. It spoke of B.T.U.'s, ignition tests, grilling efficiency and easy-clean surfaces. Everything under $200 it dismissed with the basic message: "You could do better."
What the ratings forgot to mention was anything about esthetics. They didn't say: this sucker is ugly and will take up half your yard. If you buy this grill, you will be the laughing stock of your quaint gas-lit neighborhood. Armed with the scientific data, I dragged my husband to Home Depot. For $199 ($234 assembled, $283 delivered), we found a model with a porcelain easy-clean grilling surface, two warming racks, enormous plastic trays on either side and a nice little perch in front for utensils. It came in a very 1990's shade of hunter green. It even had an impressive name: The Grillmaster.
My husband, who had accepted the propane decision grudgingly, gently tried to warn me: this was one big grill. His exact words, I later learned, were: "This is a monster." (I hadn't been listening.) He tried steering me to a slightly smaller model, which I dismissed with a haughty sigh. It looked like a trinket, and I was sure that Consumer Reports would not approve.
My husband's warning began to haunt me during the three days between the grill's selection and its delivery. I started noticing various gas grills around the neighborhood, delicate things with little wooden slats for trays. In comparison to my Grillmaster, they looked like marvels of grill economy: backyard haiku.
Finally the day of the delivery arrived. But I had forgotten that my children were performing that very morning in the school music program, which would make it impossible for me to fulfill my consumer's duty to stay chained to my house. Daringly, I left a special message on the answering machine, instructing Home Depot I would be home by 10 A.M. When I got home, at 10:15, there was an irked response from Home Depot.
To punish me, they fed my Grillmaster steroids. It swaggered in, right after lunch, and took its new position on my patio, where it began staring down the old charcoal grill. I put the vinyl cover on, and it grew another three feet. I hadn't bought a grill; I'd bought a boat. Not just any boat, the Titanic. I didn't just have buyer's remorse. I was afraid I'd have to register Republican and trade my car in for a Cadillac to make the grill feel at home.
I was only slightly mollified when our hard-core clique of charcoal purists came over for a barbecue two days later and beheld my new technological wonder like cave men discovering fire. Of course, they probably wouldn't have laughed so hard if I'd bought a cuter model.
There is a lesson in all of this, maybe several. Never leave important decisions to Consumer Reports. Listen when a man who outweighs you by 60 pounds says something's big.
And, oh yes, be careful of what you wish for, because you just might buy it.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Weehawken's 10-Year Wallflower Lands a Tenant

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
CONSTRUCTED nearly a decade ago but never occupied, the 312,000-square-foot office building at 300 Boulevard East in Weehawken has been the Hudson County riverfront's reigning wallflower.
Now its turn to dance seems to have come. With Crown Properties of Garden City, L.I., in place as a new owner and a $1.5-million renovation complete, the three-story building, now called Riverview at Lincoln Harbor, has attracted its first tenant. 
 Earlier this month EDS, a technology-services provider formerly owned by Ross Perot, signed a five-year lease for 35,000 square feet. By August it will relocate from three scattered locations elsewhere in the state to the structure, which is minutes from the entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel.
"The truth is that with not a inch of space left on the waterfront the building has timing on its side," said Seena Stein, president of Newmark Partners of Rutherford, the New Jersey operation of Newmark & Company, a national brokerage.
Vacancies are decreasing and rents are rising along the Hudson County riverfront, which comprises 10 million square feet of office space mostly in Jersey City, but also in Hoboken and Weehawken. And large blocks of space, which are in short supply, are something Riverview at Lincoln Harbor has to offer.
As of the first quarter, the vacancy rate on the Hudson County riverfront was 8.2 percent and the rate for Class A space was 3.3 percent, among the lowest in the 11-county northern New Jersey marketplace, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the national commercial brokerage. With average asking rents for prime space on the waterfront at $30.85 per square foot it is also one of only three submarkets where rents for such space is that high. (The other submarkets are the I-78 corridor in Somerset County and along Routes 10 and 24 in Morris County.)
"At this point the growth market in North Jersey is the waterfront," said Robert P. Antonicello, president of the ACI Group, a real estate services firm in Jersey City. "It is no longer a frontier."
This is good news for Crown, which acquired the Weehawken building for $15 million in cash last July, becoming its fourth owner. The acquisition marks the initial foray into the New Jersey market for Crown, which owns some 5 million square feet of office space throughout the nation, three million of it in the New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Philadelphia area.
Joseph V. Scimone, director of acquisitions for Crown, said his company had bought 300 Boulevard East "because we felt that, with a little vision and a lot of money, it would turn itself around."
Despite the building's riverfront location, its checkered ownership history, coupled with the fact that it was caught in the recession, has kept it from attracting tenants -- except for a billboard company that rents rooftop space for $200,000 for a huge Toyota sign seen by thousands of daily Lincoln Tunnel commuters a day.
The structure was built on speculation by Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus, which also developed the nearby 1.5-million-square-foot, two-building Lincoln Harbor mixed-use complex where another 1.5 million square feet of space can eventually rise.
In fact, 300 Boulevard East was actually built around a smaller structure that was once used to store sets and props for the Metropolitan Opera Company in Manhattan. Columns from the original building are all that remain.
By the time Riverview at Lincoln Harbor was completed in 1989 the market had soured and tenants has vanished, leaving the building empty and its interior space unfinished. Two years later Hartz gave back the building in lieu of foreclosure to its lender, Chase Manhattan, which sold it in 1995 to Archon, a Manhattan-based investment firm.
Because Archon was unwilling to divide the building into smaller units, no tenants were acquired, brokers said. They also said that Archon, like Chase, made no effort to spruce up the building to help it compete in a market that by 1996 was slowly improving.
CROWN bought the vacant building the following summer "at a decent price," feeling that that once it was upgraded it could woo tenants, said Mr. Scimone. "We knew we needed to invest money in the building, which was essentially mothballed for a decade, to make it attractive," he added, noting that it would be marketed for use by multiple tenants.
As part of the renovation, completed last February, the company gave the building a new lobby and upgraded the elevators. It also spent more than $40,000 on new landscaping.
To gain its first tenant, Mr. Scimone said that Crown was leasing space to EDS at $18 a square foot. (Comparable space along the waterfront rents for $25.)
"That deal was an ice-breaker, a way to get things going," he said, adding that as the building leases over the next 18 months rents will go to the low-$20's for the next few deals and top out in the mid-$20.
EDS, which is based in Plano, Tex., searched for seven months and looked at more than a dozen sites before selecting Riverview at Lincoln Harbor. "It was the best fit for the company's current and future needs," said Melissa Brown, a company spokeswoman, adding that EDS expected to expand within the building in the near future.
"The company wanted to be accessible by car to New York City and the fact that this building sits just outside the Lincoln Tunnel and is close to the Holland Tunnel was a major plus," said Eric Witmondt, president of Associated Realty, based in Parsippany, which represented EDS.
Ms. Stein, of Newmark Partners, which represented Crown, said that with EDS moving to Riverview at Lincoln Harbor "the building is viable in the eyes of potential tenants." (Insignia/ESG now handles leasing at the building.)
Mr. Scimone is hoping for a domino effect, given the space squeeze in northern New Jersey in general and along the waterfront in particular.
The lack of prime space has pushed leasing activity along the riverfront, which continues at a steady pace, to older buildings that are being renovated to modern office space. One is the 164,000-square-foot building at 2 Montgomery Street in Jersey City, which the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company recently leased. And at the 300,000-square-foot building at 30 Montgomery Street, 16 tenants have signed on in the last 11 months for a total of 37,801 square feet of space, raising its occupancy level to 94 percent from 72 percent.
At the same time the riverfront is getting two new buildings. Last month the Lefrak Organization of Rego Park, Queens, started construction on a 561,000-square-foot building at its 60-acre Newport mixed-use development in Jersey City. And this month Hartz is to break ground on a 419,000-square-foot tower about a mile south in the city.
Mr. Scimone said Riverview at Lincoln Harbor would be a less expensive alternative to those buildings as well as those in downtown Manhattan, where rents are escalating. Because the Weehawken building has large floors it is well-suited to back-office operations , although Mr. Scimone said Crown was not ruling out its potential as executive offices.
But attracting companies from downtown Manhattan -- especially financial concerns, the riverfront's main tenant source -- may be difficult since the building is not near a PATH station, which brokers said was a key draw to such employers. The Weehawken site is five blocks from ferry service to midtown Manhattan, but the closest PATH station is in neighboring Hoboken.
"The typical downtown financial firm wants that immediate access by PATH for a quick commute across the river," said Edwin H. Cohen, executive director at the Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield.
Mindful of that, Mr. Scimone said Crown intends to provide shuttle service for tenants to both the Hoboken PATH station and the Weehawken ferry. And looking to the future, he said there will be the 20.5-mile light rail system that will run along the riverfront with a station planned next to Riverview at Lincoln Harbor.
