HEADLINE: Languages And Learning, The Debate Simmers

BYLINE: By MELINDA TUHUS 

 BODY:
AS voters in California rejected bilingual education last week, a General Assembly committee in Connecticut was studying the effectiveness of bilingual education for this state's 20,000 non-English-speaking children.
In the intense debate, one side says bilingual classes are necessary to ease non-English-speaking children into regular classes and to prevent them from falling behind. Another side says these children are being isolated and held back in bilingual classes. 
 In Connecticut, several times over the past decade, Tom Scott of Milford, formerly a Republican State Senator, proposed legislation that would have eliminated transitional bilingual education. "It's not a matter of whether we teach new arrivals English, it's how we do it," said Mr. Scott, who is now a talk show host on a New Haven-area radio station. "Immersion is what we did in this country for a long time. It's only since the 60's that we have kids segregated by language."
Mr. Scott's bills were defeated. Since he left office, the debate has died down in Connecticut. Last fall, however, the legislature set up a committee to look into bilingual education. A chairwoman of the committee, State Representative Nancy Beals, Democrat of Hamden, said legislators were concerned that after several years in the program, many youngsters still had not learned English. But she also understands it's a complicated problem. "Children seem to need a firm foundation in one language before going on to another one," said Ms. Beals. "You would expect that by age 5, a child would have had that in their own language. Unfortunately we are finding that's not always true even among English-speaking kids. This seems to be an argument against total immersion for those children."
Ms. Beals said her own children learned French one year when the family lived in France, with vigorous reinforcement from her and her husband.
Mr. Scott, who still believes in his cause, said the issue has abated because no one else was as committed to it and as willing to take the heat. "The attacks on me were nasty," he said, "and came from the taxpayer-funded bilingual gravy train in Hartford and Washington."
Patricia McCann-Viseppo, a long-time member of the New Haven school board and a supporter of the district's bilingual program, sees things differently. Ms. McCann-Viseppo said the "bilingual gravy train" Mr. Scott refers to is a myth. "Bilingual education programs receive just $116 a year per pupil more than regular classroom programs," she said. "That's not a big motivator. It's also a myth that bilingual teachers would be out of jobs if the bilingual program were cut. They are certified, tenured teachers. If you have a certain number of kids per teacher by contract, you have to have a contracted number of teachers for the total number of students, whether they're in bilingual programs or not."
Bilingual classes must be offered by any school district in the state that has at least 20 students speaking a particular language other than English. Seventeen districts offer such programs. The first language of the vast majority of the students in bilingual programs is Spanish; the others are Portuguese, Haitian Creole, Polish, Vietnamese, Lao, Khmer and Albanian. Bridgeport offers programs in six languages, New Britain in three, while most of the rest offer classes in Spanish.
When there are fewer than 20 children in a district speaking the same language, they are offered classes in English as a Second Language rather than bilingual classes. And there's one district, Windham, where children participate in a two-way English-Spanish bilingual program.
The state consultant for bilingual education, George De George, said, "The bottom line is to educate the children. We have to have a quality program. It takes five to seven years for results to show up on standardized tests given in English."
Ms. McCann-Viseppo said supporters of bilingual education have done a poor job of educating people about the realities of such education.
"I think there is a lot of misinformation," she said.. "People don't understand how difficult it is to learn a language for academic use as opposed to conversational use. Parents are anxious when they see their kids in a bilingual education program for two or three years and hear them speaking English," but the children have not been moved into regular classes. Lisette McGowan is in charge of bilingual education for the New Haven schools. About 1,800 students are in the program each year, almost one of every 10 students in the district. Ms. McGowan said many Hispanic parents whose children speak English want their children in the program to learn Spanish as a way of maintaining their cultural heritage. But these students are not eligible.
The transitional bilingual program offers subject matter instruction in Spanish. Beginning students take all core subjects in Spanish, but from the start they are in regular classes for homeroom, physical education, art and music. So, in the New Haven program, at least, students are never as isolated as some critics charge. They gradually take more and more courses in English as a Second Language, then in regular classes, until they are fully enrolled in regular classes. But even then, Ms. McGowan said, students should continue language development in their first language so they don't forget it.
"We really want our students to be fully competent in two languages," she said. "We'd like to move toward bilingualism even for our native English-speaking students. In order to compete in a global economy, you need more than one language. We feel that the children in bilingual education have something to offer to native speakers of English, to expose them to their language and culture. We want to move away from the idea that bilingual education is compensatory."
Ms. McGowan said fewer than 1 percent of children entering kindergarten who are eligible for the program decline participation, and that of those who do participate, only 1 percent drop out while staying in the system. She adds that 60 percent of the students in the program have been enrolled for two years or less. Many of their families are transient, moving back and forth between Puerto Rico and Connecticut or around the tristate area. Statewide, a quarter of the students in bilingual programs move out of district each year.
Ms. McGowan said she is frustrated that the school district cannot provide more help to those students who speak a language other than Spanish. There aren't enough of them to constitute a bilingual class, so they get tutoring in English as a Second Language.
"Many of them do not do very well," Ms. McGowan said. "Their success is predicated on how good their prior schooling has been. They suffer tremendously if their education has been disrupted by war, for example. We get lots of students who have not attended school at all."
If, on the other hand, children arrived in New Haven with a good educational background, albeit in a language other than English, Ms. McGowan said they have a much easier time.
"If they already have skills in their native language, they can transfer everything; all they need are new linguistic labels."
There are many different kinds of bilingual programs, and some work better than others. New Haven teachers and administrators have visited successful programs in other states and hope to duplicate some of what they've seen. One such program, called Amigos, is in Cambridge, Mass. It is a comprehensive two-way bilingual Spanish/English program from kindergarten through eighth grade. Native speakers of each language learn the other language.
The Connecticut state consultant for bilingual education, Mr. DeGeorge, said the Amigos program was the model for the state's only existing two-way bilingual program, in Windham.
"The kids help each other with the language," he said, "and also do some study of subject content in each of the native languages." Many studies have been done on the best way to teach English to non-English speakers. A committee of experts from top universities and the Center of Applied Linguistics recently sifted through the studies. They concluded that transitional bilingual education holds a slight but clear advantage over the immersion method. The committee concluded that there is no one answer for children who need to learn English.
The principal of an elementary school in New Haven that serves a largely Hispanic population made some innovations in the bilingual program there, with good results. Alicia Carraballo has been principal of Hill Central School for five years.
"I was concerned that because of the way the program was structured, kids in kindergarten through second grade were only learning isolated words in English," said Ms. Carraballo. "It wasn't until the third grade that they were in a paired English/Spanish model."
She continued: "In fourth grade all the children take the Connecticut Mastery Test, in English, of course. Our kids were very frustrated at their scores. They were crying; they were very upset. We looked to see how we could increase English instruction while maintaining instruction in Spanish. Last year we did away with separate second and third grades. We put them together and assessed their English ability."
And there was more, Ms. Carraballo explained: "We looked at teacher strengths and developed a departmental approach. We have students who are grouped together based on English proficiency. We extended the time spent with the teacher in English and worked on writing. This year for the first time we have bilingual students who have met the state standards for fourth graders in writing. It's early, but I am pleased with the initial results. The closer we focus on the students' needs and abilities, and individualize instruction, the better we do."
There's no doubt that non-English-speaking parents in Connecticut want their children to learn English. The only question is what method works best. Maria Ruiz has three children at Hill Central School. She's convinced that the transitional bilingual program is the way to go.
Ms. Ruiz, speaking in Spanish, said: "I grew up in Puerto Rico. I've been in New Haven for five years, and I lived in New Jersey four years before that. I want my children to learn English, but not to forget their Spanish. We speak Spanish at home. My children have learned English in school. They're teaching me English. My fourth grader and even my second grader are fluent in English now. My first grader is half and half."
She continued: "There is a lot of discrimination here against people who don't speak English. I know. Fortunately, that will not happen to my children." She added that in the fall she is planning to study English.
Ms. Ruiz said she thinks the elimination of a transitional bilingual approach would be a bad idea. "For children who come here and don't know English, that would be a terrible thing. Sometimes kids come here from other places with good grades and don't know English. They would really suffer. You have to go little by little. My children all had help."
Ms. Ruiz's 9-year-old daughter, Queila Galan, said the bilingual program was fine. But when the little girl was asked how she would have felt if she'd been put immediately in all English classes, she responded -- in English -- in a way that might surprise her mother. "It's better to do it all in English," said Queila, "because English is my second language and I need to learn it better."
Queila's response demonstrates the different possibilities for all non-English-speaking children trying to learn English. While many children will swim when tossed into an immersion program, others will get lost and fall farther and farther behind.
Nationally, Hispanic high school students have a much higher dropout rate than students of most other ethnic backgrounds. While all the reasons aren't clear, experts say that language difficulties can't be discounted. In New Haven, the drop-out rate is just two percentage points above the proportion of Hispanic children in the system, which is 27 percent.
The state legislative committee studying bilingual education is forging on. Ms. Beals said she has been impressed with some of the New Haven schools the committee has visited, because of the quality of the teaching and the response of the children, who were speaking in English and Spanish. They plan to visit several more schools around the state, and issue a report in January.

HEADLINE: ART;
From Cuba, 5 Artists Concerned With the Darker Side of Life

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR 

DATELINE: THE BRONX

 BODY:
THE show at the Longwood Arts Gallery here, is the sum of installations by Abel Barroso, Tania Bruguera, Sandra Ceballos, Manuel Pina and Lazaro Savaadra. All five artists come from Cuba, not as immigrants but as guests awarded residencies at arts organizations in Buffalo, Chicago, Houston, New York City and San Diego.
The operation, which began last winter, was organized by Holly Bloch, executive director of Art in General, an alternative space in TriBeCa, and Betti-Sue Hertz, director of the Longwood Arts Project/Bronx Council on the Arts, and is supported by the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts, the Lef Foundation and the Reed Foundation. 
 The exhibition, "1990's Art From Cuba," would be nothing without its catalogue, which includes interviews with and biographies of the artists, most of whom are unknown in the United States, along with essays by the curators and contributions from authorities who live in Cuba or were born there.The "Longwood Five" range from 27 to 37 in age and except for Mr. Pina, who studied mechanical engineering in the former Soviet Union, all are graduates of Cuban art schools.
This is no ordinary show of assemblage art, for it lacks the traits that have become part and parcel of the genre, notably obsessive-compulsiveness, concern with surface effects and a sentimental regard for decay. The artists have come, some for the first time, to a country inundated with objects, and yet none of them seem overwhelmed by such horrifying profusion. On the contrary, they make their points with minimal fuss, and should they change their approach in the future it will surely be because of an improvement in their country's economic situation rather than their own encounter with consumerism.
Mr. Savaadra states in his interview that while it originated in the academy installation art was at first regarded as "ideological diversionism" but is now accepted, thanks to the influence of imported magazines. Of the three works presented by this artist, the first consists of a corner table for one with two wineglasses containing red candles and, propped against the facing wall, a mirror scrawled with the words, "I don't expect anyone but insist that someone must come."
For his second piece, Mr. Savaadra drops roughly carved wood puppets on the floor in four rows, seven to a row, where they lie as if crumpled by their fall from the strings dangling overhead. Then the artist produces a formation of nine headless ducks led by one that has a head and carries those of the flock behind him in a string bag. The birds are carved out of styrofoam and painted in dark colors except for their truncated necks, which are daubed bright red, and they fly across a wall under the title, "Dying Free."
Temporarily separated from her home, Tania Bruguera, empathizes with those for whom the condition is permanent, be they Cuban immigrants or the lost and forgotten Americans in Chicago who inspired her performance at School of the Art Institute there. As a collection of nine black and white photographs taken in that city's homeless "zone" at night -- cardboard boxes, old clothes and other trash -- Ms. Bruguera's contribution is disappointingly static and improves little when viewed as the byproduct of her performance.
Sandra Ceballos is also concerned with the darker aspects of life, but she uses hosts of pink pills, stockings stuffed with wadding, blood-stained fabric, pocket knives and color photographs of what appears to be human tissue. Her assemblages, mercifully, only hint at horror. One example is the soft sculpture that, suspended in a cradle of upholstery bands, may or may not symbolize a fetus; another is the skein of blond wool braided to look like hair and hidden under a cloth.
Pina and Abel Barroso are equally conscious of Cuban history, but Mr. Pina, a photographer, has something to say about contemporary life on the mainland, too. The first of two large computer-generated prints, "Mix the Colors," features a black woman against palm trees, while the second, "Cross the Border," focuses on a pair of shapely thighs in a miniskirt. Mr. Barroso's disaffection, on the other hand, is focused on greed and avarice and is symbolized by eight rocking horses. Rendered in a large watercolor, the horses ply the waves to and from Cuba but, carved out of plywood and decorated with black woodcuts incorporating cameras, telephones and money, they ride the floor of the gallery.
A show that is definitely more than the sum of its contents, it moves to Chicago after closing here on June 27. The numbers to call for information are (718) 409-6445 and (212) 219-0473.

HEADLINE: ATLANTIC CITY;
Back at Home Port

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
THE paint was wet and the seasickness bags were in the mail, but Scott Chew, president of the Atlantic City Packet Company, was certain last week that the tall ship Young America would make its first scheduled voyage from Gardner's Basin on Friday, when 100 Atlantic County school age children are to get a free taste of life under full sail at the start of the Omnipoint Seafood Festival.
"The only thing that could possibly stop us is the weather, and it would have to be pretty extreme to keep us in," Mr. Chew said. "The hull is made of steel-reinforced concrete. This is probably the sturdiest sightseeing boat you're going to find anywhere. You'd need a pretty big blow to keep us in port." 
 Mr. Chew, his wife, Millie, and their son, Rayford, have been living aboard the ship since they bought the twin-masted 125-foot schooner in November. Now, with a marketing assistant, a captain and a crew of five, the Chews are preparing the vessel for a triumphal return to service.
"This is one of those jobs most people dream about but never do," Mr. Chew said. "My wife and I had been talking about it for 12 years. When our son, Rayford, came into this world, we didn't feel he was old enough to do it. He's 11 now, and he loves the ship as much as we do."
He hopes the sight of the ship will draw more than stares from the Boardwalk. "The ship means a lot to many people around here," he said. "We have to show the people that it's back, for good."
Built on Long Island in 1976, the ship was brought to Atlantic City with the promise of transforming the Gardner's Basin marina area into a non-gambling tourist attraction. During the summer season, it took as many as 100 passengers on two-and-a-half-hour voyages. The ship was the city's most spectacular non-gambling tourist attraction for most of the 1980's. A favorite of high-rolling gamblers, conventioneers, casino workers and locals enamored of tall ships, the vessel nevertheless encountered financial hard times during the recession of 1987 and stopped sailing in the early 1990's.
In 1994, Steven Pagels, a New England businessman, bought the ship, towed it to Maine and spent $300,000 to repair it. Last year, Mr. Pagels was going to use the ship for chartered Caribbean sailing cruises when Mr. Chew, who had previously sailed on Lake Michigan and in the Caribbean, answered an advertisement for a business opportunity in a trade magazine. He decided to take the ship back to Atlantic City because "it had made a name for itself here," he said. "There were enough people who had sailed on it and thought that this was the highlight of their stay."
Although one casino has chartered the ship for a sail, "I haven't gone after the casinos in a big way because I don't want us to get into a situation in which we depend on them for our survival," Mr. Chew said. "I've also heard they tend to want their customers to stay indoors. This is a definite outdoor experience."
Passenger benches cover most of the deck space, and Mr. Chew advises prospective passengers to wear hats and take plenty of sunscreen. Passengers are permitted below deck only to visit the lavatories. "There's no hot tub, no sauna, no video screens, no computer games, no frills or extras of any kind," Mr. Chew said. "If it rains, we'll all get wet, which I figure should be the least of our worries."
Hoping he'll attract enough passengers, at $25 for adults and $15 for children 12 and under, is "keeping me awake at nights," he said. To break even, the ship must sail at least twice a day with at least 10 passengers.
"We want to sail as late as mid-September and then maybe go down to the Caribbean for charters in the winter, and then come back here for the spring. If things don't work out, we can always stay in the Caribbean. But I'm getting to like it here. In the Caribbean, they have lots of tall ships. Nobody even looks. Here, we're the biggest thing around. I get a lot of wows from the landlubbers."
Beyond "telling some people that we're here," Mr. Chew said he had not received any assistance from the city's tourism and convention bureau or the Casino Reinvestment and the Development Authority.
"I wouldn't have minded a little more than that, but at least, if we make it, we can say we did it on our own," he said. "At this point, we've had to put off any kind of celebrating. We don't have a bottle of champagne for the first voyage out. We can't afford it."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 8; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 281 words

HEADLINE: 'Smaller Inventory Of Homes'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Buyers Finding Smaller Inventory of Homes" April 19 portrays the current market reality of dwindling inventory and its consequent effect on home sales. There can be little doubt that pent-up demand created after nearly 10 years of flat home sales and low interest rates has confronted home buyers with a reduced supply of housing. However, homebuyers need not abandon hope of being able to negotiate a fair and reasonable deal on a house. 
Although the examples cited of multiple offers and bidding wars accurately depict a market with renewed fervor, my experience as a buyer's broker in Westchester County is that the clear majority of the houses on the market are not subject to the type of buying frenzy described in the article. A substantial percentage of the homes listed in the Westchester Multiple Listing Service have been on the market for several months, which is a normal waiting period for the sale of a house. Consequently, buyers in many instances are in a position to negotiate with a seller on a level playing field.
While the instances of multiple offers are indicative of a new trend favoring sellers, it is not necessarily representative of a marketplace where buyers are left out in the cold. Buyers who exercise care in searching for a house and adhere to fundamental principles of investing can still make a sound purchase in the current market environment. For the astute homebuyer, the message contained in the article is not one of despair. Rather, it is that caution should be the watchword when purchasing a home, particularly in a fast-paced market.
 
IRA FISCHER
The Home Buyer's Agency Ltd.
Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

HEADLINE: The Preservation Band That Sets the Tone

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
THE architectural firm of Beyer Blinder Belle was born in the tumultuous year of 1968, with a bow to Jane Jacobs and a commitment to the maverick ideas of community-based planning and rehabilitation rather than bulldozing. Today, it finds itself where its founders never expected to be: on the inside track.
The rebuilding and restoration of Grand Central Terminal? That's Beyer Blinder Belle. The remodeling of Rockefeller Center? Beyer Blinder Belle. The Ford Center for the Performing Arts, where "Ragtime" is playing? Beyer Blinder Belle again. 
 Across 42d Street from the Ford Center, Beyer Blinder Belle is designing a hotel and entertainment complex for Forest City Ratner. Allied with the Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava, it is one of three teams competing for the new Pennsylvania Station concourse that is proposed within the General Post Office on Eighth Avenue.
The tiny Swedish Cottage in Central Park bears the mark of Beyer Blinder Belle, as do renovations at La Guardia Airport, new approaches to the Williamsburg Bridge, a study of the Yankee Stadium area, the revival of the Sun Building near City Hall, a new museum in the South Street Seaport and master plans for Columbia University and Governors Island.
If Beyer Blinder Belle seems to be everywhere, it is because preservation has become an integral part of development in the years since the firm was founded by John H. Beyer (rhymes with spire), now 65 years old; Richard Blinder (rhymes with tinder), who is 62 and John Belle, 65.
Having backed into landmarks practice through rehab work, they embraced it in 1979 by adding James Marston Fitch, regarded as the dean of American preservation, to the partnership. Today, the firm enjoys an influence out of proportion to its modest size. What makes its emergence so remarkable is that the firm does not have a recognizable style, even in the numerous buildings it has designed from scratch, which include a slender, glass-clad 45-story apartment tower at 300 East 93d Street.
There is no such thing as a Beyer Blinder Belle signature project, unless it is the renovation of an iconic landmark like Grand Central that leaves the public with little sense of modern intervention.
"I've received more favorable comments on the terminal than on any other aspect of our operations," said E. Virgil Conway, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. "There have been a lot of changes but at the same time, the overall appearance is one of restoration."
Asked to name the greatest influence on their practice, the founding partners do not cite a master architect or planner.
Instead, they point to Ms. Jacobs, a writer and Greenwich Village activist, who declared in "The Death and Life of Great American Cities" (1961) that "cities need old buildings so badly it is probably impossible for vigorous streets and districts to grow without them" -- apostasy to a design establishment that was pursuing urban renewal.
In a telephone interview from Toronto, where she now lives, Ms. Jacobs recalled the emergence of Beyer Blinder Belle.
"They were looking at the fabric of the community," she said. "That was very welcome and very exciting, that there were professionals who were, at last, doing that. Also, they recognized that time is important in these things. A community can't just come by waving a wand. It has history. History was, to the modernists, an enemy. So this was a very radical realization. And an important one."
Beyer Blinder Belle's grounding in community-based planning has served it well.
"People look at them as the firm that gets things through agencies," said Laurie Beckelman, a former chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission. "But they also have compassion and sympathy toward the community, and they can work with both. They are not seen as slam-dunk, but as fair, reasonable and balanced."
It remains to be seen how long this firm -- or any firm with so many high-powered clients -- can maintain that reputation.
O NE of the prices of success is that you begin to think like a developer," said Barbaralee Diamonstein, chairwoman of the Historic Landmarks Preservation Center. "That may or may not be a bad thing." Beyer Blinder Belle is to be "congratulated and cautioned," she said. "They learned early on to merge the historical with the commercial. They have obviously perfected that and made it agreeable both to developers and to the public and private organizations, commissions and institutions that have to approve these things. A large aspect of architecture is presentation, and they are virtuosi at it."
But the firm's impressive presentation charting the many changes over time to Rockefeller Center has done little to persuade preservationists that it would be appropriate to enlarge the storefronts along Fifth Avenue and diminish the red-granite setting of Prometheus.
Although the New York Landmarks Conservancy supports the plan, it has come under fire from the Municipal Art Society, Historic Districts Council and others.
At the same time, Upper West Siders are attacking plans for a 41-story apartment tower by Beyer Blinder Belle that would adjoin the Y.M.C.A. on West 63d Street, near Central Park West. It would rise on the site of the former McBurney School, whose facade is to be preserved. Besides the sheer size of the mid-block building, opponents deplore the segregation of entrances to the lower-income rental housing at the base and the high-priced condominiums above.
And even Mr. Fitch questioned the firm's plans on behalf of Donald J. Trump to strip the St. Moritz Hotel on Central Park South to its steel skeleton and erect a new facade that would evoke, but not duplicate, the original. (Debate over that project became moot in April when Mr. Trump lost the property to the hotelier Ian Schrager.)
The future probably holds more quandaries of this kind: is preservation best served by rigorous replication of historic features or by new construction, sympathetic in spirit, that sometimes involves the demolition of existing architectural fabric?
"It's much easier to be doctrinaire when there's less at stake," said Hugh Hardy, of Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates, a firm whose restoration work includes the New Amsterdam Theater. "Their success will inevitably lead them into facing increasingly difficult issues which have as much to do with the marketplace and the client base as with the inherent ideology of the firm."
The challenge is evidently relished by the younger partners who are gradually assuming the reins at Beyer Blinder Belle.
"We've redefined what is meant by preservation," said Richard Southwick, 44, a partner since 1993. "It may mean moving a building down the block or building a new theater where two older theaters stood."
(The historic Empire Theater was rolled 170 feet along West 42d Street as part of the Forest City Ratner project. The Ford Center, designed with Kofman Engineering for Garth H. Drabinsky, incorporates significant elements from the Lyric and Apollo Theaters, but both playhouses were razed.)
"The greatest and most enriching architecture is that which layers the new and old, allowing each to express itself honestly," said Frederick Bland, a 52-year-old designer. In 1978, he became the first partner at Beyer Blinder Belle outside the original trio.
"There is nothing so precious that it cannot accommodate some new use," Mr. Beyer said. This may not be pure preservationist orthodoxy, but Beyer Blinder Belle has long prided itself in being a bit out of step. "Controversy contributes to our credibility as architects who are always reaching, always trying," Mr. Beyer said.
It seems fitting that this partnership should have emerged from the 1960's, when so many conventions were upended.
As the decade began, all three men were in Cambridge, Mass., unknown to one another. Mr. Beyer, a native of Weehawken, N.J., and Mr. Blinder, who grew up in New York City, were in different classes at the Harvard University Graduate School of Design. Mr. Belle, who had come from Cardiff, Wales, by way of London, was working for Jose Luis Sert, an architect, planner and dean of the Harvard design school.
When Le Corbusier came to Harvard in 1960 to unveil his design for the Carpenter Center for the Visual Arts, Beyer and Blinder and Belle attended the event, having no idea at the time -- as they nibbled cookies baked in the shape of Corbusier's "Modulor" man icon -- that they were standing in the same room as their future partners.
They did not get to know one another until the mid-60's, when all three worked in the New York office of Victor Gruen. It was then that they felt the tension between their instincts and those of their colleagues. "A lot of the profession was going in the direction of urban removal," Mr. Belle said.
SO they set up shop on their own at 31 Union Square West. "We weren't in the mainstream," Mr. Beyer said. "We were doing nitty-gritty stuff in the Bronx," like the 1,000-unit Jose de Diego-Beekman Houses in the Mott Haven section.
"We certainly didn't burst on the scene," Mr. Blinder allowed. "We grew and evolved." One early client, Robert Bonham, was a developer of low-income co-ops in the Bronx who went on to become the president of the South Street Seaport Museum. Through their planning and design work at South Street, the partners got to know Mr. Fitch, whom they invited to join the firm when he retired from Columbia University.
"That was our bridge to Ellis Island," Mr. Blinder said of Mr. Fitch, who gave the firm the needed credibility to pursue that commission. The $25 million renovation and restoration of Ellis Island as the National Museum of Immigration, undertaken with Notter Finegold & Alexander, put Beyer Blinder Belle squarely on the map.
Ellis Island was one of several factors weighed by the M.T.A. selection committee that was looking for architects to replan Grand Central. "The terminal needed to be preserved and restored but it also needed to be changed a bit," said Peter E. Stangl, the former chairman of the M.T.A. "John Belle shared that vision, even though he has strong preservation principles."
The most controversial aspect of the project was the decision to build an entirely new staircase on the east side of the concourse, balancing that on the Vanderbilt Avenue side. "That was kind of shocking to the traditionalists," Mr. Stangl conceded.
But not to Mr. Fitch. "The logic of the plan suggested that there would have been a balancing stair there," he said. "That's the essence of Beaux-Arts philosophy. We found working drawings that showed that a staircase could be put in. We found steel connections all prepared for the stair."
At the age of 89, Mr. Fitch retired last month from active practice. He was succeeded in the partnership by James W. Rhodes, 52, who was named on Tuesday. The other partners are Douglas McR. McKean, 42, and Richard Metsky, 40. Marilyn Marullo, 46, is the administrative officer, a position equivalent to partner.
Altogether, eight partners and two associate partners own a stake in the firm, whose gross annual billings amount to $15.5 million. There are about 100 employees. In the latest ranking, Beyer Blinder Belle was the 18th largest firm in the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects.
From a peak of 150 employees in the mid-80's, the firm shrank to fewer than 50 during the depth of the recession in the early 90's.
"We kept most of our senior staff," Ms. Marullo said, "although we had them working on the boards." Those who remained took pay cuts. The firm depended on public works and other "bread-and-butter" projects, said Maxinne Rhea Leighton, the managing director of business development.
Only six blocks from its original home, Beyer Blinder Belle occupies the second floor of a loft building at 11th Street and University Place. A 60-foot-long display wall bisects the space at a 45-degree angle, leading to the "crit pit," a large room where wide-ranging critiques occur almost every Tuesday morning over breakfast.
Its partners take pride in being more New York-oriented than many of their competitors. "They say they're on their way to Kuala Lumpur," Mr. Belle noted, "and we're on our way to the Bronx."
"I'm going through subway cards like crazy," Mr. Blinder added.
But the firm's national profile will surely grow. One project on the drawing boards involves the potential recreation of Thomas U. Walter's original 1859 design for the United States Senate Chamber.
The firm is active in planning, renovating private homes and corporate interiors. It is also cultivating business in new construction, Mr. McKean said, on the grounds that "we know how buildings are put together."
"The lack of a signature style has its liabilities and strengths," Mr. Metsky said. "It may be a liability in getting a commission for a new building. But the strength is in our ability to group together to solve complex problems. A non-signature building doesn't have to be done by one hand."
Rather than being divided among specialists, projects are given to teams of generalists who follow the work from the earliest sketches to the last punch list. The advantage is that even junior architects can gain broad experience. The disadvantage is the potential for burnout, particularly on jobs like Grand Central that go on for years.
No one is expecting Beyer or Blinder or Belle to burn out anytime soon. "As long as they want to practice architecture, it's open to them," Mr. McKean said, adding that the name of the firm will not change.
As to the future, Mr. Belle looks forward to standing in a completed Grand Central and overhearing one commuter ask another: "Doesn't the east staircase look better now that it's been restored?"

HEADLINE: JERSEYANA;
Does Anybody Have Room for One or Two More Hot Dogs?

 BODY:
The Chatter column on May 24 asked readers to share their favorite places to get hot dogs. Here are some of the responses: 
 My husband and I are originally from Passaic. About 26 years ago, we were in Israel on a tour. We met another young couple from Chicago; the husband was originally from Clifton.
When his wife found out we were from Passaic she became very excited. During a stop somewhere in the desert, she said: "I just want to know. Are the hot dogs at Rutt's as good as he tells me?"
I have no doubt that Rutt's hot dogs are known throughout the civilized world, having been spoken of by two generations who grew up going there for hot dogs and onion rings after innumerable high school basketball games.
 
MIRIAM PICKETT
New Milford
There is no better place for a "ripper" than Rutt's Hutt in Clifton. This place has been serving hot dogs and birch beer for over 60 years. Oh yeah, how about the onion rings?
 
BILL RACHLES
Naples, Fla.
 
 Stewarts, whose headquarters are in New Jersey, surely boasts the best of hot dogs, especially when accompanied by the old-fashioned frosted mug of root beer. Eating one (or two) of these franks, served by the carhop is not only delicious, but also conjures up lots of fond memories of high school dates when the thing to do was "pull in for a dog and a mug."

JANET M. BARKER
Toms River
Since I moved to New Jersey 30 years ago, I've been getting my hot dogs (and cheeseburgers and steak sandwiches) at the Anthony Wayne Charcoal Ovens on Route 46 in Wayne. Not only are the hot dogs great (everything cooked on that grill has a distinct, charcoal-broiled flavor and aroma you don't find anywhere else), but the atmosphere is unique. It's filled with antiques, including a beautiful grandfather's clock that works, and has an outdoor brick patio and great lawn with old flowering trees.
Mentioning the place would have added another dimension to your coverage of the "typical" hot dog stand. The place has been there for about 40 years. I understand it was the first establishment on that stretch of the highway, surrounded only by woods. It has a clientele of transients and locals dating from from the day it opened: regular travelers passing through to and from vacation homes, boomers who took their wives there after the prom and a whole new crowd of young adults.

TERENCE M. RIPMASTER
Hackettstown
George Petritis sold Sabrett's hot dogs and Yoo- Hoo out of a hot dog truck outside the DeWitt Theater in Bayonne for umpteen years. Moviegoers were gifted with a double header: a good movie and hot dogs at Petritis. The theater made way for progress: a McDonalds. What else? George didn't give up, however. He opened a store directly across the street, and continued his tradition, much to the love and enjoyment of the citizens of Bayonne!

KATHLEEN PACHECO
Elizabeth
Once upon a time, during the summer of 1945, two 15-year-old kids who would later become my parents met because of a hot dog.
My mother was vacationing at Loch Arbour with her parents, and my dad was working in one of the hotels. One day, on his time off, he decided to go down to the beach. Being a growing boy, he was also hungry. Ah, he thought, a hot dog would be just the thing. He spied a hot dog stand and took his place in line. As he looked up, though, the end of a delicious-looking wiener was staring him in the face, held up by the backward-facing hand of a shapely young girl. Having an eye for the ladies as well as the dogs, and desirous of making the girl's acquaintance, he took a large bite out of the hot dog. When the girl finished paying for her snack, she whirled around to see a red-faced boy with a very full mouth.
By the time she had finished yelling at him, he had recovered enough to offer to buy her another hot dog, and incidentally invited her to share the beach with him. The rest, as they say, is history. . . .
 
JOANNA RABOY
East Brunswick
I married young. We had no money, and I couldn't cook. Enter the delicious, economical hot dog. Boil water. Drop hot dogs in. Presto, dinner is served. I still love a good hot dog. But now with more jingle in my pocket, I let Nathan's do the cooking.
 
AUDREY CORN
Denville
 Proust had his madeleines, I have my hot dogs. I am descended from a long line of hot dog lovers. As a child in the 50's I remember Grandma Fanny favoring a road house called the Denville Shack, a frequent stop on our Sunday drives. By my college years, I officially welcomed spring by picking up Grandpa Eddie at his hangout in the park and driving to the Galloping Hills Caterers in Union for the first delicious dogs of the year.
 
JUDY HORWITZ WOLFF
Passaic
Boy, your topic brought back some fond memories. On St. George's Avenue in Linden there was a place called George's over 20 years. ago. There you got one of the best hot dogs and malted shakes around.
 
DEE HICKMAN
Hillsborough
Our favorite hot dog joint is not a joint. Great-tasting frankfurters (as they call them). It's the Anthony Wayne on Route 46 in Wayne. If you go, you must eat on the patio and try some of their homemade relish. Perfect.
 
SHIRLEY COCHRAN
Hackettstown
Gone are the Needic's, Sid's and Millman's. Now out in the country the closest hot dog place to these is Hot Dog Johnny's in Butzville. Great dogs, fries and birch beer in frosted mugs.
 
BARRY VERBEL
Flanders
 Over 25 years ago my Dad took me to this hot dog place in Orange, Jimmy Buffs. I could barely see over the counter and the place was always crowded. They had the best Italian style hot dogs with the peppers and potatos smothered in ketchup.
Today, Jimmy Buff's is still there and serving the best dogs in Jersey. I always stop in when I go to my mother's to visit. You don't know good dogs until you hit the Buff's. Da Best!!!
 
VINCENT A. D'ANTONIO Sr.
North Bergen
And for the New Jersey section's very last word on hot dogs, here are some etiquette tips from the National Hot Dog and Sausage Council.
Don't put hot dog toppings between the hot dog and the bun. Always "dress the dog," not the bun.
Do use paper plates to serve hot dogs. Everyday dishes are acceptable; china is a no-no.
Don't bring wine to a hot dog barbecue. Beer, soda, lemonade and iced tea are preferable.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Jill Levine, Daniel Bradford

 BODY:
Jill Beth Levine, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin R. Levine of Great Neck, N.Y., was married there last evening to Daniel Philip Bradford, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael J. Bradford of Locust Valley, N.Y. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El.
The couple are associates at Boston law firms, the bride at Foley, Hoag & Eliot, the bridegroom at Goodwin, Procter & Hoar. 
 Mrs. Bradford, 26, graduated magna cum laude from Cornell University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She received her law degree cum laude from Harvard University.
Her father is an associate dean at the Stern Graduate School of Business at New York University. Her mother, Hilda L. Levine, teaches the third grade at Landing Elementary School in Glen Cove, N.Y.
Mr. Bradford, 30, graduated summa cum laude from Yale University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and from which he also received his law degree. His mother, Emily G. Bradford, teaches American history and economics at Glen Cove High School. His father is an internist and gastroenterologist in Manhasset, N.Y., and an adjunct assistant professor of the N.Y.U. School of Medicine.

LENGTH: 1220 words

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
The Threatened Bells of St. Martin's

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
AT St. Martin's Episcopal Church on 230 Malcolm X Boulevard, at West 122d Street, the tintinnabulation of the bells, bells, bells is unusual, joyful -- and threatened.
Unlike bells that are played by pulling on a long rope, St. Martin's are arranged in an elaborate series of wires and levers known as a carillon. Played on a special keyboard, a carillon is one of music's grandest, rarest and most challenging percussive instruments, producing harmonies that, of course, are impossible on a single large bell. 
 St. Martin's is one of perhaps 250 carillons in churches, colleges and public buildings nationwide and one of two in New York City. The other, at Riverside Church in Morningside Heights, is much larger. St. Martin's carillon was built to celebrate the restoration of St. Martin's after a 1939 fire that almost destroyed the building.
But St. Martin's congregation, never huge and never rich, is shrinking and getting poorer, and its carillon has become increasingly dilapidated. Now, preservationist groups say, it needs hundreds of thousands of dollars in repairs, and the leaky tower that houses it also needs to be fixed.
Money is not the church's only problem. Even if St. Martin's can raise the cash needed for the carillon, it still needs to find someone to play it. Carillonneurs are even rarer than carillons: there are perhaps 75 in the United States, only 5 of them full-time professionals, according to the Guild of Carillonneurs in North America.
The instrument requires a player with finesse and raw strength. Next to no one is trained to teach it, so few music students have ever heard of it.
What's more, St. Martin's is in Harlem, where church music often means gospel. Black publications sometimes refer to St. Martin's carillon as "a cultural contradiction," an allusion to carilloning's roots in Europe and black churches' traditional commitment to the poor.
"Why not build soup kitchens instead of bringing in the bells, some have asked," said the Rev. David Johnson, 70, the senior minister and the eldest son of the founder, John H. Johnson. "But 'you must feed the soul as well as the body' is my reply."
Linda J. Herd, a private citizen who developed an interest in the church, hopes to nourish the soul and the carillon with a festival she has organized next Sunday. Up to five guest carillonneurs will play half-hour recitals, starting at noon. Ms. Herd said the church hoped to attract young people to a future instruction program for carillonneurs, much like the famed stone-carving program at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, and to entice benefactors to pay for repairs.
Joel M. Goldfrank, 50, a private investor on the Upper East Side who has agreed to provide a large portion of the estimated $156,000 needed to repair the bells, said he hoped to raise the rest of the money from city agencies and private contributors.
"When a church bell rings, it, at least subliminally, reminds people of their neighborhood," Mr. Goldfrank said. "In a city as sprawling and busy as New York, bells would make life more livable."
But the carillon repairs hinge on repairs to the 90-foot tower that houses it. With the help of Cityscape Institute, a nonprofit urban planning group, the church has applied for a $175,000 grant from the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, a Federal economic development program. The zone is expected to rule on the grant this summer.
"The tower is in a state of serious deterioration," said Ken Lustbader, director of the sacred sites program of the Landmarks Conservancy, the group that helped assess the damage to St. Martin's tower. "Water is leaking, the copper shielding is falling off and the masonry -- the bricks themselves -- need urgent replacement," he said.
That there is a carillon in Harlem at all is quite a feat. Unlike Riverside Church's carillon, which at 74 bells is the world's largest, St. Martin's 42-bell carillon was not a gift of John D. Rockefeller Jr. After the 1939 electrical fire left only the shell of the Romanesque Revival building, the 3,500-member congregation struggled to rebuild.
A parishioner, Arnold Rosey, originally from the West Indies, where church bells are common, gave $100 to the pastor, Mr. Johnson, specifically for a fund to buy a bell. Word spread and parishioners -- working-class men and women like laborers, hospital attendants and maids, most of them also from the West Indies -- contributed $2,000. Mr. Johnson and others decided on a carillon from the renowned Royal Bell Casting Foundry, in Heiligerlee in the Netherlands.
In two years, the congregation raised the then extraordinary sum of $45,000, and the bells were installed in 1949. For many in the congregation, however, the real climax arrived when Queen Juliana of the Netherlands came to see the bells in 1952, thronged by more than 7,000 Harlem well-wishers.
But Harlem was changing after World War II. Prosperous families began moving to Brooklyn and the Bronx. Today, there are fewer than 700 congregants at St. Martin's, and more than two-thirds live outside Harlem, said the Rev. David Johnson. As with other century-old churches (St. Martin's was built in 1887) and synagogues, deferred maintenance has often been the order of the day.
Still, St. Martin's paid attention to its bells. In 1962, the congregation sent its young carillonneur, Dionisio Lind, to learn more about the difficult art at a six-month carillon program in Belgium. Mr. Lind, now 67, plays with the verve of the accomplished carillonneur. To the outsider, it appears he is pulling off a strange combination of playing the organ and a game of handball.
Like other carillonneurs, Mr. Lind displays the four-limbed mania of the organ player, playing the keyboard, or clavier, with his hands and stomping down on foot pedals. But instead of playing a piano-like set of keys, he lifts and pushes down on a series of knobs known as batons. The batons and foot pedals are connected to the bells by wires. The heavier the bells, the more Mr. Lind has to lift and push.
The heaviest bells range from 1,150 to 3,100 pounds. Using balled fists to snap down on the batons that control them has raised heavy calluses on Mr. Lind's hands; without them, his hands would bleed.
St. Martin's strained finances have also taken their toll. Until retiring recently, Mr. Lind was a production manager at a nonprofit training group for the disabled. He played the carillon on Sundays and other occasions for a $25 fee, far less than the $200 or more that carillonneurs usually earn. Last year, when Riverside Church's carillonneur was on a sabbatical leave, Mr. Lind filled in at that church's far more celebrated carillon.
"Best thing that ever happened to me," Mr. Lind said, explaining that the church and Mr. Johnson "realized what they were missing, and they began to respect me more." Asked for a response, Mr. Johnson said, "Say I just smiled." Mr. Lind plans to play next Sunday and, as one of the country's senior carillonneurs, would be instrumental in any future instructional program.
"We are determined that there will be a future for these bells," Mr. Johnson said. "They are a cultural gold mine, like a painting. But what is most inspiring is that this is a painting paid for by poor people's money. They are poor people's bells."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dionisio Lind has been the church's carillonneur for more than 30 years. (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times)
 
Diagram: "WORK ORDER: Fixing the Bells"
Like other carillons, the one at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Harlem consists of a keyboard, or clavier, and an array of bells. The bells weigh from 20 to 3,100 pounds and are in good shape. But the wire system that manipulates the bells has rusted, loosened or otherwise been damaged since the carillon was installed in 1949, especially because of water leakage in the bell tower itself.
 
Here are the most urgent repairs:
 
1. Replace entire clavier, where carillonneur presses down on a manual lever or pedal.
 
2. Install new parts, like the umbrella system, that pull the transmission wire down, causing the transmission bar to rotate, which pulls the clapper, striking the bell.
 
3. Install new coil springs, and other parts, for tension control.
 
Also install a pratice clavier, so carillonneur can play without ringing bells.
 
(Source: Elderhorst Bells Inc.)

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Oil Can't Salve Russia's Wounds

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
POLITICAL gyrations, economic turmoil, crashing stock markets, embattled currency, collapsing tax revenue. In such troubled times, Russia might be forgiven for leaning hard on the one thing it can count on: oil and natural gas exports, paid for in dollars. Some investors worry that a sorely pressed Government might flood the already glutted world oil market and depress prices further.
So why doesn't Moscow just turn up the spigot to solve its economic and financial problems? 
 "They wish they could, but they can't," said Ann-Louise Hittle, who follows oil markets as a director of Cambridge Energy Associates, a consulting group in Boston. "They're producing as much as they can."
Far from ramping up production, the Russian oil industry has had to cut output by about 60,000 barrels a day because low prices -- about $11 a barrel for Russian exports, down from $18 a year ago -- and high production costs have made some wells uneconomical, Ms. Hittle said.
Russia is one of the world's leading oil exporters, with a big domestic industry and vast reserves, and it has a long history of using its output for its own political and economic purposes, ignoring the efforts of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries -- of which it is not a member -- to manage world supplies.
Now, though, Russia's ability to squeeze more income from oil depends on whether OPEC can agree to raise prices by cutting production at its mext meeting, later this month in Vienna. Russia plans to send a representative to the meeting, and is considering joining OPEC.
In advance of the meeting, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela agreed on Thursday with Mexico, which is not a member, to cut their production by 450,000 barrels a day. Those three nations led a coalition that managed to win agreement for production cuts last March, temporarily buoying prices.
But Russia's Energy Minister, Sergei Generalov, has said Russia cannot help OPEC by making further cuts of its own.
Instead, to raise cash, the Government has sought to privatize some of the industry. But prices for domestic oil companies proved just as disappointing as the price of oil. The Government tried to get $2.1 billion for RAO Rosneft, a huge energy company, but found no interested buyers; it recently had to drop the asking price to $1.6 billion to attract bids.
Russian oil industry executives, who were flexing political muscles at home and in neighboring nations a year or two ago when oil fetched $18 to $20 a barrel, are on the defensive, pleading for Government help with tax cuts and lower pipeline fees.
They are in a bind. Antiquated equipment at the wellhead makes trimming production a one-way proposition at many wells; once they are shut down, it would be very expensive to restart them. But at current oil prices, many of the same wells lose money on every barrel.
Unless OPEC and other major producers can agree to make another production cut, like one agreed upon in March, many analysts say oil prices may fall further, adding to the burdens of the economy. Russia exports about 25 percent of its output of about 6.2 million barrels a day, yielding 45 percent of the country's foreign-currency income. Production peaked in 1988, when most Eastern European countries were still captive customers, at 11.4 million barrels a day, but in the collapse of Communism the next year, output fell by nearly half.
Domestic energy prices in Russia are still somewhat shielded from world market trends, so the Russian oil industry has begun looking more toward domestic markets to help ride out the downturn. But ruble sales don't help refill Government coffers with hard currency.
Robert Ebel, a senior associate at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a research group in Washington, said Russian production increased slightly last year, mostly because of increasing investment by Western oil companies. But a lack of legal guarantees for foreigners has restricted the amounts that Western companies have been willing to commit to expand production further.
"It's unlikely that oil production in Russia will increase noticeably over the near term," Mr. Ebel said. "They have to make it attractive for Western companies to come in and invest." And without such investment, he said: "Russia is just about at its limit of what it can export. The pipelines are basically full."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT/EARNING IT;
Subjects Uneasy as a Benevolent Reign Ends

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: SKOKIE, Ill.

 BODY:
FOR 80 years, workers at Fel-Pro Inc., a manufacturer of automotive parts based here, have enjoyed some of the lushest benefits in corporate America.
The list is long and varied: as much as 12 weeks of vacation; scholarships; summer camp for employees' children; a fitness center; tutoring; the state's first licensed day-care center; use of a 250-acre corporate retreat, and even a $1,000 savings bond for the birth of an employee's child. 
 Not to mention solid health, pension and profit-sharing plans and a pro-nepotism policy that has meant that two-thirds of the 1,900 employees at the company's headquarters plant have had relatives on the payroll at one time or another. Or such gestures as a ham at Easter, a turkey at Christmas and candy for Valentine's Day. Even the employees' neighborhoods benefit: groups in which workers volunteer receive grants.
Pay averages $12.50 an hour, what the company calls "very competitive" wages for the industry, and workers receive an extra day's pay on their employment anniversary and birthday. And any threat to job security has been largely eliminated by a sizable temporary staff, which acts as a cushion to slack periods. Small wonder, then, that in a review by Fortune magazine last year of the nation's 100 best companies to work for, Fel-Pro ranked fourth.
"They coddled and spoiled us," acknowledged David Beller, a tool-and-die maker who has worked at Fel-Pro for 20 years. "They were very generous to their employees."
But circumstances have changed, as Mr. Beller's use of the past tense implies. Last December, the owners -- members of the Lehman, Weinberg and Morris families, descendants of the company's founder, Albert Mecklenburger -- said they intended to sell Fel-Pro. In January, word came of a takeover by the Federal-Mogul Corporation, a gritty Michigan company four times Fel-Pro's size.
In the months since, a large cloud has, not surprisingly, formed over this workers' paradise as employees confront the inevitable unease and search for reassurance about their prospects under a traditional corporate regime and its emphasis on maximizing profits.
"Everybody's nervous," said Lucy King, 34, a longtime employee in the packaging operations. "We really don't know what to expect. It's scary."
The skittishness is widespread -- and magnified by the jarringly quick dispatch of a few dozen marketing, accounting and other support people to Federal-Mogul's headquarters in Southfield, Mich., or to unemployment lines. Indeed, several people who initially agreed to be photographed for this article subsequently declined, saying they felt uncomfortable in the current corporate environment.
It is fair to say that such feelings are new to the factory here. Fel-Pro began in 1918 as Felt Products, which made a horse blanket that fit under saddles before felt was widely used as a sealant in automotive parts like gaskets. Over time, corporate policy that may have begun as benevolence grew to become a way of business that the company's fans say was as resolutely focused on the bottom line as any leaner-and-meaner approach.
"The benefits paid for themselves, with additional cooperation, higher productivity," said Robert O'Keefe, a retired vice president for industrial relations. "We used to say we couldn't not do it because it was an enhancement to our profits."
Workers take some comfort in various provisions of the $720 million stock-and-cash deal that the Fel-Pro families negotiated with Richard A. Snell, the chairman of Federal-Mogul. Under the agreement, various benefits will be maintained for specified periods while others will be replaced by those of the new parent.
Indeed, Mr. Snell said recently that "the first agenda item" in negotiations with the families was Fel-Pro's special corporate culture of near womb-to-tomb beneficence.
STILL, interviews with employees here found considerable skepticism about how they will fare. They know that even as Federal-Mogul tries to accommodate Fel-Pro, it is also digesting a much larger acquisition of a British automotive supplier, T & N P.L.C.
Generally, workers seemed resigned to losing most of the lesser fringe benefits while hoping for the best on vital interests like health insurance -- and keeping their jobs.
"You can never say with a big company like Federal-Mogul," said Frank Donis, 26, who works in the paper unit and whose mother, sister and an aunt all worked for Fel-Pro. "If things go down, the company's going to have to make adjustments."
One source of unease is Mr. Snell's intention to build what he calls an "all-star" team drawn from the top talent in the company; that is, Federal-Mogul will identify its best workers and protect them from layoffs. But job losses are coming: Federal-Mogul hopes to shrink its worldwide payroll of 41,000 by about 10 percent, much of it through attrition. The company has not, however, specified Fel-Pro's share of the pain.
Another unwelcome change: Kenneth A. Lehman, who served seven years in various Peace Corps positions before joining the family business and rising to co-chairman, will not join the Federal-Mogul board, as intended when the deal was announced. The reason, Mr. Lehman said, is that it might have presented a conflict: he is administrator of family trusts, and being a board member could, for example, inhibit sales by the trusts of Federal-Mogul shares because of his status as a company insider.
"They've got a big challenge on their plates," Mr. Lehman said in an interview the week after the deal closed in late February, referring to Federal-Mogul management. "They will be trying to forge a new culture for a big new global company."
Sounding not entirely confident, Mr. Lehman added that if Federal-Mogul was convinced that treating employees well improved the bottom line, "then hopefully they'll use us as a model."
That is not at all certain, judging from what typically occurs in such situations, said Jim Sillery, senior consultant at Watson Wyatt Worldwide in Chicago.
"The culture of the acquirer tends to become dominant," he said. "Fel-Pro's benefits will begin to look a lot like Mogul's," he predicted, noting that agreements covering benefits were not necessarily binding and were subject to interpretation.
Jonathan Weatherly, a consultant at Towers Perrin in Chicago, agreed. In the face of "overriding" pressure from auto makers on suppliers to squeeze costs, Mr. Weatherly said, "it really is hard to see all the nice features of the Fel-Pro culture surviving."
 As it stands now, Fel-Pro workers' profit-sharing plans can be rolled over into Federal-Mogul's 401(k) plan; medical and dental coverage converts to Federal-Mogul's similar, and in some respects better, plan in 1999. The summer day camp and wellness center will remain for at least two years, and vacations will be capped at four weeks, except for employees already entitled to more time.
The Fel-Pro families have set aside proceeds from the sale to maintain the scholarship program for five years.
One clear plus, however, is that Federal-Mogul hopes to extend its year-old stock option plan to Fel-Pro employees. The Federal-Mogul board is expected to approve the move within weeks.
Another, some employees say, is expanded opportunity as part of a $5 billion company. "Maybe all the benefits aren't there, but you can maybe get a job somewhere else in the country," said Larry Jenrich, 35, an inventory analyst in the distribution center for whom Fel-Pro paid for two years of college.
But benefits not already enjoyed by other Federal-Mogul workers seem jeopardized in the long run.
Roderick M. Hills, a longtime director of Federal-Mogul, said any loss would be minimal.
"We are hoping the Fel-Pro people will have as much impact on Federal-Mogul as vice versa," he said. "But you can't take the best of everything and spread it to everybody."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard A. Snell, the chairman of Federal-Mogul, talked with a Fel-Pro employee in January after a speech to workers regarding the acquisition of their company and how the deal would affect their work lives. (Todd Buchanan)

HEADLINE: Summertime, and the Driving Is Breezy

BYLINE: Contributing to this report were Michelle Krebs, James G. Cobb, Peter Passell, Fred Brock and Keith Martin.

 BODY:
SUMMER is around the corner, and the forecast, thanks to El Nino, is for a dry, sunny season -- ideal conditions for open-air motoring.
Some three dozen open-top car models are currently available in the United States, at prices of $20,000 to $350,000. And while low-end models continue to fade away for lack of interest -- the Honda Civic del Sol and Toyota Paseo are among this year's casualties -- fancy droptops are being added. Among these are the Volvo C70, which goes on sale next month, and the Mercedes-Benz CLK Cabriolet, due this fall. 
 Here is a rundown of the topless cars on sale this summer, excluding a number of sport utility vehicles -- like the Chevrolet Tracker, Isuzu Amigo, Jeep Wrangler, Kia Sportage and Suzuki Vitara -- that also have roofs that come down or come off. Prices are for base models; luxury and gas-guzzler taxes are not included.
 
ACURA NSX-T $88,782. Mid-engine, rear drive; 2 seats.
The NSX-T is lightning-quick, thanks to its very light aluminum body, its wind-slicing profile and its V6 engines that use Formula One racing technology. Indeed, since it is built to Honda's exacting standards, the NSX has been criticized for being too perfect -- a trouble-free appliance that thinks it's a Ferrari. Still, it is a pleasant and reliable exotic car that can be driven every day.
 
ASTON MARTIN DB7 Volante, $141,600. Front engine, rear drive; 4 seats.
The DB7's road manners cannot be faulted, and the supercharged V8 is capable of pushing the two-ton grand touring car from zero to 60 in a mere 6 seconds. But what really separates this elite convertible from the pack is aesthetics: the lithe swoop of the fenders, the mirror-like paint job, the aromatic leather, the faultless walnut trim. Too bad the DB7 costs twice as much as the rather similar Jaguar XK8.
 
AUDI CABRIOLET $35,100. Premium, $38,800. Front engine, front drive; 4 seats.
Its superclean styling still looks fresh, but the Cabriolet is the last of the previous-generation cars in Audi's lineup. Because its V6 doesn't meet stricter pollution standards, the '98 is not available in California, Connecticut, Massachusetts or New York.
 
BENTLEY AZURE $339,900. Front engine, rear drive; 4 seats.
All you really need to know about the Azure is its price. With only 93 sold last year, you'll surely have the only one on the block. It will get you a good table at Spago and will win you respect from Hollywood's toughest critics: valet parking attendants.
 
BMW 3-SERIES 323i, $34,700; 328i, $41,500; M3, $45,900. Front engine, rear drive 4 seats.
In all of its many body and drive-train configurations, the 3-Series was a benchmark when it was remade for 1992, and it remains one of the world's most pleasurable cars for everyday driving. Exceptionally rigid for a convertible, it handles brilliantly. New this year is the 6-cylinder 323i, which replaces the 4-cylinder 318i, and a convertible version of the legendary, high-performance M3.
 
BMW Z3 1.9, $29,995; 2.8, $36,470. M Roadster, $42,770. Front engine, rear drive; 2 seats.
The M Roadster promises a high-octane fix for the Z3's shortcomings. For while the voluptuous body grabs attention, the car's performance hasn't matched its appearance -- especially the wimpy, buzzy 4-cylinder 1.8. And the Z3, built in South Carolina, lacks BMW's usual refinement.
 
CHEVROLET CAVALIER Z24 $19,910. Front engine, front drive; 4 seats.
A small package with reasonable accommodations for at least two people and some luggage, the Cavalier has a family resemblance to its big brother, the Camaro. The interior is attractive and functional, although the hard, unsupportive seats make long trips unpleasant. The 4-cylinder engine is adequate, and the handling is good.
 
CHEVROLET CAMARO V6, $22,650; Z28, $27,975. Front engine, rear drive; 4 seats.
The venerable Camaro and its Pontiac counterpart, the Firebird, may be living on borrowed time. The 30-year-old muscle car formula -- raw power, reasonable price -- has lost its magic in an era of high insurance rates and sport-utility mania. The Camaro still performs, but it feels dated.
 
CHEVROLET CORVETTE $44,990. Front engine, rear drive; 2 seats.
The classic nameplate was saved from General Motors' budget cutters to be reborn as the best 'Vette ever. While some aficionados dislike styling touches seemingly borrowed from Acura, there is little grousing about the performance of the 345-horsepower V8 -- or about the newly accommodating interior and a trunk that can hold golf bags.
 
CHRYSLER SEBRING JX, $21,235; JXi, $26,500. Front engine, front drive; 4 seats.
America's best-selling convertible is built in Mexico and has little in common with the Mitsubishi-built coupe of the same name. Spacious, stylish and comfortable, the Sebring offers good value. It also has a rarity among convertibles: a back seat big enough for two adults. But order the JXi V6; the 4-cylinder JX is overwhelmed.
 
DODGE VIPER RT/10 $64,700. Front engine, rear drive; 2 seats.
Only in America! No other country could produce such a bold, aggressive, over-the-top car -- the whopping 8-liter V10 engine produces an awesome 450 horsepower. But the performance is American-brutal, not European-refined.
 
FERRARI F355 SPIDER $138,115. Front engine, rear drive; 2 seats.
Ferrari's V12's get the attention, but for enduring driving pleasure it's hard to beat the smaller, lighter F355, with its V8 just in front of the rear wheels. Like all Ferraris, this one requires getting used to. The manual gearbox is balky; the cockpit is cramped for 6-footers. And judged purely by the numbers, it performs no better than a Porsche or Corvette. But for those hooked on the wheel's rock-solid feel and the engine's sensual howl, there is no substitute.
 
FORD MUSTANG $21,175; GT, $24,675; Cobra, $29,035. Front engine, rear drive; 4 seats.
The original pony car will be revamped next year, and it may eventually stand alone in this shrinking market. Still, the Mustang has enjoyed a slight resurgence in sales, and it comes in versions from plain (3.8-liter V6) to muscular (4.6-liter V8). Each offers a lot of performance for the price.
 
JAGUAR XK8 $70,480. Front engine, rear drive; 4 seats.
With its lean body, ground-hugging profile and long hood, the XK8 is, quite simply, a ravishing beauty. Inside, the sumptuous cabin sets standards. And the 4-liter, 290-horsepower V8 is smooth and powerful. Except for the price, what's not to like?
 
LAMBORGHINI DIABLO ROADSTER VT $284,000. Mid-engine, all-wheel drive; 2 seats.
The wedge silhouette, angular lines and side air intakes give the Diablo the aggressive look of a Formula One race car, and with a 492-horsepower V12 it nearly performs like one. Alas, with a price so high, few will ever have the experience.
 
MAZDA MX-5 MIATA $20,220. Front engine, rear drive; 2 seats.
The first Miata revived the moribund roadster market, and its many fans held their breath when Mazda announced a redesign. They're breathing easier now, because the qualities that made the car shine -- its light weight, its agility, the growl of its eager 4-cylinder engine -- have been made better. The styling remains simple and timeless, and there is 140 horsepower, up from 133. So nimble it feels like an extension of the driver, the Miata may offer more fun per dollar than anything else on the road.
 
MERCEDES-BENZ SLK230 $40,295. Front engine, rear drive; 2 seats.
Quiet and weatherproof, with a hard top that draws a crowd when it retracts into the trunk, the SLK pleases baby boomers nostalgic for the SL roadsters of the 50's. The interior is packed with retro touches like white gauges trimmed in chrome. The supercharged 4-cylinder is economical and fairly peppy, but the overall effect is more luxurious than sporty.
 
MERCEDES-BENZ SL SL500, $80,495; SL600, $125,595. Front engine, rear drive; 2 seats.
Along with the S-Class sedans, which will be replaced next year, the SL roadsters are the last remnants of the "old" Mercedes-Benz: very expensive, very solid and just a bit uptight, without the youthful feel of newer Mercedes models or the glamour of, say, an XK8. Still, SL's are extremely refined, technologically advanced and socially impressive. No wonder movie stars drive them.
 
MITSUBISHI ECLIPSE SPYDER GS, $21,850; GS-T, $27,080. Front engine, front drive; 4 seats.
A car long on pizazz but short on practicality, the Spyder has a futuristic look and, with the GS-T's turbo version of the in-line 4-cylinder, spirited performance. Indeed, with so much power running through the front wheels, the driver must pay attention to keep the car on track. The back seat is not just tight -- it is virtually unusable.
 
PLYMOUTH PROWLER $40,000. Front engine, rear drive; 2 seats.
If you want to see and be seen, hardly anything gets more stares than this nouveau street rod. The Prowler could scarcely be more impractical -- there's no place to put anything -- and the standard-issue V6 is nothing special. But the Prowler is built for cruising, not commuting.
 
PONTIAC SUNFIRE SE, $19,995. Front engine, front drive; 4 seats.
The Sunfire packs the flashy styling and gutsy performance of Pontiac's larger cars into a small, reasonably priced package. Although it is a near-twin of the Chevy Cavalier, the Sunfire's look is inspired by the Firebird. The ride is characteristically Pontiac: firm, but not stiff.
 
PONTIAC FIREBIRD $24,830; Trans Am, $30,240. Front engine, rear drive; 4 seats.
Like their Camaro counterparts, Pontiac's pony cars offer power and performance at an attractive price. But the Firebird goes further, with bold, outrageous styling. Like the Camaro, the car has a shrinking market, and its future is uncertain.
 
PORSCHE BOXSTER $41,765. Mid-engine, rear drive; 2 seats.
The Boxster's proportions and bulging fenders mimic Porsches of the past, but many of the touches -- like fan-shaped mirrors and cat's-eye buttons -- are thoroughly modern. No speed demon, the Boxster offers a nearly perfect balance of power and knife-sharp handling. It is a joy to drive at any speed.
 
PORSCHE CARRERA CABRIOLET $81,745. Rear engine, rear drive; 2 seats.
Like the other all-new 911's, the Cabriolet is a rear-engine rocket ship that coddles occupants with luxury appointments and electronic gadgets. Space is well used, with rear jump seats that fold for more storage.
 
SAAB 9-3 $37,050; SE, $42,050. Front engine, front drive; 4 seats.
When the well-made, tight-fitting insulated top is up, it's easy to forget you're in a convertible, and two adults can fit reasonably well in the back. With Saab's traditional road-hugging qualities, the 1999 9-3 is fun to drive, and the 185-horsepower turbo-charged 4 has plenty of punch.
 
VOLKSWAGEN CABRIO $18,475; GLS, $22,790. Front engine, front drive; 4 seats.
A perennial favorite of young women, the Cabrio remains a fun and functional convertible -- and its back seat can actually accommodate passengers. But they'd better travel light: A picnic lunch is about all that will fit in the trunk. This is the last season for the current Cabrio; it gets a makeover before next summer.

VOLVO C70 $44,000 (estimated). Front engine, front drive; 4 seats.
Volvo's first convertible since 1956 goes on sale next month, and, no, it doesn't look like a box without a top. The styling is sleek and the appointments are elegant, but the C70 shows Volvo's usual attention to safety, including roll bars that pop up behind the rear headrests. The turbo 5-cylinder is spirited, but the car's handling is uninspired.
