HEADLINE: Death Penalty For Ex-Guard In Murder of 3

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
In the first death penalty trial since New York State reinstated capital punishment in 1995, a Brooklyn jury sentenced a former jail guard to die yesterday for murdering three people in a robbery at an illegal social club.
The former guard, Darrel K. Harris -- who was given a medal by Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1987 for saving another correction officer's life in a riot at a Brooklyn jail -- was sentenced to execution after jurors rejected defense arguments that his past heroism and other mitigating factors that were offered were reasons to spare his life. 
 When the sentence was announced in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, the 40-year-old Mr. Harris, a man with a neatly trimmed mustache and beard who wears an ear lobe stud, stared ahead without any show of emotion. Before the jury's decision was announced in the courtroom, Mr. Harris had been informed of it and did not react visibly then because "we all knew this was possible," one of his lawyers said later.
One juror began sobbing and nearly collapsed as she left the box after the panel of seven women and five men was dismissed by Acting Justice Anne G. Feldman, who thanked them for performing "this very difficult civic obligation." Another juror dabbed her eyes with her fingers.
The jury had a choice of either a death sentence or life in prison without the possibility of parole.
As mitigating factors, the defense argued that serious psychological problems and cocaine and alcohol abuse had not only caused Mr. Harris to plunge from hero in 1986 to triple killer a decade later, but had also fueled his rampage.
If Mr. Harris is executed by lethal injection, as prescribed under the law, he will be the first person put to death in the state since 1963, when the death penalty was carried out in the electric chair.
But years of legal appeals are likely.
Relatives of Mr. Harris hurried from the courtroom without talking to reporters. But his victims' relatives, some of whom wept quietly as they left the courtroom, expressed gratification at what they deemed a just penalty for the bloodletting at the after-hours spot, Club Happiness, in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, in the early morning of Dec. 7, 1996.
"We got what we wanted," said Moses Sims, whose brother, Jerome, the club manager, was among the victims. "We could have dealt with life without parole, but this was our first priority," he said of the death sentence, which the jury announced after 22 hours of deliberations over four days.
"I'm relieved," said Mr. Sims, who trains prize fighters, adding that he planned to "put a flower" on the grave of his brother, who was 58 when Mr. Harris shot him in the head. Mr. Harris had ordered the five people in the club to get down on the floor as he began his robbery.
Besides Mr. Sims, Mr. Harris fatally shot another man in the head, Michael Harris, 37, who was not related to him. A third shooting victim, Eddie Brown, 50, survived his head wound. And when Mr. Harris ran out of bullets, he fatally stabbed Evelyn Davis, 32, despite her cries to be spared because "I have five babies," according to Mr. Brown and a second witness, Newbry Mitchell, who escaped.
The Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said that "we must remember that this trial was a search for the truth and an effort to do justice in the memory" of the victims. Mr. Hynes, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for governor, has long said that he opposed capital punishment but that he was duty-bound to seek it in appropriate cases while the death penalty law was on the books. He has brought five capital murder cases, the most of any district attorney in the state.
Mr. Hynes's trial prosecutors had told the jury that death was the appropriate penalty. "This was the mechanical, methodical execution of people" during a robbery, making it the "the type of crime for which the death penalty was enacted," declared one of the prosecutors, Jonathan Frank, who tried the case with Heide Mason and Keith Dolan.
But a lawyer for Mr. Harris, Russell Neufeld, called the death sentence "a tragedy for the people of the state of New York and for all the families involved." The victims' families, he said, "feel this will ease the pain of the loss," but the sentence of execution was "not a solution."
Mr. Neufeld said defense lawyers would argue in appealing Mr. Harris's conviction and sentence that New York's capital punishment law was unconstitutional under the Constitutions of both the United States and the state, and that Justice Feldman's denials of various defense motions at the trial had kept Mr. Harris from obtaining a fair trial.
After the sentence was announced, Justice Feldman ordered a suicide watch on Mr. Harris.
In a statement released yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said: "This willful taking of three innocent lives is precisely the kind of heinous crime the state contemplated when it reinstated the death penalty three years ago. I hope today's decision brings some measure of justice to the victims' families and that it deters others from taking human life."
The jurors left the courthouse in a van without talking to reporters. Reached at home, one of them, a science teacher who prepares students for high school equivalency diplomas, said, "Please, please, I don't want to speak with anyone." The jurors, who ranged in age from their 30's to 60's, also included five people in health-related jobs, four in office or blue-collar employment, a retired woman and an unemployed man who last worked as a truck driver. Five have college degrees, including a woman with a Ph.D. in English literature.
Earlier this year, Mr. Harris's case nearly ended in a plea bargain that would have spared his life. But instead, as Mr. Harris began entering his guilty plea on Feb. 23 -- which would have sent him to prison for life without parole -- he stunned the courtroom by suddenly aborting it.
When Justice Feldman asked him twice whether he was "pleading guilty because you are guilty," Mr. Harris said no.
Mr. Neufeld tried to explain shortly afterward that his client had intended to plead guilty but wanted to stop the proceeding because he had not fully understood until then that he was giving up his right to appeal the life-without-parole term.
But at that point, prosecutors refused to accept any guilty plea, arguing that if Mr. Harris sought to withdraw it in the future, his earlier responses to Justice Feldman would allow him to argue -- with a good chance of success -- that his guilty plea had been coerced.
So Mr. Harris's original not-guilty plea stood, and the case went to the jury.
A lawyer for Mr. Harris, Colleen Brady, in her final argument before the jury began deliberating a sentence, had urged the panel to exercise "justice tempered by mercy," holding that Mr. Harris was not "the worst of the worst."
With no previous criminal record, and having saved a life, Mr. Harris had shown "there's some value in him," warranting life in prison, said Ms. Brady, part of a team with Mr. Neufeld and Timothy Rountree from the Legal Aid Society's capital defense unit.
To sentence Mr. Harris to death, the law required the jury to find unanimously "beyond a reasonable doubt" that aggravating factors in the case "substantially" outweighed the mitigating factors proposed by the defense. The two aggravating factors were that Mr. Harris intentionally committed murder while carrying out a robbery and intentionally killed more than one person.
The defense conceded that Mr. Harris was the killer, but disagreed with the prosecution on what had driven him to commit the crimes.
The defense insisted that there had been no robbery and that rather than killing to eliminate witnesses, as the prosecution contended, Mr. Harris had been a severely disturbed man who had "snapped." A psychiatrist testified about severe childhood beatings by Mr. Harris's mother and, in adulthood, about his job losses, drug and alcohol abuse and what he called the traumatic effects of the 1986 jail disturbance in which Mr. Harris saved his colleague.
The defense argued that the violence had left him with the kind of severe psychological and emotional problems diagnosed in many war veterans as post-traumatic stress disorder. The city's Correction Department forced Mr. Harris to resign in 1991 because of his drug use. All this, the defense argued, justified a conviction for first-degree manslaughter, punishable by up to 25 years in prison for each killing. But the jurors disagreed, finding Mr. Harris guilty of first-degree murder and setting up the penalty phase of the trial.
The death sentence came as the tempo of capital trials has picked up in the state. Testimony began Monday in Poughkeepsie in the second such trial, in which Dalkeith V. McIntosh is charged with murdering his estranged wife and her daughter from a previous marriage.
Jury selection is under way in Brooklyn for the third such trial, in which Jermaine Page is accused of the execution-style murder of a man while robbing him. And selection of a jury is to start later this month in the Suffolk County trial of Robert Shulman, who is accused of killing and dismembering three prostitutes.
It was on March 7, 1995, that a newly elected Gov. George E. Pataki fulfilled one of his central campaign vows by signing into law the latest bill that the Legislature had passed to reinstate capital punishment after New York State's highest court, in 1984, declared the remaining provision of the state's previous death penalty law unconstitutional. In doing so, the court voided a death sentence imposed the year before in the last capital trial in a New York State court..
The last person executed in the state, Eddie Lee Mays, was put to death in the electric chair in 1963 for killing a woman while robbing a bar.

HEADLINE: Easing Loans Would Thwart Russian Reforms

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Jeffrey D. Sachs (Op-Ed, June 4) is right that the International Monetary Fund is not looking good in Asia and Russia. Its bailouts favor speculators that charged sky-high interest rates and fail to restore output and employment. However, Mexico's bailout was not very different from Russia's and succeeded in restoring growth. It also saved Latin America from a long spell of no growth and inflation. Moreover, it made money for donors. So what are we missing now? 
 To put it bluntly: not enough money. Partial bailouts may be worse than none. They speed up the exit and do not lay the ground for the early return of flight capital. While $50 billion was enough for Mexico, funds committed for Indonesia are only a fraction of the country's needs.
In addition, since bailouts are accompanied by a nagging foreign presence, political equilibrium is shaken down to its roots, scaring away a wellspring of growth: direct foreign investment.
 
GUILLERMO A. CALVO
College Park, Md., June 4, 1998
 
The writer is director of the Center for International Economics at the University of Maryland.

HEADLINE: Easing Loans Would Thwart Russian Reforms

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Here we go again: Jeffrey D. Sachs attacks the International Monetary Fund (Op-Ed, June 4). He derides the high interest rates that have been required to retain flight capital, charges that the Russian Government is "corrupt and mismanaged," declares that the ruble probably can't be saved, and proves that the I.M.F. is a poor predictor of the results of its policies. 
 If money is fleeing Russia, the exchange rate will depreciate unless the central bank can find foreign money to exchange for the rubles presented. It clearly doesn't have it. Does the I.M.F.? Not enough, which suggests that high interest rates be employed to retain the funds.
Mr. Sachs only implies what he would do. I conclude that he would put himself in charge of the monetary fund, not give Russia any money until its Government is replaced, let the exchange rate fall, and give Russia lots of money so it can pay off the foreigners and keep interest rates low. He doesn't provide any predictions of economic performance, but I wouldn't put much confidence in his either.
 
JOHN T. BENNETT
Alexandria, Va., June 4, 1998

HEADLINE: The World;
A Global Divide on Abortion Splits Poor From Rich

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
IT has become an article of faith among those who oppose abortion in the United States that promoting abortion anywhere else, particularly in the world's poorest countries, is tantamount to an attack on the cultures of those countries. It is a new argument from the conservative right, but it echoes charges that the radical left used to make, to the effect that family planning programs targeted at the third world were a kind of neo-imperialistic genocide.
A statistical look around the world shows that if cultural sensitivities are reflected in laws about abortion, there is a remarkable divide between richer countries and poorer ones where abortion and its effects are concerned. But other statistics demonstrate that the pattern of legality does not reflect how women in those societies choose to act.
 
Unequal Death Rates
In the global south, where abortion laws are the most restrictive, abortion rates are still quite high; deaths from abortion are much higher there than elsewhere, because the abortions tend to be unsafe. The industrial countries of the global north are almost universally less restrictive in their abortion laws. They also have the lowest rates of abortion-related deaths. 
 Of about 20 million unsafe -- sometimes legal, but more often illegal -- abortions estimated to take place each year worldwide, 90 percent occur in developing countries, according to the World Health Organization. Of the 80,000 deaths that result, 95 percent are in poor nations. That number does not include women who die of miscarriages due to health problems or poor prenatal care; such data do not exist.
The anti-colonial case has been made forcefully by Representative Christopher H. Smith, the New Jersey Republican who has blocked American payments to the United Nations with an amendment denying money to any organization that lobbies for liberalized abortion laws in any country. Mr. Smith, a supporter of international child survival programs, says helping poor children, not preventing them from being born, should be the priority of foreign aid.
His legislation, which President Clinton has vowed to veto when it reaches his desk, has created alarm among family planning and women's health organizations, who see its bar to advocating abortion as a challenge to free speech and a chilling factor that would reduce the amount of money going to all types of population work, including contraception, in the poorest countries, where they think it is needed most.
Mr. Smith said in a telephone interview that he drew a distinction between contraception and abortion. "We have made it clear we would put more money into family planning," he said. "We offered the Administration $100 million dollars more in family planning aid if they would get out of the abortion business." He added: "Family planning is preventive and its use is up to the individual. But those of us who respect the lives of unborn children recognize that whether it be dismemberment, abortion or chemical poisoning, abortions, legal or illegal, are violence against children everywhere."
Family planning organizations and women's health groups do not argue that abortion should be encouraged as a method of birth control. But they do argue for less restrictive laws in many countries on the ground that such laws would cut deaths. They also say family planning and community health groups in Africa, Asia and Latin America have to deal with the results of botched and life-threatening abortions, sometimes by completing the process of clearing the womb -- a procedure that would put them on the wrong side of American law if Mr. Smith's proposal were adopted.
Mr. Smith argues that he would rather spend money on programs like immunizations, nutritional health for mothers and other forms of health care that would help children in developing societies survive, rather than aiding organizations that are associated with abortion. When asked about the problems posed by unsafe abortion, he said, "We need positive alternatives like the 4,000 crisis pregnancy centers here, where women who have difficulties can be helped in many ways."
Advocates of family planning respond that the overall effect of his proposals could be to harm the ability of mothers to care for their families. "Public health experts will be the first to tell you that child survival is most enhanced by enabling women to space their childbearing," said Gloria Feldt, president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, the oldest and largest family planning organization in the world.
Dr. Nafis Sadik, executive director of the United Nations Populations Fund, said the argument that family planners from richer nations are coercing the women of the developing world should be turned upside down. The real coercion in many places, she said, "is that women are being forced to have children by their families or by social pressures."
"Now that women are getting choices, people seem to be starting to object," said Dr. Sadik, a physician from Pakistan. "It's being made out that a woman wants to be pregnant all the time. That's not what all the detailed surveys and research show. Most women don't want to be serially pregnant. They want to have, if not two children, maybe four children, not eight children -- and they don't want to have them every year."
Because family planning services are not available to millions of women who want them -- more than 350 million in the developing world, according to surveys -- they turn to abortion, even where illegal, and will continue to do so as a last resort, experts say. "Contrary to public belief, most of the unsafe illegal abortions take place among married women," Dr. Sadik said.

HEADLINE: Empty Suits In the Board Room;
Under Fire, Mutual Fund Directors Seem Increasingly Hamstrung

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
WHAT'S a mutual fund director to do? Lately, when independent directors have stood up to fund managers, they've gotten their ears boxed. And when, to some eyes, the directors have let fund managers go their own way, they've gotten their ears boxed again.
Consider events of the last two years, a period in which the fund industry has experienced some of its most rapid growth: 
 * When the independent directors of two fund families, the Navellier and Fundamental funds, asserted their legal authority to remove portfolio managers at some of those funds, they swiftly found themselves the targets of nasty proxy battles waged by the fund managers -- and, in the case of the Navellier directors, a shareholder lawsuit.
* When the Securities and Exchange Commission brought charges against the managers of the Parnassus fund and the Rockies fund, contending violations of securities laws, it also charged the funds' independent directors with failing to properly value securities owned by the funds.
* Morningstar Inc., the financial publisher in Chicago, questioned the independence of directors after finding that among the 82 largest fund families, the more that directors were paid, the more that shareholders shelled out in expenses.
* In a lawsuit brought by a shareholder of the Brazil Fund, a closed-end fund managed by Scudder Kemper Investments, a Federal judge in Manhattan agreed with the plaintiff that outside directors who received compensation for sitting on the board of more than one fund in the same family might not be independent at all.
Rarely, if ever, since the current system of mutual fund oversight was laid out in the Investment Company Act of 1940 have fund directors been under fire on so many fronts at once.
"On the one hand, you've got innumerable parties, including the S.E.C., emphasizing the importance of the independence of directors," said Robert J. Zutz, a partner in the Washington office of the Kirkpatrick & Lockhart law firm and a specialist in mutual fund law. "But on the other hand, where to the greatest degree imaginable, directors have exercised their independence, they get caught up in these unfortunate situations. Ultimately, it could cause a director to pause and take the consequences into account before deciding to act."
To almost any degree that directors hesitate, individual investors stand to lose. Shareholders in most publicly traded corporations can expect various parties -- institutional investors, independent watchdog groups and securities analysts, to name a few -- to help a company's board keep an eye on what insiders are doing. But the fund industry leaves the job almost solely to independent directors -- a disparate bunch. At even the biggest fund families, they can range in background from experienced corporate managers and directors to the friends or college buddies of the top executives of the fund management company.
Their authority, moreover, is unique in American business, because of the peculiar legal fictions that define mutual funds. In theory, a fund is owned by its shareholders, who hire independent directors to run it. The directors select companies to manage the fund, to underwrite the sale of shares and to provide services to shareholders.
In practice, of course, the entire operation is run by one fund company -- Fidelity or Merrill Lynch, Navellier or Fundamental -- which not only provides all those services, but is the brand name that brings shareholders to the fund.
And in recent years, as even some of the most mediocre fund companies have generated spectacular returns, the balance of power has kept shifting further from fund directors and toward the companies that conceive, market and manage mutual funds.
MANY people in and around the fund industry say that is just fine. After all, they note, funds have piled up $5 trillion in assets -- doubling in size in just the last three years -- with barely a whiff of the scandals seen in the banking, savings and loan, brokerage and insurance industries. But around the fringes of the fund business, the strain is starting to show.
"So many mutual fund companies are so new that the industry has just not had enough time and experience to sort out the rules and responsibilities," said John A. Hill, chairman of the First Reserve Corporation, an energy investment firm. He also serves as an independent director of the Putnam funds and has sat on the boards of several publicly traded companies. "Some mutual fund boards are aware of the issues," he said, "but many others are not very aware at all."
The S.E.C., for its part, has acknowledged that some aspects of mutual fund governance need examination. But the commission appears to be edging quite gingerly into the subject.
"The proper role of a fund's board has become a bit controversial lately," allowed Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman, in an address last month to fund industry executives. This fall, he said, the S.E.C. will be the host for a round table intended "to air the issues and to work toward a consensus on whether changes are needed in the current system."
Already, the commission has been flooded with requests from fund companies, corporate governance experts and academics to participate in the round table, S.E.C. officials said. But until that discussion takes place, many directors may be wondering if taking decisive action is more likely to harm than help investors.
Certainly that is the question raised by events surrounding Navellier Aggressive Small Cap Equity, once a $250 million fund, which saw its assets shrink by three-quarters last year as the fund's manager battled with its independent directors.
Louis G. Navellier, a money manager based in Incline Village, Nev., founded the fund in 1993. Three years later, Mr. Navellier proposed merging the fund into a separate fund group that had a different set of independent directors -- steps that he said would reduce operating expenses through economies of scale.
But the directors of Aggressive Small Cap Equity opposed the move, and the difference of opinion quickly grew ugly.
The board, which said Mr. Navellier refused to provide information about his management company, dismissed him in March 1997 and hired Massachusetts Financial Services, proprietor of the MFS family of mutual funds, to manage the fund.
Mr. Navellier, who said he provided the board with all the information to which it was entitled, fought back. Under the Investment Company Act, the directors were required within 120 days to get shareholder approval for the manager change. With a campaign of mailings and phone calls, Mr. Navellier rallied enough investor support to block the move. The directors rehired him -- and subsequently resigned.
It is difficult, though, to declare anyone a winner. During the battle, most shareholders simply moved their money out of the fund, whose assets have dwindled to $60 million. And now, Mr. Navellier has joined with several of his loyal shareholders in a class-action suit against the former independent directors, their lawyer and MFS, seeking to recover up to $14 million in capital gains taxes that shareholders incurred last year.
The defendants and others in the fund industry have asked why the S.E.C. did not support what the independent directors believed was an attempt to protect shareholders.
"In this case, the Navellier directors did precisely what they were supposed to do: They raised the issues and went to shareholders to vote on them," said C. Meyrick Payne, a senior partner at Management Practice, a New York consulting firm that works with independent directors. "But there was a moment when you wondered whether the S.E.C. should have been a little more supportive."
Barry Barbash, director of the commission's division of investment management, which regulates mutual funds, declined to comment on the Navellier case. But in general, he said, the agency seeks to avoid taking any action that could influence how shareholders vote in a proxy contest.
"The S.E.C. tries to play referee and make sure everybody plays fair," Mr. Barbash said. "We'll throw a flag if someone is clearly violating the rules. But a proxy contest is not a situation where the S.E.C. should come in and say something that will change the outcome of the game."
If Navellier were an isolated case, it might be dismissed as an anomaly in a rapidly growing, diverse industry. But another confrontation is occurring at the Fundamental funds, a New York-based family of six funds with total assets of about $170 million. And in this case, shareholders may be faced with an even less appealing set of choices.
Fundamental's history has not been full of investing success; its volatile funds tend to careen between the top and bottom performance quartiles. Fundamental's New York Muni, its largest fund, is the only municipal bond fund of any type to lose money in the last five years.
Believing that investors in the funds had suffered enough, their directors voted last year to seek a replacement for the company that has long managed the funds.
Initially, Vincent J. Malanga, president of Fundamental Portfolio Advisors, the fund manager, supported the move; in fact, he found a potential replacement, Tocqueville Asset Management, which oversees a family of funds operating under the Tocqueville name. The board concurred, and, as an interim measure, a manager from Tocqueville began managing the Fundamental funds last year.
According to the fund's filings with the S.E.C., the board soon discovered that the manager had been routing portfolio trades through a Tocqueville-related brokerage firm, a potential violation of securities regulations. Tocqueville dismissed him, but the four independent Fundamental directors split on whether to go ahead with the plan to hire Tocqueville permanently. The two directors who opposed the hiring resigned.
In the meantime, Mr. Malanga and his firm were charged by the S.E.C. with failing to disclose the risks involved in special securities owned by one of the Fundamental funds in 1993-94; the firm, without admitting or denying the allegations, recently settled a false-advertising complaint by the National Association of Securities Dealers over the same issue.
Now Mr. Malanga has turned against Tocqueville; he wants shareholders to replace all the board members with a new group that, presumably, would again name him the funds' manager. The directors responded by throwing out Mr. Malanga and his firm last Monday and hiring Toqueville to take over the funds -- a move that requires shareholder confirmation within 120 days.
Given the situation, even the most educated shareholders might have trouble deciding what is in their best interest. As with the Navellier funds, many have decided to flee rather than to choose sides; assets have dropped by nearly one-third over the last year. And while a consequence of that decision for investors is to lock in losses, some in the industry say it is the best way to discipline fund managers.
"We realize that if a fund company is not looking out for shareholders, we get to vote with our feet," said Gregory D. Sullivan, a principal at Sullivan Bruyette Speros & Blayney, a McLean, Va., investment adviser. "There are a lot of alternative funds for us to consider."
The system, of course, is set up to provide checks and balances other than pitched battles and mass redemptions of shares. But if shareholders can get hurt when a fund's directors and its managers are at loggerheads, they can also suffer if everyone gets too cozy.
That is the assertion in a lawsuit that threw the fund industry into a tizzy last year. The lawsuit, brought by a shareholder of the Brazil Fund, contends that directors of the fund were likely to put the interests of Scudder, its manager, ahead of those of shareholders, because the directors received tens of thousands of dollars for overseeing scores of other Scudder funds as well.
Judge Robert W. Sweet of Federal District Court in Manhattan, in refusing to dismiss the complaint, said that "the close and financially rewarding relationship with Scudder is sufficient to call into question the independence and disinterest of these directors." The case is pending.
The industry mainstream was shocked by the judge's ruling. "I think he was off his rocker," said Thomas R. Smith Jr., a partner at the New York law firm of Brown & Wood and co-chairman of an American Bar Association task force that wrote a legal guidebook for fund directors. "The whole structure of the '40 Act provides that serving on more than one board will not make you" an insider, he said.
The S.E.C. took no formal position in the case. "Our view is that the amount of money a director is making does not make him independent or not independent," said Mr. Barbash. "But shareholders should be told how much the directors are being paid." That information is included in a fund's S.E.C. filings.
Fund companies have less direct control over fund directors than one might assume. Independent directors themselves usually select nominees to fill vacancies, and nominees must be voted on by shareholders. Independent directors also set their own salaries and hire their own outside lawyers. And while the law requires only that 40 percent of a fund's board be independent, in practice they constitute a majority on nearly all fund boards.
Fund directors also say they regularly stand up to a fund's managers. "I'd say that every year we have some issue, particularly involving the contracts to manage the funds, where we have some disagreement with the manager," said Mr. Hill, the Putnam director.
That does not mean that directors are always pushing for lower fees. "We have to make sure that the fees the funds are paying are competitive enough to keep the players in the game," said Stephen K. West, a lawyer at the New York firm of Sullivan & Cromwell who serves as an independent director of the Pioneer and Winthrop Focus funds. "The competition for managerial talent is enormous, which has caused the cost of running the business to explode."
As the fund industry has boomed in size, fund companies have seen their profitability soar. In part, the growth comes from having more assets to manage. But an oft-cited Morningstar study found that newer funds charge higher management fees than older funds. And in another study, Morningstar found that directors were paid more by fund families with higher expenses, raising "serious questions about the role independent trustees play in protecting shareholders."
Signals from the S.E.C. have been mixed on this front. Regulators have warned that they will be quick to question the directors of fund companies that consistently get higher-than-average management fees but produce below-par performance. Yet Mr. Levitt told fund executives last month that "directors don't have to guarantee that a fund pays the lowest rates, but they do have to make sure that fees fall within a reasonable band."
The agency has been more consistent in challenging directors whom it judges have failed to oversee fund managers' conduct. The S.E.C. recently has brought enforcement cases against the Parnassus fund, a mutual fund, and the Rockies fund, a closed-end fund, charging independent directors with failing to adequately police how the fund's managers valued certain stocks. The charges are being fought by the directors and the fund companies involved.
WHILE a different form of corporate governance might be able to better assure the independence and competence of directors, shareholders don't seem to be banging down the doors for change. Still, some new ideas might come up at the S.E.C. round table this fall.
In much of the rest of the world, and in unit trusts in the United States, fund directors are not responsible for setting a fund's management fee. Free from questions about the economics of a fund's management contracts, directors could spend their time monitoring a manager's business practices -- how brokerage commissions are allocated, whether investment guidelines are being followed and the like.
And shareholders are now being given more leeway to directly influence the governance of their funds. Last month, the S.E.C. ruled that directors of closed-end funds must adhere to results of votes on shareholder proposals to replace the manager of a fund. (A closed-end fund operates much like a mutual fund, except that its finite number of shares are traded on a stock exchange.)
The industry may also take a fresh look at some existing, alternative governance plans. The boards of the American Express IDS funds, for example, employ full-time officers separate from the officers of the management company. That structure emerged after a struggle for control of the funds' managers in the late 1950's.
"When the board is confronted with issues that raise questions about whether a fund's assets are being properly used and managed, that structure adds an additional safeguard," said Leslie Ogg, president of the Board Services Corporation, the independent company that oversees the operations of the American Express IDS funds.
Even that structure does not guarantee that directors will stand up to management on all issues. For that, Mr. Ogg said, responsibility ultimately lies with Washington.
"It does take a strong S.E.C. to make independent directors effective," Mr. Ogg said. "In the end, as a director you've got very little economic leverage. You've only got your prestige. That's the point where a director has got to be able to say that he has the support of regulators in acting independently."

 CORRECTION:
An article on June 7 about challenges to the power of mutual fund directors attributed a quotation erroneously. Thomas R. Smith Jr., a partner at the New York law firm of Brown & Wood, said in an interview that he disagreed with a ruling in which Judge Robert W. Sweet of Federal District Court in Manhattan refused to dismiss a complaint that a fund's directors were likely to put the interests of management ahead of those of shareholders. But it was not Mr. Smith who said the judge was "off his rocker" in making the ruling. That phrase was used by another lawyer, not quoted in the article.

"Minding the Store"
On average, corporate directors earn more for their service than do the directors of mutual funds. But directors of the biggest fund companies are paid more than directors of the biggest corporations. And while a large portion of the typical corporate director's pay comes in the form of incentives that increase in value if the company performs well, mutual fund directors receive virtually no incentive pay.

HEADLINE: On Top of the World

BYLINE: By Alexander Frater; Alexander Frater's most recent book is "Chasing the Monsoon."

 BODY:

THE GREAT HILL STATIONS OF ASIA
By Barbara Crossette.
Illustrated. 259 pp. Boulder, Colo.:
Westview Press. $28. 
 The first Europeans to reach India were bewitched by its beauty and strangeness but shocked by its climate. In 1690 an English clergyman, James Ovington, noted that few survived more than a couple of miasmal rainy seasons -- "Two moussouns are the Age of Man." A century later officials recorded the life expectancy for a European male as 31, a female 28. Then, without knowing why -- 6,000 feet is the ceiling of the malaria-bearing anopheles mosquito -- people realized health lay high in the hills, so when the soaking, febrile heat of summer began stealing across the plains, the viceroy himself led the exodus. For several months, ruling India from above the clouds, they enjoyed the luxury of sleeping under blankets, attended "ball after ball, each followed by a little backbiting," and built towns complete with tearooms, clubs, honeysuckle-framed cottages and pretty steepled churches. Though hill stations were a British-Indian innovation (96 of them went up), they soon began appearing in Indonesia, Burma, Sri Lanka, Malaysia, the Philippines, even Vietnam.
 Barbara Crossette, the United Nations bureau chief for The New York Times, has reported extensively from the area and in 1996, while traveling through the uplands of Indonesian Sumatra, hit on the idea of making a high-altitude circuit through eight countries. Though she calls the result "only a travel book," "The Great Hill Stations of Asia" should be required reading for anyone contemplating an Asian journey; the region's history, politics, religion and economics are brilliantly summarized in a series of crisp, scholarly briefings. Yet she also maintains a lively social curiosity: she finds the Vietnamese "warm, inquisitive, generous people who want to draw an outsider into whatever activity is at hand," while Burma, despite its evil administration, remains a country "blessed by nature, where there are always things to eat or sell and the means to live in dignity."
 Of the 18 hill stations she visited, two had American connections. Kodaikanal was founded as a summer retreat in 1845 by American missionaries 7,000 feet up in southern India's Palni Hills. Though the first church -- roofed with Huntley and Palmer biscuit tins -- was flattened by a mountain storm, the schoolhouse grew into the famous Kodaikanal International School, still unequivocally American in its style and curriculum. (The first principal, Margaret Norton Eddy, herself went to school in Kansas with Buffalo Bill Cody.) Today, in season, up to 10,000 Indian tourists are bussed daily into Kodaikanal -- a reminder that Asia's hill stations, far from being derided as crumbling colonial relics, are enjoying a reincarnatory boom as Asia's prosperous post-colonial middle classes themselves swarm upward to enjoy cool air and mountain scenery.
 Until the United States ceded it to the Philippines in 1991, the Club John Hay at Baguio, its cultural roots in the Poconos or upstate New York, was the only American hill station in Asia established for expatriates. Even as Crossette explored this quiet and beautiful spot, walked the gardens and visited "the silly little Cemetery of Negativism, where earnest Americans 'buried' bad things like sloth and mendacity," she knew the new tenants had plans for a luxury hotel, shopping mall and championship golf course.
 Many young Asians, furiously building for the future, display a curious lack of interest in the past; for them Year 1 of the new ephemeris started on the day they kicked out their foreign oppressors. This makes historical research chancy. She found bookshops and libraries in the hill stations largely bereft of material -- though in Sri Lanka's Nuwara Eliya, set among tea plantations, she got lucky and tracked down a reluctant 95-year-old historian. (During a recent visit I could find only a 1929 newspaper carrying a leopard alert: "At least six of the brutes are on the prowl.")
 Crossette has a weakness for hotels and writes about them at length, here complaining about the service, there the state in which previous guests have left them. "South Asians seem to me to be inexplicably hard on public buildings," she writes. "They scar walls, stain carpets and slash upholstery with remarkable casualness." In the Sumatra highlands she stayed at the delightful Pusako at Bukittinggi, but seems to have missed the floor show in which impassive, barefooted female dancers jump vigorously up and down on piles of plates, reducing them to splinters. (She also neglects to mention the local duck races; mallards with the musculature of auks fly 110-yard sprints and win their owners one-tenth of an ounce of gold.)
Air-conditioning and antibiotics have changed the nature of life in the torrid zone. Tropical fatigue is now a recognized medical condition; you can get pills for it. The hill stations should be redundant, yet, as this surprising, entertaining and elegantly written book demonstrates, many continue to flourish. And though Crossette often dwells necessarily in the past, her reportorial instincts remain on full alert. In Mandalay, for example, she found everyone talking about a new hospital for eye, ear, nose and throat specialists that had recently collapsed, crushing an unknown number of staff members and patients: " 'You won't read about that in the newspaper,' someone said. 'But we all know what is going on.' Money laundering and corruption is what he meant."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 14; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 738 words

HEADLINE: FROM THE DESK OF;
In China, Tomorrow Belongs To Greed

BYLINE: By AMY WU; Amy Wu, a native New Yorker, is currently working as a journalist in Hong Kong.

 BODY:
THE house my great-grandparents owned sits in a narrow concrete alley in Shanghai. The walls are decaying like a rotten tooth, and the door opens into a rusty kitchen. The clock in the sitting room is a relic from before Mao came to power, the light fixture dangles as a memory from earlier days. My grandparents were married in this house, now filled with dog-eared books and broken dishes. Some call it junk; I call it history.
Nonetheless, it is a history that is quickly disappearing in the new China. 
 On a recent trip to Shanghai, from my current home in Hong Kong, I made the rounds to relatives' and friends' new homes. I found them spacious and modern, with imported goods far outnumbering domestic. The interiors included English-style furniture, Greek-style columns and French-style chandeliers. The homes are filled with the newest Western gadgets, too -- microwave ovens, 48-inch televisions, a telephone in each room and remote-control heating. And their balconies overlook a city that is quickly coming to resemble Tokyo or New York.
This is the face of overnight modernization, toward an extreme without an in-between, especially among an under-30 generation keen on being rich and flaunting it.
On a trip to Beijing, my two 20-something cousins bragged about eating out every night and proudly waved a dinner receipt for $35 -- no small sum in China. They made a big show of checking for voice messages and chatting on their expensive cellular phones. Ditto for a friend in Shanghai who buys only imported and expensive European foods, not because she loves them, but because it shows status.
One cousin in Shanghai was full of questions about the latest Western fashions and trends, including the coolest cars. He had spent much of his early 20's dancing at expensive discos. Although, like many young Chinese, he has a low-paying, menial job, he spends every cent.
In fact, when I asked young people about their goals and their thoughts about saving for the future, I received quite a few blank looks. There were no dreams of joining the democracy movement or of even attaining an M.B.A. One young man was the most frank: "My goal for the future is to be rich."
It is not simply getting rich, though, but getting rich fast that's the new religion.
One middle-aged woman I met has two daughters who have made millions of dollars and have expensive apartments in Hong Kong and Shanghai. They have had several wealthy boyfriends, and one of them recently married a wealthy man from Beijing at least a dozen years her senior. They make their living as high-class prostitutes.
I know several young people who are involved in other illegitimate businesses. One has opened a store that sells under-the-counter, pirated compact disks and videos. Another is networking to acquire financing for an electronic gambling business. Of course, the money they amass goes toward buying the high life.
I'm 22 and have been working in Hong Kong for more than a year. Members of my generation here are often accused of being wasteful, greedy and hedonistic, but at least young adults in Hong Kong show some dedication to self-improvement, the entrepreneurial spirit and the value of hard work.
Among my generation elsewhere in China, waste, greed and pleasure-seeking seem to have won out over capitalism's more appealing virtues; meanwhile, much of the country is mired in poverty.
A family friend brought me to see her dying godmother in a Government hospital in Shanghai. It was dingy and filthy, and the February chill rattled the windows. It was a place where the old die alone -- something that would have been unthinkable in the China of my great-grandparents.
Politicians and Westerners talk about China's growth in terms of G.D.P., construction spending and average salary. No one talks about growth that sometimes is so fast that it strips away respect for tradition and an appreciation of history.
MY great-aunt still lives in the home she inherited from my great-grandparents. She is in her 80's and refuses to leave the house, which will surely be torn down someday to make way for another shoddy skyscraper. But young Chinese cannot seem to see beyond the facade of wealth.
The trick is to strike a balance of past and present, to heed the warnings from across Asia about the risks of change at a breakneck pace. Otherwise, when the new wipes out the old, what really will be left?

SECTION: Section 6; Page 102; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 836 words

HEADLINE: Sitting Out The Boom;
'We've Saved All Our Lives'

BYLINE: By Amy Silverman; Amy Silverman is a staff writer at The Phoenix New Times.

 BODY:
Betty and Paul Bellanger are riding out the go-go 90's in Sunnyslope -- a run-down neighborhood in north Phoenix -- inside a small, neat house with a chain-link fence and an ancient, mint-green pickup truck out front. The Bellangers have feisty opinions about many things, they watch a lot of television (mostly public) and they read. That's how they know about the money boom, which otherwise is not a daily reality in their house. Betty, 66, is a homemaker; Paul is a retired electrician. He's 67. Their monthly income is $2,400, including Paul's Army and union pensions and both their Social Security checks. With this the Bellangers pay the bills, feed a savings account and still manage to send $300 a month to their grandson David, who's studying computers at the University of Arizona in Tucson.
The Bellangers' old-fashioned attitudes about money -- you save it by not spending it -- were shaped during the Depression and World War II, when hard times made every dollar worthy of a tight grip. During a recent evening of talk, they made it clear that the boom, to them, is a slightly menacing illusion. They also kidded around and, more than once, finished each other's sentences. Apparently, 47 years together have put them in sync, particularly on matters of the wallet. 
 Betty: Yeah, it was on "Frontline." They were saying how because the economy's booming and everything's so wonderful, people aren't saving money. I don't think most people save money.
Paul: They get it and they spend it.
Betty: They think that their plastic card is not money and they are perfectly willing to mortgage their entire future and pay 21 percent interest. The clothes they bought are long gone and they're still paying for them. That's so dumb! We have a fixed income but----.
Paul: But we've saved all our lives. Even if it was only a dollar a week, since we first got married, we saved.
Betty: I'm just astonished at how children spend money. Our daughter's 41 and she'll say, oh, it doesn't matter, it's only a dollar. It's only a couple of dollars. A dollar or a couple of dollars? That's a lot of money!
Paul: And then at the end of the month she's crying because she's broke.
There's a lot the Bellangers don't understand about these flush times. Like: why do people put so much faith in the stock market when common sense dictates that a crash surely must come?
Paul: That market has just gone too far----.
Betty: It's like a balloon! It goes so high, and then it breaks under pressure.
Paul: That's the only thing that worries me, that our pensions are stuck in some sort of----.
Betty: There's kids right here within walking distance of my house that are hungry, and yet we give millions to all these foreign countries. That'd be like you and your husband getting your paychecks and giving 75 percent of it to the neighbors across the street. Well, that's really nice of you, but if we ran our home the way the Government runs theirs----.
Paul: We'd be out in the streets.
Wary of the future, the Bellangers have socked away enough cash to last maybe five years.
Betty: There is no such thing now as a stable job. Used to be that you went to work for a company and you worked there until you retired. This friend of ours did that real fine microscope work at Honeywell and she got laid off. Now they're going to move the whole shebang to Mexico. Whatever happened to loyalty, where if a company hired you, they kept you? As long as you did your job, of course.
Paul: Well, they've gotta please the people investing in the economy. They don't make "x" many hundred millions of dollars a year, they're losing money.
Betty laughs. The Bellangers extract a lot of amusement from the boom. For instance, they think it's very funny that people believe they deserve all the money they're raking in.
Paul: They worship it. That's their whole goal in life, to just pile up a mass of money so they can sit there and look at it, I guess.
Betty: What can they do with it all? You can sleep in one bed, you can ride in one car. Why do you need to have 14 houses and a wardrobe closet as big as my living room?
Of course, this is a woman who refuses to pay the outrageous price demanded for an ice-cream cone at Baskin-Robbins. Betty saves a mishmash of vegetables for soup and she absolutely hates shopping -- but she's hardly a miser. Last year the Bellangers scraped up $550 in donations and went on a shopping spree at Toys "R" Us, buying two toys each for 65 kids at the Sunnyslope Community Center in their neighborhood.
Betty: We had the best time! Several of them came up to me and said: "Betty, is it O.K. if we don't open our presents until Christmas? Because we don't have presents at home." That's horrible! I read in the paper about four years ago -- and if I ever see this woman I'll kill her with my bare hands -- some movie or TV star, they said she spent $25,000 on a white-and-silver Christmas tree. That's obscene. Do you know what I could do with $25,000 for those kids?
